DOC.HEAD: New York Republicans Open Convention By Taking Abortion-Rights Stance
DOC.TEXT: New York Republicans opened their state convention Tuesday and approved an abortion-rights platform without debate. The plank states that ``state government must not become a `big brother,' regulating people in their personal affairs and lives.'' ``The New York state Republican Party reaffirms its historic commitment to the right of privacy and reproductive rights,'' it says. U.S. Sen. Alfonse D'Amato, who delivered the keynote address at the convention, later told reporters that ``the platform should have been neutral. ... Now you have a position that's pro-choice. Why?'' State Assemblyman George Pataki, chairman of the Republican platform committee, said the stance should be considered ``all encompassing'' and conceded that the plank ``is a break with the national platform which is strong right-to-life.'' The plank was the first test of the party's new leadership at the convention. J. Patrick Barrett took over as party chief less than a year ago. Democratic Gov. Mario Cuomo has made it clear that he plans to use his position in favor of abortion rights as a weapon against Republicans this year in his bid for re-election. Pierre Rinfret, a 66-year-old Canadian-born economist who has never run for public office, is expected to be named the Republican gubernatorial candidate. According to party leaders, he supports a woman's right to an abortion.

DOC.HEAD: House Fails to Override School Finance Veto
DOC.TEXT: Three days before a court-ordered deadline, Texas again failed to overhaul its finances to give more money to poor schools, but Gov. Bill Clements says the state actually has three weeks to get the job done. The House, in a largely party-line vote Tuesday, failed by eight votes to muster the 100 needed to override Clements' veto of a $555 million school-finance bill. The House then adjourned. The Senate voted last week for an override. The Democrat-controlled Legislature had designed the bill to answer a unanimous Texas Supreme Court order to give more money to poor schools. If a measure is not enacted by Friday, a court-appointed master will come up with a plan. ``I think a compromise will be reached that will be acceptable to everybody concerned and will be an excellent bill,'' the Republican governor said. ``I think in a matter of another week we'll have it all done and everybody can go home and have a good time.'' House Speaker Gib Lewis said he expected Clements to call lawmakers back for a fourth special session on school finance as early as today. ``We will continue to negotiate, work with the governor and find out what issues that we can compromise with him,'' Lewis said. ``One thing I am trying to prevent and I'm going to try the best I can is not allow a master to write a school plan for the future of Texas education.'' Clements has said lawmakers have until June 21 to enact a bill, because that is when court master William Kilgarlin will file his final plan for the 3.1 million-student school system. In October, the Supreme Court declared Texas' school finance system unconstitutional because of wide disparities in spending between rich and poor districts. As in most states, schools in Texas are supported mostly by property taxes. Courts in a dozen states have overturned school finance systems in recent years. The others are Kentucky, New Jersey, Kansas, Wisconsin, California, Connecticut, Washington, West Virginia, Wyoming, Arkansas and Montana. In vetoing the bill last week, Clements decried the half-cent sales tax increase lawmakers want to help pay for the measure. Rep. Eddie Cavazos, a Democrat from Corpus Christi, said a court-written plan is looking more attractive to those who represent poor districts. ``We've done the best we can, and they won't accept it. That's fine. Let them try to deal with a master,'' said Cavazos, chairman of the House Mexican American Legislative Caucus.

DOC.HEAD: College Donations Reach Record $8.9 Billion
DOC.TEXT: Rebounding from a slump last year, private donations to colleges and universities rose 8.8 percent to a record $8.9 billion in the 1989-90 academic year, a report says. After a 3.5 percent decline in private giving in 1988-89 that many blamed on the 1987 stock market crash, donations returned to more normal patterns, according to the report issued Tuesday by the Council for Aid to Education. ``Despite the continued sluggish pace of the economy and generally poor corporate profits, individual Americans and a variety of American institutions ... seem willing to sustain their support of higher education,'' said council president Arnold Shore. As it has since 1985-86, Stanford University received the most contributions of any institution _ $188.6 million. The council's national figures are estimates based on survey responses from 1,132 colleges and universities. Among the findings: _Alumni contributions rose 12.2 percent to $2.29 billion; _Gifts from non-alumni individuals were up 7.8 percent to $2.08 billion; _Corporate giving totaled $1.95 billion, up 5.1 percent; _Foundation support rose 8.4 percent to $1.74 billion; _Religious organizations donated $237 million, up 20.1 percent; _Contributions from other sources reached $632 million, up 10 percent. Twenty colleges and universities attracted approximately 23 percent of all contributions to higher education, according to the survey. Following Stanford, those schools were, in order: Harvard University, $185.4 million; Cornell University, $157.1 million; Yale University, $122.8 million; University of Pennsylvania, $121.9 million; Columbia University, $110.4 million; University of Southern California, $102.6 million; University of Wisconsin-Madison, $102.2 million; Duke University, $102 million; University of Minnesota, $100.2 million; Massachusetts Institute of Technology, $95.7 million; Johns Hopkins University, $84.1 million; Princeton University, $80.3 million; University of Washington, $76.4 million; University of Illinois, $73.1 million; University of California-Los Angeles, $72.8 million; University of Michigan, $70.7 million; Ohio State University, $68.6 million; Northwestern University, $68.5 million, and University of California-Berkeley, $68.3 million.

DOC.SECOND: PM-AP Photo Package: Heart to Heart,0293
DOC.HEAD: U.S. Team of Doctors Helps Soviet Children With Heart Defects
An AP Photo Package
LaserPhotos NY320-NY325 sent May 25,26.
DOC.TEXT: The group of Oakland, Calif., medics is known as Heart to Heart, and to many Soviet families, they are more than an exchange program. They are the gift of life to children born with heart defects. After her husband's summit meeting with President Bush, Raisa Gorbachev plans a visit next week to Oakland's Children's Hospital, Heart to Heart's base. More than half the 50,000 children born in the Soviet Union each year with heart defects die before their first birthdays. The Heart to Heart team of doctors and nurses know they personally can help only a few of those children, but their educational programs for both medical personnel and parents are designed to benefit a greater number. The group is planning its third trip to Leningrad this fall to operate on several children and teach more Soviet doctors advanced heart techniques. Earlier this year, 130 families, who had learned of the 15-member team's visit from newspaper stories or friends, traveled great distances just for the chance to have their children examined at Leningrad's Children's Hospital. The waiting room was a mixture of elation and sadness as some parents learned their children could be operated on and others were told their child's condition was inoperable. Most of the operations actually are simple, the U.S. doctors say, just a matter of having the proper training and equipment. Within days, they say, many of the children are up and around, showing renewed energy. Then nurse Lili Cook can tell those parents, ``From now on, your children can lead a normal life.''

DOC.HEAD: Antique Dealer Wins Right to Hang Out Queen Victoria's Bloomers
DOC.TEXT: An antique dealer has won a court battle giving her the right to hang Queen Victoria's bloomers from her market stall. Anne Swift, who runs a store in Portobello Road, London's main antique shopping area, successfully appealed against a ban imposed by local councilors. ``Could you say Queen Victoria's undergarments have connotations of dirt and shabbiness?'' Mrs. Swift asked in a London magistrates court on Tuesday. Councilors had banned stalls from selling second-hand clothing but allowed Mrs. Swift to continue as long as she displayed garments flat. Mrs. Swift deals exclusively in antique textiles. Appealing the order, Mrs. Swift told the court she could not sell the valuable Victorian garments that way because they would become creased and damaged. Dermot Woolgar, representing the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, said the stall was ``a shambles'' and obstructed the view of other stalls. Among the antique lace, needlework and fabrics on sale were several items said to have been worn by Queen Victoria. The garments included three camisoles valued at $500 each, one nightgown at $845, and a pair of bloomers, whose price is available on application.

DOC.HEAD: Carroll Is Named AP's Washington Enterprise Editor
DOC.TEXT: Kathleen Carroll, an editor for newspapers in California and Paris after a six-year tenure with The Associated Press, has returned to the news cooperative as news editor for enterprise in Washington. The appointment was announced Tuesday by Washington Chief of Bureau Jon Wolman. Carroll, 34, was assistant city editor of the San Jose (Calif.) Mercury News from 1986 to 1988. She also was a financial editor for the International Herald Tribune in Paris from 1984 to 1986. Carroll joined the AP in 1978 in Dallas. She was a newswoman there and in Los Angeles, news editor in Newark and assistant chief of bureau in Los Angeles, where she resigned in 1984. Carroll is a native of Hattiesburg, Miss., and attended the University of Texas at Arlington. She began her journalism career at the Dallas Morning News. In Washington she succeeds Wayne Davis, who has taken a leave of absence.

DOC.HEAD: Wilhelm Is Named AP's Beijing Bureau Chief
DOC.TEXT: Katherine A. Wilhelm, a newswoman in the Beijing bureau of The Associated Press, has been named chief of bureau in charge of AP operations in the People's Republic of China. The appointment was announced Tuesday by AP President Louis D. Boccardi and is effective July 1. Wilhelm, 32, has covered China for the AP for the past three years. She succeeds Jim Abrams, who will move to the United States for an assignment in AP's Washington bureau after four years as Beijing bureau chief. Wilhelm joined the AP in Louisville in 1983 and transferred to Pittsburgh later that year. She also worked on the AP's Foreign Desk in New York before her assignment in China. Wilhelm is a native of East Brunswick, N.J., and a history graduate of Niagara University. She holds a master's degree in Chinese studies from Harvard University and a master's in journalism from Columbia University.

DOC.HEAD: Chicago Goes Crazy Over Cicadas
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
Eds: Cicada pronounced si-kay'-duh
DOC.TEXT: This city is going bonkers over bugs. There are nightly updates on the TV news, recipes in the newspaper, even a special hot line heralding not the coming of the apocalypse, but the emergence of inch-long critters called cicadas. The noisy devils unearth temselves every 17 years to mate, shriek incessantly, and drive homeowners crazy. Millions of the winged creatures are expected to emerge in parts of Illinois, Iowa, Indiana and Wisconsin during the next few days, covering back yards and forests with their brownish, crunchy bodies. After mating and laying eggs that will remain underground for another 17 years, the cicadas will die. The orgy should be over by early July, and experts say the creatures are harmless. But that hasn't calmed the hysteria. ``It's completely unfounded,'' said Field Museum entomologist Phil Parrillo. ``People are going out and getting insecticide to spray on them, but they're only going to be here for a few weeks. Gee whiz, don't worry about it.'' The males produce a large shrill sound; the females are mute. ``They may be a nuisance in terms of the sound that they make,'' he said Tuesday. And they can damage young trees where they lay their eggs. ``Other than that, they're really not going to cause a problem,'' he said. Midwesterners might get a different impression from reading the newspaper or watching the news lately. ``The cicadas have reached Elmhurst,'' a broadcaster announced in a teaser for a recent television newscast. WLS-TV news has run five or six reports ``saying that they're on their way, and also a story on what people can do to protect their young trees,'' said Jim Lichtenstein, assignment editor. The cover of a recent Chicago Tribune Sunday magazine featured the warning: ``Get Ready! The 17-year itch of the cicada is about to begin.'' The Chicago Sun-Times last week set up a hot line, which has received at least 60 calls a day from curious or horrified homeowners with questions about the bugs, said Jim Martinez, metropolitan editor. The newspaper even printed recipes for readers brave enough to eat the creatures. Michael Kendall, a Chicago attorney, tested one of the recipes with some cicadas he found Monday night in his brother's suburban back yard. ``We parboiled them and then sauteed them in butter and garlic and ate them sort of like shrimp,'' Kendall said. ``They taste like sort of a starchy potato. They had a sort of scalloplike consistency.'' Parrillo says this batch of cicadas _ Brood 13 _ lives in the top third of Illinois, parts of eastern Iowa and western Indiana, and in southern Wisconsin. Other broods, on different 17-year cycles, live throughout the eastern United States, and some cicadas emerge every 13 years, he said. He knows of no other periodic cicadas that are appearing this year. ``If people can set aside their insect phobia long enough to appreciate what's happening ... it's something that I think they should go out and take a look at,'' said Parrillo, blaming the news media for helping create cicada mania. But the Sun-Times' Martinez said the bugs warrant the coverage. ``How often do you have all these little bugs coming out of the ground, making so much noise, being such a nuisance?'' he asked. ``It's just a fascinating bit of nature that we don't often get a chance to look at.''

DOC.HEAD: Afghan Fundamentalists Threaten Aid Agencies and Women
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Now that the Soviet army has left Afghanistan, Moslem fundamentalists are turning their wrath on Western aid agencies and Afghan women who work for them. Threats of ``revolutionary action'' against the women issue from faceless tribunals with mystery memberships and names like Council of Islamic Jihad, Reformist Movement of Moslem Youth and Mujahed Brothers. Jihad means holy war and mujahedeen are holy warriors. Leaders of guerrilla groups fighting the Soviet-sponsored government in Kabul deny knowledge of the tribunals, which have made their presence known through letters warning Afghan women away from the Western agencies. More than 3 million Afghan refugees live in camps around this frontier town at the foot of the Khyber Pass, the route to Afghanistan. Scores of humanitarian aid groups established headquarters in Peshawar after the Red Army entered the Afghan civil war in December 1979 and refugees started streaming into Pakistan. The last Soviet military forces left last year. Letters signed by the groups, written by hand or typed, began circulating in refugee camps in May. One said the aid groups engaged in ``immoral activities, one of the characteristics and products of Western civilization that is not proper for Moslem women.'' A mob of about 5,000 people in the Nasir Bagh refugee camp attacked operations of Shelter Now International, which is financed by several Christian groups, causing nearly $1 million in damage. Over mosque loudspeakers Moslem clerics exhorted the mob and denounced Western influence. The targets were a sewing center for widows and an elementary school for girls. Nasir Bagh is considered the showcase of the 250 refugee camps in Pakistan's Northwest Frontier Province. In mid-May, about 100 Afghan men chanting ``Down with foreigners!'' and ``Death to Afghans who work with foreigners!'' destroyed a concrete factory established by Shelter Now International in Afghanistan's eastern Nangarhar province. A mob attacked the Austrian Relief Committee headquarters in Peshawar the next day, but did little damage. ``Most refugees have nothing to do with this whole business,'' said Ted Albers, a spokesman for an umbrella group of 51 agencies. He said rivalries among the seven guerrilla organizations based in Pakistan had caused much uncertainty but there was no evidence of a coordinated effort to undermine Western aid programs. Much of the foreign aid has gone to Hezb-i-Islami, or Party of God, led by Gulbuddin Hekmatyar. Tales abound of how Hekmatyar, known for anti-West rhetoric, threw acid in the faces and on the arms and legs of unveiled Afghan women in the early 1970s before fleeing to Pakistan. President Najibullah of Afghanistan has emphasized the fundamentalist element of the rebel groups in his propaganda campaign against the guerrillas. Women in Kabul, particularly teen-age girls, say they fear they would be forced back into veils if Hekmatyar or Abdul Rasul Sayyaf came to power. Sayyaf, prime minister of the guerrilla government, will not talk to female journalists and forces Western women to wear tent-like veils in his presence. Gulzar Khan, Pakistan's commissioner for Afghan refugees, would not say what the government was doing to protect the aid agencies or their programs for women, but said: ``You can't wish it away. The problems are there.'' Afghan women are afraid. A young woman concealed in a voluminous shawl glanced around nervously before hurrying into a walled compound in Peshawar's maze of alleys. She calls herself Farida, fearing to use her real name because she is on a list compiled by self-appointed protectors of Islamic purity. Farida, 31, runs an elementary school financed by a West German agency. She has been threatened repeatedly by fundamentalists and blames radical followers of Hekmatyar. A bomb was found outside the school in 1984 and defused. Hekmatyar denies responsibility for such acts. Farida said of the radicals: ``For 10 years I've been with these people. They are not like humans. Sometimes they call me and say, `We want to kill you.''' What should have been a five-minute drive to Farida's school took nearly half an hour because she did not want it known that a foreign journalist was visiting. ``I'm afraid, but I take care of myself and I want to give courage to the girls,'' she said. She goes to her school each morning in one outfit and is dressed differently when she leaves. For two months, she couldn't reach her home because Afghan men blocked the way. Farida opened the school in 1980 with 27 students. She now has 575 girls and 363 boys, taught separately. ``My heart wants to help these refugee children,'' she said. ``This is the chance for Afghan children. ``The future for women in Afghanistan is very dark. The difficulties are many.''

DOC.HEAD: Fall Schedules: Fox Aims at NBC, CBS Unveils Nine Shows
LaserGraphic
With PM-Fall TV-List
DOC.TEXT: Fox Broadcasting Co. takes dead aim this fall at NBC's Thursday night dominance, pitting America's most alienated TV family, ``The Simpsons,'' against the blithe Huxtables of ``The Cosby Show.'' ``We believe you have to take risks,'' Peter Chernin, Fox's entertainment chief, told advertisers Tuesday in previewing the fall lineup. ``We don't think you can play it safe any longer in the current network environment.'' CBS unveiled nine new series after three straight third-place seasons in prime time. Two are hourlong action dramas, ``The Flash,'' about the superfast crimefighter from the comic pages, and network TV's first environmental action show, ``The Green Machine,'' in which the heroes fight polluters. Chernin announced nine new series in Fox's move from three to five nights of prime-time programming. To make room, Fox cut its original series, ``21 Jump Street,'' as well as ``Alien Nation,'' ``Booker'' and ``The Outsiders.'' ``The Simpsons'' will take on ratings giant ``Cosby'' on Thursday night, followed by ``Babes,'' a sitcom about three large sisters who share a cramped New York apartment and Zip Code dress sizes. Then, at 9 p.m. Eastern time, Fox goes for the younger viewer with ``Class of Beverly Hills,'' the story of Midwestern teen-age twins who confront the issues of growing up in the surreal, monied ambience of Beverly Hills High. CBS Entertainment chief Jeff Sagansky, announcing his first full schedule since he was hired last fall, overhauled all nights except Tuesday and Sunday, giving the network four nights of comedies. CBS' roster includes five new hourlong series; four new sitcoms and a comedy once on NBC, ``The Hogan Family.'' It also has a movie package of such hits as ``Born on the Fourth of July'' and ``Do The Right Thing.'' Low-rated ``Saturday Night With Connie Chung'' moves to Mondays as ``Face to Face With Connie Chung,'' but CBS dropped the Vietnam War series ``Tour of Duty,'' ``Falcon Crest,'' ``The Famous Teddy Z,'' ``City'' and ``Sydney.'' Sagansky said the Western ``Paradise'' may be renewed. ``Wiseguy'' is in backup status, he added. Ken Wahl would return in the first few episodes, then be succeeded by Stephen Bauer as a new undercover agent. CBS' new sitcoms are the movie spinoff ``Uncle Buck,'' the blue-collar ``Lenny,'' ``Four Alarm Family,'' about a widowed firefighter with four kids, and ``Evening Shade,'' starring Burt Reynolds as an ex-football star who moves his family back to the small Arkansas town of his boyhood. Edward Woodward of CBS' late ``The Equalizer'' will return in the hourlong ``Over My Dead Body'' as a crime novelist paired with a young obituary writer. CBS' other new hourlong entries are ``WIOU,'' a drama about the cutthroat world of local TV starring John Shea, and ``The Hammersmiths,'' a drama with Lucie Arnaz about three generations of a family. Fox offers ``American Chronicles,'' a half-hour documentary series by Mark Frost and David Lynch, creators of ``Twin Peaks,'' and an hour series of various video projects, ``Fox Video Hour.'' Fox's other new hour show is ``D.E.A.,'' which mixes documentary and drama about the exploits of the Drug Enforcement Administration. On Monday's ``Fox Night at the Movies'' the fourth network will combine theatrical and made-for-TV movies aimed at younger viewers. ``We think we're in a real real dogfight out there,'' Chernin said. ``We think we're in competition not only with the other netwroks, but also with cable, VCRs, Nintendos and every other leisure time activity. We've got to go out there and kick and scream to get viewers.'' Fox will anchor its Sunday schedule with ``True Colors,'' a sitcom about interracial marriage that Chernin called ``Fox's answer to `The Brady Bunch.''' It stars Nancy Walker as an acerbic mother-in-law. It will be followed by ``Parker Lewis Can't Lose,'' high school adventures with Dobie Gillis and Ferris Bueller overtones; the sketch comedy of ``In Living Color;'' comedian Chris Elliott in ``Get a Life'' as a 30-year-old newsboy; the miserable Bundy family of ``Married ... with Children,'' and ``Good Grief,'' about two brothers-in-law who operate the family mortuary. Fox will close Sunday night with ``Against the Law,'' a courtroom drama starring Michael O'Keefe as ``television's first gonzo, rock 'n' roll lawyer,'' Chernin said. Fox has 129 affiliates, compared with more than 200 each for CBS, NBC and ABC, but isn't considered a network by the Federal Communications Commission. It is expanding this fall under a one-year FCC waiver that lets it broadcast 18{ hours a week of prime-time programming without being subject to restrictions that bar CBS, NBC and ABC from the lucrative syndication business.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutors Delay Filing Charges Against Environmentalists Injured in Blast
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Earth First! cq
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors indefinitely postponed Tuesday's scheduled arraignment of two radical environmentalists accused of carrying a pipe bomb that exploded in their car and injured them. ``We've decided to review all the evidence, including laboratory test results, before making any further decision,'' said Chris Carpenter, an assistant district attorney for Alameda County. Reviewing the local and FBI lab tests could take several weeks, he said. Judi Bari and Darryl Cherney of the group Earth First! had been scheduled to be arraigned Tuesday on charges of criminal possession of explosives. Cherney's attorney, Doug Horngrad, said the prosecutors' action indicates the charges were groundless. ``If they had a case to go forward on, they would have filed charges today,'' Horngrad said. ``I'm of the opinion there aren't going to be any charges.'' The two activists were arrested Friday after a pipe bomb exploded in their car in Oakland. Bari, 40, remains in stable condition at Highland Hospital with a fractured pelvis and internal injuries; Cherney, 33, suffered a cut over his left eye and a scratched cornea. In addition to the possession charges, Cherney was booked for possession of a destructive device in a public place and for possession of a booby trap. Bari was booked on all but the booby trap charge. Bail was set for each at $100,000. Cherney was released late Monday on Bari remains under protective custody in the hospital. Police are looking for a link between the Oakland car blast and a May 10 pipe bomb that exploded at the Louisiana-Pacific Lumber Co. in Cloverdale, about 80 miles north of San Francisco. But Earth First! supporters say Cherney and Bari are committed to non-violence and were victims, not criminals. The two were driving to Santa Cruz for a rally to drum up support for Redwood Summer, an Earth First!-sponsored campaign of blockades and other protests to slow logging of ancient redwood trees in Northern California. The campaign is modeled after the civil rights movement's Mississippi Summer. Earth First!, widely considered a radical, extremist environmentalist group, was founded in 1979 with the slogan ``No compromise in defense of Mother Earth.'' The group has gained notoriety for driving spikes in trees to damage logging equipment and using other ``monkey-wrenching'' techniques.

DOC.HEAD: Boat People Vow to Resist Attempts at Repatriation
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Nguyen Van Nam sat at his ``home'' at the High Island Detention Center, the middle tier of a three-level bunk bed he shares with his wife and two children, and vowed to die rather than return to Vietnam. If Hong Kong refuses to grant him refugee status, he said through an interpreter, ``We would rather be dead here than go back to Vietnam.'' Similar responses were echoed by several other High Island residents during interviews Tuesday, indicating that the days of tranquility for what has been a model detention center for Vietnamese boat people may be numbered. So far, High Island has been free of the rioting, mass escapes and occasional suicide attempts that have plagued other detention centers for boat people since a group of 51 Vietnamese were forceably repatriated late last year. The government has refused to allow journalists into any detention center since the deportation, citing safety concerns. But in recent days, small groups of journalists have been taken to High Island in an apparent attempt by the government to put the best face on the camps, where squalid living conditions have been the subject of harsh international criticism. ``We have at the moment a happy camp,'' Police Supt. R.L. Nicholls said of the facility, which is in a country park about an hour's drive from downtown Hong Kong. But, he added, ``We don't think the complexion of this camp will last much longer.'' A main reason that High Island has remained relatively calm is that almost none of its residents have gone through the screening process that determines who will be resettled overseas and who will be repatriated. The camp is home to almost 7,000 people. By contrast, nearly 8,000 of the 22,000 Vietnamese at the Whitehead Detention Center have been informed they will not be granted refugee status. Security forces have fired tear gas to quell rioting and uncovered hundreds of homemade weapons at the camp in recent months. The screening of High Island residents is scheduled to begin this summer. Police at the facility expect some resistance and there are already signs of impending defiance. ``I'll never go back to Vietnam,'' said a 33-year-old man surnamed Tran, who vowed to commit suicide if the government tries to force him back. ``They can force me to go back to Vietnam only if they tie my feet and hands,'' said Nguyen Son Ha, 49, from the northern Vietnamese province of Quang Ninh. Several Vietnamese expressed concern about the screening process, in which immigration officials determine who qualifies for refugee status. To qualify for such status immigrants must prove they fled their homeland out of a well-founded fear of persecution. All High Island residents interviewed by this reporter expressed confidence they would be screened in, but more than 80 percent of the boat people screened so far have been rejected. Vietnamese residents confirmed that High Island, which opened in November, is a relatively quiet camp with little crime. But they complain about the quality of food, the lack of books and magazines and what they consider harsh treatment by some police officers. The boat people are crammed into 22 huts, each family sharing a tiny bunk-bed tier, and the camp is surrounded by an approximately 20-foot-high fence topped with two loops of barbed wire. Many Vietnamese lie listlessly on their beds as children scamper up and down the center aisle. But Nicholls points out there is more space between the huts at High Island than at other detention centers, and there is a basketball court and open concrete space for other games. He said about 900 children attend classes managed by international volunteer agencies, and a $77,000 jungle gym donated by a U.S. Buddhist organization is popular. Luu Chi Tich, a 49-year-old sports instructor from Hanoi summed up the feeling in the camp. ``In general, we are sad here.'' About 55,000 refugees who fled communist Vietnam to this British colony live in camps. Nearly 11,000 are considered refugees, another 10,600 are considered illegal immigrants and the remainder await screening.

DOC.HEAD: Eight Hong Kong Drug Traffickers Hanged
DOC.TEXT: Eight Hong Kong residents convicted of trafficking in heroin were hanged today despite appeals from British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and the human rights group Amnesty International. Prison officials it was the highest number of hangings on a single day and the first time a foreign woman has been executed in Malaysia. Despite widespread criticism, Malaysian officials say they will maintain the mandatory death penalty for anyone convicted of drug trafficking. Officials say there are about 350,000 drug addicts among Malaysia's 17.8 million people and Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad has called illicit drugs Malaysia's ``No. 1 enemy.'' Since 1975, 250 people have been sentenced to death for drug trafficking. Of those, 92 have been hanged, including the eight today. Those hanged include 26 foreigners: six Singaporeans, three Thais, three Filipinos, three Indonesians, two Australians, a Briton and the eight from Hong Kong. Under Malaysian law, a drug trafficking conviction does not require proof of sale. The possession of more than one-half ounce of heroin or 3{ ounces of marijuana is considered trafficking. Han Tsui Ling, 32, a waitress, and Chow Sing, 42, a used car dealer, were hanged today at Kajang prison, 18 miles south of Kuala Lumpur. Au King Chor, 32, Chan Yiu Tim, 32, and Yuen Kwok Kwan, 28, all transport workers; Li Chi Peng, 28, a waiter; Ip Tak Meng, 36, a supervisor in a vegetable marketing company in Kowloon; and Ng Yin Kwok, 37, director of an insurance company in Kowloon, were executed in Taiping Prison, 150 miles north of the capital. Police said the eight were on their way to Brussels with more than 28 pounds of heroin in five suitcases when they were arrested at Penang International Airport, 180 miles northwest of Kuala Lumpur in October 1982. They were convicted in May 1985 and the Supreme Court turned down their appeals four years later. A ninth Hong Kong resident arrested in the case, Tam Tak Wai, has been sentenced to life.

DOC.HEAD: Family's Long Search For a `Drifter' Ends With His Death
DOC.TEXT: Douglas Beattie's final bed on a cold, rainy night was a steel trash bin. Death came in the morning, when the container was emptied into a garbage truck and the 36-year-old drifter was crushed. Authorities were disturbed by the manner of Beattie's death, but it wasn't the first time a homeless stranger had passed away. A thousand miles away, Paula Wyatt had been waiting for word of her brother for nine years, since he abruptly left home. He died without her learning what led him to flee or how he had spent the intervening years. ``This isn't a person who wasn't loved. He was loved dearly by a lot of people,'' a sobbing Mrs. Wyatt said in a telephone interview from her home in Whitehall, Pa., a Pittsburgh suburb. ``His life has been a mystery for the family. He was a kind and gentle person. He just couldn't hack it. ... We tried so hard to find him and we couldn't.'' Beattie was something of a loner and had a drinking problem. Before he disappeared for good, his two brothers and two sisters sometimes lost track of him during drinking binges, they said. The circumstances of his death have been so devastating that some family members have been told only that he died of exposure, said Mrs. Wyatt. ``We are all carrying a lot of guilt, a super amount of guilt,'' she said. ``If we had been able to reach Doug, it may have made a difference.'' Two years ago, the family tried to track him down to inform him he had inherited about $15,000 from his aunt, said Ron Wyatt, Beattie's brother-in-law. Ed Tutewiler of the Salvation Army in Wausau said he has seen hundreds of men like Beattie, guys ``running away from themselves by hitting the road.'' What's different is the way Beattie died. ``Someone crushed by a garbage truck is unusual. Someone's throat slit isn't,'' Tutewiler said. ``The streets are far more dangerous to someone doing harm to you (than) a freak accident like this.'' An autopsy found that Beattie was alive when the garbage truck lifted the trash bin and unloaded it May 10. The autopsy couldn't determine whether he was conscious. A bulldozer operator at a landfill spotted the mangled body among some rubbish. Authorities identified Beattie from a card he carried from a post office. All Mrs. Wyatt knows about Beattie's life since he left in 1981 is what the police told her _ that he had been in Reno, Nev., within the past two years, was arrested for trespassing in Oregon in June and arrived in Wausau about May 3. Beattie's family remembers him as kind to children. He had worked as a bartender and had a talent for drawing; they had hoped he would become an architect. Seeking to explain his problems, the family said Beattie's father died when he was a baby. When he was a teen-ager, Beattie's mother barely escaped a fire that destroyed their apartment, said Ron Wyatt. Beattie's stay in Wausau was like that of other drifters, authorities said. Police officer Craig Dunbar found him wandering the streets drunk on May 3 with $2 to $3 in his pockets. Dunbar took him to a mental health center, the local equivalent of the drunk tank in the town of 33,000. ``He appeared very healthy, just drunk,'' Dunbar said. ``He didn't seem like a bad guy, a troublemaker.'' After his release from the center, Beattie spent two nights in a motel courtesy of the Salvation Army, Tutewiler said. On May 9, a Roman Catholic priest offered to pay for his stay at a motel. Later that evening, Beattie called the Rev. Jerome Hoeser from a restaurant, telling him the motel claimed not to have a room. The priest told Beattie to call him again from the motel. Hoeser never received another call. The motel had vacancies, Hoeser said, but apparently mistrusted Beattie because he didn't have ID. ``There was no reason why he shouldn't have been able to find a place,'' the priest said.

DOC.HEAD: EPA Memo Warns of Threat of Explosion at Nuclear Waste Dump
DOC.TEXT: Gases could build up and explode at an underground radioactive waste dump the government hopes to open this year, according to a memo by an Environmental Protection Agency official. The memo was released Tuesday at a hearing on the proposed Waste Isolation Pilot Plant, which the Department of Energy hopes to use as a permanent repository for wastes from nuclear weapons plants. The government hopes in the fall to begin a five-year test program storing waste in the underground salt beds 26 miles southeast of Carlsbad. The EPA held Tuesday's hearing to consider a variance that would allow DOE to bypass certain hazardous waste treatment requirements. To get the variance, the DOE must show the wastes would not leak out. The memorandum, prepared in August by Ben Smith of the EPA's Land Disposal Restriction branch, raises safety concerns that should be addressed in an independent investigation, said James Werner, a spokesman for the Natural Resources Defense Council, which released the memo. Smith wrote that low-level waste would probably contain acetone and various alcohols widely used as cleaning solvents. ``If these solvents are present ... the possibility of accumulation of flammable gases in the waste storage rooms ... is significant,'' he wrote. ``Such an explosion could kill hundreds of workers and destroy the $700 million repository.'' Smith said in an interview in today's New York Times that the Energy Department had never seriously considered the threat of an explosion. His superiors disregarded his conclusions, Smith said. An EPA spokesman said the agency had a consultant study the issue after it received Smith's memo. Based on the consultant's findings, ``We didn't think there was a serious gas buildup explosion threat for the period we're talking about,'' said Matthew Hale, an official in the EPA's Office of Solid Waste. The five-year program will allow EPA to determine how much gas is generated in underground storage, Hale said. Gas buildups will be monitored during the period. Michele Merola, a spokeswoman for Concerned Citizens for Nuclear Safety, charged that the DOE's variance petition was ``being rushed through the EPA at top speed.'' An activist who identified himself as Richard Deyo was charged with disorderly conduct after jumping onto the stage at the hearing and upsetting the podium.

DOC.HEAD: `Back to the Future III' Launches Summer Season With $23.7 Million Haul
DOC.TEXT: ``Back to the Future Part III'' grossed $23.7 million over the four-day Memorial Day weekend for the No. 1 spot at the nation's box office. The Universal Pictures time-travel sequel starring Michael J. Fox earned $20 million less than ``Back to the Future Part II'' did over the five-day Thanksgiving weekend last year. ``It won't be the biggest opening weekend this summer, but we're very happy,'' said Tom Pollock, chairman of MCA's motion picture group, makers of the ``Back to the Future'' trilogy. ``Movies are not judged on opening weekends. They have to be judged on how long they play and how much money they earn in relation to their cost.'' ``Back to the Future Part III'' has received better reviews than its immediate predecessor, which even Universal admits was not very good. ``Back to the Future Part III'' did not open as well as the Memorial Day films from the last three years. In 1989, ``Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade'' made $37 million; in 1988, ```Crocodile' Dundee II'' grossed $24.5 million, and in 1987 ``Beverly Hills Cop'' took in $33 million. According to figures compiled by Exhibitor Relations Co., ``Back to the Future Part III'' far outdistanced second-place ``Bird on a Wire,'' with Goldie Hawn and Mel Gibson. That film, also a Universal release, grossed $12.8 million. In third was ``Pretty Woman'' with ticket sales of $8.2 million. The comedy starring Julia Roberts as a streetwalker and Richard Gere as a corporate raider now has made more than $120 million, making it the year's biggest moneymaker. Here are the top movie ticket sales for Friday through Monday as tallied by Exhibitor Relations, with distributor, weekend gross, number of theater screens, average per screen, total gross and number of weeks in release. Figures are based on a combination of actual box-office receipts and studio projections where actual figures are not immediately available. 1. ``Back to the Future Part III,'' Universal, $23.7 million, 2,019 screens, $11,740 per screen, $23.7 million, one week. 2. ``Bird on a Wire,'' Universal, $12.8 million, 1,949 screens, $6,565 per screen, $33.4 million, two weeks. 3. ``Pretty Woman,'' Disney, $8.2 million, 1,803 screens, $4,542 per screen, $120.2 million, 10 weeks. 4. ``Cadillac Man,'' Orion, $6.5 million, 1,844 screens, $3,509 per screen, $15.3 million, two weeks. 5. ``Fire Birds,'' Disney, $6.4 million, 2,006 screens, $3,170 per screen, $6.4 million, one week. 6. ``Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles,'' New Line, $3 million, 1,970 screens, $1,516 per screen, $118.1 million, nine weeks. 7. ``The Hunt for Red October,'' Paramount, $2.1 million, 1,061 screens, $2,006 per screen, $110.8 million, 13 weeks. 8. ``Tales From the Darkside,'' Paramount, $1.6 million, 1,025 screens, $1,598 per screen, $14.5 million, four weeks. 9. ``Joe Versus the Volcano,'' Warner Bros., $821,125, 746 screens, $1,101 per screen, $37.6 million, 12 weeks. 10. ``Spaced Invaders,'' Disney, $734,724, 949 screens, $774 per screen, $13.7 million, five weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Maoist Rebels Kill Two Vargas Llosa Supporters in Separate Attacks
DOC.TEXT: Shining Path rebels assassinated two leaders of presidential candidate Mario Vargas Llosa's Democratic Front coalition in separate attacks, police said. The shootings took place less than two weeks before Vargas Llosa, a celebrated novelist and free-market advocate, faces centrist Alberto Fujimori in a runoff presidential election. Fujimori, a political newcomer, is favored to win the June 10 showdown. Felix Vega Riquelme, the former governor of Piura, was shot to death on Tuesday in the coastal city 530 miles northwest of Lima, police said. Hours later, in the Andean city of Cerro de Pasco, Prospero Delson Huaman was shot and killed, police said. Cerro de Pasco is 110 miles northeast of Lima. Vega was gunned down by two men on a motorcycle as he was getting out of a pickup truck, police said. An unidentified companion was seriously wounded. Delson was shot twice in the head by two rebels as he walked home from his job at the Centromin mining company, police said. Before the formation of the Democratic Front coalition, both men were leaders of the center-right Popular Action Party of former president Fernando Belaunde. The Maoist-inspired Shining Path has tried to sabotage the electoral process in Peru. Before April 8 general elections, the rebels called an armed strike in Lima and most of Peru's countryside. The government says more than 18,000 people have died in political violence since the Shining Path took up arms 10 years ago. Also Tuesday, police said villagers armed with sticks, stones and machetes battled over a disputed plot of land, leaving seven people dead. As many as 50 people were injured in the clash, which took place Monday night between the small Andean villages of Lircaycacca and Chinabamba, police said. The villages are 30 miles southeast of Huancavalica, an Andean city 145 miles southeast of Lima. The land battle followed three years of deteriorating relations between the two isolated villages, police said. Earlier clashes between the villages, each of which has 200 to 300 residents, resulted in injuries but no deaths, police said.

DOC.HEAD: States Cutting Food Program for Women and Children
DOC.TEXT: State governments, squeezed hard by rising milk, orange juice and cereal prices, are making cuts in a federally funded program that furnishes food to needy women, infants and children. Thirty-six of 44 state governments responding to a recent survey said they were cutting their portions of the $2.1 billion Special Supplemental Food Program for Women, Infants and Children, also known as WIC. The survey was taken by the National Association of WIC directors. Rep. Tony P. Hall, D-Ohio, chairman of the House Select Committee on Hunger, said a survey by his panel came up with virtually the same results. ``It means we won't have as many healthy children and mothers as we wanted because all of these people are medically at risk for malnutrition and anemia,'' said Hall. The program provides poor women and their youngsters with vouchers redeemable at the grocery store for specific kinds of food in stated amounts. Included are milk, cheese, cereal, juice and infant formula. It provided food to a record high 4.55 million individuals in February. The program has been a favorite with Congress, which has increased its funding every year despite demands for cutbacks in the Reagan era. Hall is seeking a $150 million increase annually for the next five years, with the first installment coming Oct. 1. The extra funds once were envisioned as a way of expanding the program but supporters now are doubtful. ``If we stay even, we'll be lucky,'' Hall said. Rising prices for milk, and to a lesser degree, orange juice and cereal, have been pinpointed as the prime sources of the budgetary strain. The Agriculture Department's food and nutrition service had figured on inflation in food prices this year of a little over 4 percent. Authorities said the cost of basic items have risen at about double the expected rate. Thus, grants to the states have not been enough to maintain benefit levels. States have found varying ways to economize. ``We've talked to the states about the first measure being to find less expensive ways to provide the same nutrition without cutting volume of food or nutritional value of food,'' said F. Philip Shanholtzer, a spokesman for the food and nutritional service. Texas has cut the cereal allowance for 1-year-olds and 2-year-olds from 36 ounces a month to 24 ounces a month and will drop 27,000 program participants. Those receiving benefits reached a peak of 357,000 in January. ``When prices go up on food items, that means our budget won't go as far and we have to serve fewer people,'' said Ray Krzesniak, chief of staff services for the Health Department's bureau of women, infants and children. Texas gets $148 million from USDA under the program as well as $5.5 million in state funds plus a hefty rebate on each can of infant formula. Meanwhile, Iowa is planning to end benefits for post-partum women who are not breast-feeding. That would drop an estimated 4,000 participants and reduce the total of individuals receiving benefits to 45,000 for a $400,000 savings. California plans to cut the monthly juice allotment for children 3 years old to 5 years old for an expected savings of $1.2 million. It also hopes to save $6 million by eliminating vouchers for cheese. Currently only about half of those eligible are receiving benefits, according to Bach. Many states are not able to provide food to individuals who fall into the lowest priority categories. ``There are literally millions of young children who would qualify for WIC who are not getting served,'' Bach said.

The Agriculture Department is proposing to resume imports of ostriches and other flightless birds banned for the last nine months after exotic ticks were found on some of the creatures. The African Bont ticks and Bont-legged ticks were found on ostriches imported from Tanzania on Aug. 2. The ban went into effect on Aug. 15. The ticks carry heartwater and East Coast fever, diseases that are not found in the United States and which do not affect humans but which can become established among livestock and wildlife. The ostriches had been released from their 30-day quarantine at a USDA-approved facility in Mundelein, Ill., without discovery of the problem. The birds then were moved to farms in Texas, Oklahoma, Ohio and Illinois. Officials said there was no sign that the ticks had become established there. Other birds covered by the plan include cassowaries, emus, kiwis and rheas.

DOC.HEAD: Duke's Affirmative Action Ban Passes Louisiana House
DOC.TEXT: A bill sponsored by former Ku Klux Klan leader David Duke to ban affirmative action easily passed the Lousiana House. The 66-28 vote Tuesday sent the measure to the Senate. The vote crossed party lines; 13 representatives abstained. ``You can camouflage things but racism is racism,'' said one opponent, Democratic Rep. C.D. Jones, who is black. He added, ``You still must understand that we live in the United States and federal law takes precedence over the Louisiana Legislature, and thank God for that.'' Duke, a former KKK grand wizard elected to the House as a Republican from a nearly all-white district in 1989, argued that affirmative action seeks to ``eradicate discrimination by putting in a policy of discrimination.'' ``This bill simply prohibits racial discrimination in hiring, promotion, scholarships,'' he said. ``There is no justification to discriminate against someone who works hard, who is qualified for a job.'' The 39-year-old founder of the National Association for the Advancement of White People is running for U.S. Senate. The state GOP has endorsed another candidate.

DOC.HEAD: Strong Earthquake Rocks Northern Peruvian Coast
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with 13 killed. Picks up 4th graf pvs, `The quake...'
DOC.TEXT: A strong earthquake centered just offshore rattled northern Peru, killing at least 13 people and causing panic among residents of coastal cities, according to the Geophysical Institute and radio reports. The quake, measuring 5.8 on the Richter scale, was centered in the Pacific Ocean 110 miles southeast of Chiclayo, the Geophysical Institute said. Chiclayo is 410 miles northwest of Lima. The Civil Defense Authority reported 13 deaths _ five each in the neighboring towns of Rioja and Moyobamba and three in Cajamarca. All three towns are southeast of Chiclayo and within 150 miles. A civil defense spokesman did not give details of how the victims were killed. The spokesman, who did not give his name, said houses were destroyed in the quake. The quake was felt as far north as the coastal town of Talara, 170 miles northwest of Chiclayo, and as far east Cajamarca, an Andean city, the radio reports said. The Geophysical Institute said the quake shook Chiclayo with a force of between 3 and 4 points on the Richter scale of ground motion. A quake measuring 4 on the scale can cause moderate damage.

DOC.HEAD: AIDS Columnist Assaulted in Restaurant
DOC.TEXT: A man who writes a newspaper column about his daily struggles with AIDS was thrown through a restaurant window, police said. Clifford Moyers, who writes a ``Living with AIDS'' column in the Columbia Tribune each Sunday, was hospitalized in stable condition, police said. Moyers said he was discussing gay rights with friends at a restaurant early Sunday when men at a neighboring table ``started making `faggot' remarks against us.'' He was thrown through a plate-glass window in the foyer, police said. Two men were arrested and released on bond. A hearing was scheduled for today to decide whether to charge them, said Boone County prosecutor Joe Moseley.

DOC.HEAD: Preschool At Center of Molestation Case Razed
DOC.TEXT: A bulldozer razed the McMartin Pre-School, bringing to an end a frantic search by parents for secret tunnels and hidden chambers where they claim their children were molested and engaged in satanic rituals. Some of the parents held a news conference Tuesday to demand the state bar association investigate District Attorney Ira Reiner's prosecution of the case, the longest and costliest criminal trial in U.S. history. Raymond Buckey, 31, is the remaining defendant in a case dating to 1984 that once involved hundreds of child molestation allegations at the school. The six other defendants were acquitted or charges against them were dropped. Buckey is being retried on eight molestation counts unresolved by a jury that acquitted his mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey. In Manhattan Beach, construction crews Tuesday razed the single-story school building to make way for an office building. Private investigator Ted Gunderson, a former FBI agent hired by parents and others sympathetic to the alleged victims said he found ``disturbed dirt'' beneath the school. He said it indicated tunnels and secret chambers once existed. The district attorney's office conducted a similar excavation several years ago but found no evidence of tunnels. The parents' group, who previously have criticized Reiner for allowing the trial to stretch indefinitely without success, Tuesday attacked him for refusing to help their excavation. ``We shouldn't have to be paying for this,'' said JoAnne Farr, whose 12-year-old daughter attended the McMartin Pre-School. Reiner has defended the prosecution and said he continued the case out of the parents' desire for justice. Parent Marilyn Salas said courts in California should supply a child's advocate to help children through testimony and to instruct judges and juries on how children go through the process of remembering events. She said recanting and then recalling details was normal for children but considered unreliable by adults. Acquittals in the McMartin case came after some of the children repeatedly changed their stories. Salas said parents would like the state to change its statute of limitations to allow children time to grow up. The current statute gives people six years to bring charges in most crimes.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed, Gold Down
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was mixed in Europe late this morning and foreign currency dealers said trading was again dominated by cross-movements. Gold prices fell. ``People really don't know what to do,'' said an analyst in Milan, Italy. ``They go into the dollar even though they don't really believe in it because they don't believe in the other currencies either.'' However, the West German mark was again firming, helped by receding fears about the costs and consequences of monetary union with East Germany, traders said. After a burst of speculation earlier this week, the market no longer expects the Deutsche Bundesbank to tighten monetary policy at its Central Bank Council meeting on Thursday, they said. Traders said the market was waiting for several important U.S. economic indicators this week, including Friday's release of U.S. employment data for May. In Tokyo, the dollar rose 0.05 yen to a closing 150.75 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at 150.70 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Tuesday: _1.6725 West German marks, up from 1.6710 _1.4070 Swiss francs, down from 1.4080 _5.6380 French francs, up from 5.6280 _1.8820 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8810 _1,229.70 Italian lire, up from 1,228.25 _$1.1795 Canadian, down from $1.1815 In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.7055, more expensive for buyers than $1.6953 late Tuesday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $366.50 a troy ounce, down from $367.60 late Tuesday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $365.70 a troy ounce. In Zurich, the bid price was $365.85, down from $367.50 late Tuesday. Gold in Hong Kong fell $2.01 to close at a bid $367.47. Silver fell in London to a bid price of $5.14 a troy ounce, from Tuesday's $5.17.

DOC.HEAD: Rain Across Northeast; Tornadoes Threatened in Texas
DOC.TEXT: Rain fell in the Northeast, parts of the northern Plains and in the inland mountains of the Pacific Northwest early today. A tornado watch was in effect for portions of central and north-central Texas, with storms and flood-producing rain predicted around the south-central Plains. Temperatures dropped close to or below freezing overnight in parts of northern Michigan and Wisconsin and mountainous areas of Pennsylvania. Rain was expected to move into the Atlantic later today, leaving partially sunny skies in the Northeast. Scattered but heavy thunderstorms were expected in much of the coastal Northwest, especially Oregon. Three tornadoes touched down in Texas, one in New Mexico and one near Denver on Tuesday, the National Weather Service said. They caused no serious damage or injuries. Winds gusted to 90 mph at Hobart, Okla., damaging the roof of a medical center. Heavy rainfall Tuesday included more than 2 inches in the afternoon at Atlantic City, N.J. The nation's high for Tuesday was 104 degrees at Presidio, Texas.
