DOC.HEAD: Accu-Weatherman Raps the Weather
DOC.TEXT: Charts and graphs are mighty boring, weathermen can leave you snoring; but use some rap and fate be willin', you'll know real soon if it's hot or chillin'. To add some spunk to weather reports, a syndicated forecaster rapped to the music of Technotronic on Tuesday, and his word was heard from Boston to Kansas City. ``Somebody put me up to it last week,'' said Elliot Abrams of Accu-Weather Inc., which supplies local forecasts to radio stations across the country. ``They said the only thing they haven't heard me do was a rap version.'' Listeners in Pennsylvania and Ohio heard the version Tuesday. Stations in Boston, Cincinnati and Kansas City had rap reports Monday. ``Elliot has a lot of poetic lines in his system and they're trying to get out,'' said Mark Helms, executive editor at KYW-AM, an all-news station in Philadelphia. ``It's not something we would try every day.'' The forecast for Pennsylvania was: ``Now dudes are wondering what comes here next, so I'll be reading from this text; the word is going to bring no sorrow, 'cause rain that's here is gone tomorrow. ``It's raining. (Thump, thump, thump.) It's raining. ``Take this message to the street, tomorrow will not bring any heat; the clouds will leave but it stays cool, so wear a coat, don't be no fool.'' The translation: Rain Tuesday, then clearing and cooler. ``He sounded good with it. I was stomping my foot,'' said John Cigna, the morning host on KDKA-AM in Pittsburgh. The music was from Technotronic's ``Pump Up The Jam'' album.

DOC.HEAD: World's Newspapers Face Growing Classroom Competition from TV
DOC.TEXT: Newspaper publishers from Japan to Sweden are finding increased competition from TV for youthful attention and classroom time. Participants at a daylong international conference Tuesday focused on the role of newspapers inside and outside classrooms in promoting literacy and creating future newspaper readers. The gathering, which drew 165 participants from 20 nations, was a prelude to a three-day conference beginning today on the American Newspaper Publishers Association's 25-year-old ``Newspapers in Education'' program. The program is aimed at promoting use of newspapers in schools around the world to help youngsters develop lifelong reading habits. Several publishers, including those from countries with the highest literacy rates, said television is cutting into the reading habits of young people. In Japan, for example, ``disenchantment with newspapers is proceeding at a frightening pace,'' said Kazuo Ichiriki, chairman and owner of the newspaper Kahoku Shimpo, in Sendai. Japanese high school students spend an average of just six minutes a day reading newspapers and 20 percent of university students don't read newspapers daily, Ichiriki said. Japanese publishers began a Newspaper in Education program 4{ years ago, said Ichiriki, because people from that nation were spending just 30 minutes a day reading and two hours a day watching TV. About 85 percent of Japanese schools now make use of newspapers in classroom lessons. The programs are important ``not just to protect our self-interest but because the future of Japan could be adversely affected,'' he said. ``We are in a war in fighting for resources and recognitiion in schools,'' said Uzal H. Martz, Jr., president and publisher of the Pottsville (Pa.) Republican. In Sweden, newspaper readership among 9-to-14-year-olds has declined slightly recently after a decade of stability, largely due to increased television viewing, said Birgitta Pahlen, Newspapers in Education manager for the Swedish Newspaper Publishers Association in Stockholm.

DOC.HEAD: L.A. Council Outlaws Ammo Sales Before Holidays
DOC.TEXT: The City Council passed a measure outlawing ammunition sales during the weeks before the Fourth of July and New Year's Eve holidays, when thousands of bullets are fired into the air by revelers. Eight people were wounded last New Year's by slugs that plummeted back to the Earth, hitting the ground at near-muzzle velocity. A spokesman for a gun owners group said the problem should be addressed through education, not legislation. Banning ammunition sales is ``like trying to solve the problem of accidents at rush hour by prohibiting the sale of gasoline between 3 and 6 p.m.,'' said B.J. Johnson. ``It's going to be an inconvenience for the persons who love to stand in line just before New Year's Eve or the Fourth of July to buy ammunition for the purpose of discharging their weapons,'' said Councilman Richard Alatorre, who sponsored the measure. Mayor Tom Bradley is expected to sign it.

DOC.HEAD: Amnesty International Urges Release of Congo Priest and Others
DOC.TEXT: Amnesty International today urged the Congo to either try or release 26 political prisoners, including a Roman Catholic priest and an ex-president held in the West African state since 1987. The Rev. Joseph Ndinga's arrest reportedly stemmed from an order that church bells be sounded to warn that government forces were approaching to detain ex-President Joachim Yhomby-Opango, Amnesty said. Some of the detainees have been accused of plotting to overthrow the government of President Denis Sassou-Nguesso, who belongs to the Congo's Mbochi ethnic group. All the detainees are members of a rival group, the Kouyou. The London-based international human rights organization said it had received reports that some of the detainees have been severely beaten in jail and it has grave doubts that they would get a fair trial. The 26 prisoners, mostly civilians, were among some 70 members of the Kouyou group arrested in 1987 or 1988 in the Congo capital, Brazzaville, or in the northern town of Owando, where Ndinga has his parish, Amnesty said. All the others were released without being charged before the end of last year. ``Amnesty International believes that some of the remaining 26 are being held because of their nonviolent opposition to government policies or their family or ethnic connections with those accused of conspiring against the government,'' the organization said in a report. Yhomby-Opango was jailed for five years without trial after he was deposed in 1979. He was rearrested in 1987. Amnesty said it has adopted Ndinga as a ``prisoner of conscience.'' The organization has adopted or is investigating 3,180 such prisoners worldwide _ people it believes have never advocated violence and are held purely for their political or religious beliefs.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Set to Begin 13-Country Tour Despite Hospitalization
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela, recuperating from minor surgery, will probably remain hospitalized until the end of the week but is scheduled to begin a 13-country tour on Monday, officials said today. ``Mr. Mandela is up and about this morning and just fine,'' said Dr. Gordon Cohen, director of the private Park Lane Clinic. ``I don't expect him to go home before the weekend.'' The 71-year-old African National Congress leader was admitted to the clinic Sunday night for a complete physical examination that had been planned for some time, ANC officials said. During the examination, a minor operation was performed Monday, Cohen said. Neither the doctor nor Mandela's family would disclose the nature of the operation, but Cohen said it was not serious and had no long-term implications. He said Mandela was resting, recuperating and receiving selected visitors. Mandela's wife, Winnie, said after visiting her husband Tuesday night, ``If it wasn't for the crowds at his home, he would have been home already. But his doctors felt he should rest.'' According to a draft program released today by the ANC, Mandela will visit 13 countries in Europe, North America and Africa from June 4 to July 18. He will visit many of the European countries where South African President F.W. de Klerk met government leaders earlier this month. Mandela's U.S. schedule calls for a ticker-tape parade in New York City on June 20, an address to a joint session of Congress and the United Nations General Assembly, and visits to Atlanta, Miami, Detroit, Los Angeles and Oakland, Calif. Mandela has said he intends to counter de Klerk's message that reform of apartheid is underway in South Africa. Mandela is also to visit Botswana, France, Switzerland, West Germany, Itay, the Vatican, Canada, the United States, Ireland, the United Kingdom, Uganda, Ethiopia, Kenya and Mozambique. He is expected to meet government leaders in each country he visits. Mandela's trip to the United States was to have overlapped a visit there by de Klerk. But de Klerk postponed his visit on Tuesday because of controversy over his scheduled meeting with President Bush before Mandela.

DOC.HEAD: Fear and Chaos in Liberian Capital As Rebels Close In
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES thruout with attack on U.N. compound. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Government troops attacked a U.N. compound early today where members of rival tribes had taken shelter, killing a U.N. security guard and abducting at least 30 men, witnesses said. The incident came as frightened Liberian families packed their belongings and fled the capital amid rumors that rebels are closing in. Top ministers are apparently deserting President Samuel Doe to join the exodus. ``We don't want to be slaughtered,'' said a Liberian outside the embassy of neighboring Sierra Leone, where dozens sought visas Tuesday. Many shops and schools were closed. In recent days, fighting between government troops and the rebels moved to within 35 miles of Monrovia. Several hundred men, women and children of the Gio and Mano tribes had sought refuge at the U.N. compound amd were sleeping in the open there when about eight soldiers attacked at about 3:45 a.m., witnesses said on condition of anonymity. Jerry Samu, a U.N. security guard being treated for a bayonet wound in the back, told reporters the soldiers said they were looking for rebels, who get their support from the Gio and Mano tribes. When guards refused to open the gates of the compound, about 5 miles from the city center, soldiers jumped the 5-foot wall, rounded tribespeople up at gunpoint and made them strip, then loaded them naked into several military jeeps, the witnesses said. Reporters who visited the compound were show a bundle of clothing, shoes and sandals. Witnesses said it belonged to the abductees. A woman who escaped said the soldiers were from Doe's Krahn tribe. ``I heard them speaking Krahn,'' said the woman, who would not give her name. ``One soldier wanted to kill us women. Another said to let the women and children go. Then they let us go and took the men away.'' They said the vehicles headed down the road away from Monrovia in the direction of Scheiffelin army barracks. Joseph Leeway, chairman of a committee of refugees, gave U.N. officials a list of 27 missing people. ``These are just the names that we could get,'' he said. ``We think there were many more. It is a Krahn plot to eliminate Gios and Manos.'' The attack came a few days after U.N. Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar sent a special envoy to Liberia to discuss the war with Doe's government. On Sunday, Gios and Manos sought asylum at the U.S. Embassy, but were turned away and sent to the United Nations. Those seeking shelter say they want protection and safe conduct out of the country. Meanhwile, the Liberian Senate was meeting this morning to discuss a request from Doe for early elections in hopes of resolving the 5-month-old conflict. On Tuesday, Doe's beleaguered government broadcast appeals for the public to ``go about your normal business'' and refrain from panic. But government officials themselves appeared far from calm. Diplomats said Doe, who took power in a bloody 1980 coup, has been moving from one location to another during the night. His presidential jet and an army Cessna were kept ready at an airfield in the capital. Some government ministers have apparently already deserted Doe. According to news reports and Western officials who met government leaders, the portfolios for foreign affairs, internal affairs and information were being handled by acting ministers. Although no authoritative word was available on the latest fighting, reports broadcast Tuesday quoted rebel leader Charles Taylor as claiming his troops had been attacking soldiers around the country's main airport, an hour's drive from Monrovia. However, businessmen in the area said the airport remained open, and British Airways said its flights were still arriving. Doctors in the capital set up a committee and mapped out emergency plans to deal with casualties in case the city is attacked. The military appeared less prepared. Scheiffelin Barracks, which would be the last line of defense between the rebels' front line and Monrovia, appeared deserted but for a half dozen soldiers at a roadblock. Supermarkets in the capital did brisk business, although shortages were worsening and prices climbing. Photographic studios also did well as people lined up for passport photographs needed to apply for visas. At many other businesses, people did not bother to show up for work. ``What for? Everyone's waiting for the rebels,'' said one man. Many Monrovians said they not only fear the rebels but are also frightened by undisciplined government soldiers, who they say are often drunk or drugged. The national radio carried communiques Tuesday ordering soldiers not to harass civilians. But refugees said soldiers unable to halt the rebel advance sometimes had turned their wrath on civilians, raping, killing, looting and burning down homes as they retreated toward the capital.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Israelis Intercept Seaborne Guerrilla Attack; 4 Raiders Killed
DOC.TEXT: Palestinian guerrillas in small speedboats launched a two-pronged attack on Israeli beaches crowded for the Shavuot holiday today. Israeli soldiers killed four of the raiders and captured several more. No Israelis were reported killed or injured, but thousands were forced off beaches on the Festival of Weeks holiday which marks the giving of the Ten Commandments. Israel armed forces radio said the mother ship came from Libya and the guerrillas had planned to kill civilians in Tel Aviv.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Barry Claims Government Tried to Kill Him With Crack
DOC.NOTE: EDs: CORRECTS 4th graf, ``The prosecutors ... to make quote ``And then to try to kill me,'' not, ``And then they tried to kill me.''
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry acknowledges in a published interview that he smoked crack cocaine the night of his arrest, but he contends federal authorities tried to kill him by providing a potent dose. In an interview in today's editions of The Washington Post, the mayor also said he was confident he would not be convicted on drug and perjury charges because ``in this town all it takes is one juror saying, `I'm not going to convict Marion Barry.''' Barry said the FBI sting operation in January that led to his arrest was part of a long effort by federal authorities to discredit him. ``The prosecutors have been dipping and dabbling in the politics of Washington for a long time, and it's unconscionable,'' the mayor was quoted as saying. ``And then to try to kill me, it's unprecedented.'' Barry said the videotape that recorded the sting and his arrest ``is more damaging to the government than to me.'' ``It shows they bought the liquor, they did everything there. They had me ingest cocaine, crack cocaine, which could have killed me ... I could have been dead now, with 70, 80, 90 percent pure cocaine,'' the mayor said. Judy Smith, a spokeswoman for the U.S. attorney, was not at home to comment on Barry's remarks, her husband said late Tuesday night. On Tuesday, a federal judge set the stage for Barry's trial to begin next week when he tentatively refused to separate 14 criminal charges into two cases. Meanwhile, close advisers were telling Barry that he should abandon his re-election hopes and seek a deal with prosecutors, said top city officials who spoke on the condition they not be identified. But Barry's campaign staff director, Anita Bonds, denied a report that the mayor would consider making a deal with the government. Barry ``is getting himself ready for trial. Plea bargaining is not in the picture,'' Bonds said. U.S. District Court Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson said that by Thursday prosecutors must provide the defense with names of government witnesses and any previous statements those witnesses have made to investigators. Assistant U.S. Attorney Richard Roberts said prosecutors expect to have about 30 witnesses testify against Barry. Jury selection is scheduled to start Monday. The mayor is charged with three felony counts of perjury before a federal grand jury in connection with his alleged involvement with drugs. He also is accused of 10 misdemeanor counts of cocaine possession and one misdemeanor count of conspiracy. Barry's lawyers had asked to sever the conspiracy charge and five drug possession charges brought May 10. Defense attorneys argued that the government hadn't named Barry's alleged co-conspirators and hadn't given times and places for the new charges. Jackson said that splitting the charges into two trials would create problems. ``I don't know how we would pick a second jury'' that hadn't been exposed to testimony from the first trial, the judge said. Barry's lawyers said they would not try to use alcoholism as a defense. The defense could have called witnesses to suggest that Barry's drinking diminished his capacity to give complete and accurate answers to investigators. Using such a defense would have required Barry to turn over his medical records to the government. Barry was treated for substance abuse at clinics in Florida and South Carolina after his Jan. 18 arrest. As for Barry's political plans, the sources said that longtime Barry associates Ivanhoe Donaldson, Joseph Yeldell and Elijah Rogers all have urged the mayor not to seek re-election in recent days. The same men also have advised the mayor to enter plea negotiations, the sources said. When Barry left a weekend meeting with those former aides, the mayor ``was leaning against'' running for a fourth, four-year term, said sources familiar with the discussion. But sources also said that Barry was far less responsive to suggestions that he negotiate with prosecutors. Barry campaign officials picked up petitions Friday for a potential re-election bid, the first formal step to a possible candidacy.

DOC.HEAD: House Members' Outside Income: Speaking Fees, Free Trips, Wedding Gifts
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 6th graf, And winter ... to INSERT Madigan's home state
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Howard Coble won $600 in a pinball tournament. Rep. Silvio Conte sold $250 worth of hay. And Rep. Olympia Snowe got $9,914 in wedding gifts. Those nuggets are among the information, from the momentous to the trivial, spread on the public record Tuesday when the House released its annual financial disclosure forms. The forms illustrated how for most House members, the $89,500 salary the taxpayers paid them in 1989 was only part of their total income. And they showed how widespread is the practice not only of accepting speaking fees from special interests, but also of accepting expense-paid trips to make the speeches. For example, Rep. Robert Livingston, R-La., who is on the panel that doles out money for defense, made separate trips to California in February and December, collecting $6,000 each time from defense contractors. Rep. Billy Tauzin, D-La., reported 24 free trips during the year to speak to interest groups. Often the travel appears to be less than all work. The American Horse Council paid for two days in Lexington, Ky., for Rep. Toby Roth, R-Wis., and his wife, including tickets to the Kentucky Derby. And winter speaking trips often are to destinations warmer than Washington. Rep. Edward Madigan of Illinois and his wife made such forays to Rancho Mirage, Calif.; Orlando, Fla.; and Phoenix, Ariz. Two of the trips were to speak to groups affected by the House Agriculture Committee, on which Madigan is the senior GOP member. Rep. William Gray, D-Pa., got five days with his wife in Jamaica for a conference sponsored by the Aspen Institute, which also paid for a separate trip for Gray to Bermuda. Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., chairman of the tax-writing Ways and Means Committee, was the overall speaking fee champion, collecting $285,000 during the year. Members are allowed to keep only $26,850, so Rostenkowski gave the rest to charity. Others receiving top dollar for speaking were Gray, the No. 3 House leadership figure, who took in $164,098, and Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo., who claimed $160,517. Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., reported he received $32,000 in honoraria, and Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., reported $34,500. Republican Whip Newt Gingrich of Georgia collected $67,491, and handed over $29,304 to the Atlanta Zoo. As part of a bill raising their government salaries, House members agreed that 1990 will be the last year they will receive honoraria. Senators will allow themselves lower government salaries than House members after this year but will keep their speaking fees. Among the bits of financial trivia reported Tuesday: _Rep. Olympia Snowe, R-Maine, was married during the year to Maine Gov. John McKernan, and listed her wedding gifts, including a bicentennial bowl worth $310 from Sen. George Mitchell, a Democrat. According to the list, she could still use three place settings in her china pattern. She's got enough candlesticks. _Rep. Silvio Conte, R-Mass., put his total worth at $2.2 million. Along with stock dividends and rental income, he listed $250 from the sale of hay. _Rep. Howard Coble, a North Carolina Republican, said he won $600 in a congressional pinball tournament sponsored by the Amusement and Music Operators Association. He said he gave it to charity. _Rep. Alex McMillan, R-N.C., wasn't required to, but he kept track of the little goodies that flowed into his office from lobbyists and others in 1989. His list included books and T-shirts, pork rinds, bug spray, a golf umbrella and three pairs of socks. There was an IBM paperweight, a miniature television, candy, wine and two tickets to Washington Redskins football games. Total: $2,145.38. _Republican Rep. James Sensenbrenner of Wisconsin is a philatelist who values his stamp collection at $25,000. Rep. Bill Archer, R-Texas, collects coins and says his collection is worth more than $16,000. _Reps. Lynn Martin, R-Ill., and Barbara Kennelly, D-Conn., each received small Oriental rugs from Benazir Bhutto, the prime minister of Pakistan, who made a speech to a joint meeting of Congress last year. _Freshman Republican Rep. Porter M. Goss of Florida turns out to also be among the wealthiest members of Congress. His assets are valued at $5.4 million to $10.9 million or more, including stocks, bonds and real estate. In addition to their speaking fees and other honoraria, members of Congress and most other federal officials are required to disclose their assets, not including their homes; their investments, most liabilities and gifts. But the numbers usually are not precise because the forms require that values be listed only by broad category. For example, a multimillion-dollar holding is reported only as worth more than $250,000.

DOC.HEAD: Two Dead in Natural Gas Blast
DOC.TEXT: Emergency workers burned off gases still leaking today from a runaway oil and gas well that exploded, killing two workers and injuring four others. Most of about 200 people evacuated after the Tuesday afternoon series of explosions returned home Tuesday night. Those within a one-mile radius were told to wait until the well is capped, Jasper County civil defense director Joe Stringer said this morning. He said 60 to 65 people were kept away from their homes today. Crews cleared away debris from the collapsed rig in hopes the capping could be completed by afternoon. Officials used flares and flame throwers Tuesday to set fire to the escaping gas, said Jim Maher, director of the Mississippi Emergency Management Agency in Jackson. The fire was a precaution against poisonous hydrogen sulfide gas, which occurs naturally in some fields. A spokesman for Wild Well Control Inc. of Spring, Texas, said Tuesday night that no traces of hydrogen sulfide were detected. The well is owned by R & H Oil & Gas Inc., of Tickfaw, La. Officials there said the well was 20 years old and they were in the process of drilling to deeper levels for oil and gas. Alex Thomas, who lives within a half-mile of the rig, said he heard four successive explosions about 2 p.m. Others said there was another blast later in the afternoon. Roads were closed leading to the well, which is about 75 miles southeast of Jackson, as was a five-mile stretch of U.S. Highway 11. Salt water, sand and mud were seeping out of the well along with the gases, said Mississippi Emergency Management Agency spokesman Dusty Perkins. Before a pilot light was set to keep the gases burning, the silt occasionally extinguished the flame and allowed gases to escape into the air. Dwayne Kennedy, 24, died at the scene and Dudley Barnett, whose age was unavailable, died later Tuesday at the South Alabama Burn Center in Mobile, authorities said. Well workers Donnie Bolivar, 31 and Michael McCormick, 32, were listed in critical condition at the burn center. Charles Windham, 40, was listed in serious but stable condition at the Mississippi Firefighters Memorial Burn Center in Greenville. Another man was treated for minor injuries.

DOC.HEAD: Freed Hostage Sentenced To Jail In Child Custody Case
With PM-Hostages
DOC.TEXT: Jacqueline Valente, freed in Beirut in April after more than two years as a hostage, was sentenced to two months in prison today for taking two daughters from her ex-husband in defiance of a custody ruling. Prosecutors had requested only a one-month suspended sentence during the hearing in Toulon, but the presiding judge, Andre Fortin, decided to impose a harsher penalty. He said Ms. Valente, 32, had committed a ``premeditated kidnapping'' in 1983 and expressed irritation that she refused to answer questions about the mysterious circumstances of her own abduction. Ms. Valente was allowed to remain free pending an appeal and possible medical tests. She was sentenced to six months in prison, four of which were suspended. The case dates back to August 1983, when Ms. Valente refused to take her daughters _ Marie-Laure and Virginie _ back to their father after one of their regular visits with her. No word was heard about Ms. Valente and the girls until November 1987, when a Fatah-Revolutionary Council _ a Libyan-backed Palestinian group led by terrorist Abu Nidal _ declared it had taken them hostage, along with five Belgians also aboard a yacht in Mediterranean. The two girls were freed in 1988, and Ms. Valente was freed April 10, along with her Belgian companion, Fernand Houtekins, and their own daughter, Sophie-Liberte. Prior to the release, Sophie-Liberte had been widely described as a 2-year-old born in captivity. But relatives and others, after meeting her in person, agreed she was at least 4, leading to press speculation that the yacht was seized much earlier than previously reported. Newspapers also said that the hostages had been kept in Libya, despite their claims they were held in Lebanon, and had been abducted by the Libyan navy, not by Abu Nidal's group. Ms. Valente and Houtekins refused to discuss these matters in public, saying they did not want to jeopardize efforts to free Houtekins' four relatives still held. During the court proceedings, Ms. Valente's lack of substantive answers prompted the judge to accuse of her of ``bad faith.'' She frequently testified she did not remember details about her abduction. Fortin said Ms. Valente took the two girls out of France clandestinely, using false passports. ``And the children _ in all of this did you think of them?'' he asked. Ms. Valente's ex-husband, Pascal Betille, declined to comment on the judgment, saying he wanted to minimize any adverse effects on the two girls. He expressed hope that authorities would grant his request to cancel Ms. Valente's visiting rights.

DOC.HEAD: Hydrogen Leak Forces Launch Postponement
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to CORRECT time in 2nd graf, CLARIFY in grafs 3 and 9 that general area, and not exact site, of leaks was found last night. Picks up 10th graf, `Shuttles have...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto CSB2 of May 29
DOC.TEXT: NASA said it will be late tonight before engineers can pinpoint two hydrogen leaks that forced cancellation of today's launch of Columbia and its $150 million observatory. The planned 12:38 a.m. liftoff was scrubbed just six hours before launch after sensors detected rising levels of hydrogen gas in Columbia's engine compartment. The gas leak occurred while the shuttle's rocket propellant tank was being loaded with liquid hydrogen and liquid oxygen. NASA spokesman Bruce Buckingham said today that all of the propellant must be vented from Columbia's big external tank before workers can search for the exact point of the leaks in the maze of plumbing in the spacecraft's aft engine compartment. Buckingham said that it will be late tonight or early Thursday before NASA engineers know for certain what repairs are needed. Earlier, NASA spokeswoman Lisa Malone said it will be ``at least several days'' before another launch attempt. Columbia's seven astronauts were in their quarters several miles from the launch pad Tuesday when the hydrogen leaks were discovered. They were to have boarded the space shuttle about two hours before launch. Four of the astronauts left the Kennedy Space Center this morning to fly to their home base at the Johnson Space Center near Houston. The other three crewmen were to follow later today. Although concentrated hydrogen is highly explosive, Malone said Columbia ``was never in an unsafe position at any time.'' NASA engineers spent hours opening and closing valves and watching a network of sensors before finding the general area of the leaks about midnight. One was from a 17-inch valve in a pipe that carries fuel from the tank to the engines; the other was in ground equipment, Malone said. Shuttles have three main engines that burn a propellant of oxygen and hydrogen. The propellant, chilled to a liquid, is loaded into the external tank about five hours before launch. The tank actually contains two vessels, one for the oxygen and one for the hydrogen. The two elements are combined in the rocket engines, where they ignite and produce thrust. About 5 percent of the liquid hydrogen _ or nearly 20,000 gallons _ had been pumped into the external tank when the scrub was announced, officials said. Less than 25 percent of the liquid oxygen _ or 35,800 gallons _ had been loaded. Columbia is to be the first shuttle flight in five years devoted entirely to scientific research. Its payload, an observatory called Astro, will study invisible radiation streaming from distant stars and galaxies. The crew will work an intense, around-the-clock schedule of observations during the nine-day mission. The observatory includes three telescopes that detect ultraviolet radiation given off by stars and planets, and a fourth telescope that will detect X-rays. ``We humans look at the universe in visible light,'' said Lennard Fisk, chief NASA scientist. ``But the universe is, in fact, bright in many other kinds of radiation, and Astro will allow us to see the universe in ultraviolet light and in X-rays.'' The Astro instruments are in Columbia's cargo bay. They will be operated remotely by astronauts on board the shuttle and by signals from the ground. Columbia's crew includes four astronomers _ Jeffrey A. Hoffman, Robert A. R. Parker, Samuel T. Durrance and Ronald Parise. The commander is Vance D. Brand, the pilot Guy S. Gardner, the seventh crewman John M. Lounge. The astronauts also will give science instruction to 42 middle school students at two NASA centers. The teaching will be recorded on videotape and distributed nationwide. Columbia also has on board a ham radio, and the astronauts hope to talk to cosmonauts aboard the Soviet space station Mir and to operators of amateur radio stations around the world.

DOC.HEAD: Frugal Woman Lived Poor, Died Rich
DOC.TEXT: To those who knew the frugal ways of longtime newspaper reporter Virginia Wood Davis, she was the last person they thought would leave behind a personal fortune worth $2.5 million. ``We thought Virginia was poor _ she had everyone fooled,'' friend and executor of the will Jim Taylor said this week. ``I have cursed and fussed and just asked, `Why Virginia, why?''' Until shortly before she died of cancer on Feb. 1 at the age of 70, all she appeared to have was her two-bedroom house here, a few household and personal belongings, and her Ford truck. But before her death, Ms. Davis put about $2.1 million into certificates of deposit divided among her friends. In a will, she bequeathed 80 percent of the remaining $400,000 to the journalism department at her alma mater, Western Kentucky University. She also left a 194-page typewritten account of her life, her own eulogy, and instructions for her cremation. Ms. Davis had been a reporter and editor since 1943. She worked for 13 newspapers, including the Tampa Times, the Tampa Tribune, The St. Petersburg Times, and the Pasco News in Dade City. Her last job was with the McCreary Co. Record in Whitley City, Ky. At the end of her career, in the early 1980s, she earned $325 a week. Friends and relatives say she saved money and denied herself even the most basic comforts. Ms. Davis' clothing appeared to be second hand and most of the vehicles she drove had seen better days. To beat grocery store prices, Ms. Davis would go to nearby fields and pick unharvested leftovers. ``Virginia could not stand to see any of the vegetables go to waste, but some of the stuff was not any good,'' said friend Pauline McCall. ``She insisted on picking it.'' Ms. McCall believes her friend saved fanatically because she was afraid she would be faced with a major emergency and wouldn't be able to handle it. ``We just all accepted Virginia for who she was,'' Taylor said, ``our friend.''

DOC.HEAD: Pacific Salmon Saga: Soviets Net Japanese and North Koreans
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to RECAST lede and UPDATE with new numbers of Japanese aboard vessels, report they will be tried. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Soviet patrol boats have arrested 170 Japanese fishermen caught aboard North Korean vessels, and Moscow will reportedly put the men on trial for ``malicious poaching'' in Soviet waters. The incident in the North Pacific has proved potentially embarrassing to the Japanese government and revealed further strains in the alliance between North Korea and the Soviet Union. Foreign Ministry spokesman Taizo Watanabe said today the Japanese Embassy in Moscow began inquiries into the seizure about 10 days ago. Japan and North Korea have no diplomatic relations, but the unfolding saga has revealed a burgeoning relationship between the two countries' fishermen. Among the 202 crew members on the vessels were 170 Japanese. The officers and other crew members were North Koreans, Japanese authorities said. The Japanese coast guard said a Soviet naval vessel escorted eight of the seized fishing boats early today to port in the Soviet-held island of Shikotan in the Kuril chain, 45 miles off the northern Japanese island of Hokkaido. The Japan Broadcasting Corp. quoted a Soviet official in Moscow as saying the fishermen would be tried on Shikotan within five days. Such incidents usually are settled by fines or confiscation of fishing boats. Japan has an agreement to take 11,000 tons of Soviet salmon a year, and regularly fills that quota. It was not immediately clear what advantage the Japanese fishing company, Shoho Fisheries Co., gained from fishing under the North Korean flag. A fishery official, who demanded anonymity, said North Korea had no agreement to capture Soviet salmon in the North Pacific fishing waters. Soviet authorities have accused North Korea of ``malicious poaching'' of salmon that spawned in Soviet rivers, Kyodo News Service reported from Moscow. Agreement on a quota is required before a country's vessels can take salmon that originated in another country's rivers, said Tatsuaki Maeda, a Hokkaido University professor who specializes in fishing territories. ``It is still illegal to go fishing in Soviet territory under the North Korean flag, and in that sense, I don't understand the merit of sending disguised (Japanese) ships over there,'' Maeda said. He said, however, that it was possible the Japanese fishermen might have thought there would be no problem since North Korea and the Soviet Union are allies. Such a deal also could have given the North Koreans much-desired foreign currency, he said. Maeda said several countries have fished salmon on the high seas without quota agreements and have been overlooked for years, paying no penalties and angering fishermen from countries bound by quota agreements. The non-quota fishing countries include North and South Korea and Taiwan, he said. The North Korean-flagged ships were seized outside the 200-mile Soviet zone, the Foreign Ministry said. But under international rules, migratory fish such as salmon belong to the country where they were spawned. A spokesman for a Hokkaido fishing company, Kitajima Fisheries, said his company's vessel was one of those hired out through another Japanese company to provide ``technical guidance'' to the North Koreans. ``We are not poaching fish,'' said the spokesman, who refused to have his name used. The Soviet Embassy in Tokyo declined to comment today on the case.

DOC.HEAD: Brothers Can Visit, Say Couple Who Returned One Boy to Orphanage
DOC.TEXT: Two brothers separated when their adoptive parents returned one of them to an orphanage will be allowed to visit each other, the couple has decided after a legal battle. A tentative agreement reached Tuesday will allow the boys to visit weekly, with flexibility for scheduling conflicts or for the changing desires of the children. The older boy, identified only as 11-year-old Tony, was given up by a suburban Bellwood couple after six years about six months ago, when the couple said they could not form an emotional attachment to the boy. When the boy later asked to see his 8-year-old biological brother, who was still living with the couple, the couple declined, saying they were afraid the older boy was emotionally unstable and potentially violent. Tuesday's settlement appeared to end three months of court battles seeking to allow visitation between the two boys. An April court order allowed visits. But the couple went back to court to stop the visits, making new claims about the older boy's violent tendencies. Cook County Public Guardian Patrick Murphy, representing the older boy, countered with demands that the parents undergo psychological testing and provide depositions documenting the older boy's behavior. Murphy said Tuesday the latest demands were dropped and he was satisfied with the agreement. ``It's what we originally asked for,'' he said. Murphy, who had filed a lawsuit seeking $50,000 in emotional damages from the parents, also agreed to drop the lawsuit. ``The emotional harm was for refusal to grant visits,'' Murphy said. ``This negates that.'' The older boy, originally returned to the Hephzibah Children's Association Orphanage, is now living with a foster family in suburban Oak Park.

DOC.HEAD: Arab Leaders Call for Sanctions Against Nations Backing Israel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout with UPDATE with sanctions asked for country's backing Jerusalem as capital, support for PLO, Jordan, summit ends. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Arab leaders today called for political and economic sanctions against nations that recognize Jerusalem as the capital of Israel, and they denounced U.S. policies in the Middle East. They also promised to take action against countries that support the emigration of Soviet Jews to Israel and Israel's continued control of the occupied territories, a Palestine Liberation Organization spokesman said. However, the Arab leaders' statement at the end of their summit meeting did not contain the harsh condemnation of U.S. policy that Iraq, the PLO and other Arab hard-liners had demanded. Egypt and Saudi Arabia led the moderates. Winding up the three-day summit, the Arab leaders also pledged to take united action to ensure the world's 5 million Palestinians gain an independent state. They said Arab east Jerusalem should be its capital. In their closing communique today, the representatives of 16 Arab nations said, ``The summit affirmed that the Arab powers will take political and economic measures against whichever country recognizes Jerusalem as the capital of Israel.'' It did describe the measures or name nations to be targeted. ``The purpose for which the conference was convened has been realized,'' Yasser Abed-Rabbo, a member of the PLO's ruling execuive council, told reporters. He also said in an earlier session with reporters that the Arab leaders called for sanctions against countries that encourage the emigration of Soviet Jews to Israel and the Israeli occupation of Arab land. The summit hard-liners had demanded tough action to block the expected emigration of as many 750,000 Soviet Jews to Israel in the next few years. The influx began after U.S. officials tightened immigration quotas and Soviet authorities relaxed their rules for travel to Israel. The moderates have been arguing against using the Arabs' economic wealth as a political weapon, and they have been battling to avoid provoking tension amid the climate of uncertainty in the volatile Middle East. It was not clear whether the proposed sanctions would involve disrupting Arab oil exports, as Iraq has proposed. But most analysts believe it is unlikely that the Arab producers will impose an oil embargo as they did in 1973 to protest Western support for Israel in the October war of that year. Abed-Rabbo said the leaders agreed to form a committee of the foreign and economic ministers of the 21-member Arab League to draft within two months ``a detailed plan of action that links the political and economic relations with other countries to their policy toward the Arab cause.'' Abed-Rabbo leads the PLO delegation that has been negotiating with the United States in Tunis, Tunisia, since PLO chairman Yasser Arafat publicly renounced terrorism and recognized Israel's right to exist in November 1988. Israeli immigration officials said Sunday they expect up to 20,000 Soviet Jews a month, with 150,000 arriving in the Jewish state this year. The current influx of Soviet Jews to Israel is coming mainly through Hungary, Poland, Finland and Austria. The Arabs fear that the unrestricted immigration of large numbers of Soviet Jews to Israel will undermine peace efforts. They are also concerned that many of the Soviet Jews will be settled in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, forcing out hundreds of thousands of Palestinians. The occupied territories, seized by Israel in 1967, were designated an independent Palestinian state by the PLO's parliament-in-exile, the Palestine National Council, in 1988. The Israelis also seized Jerusalem in the 1967 war and later annexed it. In the closing statement, the Arab leaders condemned the U.S. House and Senate for supporting Israel's claim to Jerusalem as its ``eternal capital.'' They made the statement even though the United States officially recognizes Tel Aviv as Israel's capital. U.S. policy is that the status of Jerusalem must be negotiated. However, the summit stopped short of a threatened denunciation of the U.S. administration for supporting Israel and being biased against the Arabs. The summit also paid tribute to the 30-month-old Palestinian uprising in the Israeli-occupied lands. The leaders stressed the ``necessity of extending official and public assistance materially and politically until the ultimate objective is achieved, and the Palestinian state is created'' in the West Bank and Gaza.

DOC.HEAD: New Russian President Negotiates Coalition Government
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 6 grafs after 12th, `The session...' to UPDATE with details on negotiations over coalition government. Pickup 13th, `In Ottawa...'
DOC.TEXT: Boris N. Yeltsin, the newly elected president of the Russian republic, sat down with 130 legislators today to negotiate the makeup of a coalition government for the largest Soviet republic. Legislators said Yeltsin immediately came under pressure to retain as Russian prime minister Alexander Vlasov, a member of the Communist Party Politburo who had been Yeltsin's rival in Tuesday's balloting for president. Yeltsin opened today's meeting in a businesslike fashion and set only one limit, asking that one of his deputies be a woman, legislators said. Yeltsin, a frequent critic of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and his gradual reforms, was reported to have gained the last few votes he needed by offering to guarantee a place in his government for other factions. Although most of the Russian legislators are Communist Party members, they range from radical reformers like Yeltsin to hard-liners unhappy with even the more modest innovations of Gorbachev. Yeltsin won his new job Tuesday on the third ballot in the Russian Congress of People's Deputies. Yeltsin poses a substantial challenge to Gorbachev, both through his personal popularity and his demand that much authority be transferred from Gorbachev's central government to the republics. That would greatly increase his power, since Russia is the largest republic with 52 percent of the Soviet Union's 289 million people and three-quarters of its land. The strapping, white-haired Siberian said Tuesday he would seek reconciliation with Gorbachev and avoid confrontation with him as long as it would not hurt Russia's interests. He took the first step in that direction today, meeting in the ornate St. George's Hall of the Grand Kremlin Palace with representatives of each political faction and each ethnic region in the Russian Federation. Yeltsin asked for two to three nominations for each ministerial post in the Russian government. He said the candidates would be presented to the full Russian Congress for confirmation starting Thursday. It was not clear how such a system would lead to the delicate balance of political forces and personalities typical of a coalition government in the West. The session was closed to reporters after the first few minutes. Legislators said the talks were not aimed at parceling out portfolios in the Council of Ministers to specific political parties or factions. ``We don't really have hard political divisions like that right now,'' explained Igor Bratishev, an economist and deputy from Rostov-on-Don who participated in today's meeting with 130 legislators arrayed around a vast rectangle under the ornate vaulted ceiling of St. George's Hall. So far, 24 legislative groups have registered, including Yeltsin's own Democratic Russia and one called Communists of Russia. But the majority have a narrow focus, such as ecology, medical workers and legislators concerned with the problems of refugees. The so-called ``conciliation committee'' is seeking a consensus on candidates for prime minister and the three assistants to Yeltsin, said Vladimir Ivanov, a legislator from Buryatia near Lake Baikal in Siberia. ``People want Yeltsin to suggest Vlasov for prime minister,'' Ivanov said. The committee, representing each political group and each ethnic region in the Russian Federation, is examining candidates' personal qualifications and morale convictions, Bratishev said. In Ottawa, Canada, on Tuesday Gorbachev told reporters he was ``somewhat concerned'' about Yeltsin's victory but encouraged by the new Russian president's vow to settle divisions in the Congress and work with the Kremlin leadership. ``If, however, he is playing a political game, then we may be in for a difficult time,'' Gorbachev said. Gorbachev, who was to arrive in Washington today for a summit with President Bush, spent days watching the struggle for control of the Russian Congress. He even took the floor to speak against Yeltsin. Yeltsin and many Soviets said the election could help advance reforms in the Soviet Union. ``It may be a blessing in disguise,'' Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady Gerasimov told reporters at the United Nations in New York. ``Gorbachev has his critics from both the left and the right, and possibly it is better to have the election of a critic from the left.'' Vitaly Churkin, another Foreign Ministry spokesman, said Yeltsin's election ``might actually help Gorbachev because Gorbachev is for radical reform, and he needs more popular support for that.'' Gorbachev brought Yeltsin to Moscow to head the city's Communist Party, but the two men fell out over Yeltsin's public criticism in 1987 of the pace of reform and have been at odds ever since. As president of the Russian Congress, a newly created body that holds the Russian Federation's highest government authority, Yeltsin acts as chief executive of the republic. As the first president of a newly reorganized legislature, he will play a major role in shaping his powers and duties, which as yet are unclear.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Soviet Leader To Meet South Korean President Roh in San Francisco
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs., no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, in a bid to expand Soviet contacts with industrialized countries, will meet in San Francisco after the Washington summit with South Korean President Roh Tae-woo, U.S. officials said today. The two countries have no formal diplomatic relations and the Soviets maintain strong ties with North Korea, which conducted a brief and now-suspended dialogue with the pro-U.S. government in Seoul. Gorbachev is struggling to get a grip on the Soviet economy. As he left Moscow for talks beginning on Thursday with President Bush, the Soviet capital and other cities were experiencing panic buying in anticipation of broad price hikes pegged to adoption of a market system. U.S. officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the meeting with Roh would be held while Gorbachev was in San Francisco as part of his sight-seeing expedition after the summit talks concluded on Sunday. Gorbachev also is stopping in Minneapolis after his four days in Washington. The meeting is the most dramatic gesture by the Soviets toward South Korea, a foe for more than 40 years of Moscow-backed North Korea. Moscow is emerging as a promising trading partner for South Korea, and trade and other relations are expanding rapidly. In December 1989, the Soviet Union and South Korea opened ``consular departments'' in their trade offices in each other's capitals and began limited consular service. The arrangement restricts the functions of the departments and the qualifications of officials working there. The departments cannot fly national flags, and officials working there are denied normal diplomatic privileges. In March, South Korean news reports said the Soviet Union has proposed opening full consular ties with South Korea as a prelude to establishing formal diplomatic relations. The proposal from Soviet officials came as Kim Young-sam, leader of South Korea's governing party, visited Moscow and said his country's basic position is to move directly to formal diplomatic ties without going through an intermediary step, the news reports said. South Korean Foreign Minister Choi Ho-joong signed an agreement in Prague in March establishing formal diplomatic relations with Czechoslovakia. Last year, Poland and Hungary set up ties with South Korea. The Bush administration, which has been encouraging dialogue between the two Koreas, welcomed the return Monday by North Korea of the remains of five American servicemen killed in the Korean conflict. It was the first return of American remains in 36 years by North Korea. North Korea's ambassador to the United Nations, Ho Jong, said in an interview published Sunday that his country wants ``practical measures'' to improve U.S.-North Korean relations. The new North Korean attitude appeared to be linked to Moscow's previous efforts to expand contacts with South Korea. U.S. officials have said North Korea may also be concerned that the turmoil within the Soviet Union could threaten the large-scale assistance Moscow provides to that country.

DOC.HEAD: Eight Indicted on Charges of Enslaving 100 Mexicans
DOC.TEXT: A flower grower and seven other people are charged with enslaving more than 100 undocumented workers from Mexico and forcing them to work long hours at petty wages. Lured by promises of good pay, the Mexicans were smuggled into the United States, then kept at the 50-acre ranch until they could pay off a $435 smuggling fee, according to a federal grand jury indictment issued Tuesday. The ranch operators beat workers and threatened to alert immigration authorities if they tried to leave the compound, which was surrounded by a 7-foot fence, the indictment alleged. Ranch owner Edwin M. Ives, 54, and five other people face up to 52 years in prison and $2 million in fines if convicted of all 15 charges in the indictment, federal prosecutors said. The charges involve labor and civil rights violations and a federal anti-slavery statute, said Assistant U.S. Attorney Carol Gillam. Two ranch foremen, Naju Lnu and Paringer Singh, were named in a criminal complaint filed last month. ``This is a very significant case that involves very serious violations of people's human rights,'' Gillam said. The charges were developed based on allegations by former workers and ranch documents, Gillam said. Ives' attorney, Robert M. Talcott, has maintained that Ives was not aware of any abuses at his Griffith Ives Co. ranch in Somis, in Ventura County about 50 miles northwest of downtown Los Angeles. The indictment alleges that Ives supervised the ranch operation and on one occasion personally recruited an undocumented worker and told another that he could not leave the ranch until his smuggling fees were paid. Prosecutors maintain the workers toiled 16 hours a day for a fraction of the $4.25-per-hour minimum wage. In addition, workers were required to buy food and basic staples from a company store at inflated prices, the indictment said. ``As a result of these deductions, the alien workers often received net pay for over 160 hours of work in a 15-day period of less than $100, and in some cases, actually no pay, because the deductions exceeded the amount of the paycheck,'' the indictment said. One worker allegedly suffered permanent head and back injuries during a beating. Ives refused to pay for treatment in the United States and instead gave the worker $100 to help pay for treatment in Mexico, the indictment said. Also named in the indictment were Pedro Pinzon, 30, Rony Havive, 30, Alvaro Ruiz, 39, Josue David Pinzon, 23, and the alleged smuggler, Mauro Casares, 64.

DOC.HEAD: Super Spellers Compete for $26,550 in Cash Prizes
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New throughout with early eliminations; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: A 12-year-old Nevada girl misspelled the word ``irreducible'' today to become the first youngster eliminated from the 63rd annual National Spelling Bee. Aimee Baumann, a sixth grader at Carson Valley Middle School in Gardnerville, Nev., put an ``a'' instead of the second ``i'' in the word. Baumann, the 15th contestant, and seven others were eliminated in the first round of the two-day contest that drew a record 226 local champions from across the nation. The second round began with 218 youngsters. Cheryl Caprio, 14, of Grand Island, N.Y., misspelled ``thoracic,'' which is related to the area of the body between the neck and abdomen. The 51st contestant, Caprio incorrectly spelled the word as ``therassic.'' Lori Kensel, 11, of Tampa, Fla., misspelled ``opulent,'' while Taylor West, 11, of Altavista, Va., incorrectly spelled ``leasable.'' About an hour into the contest, Jessamyn Tracy, 13, Anchorage, Alaska, misspelled ``leopardess,'' a female leopard. Three others eliminated in the first round were Kristin Cashore, 13, Dallas, Pa.; Christa Logsdon, 12, New Washington, Ohio and Mark Weinsier, 13, of Plantation, Fla. Three researchers in November put together a list of 1,000 words for the bee, knowing that 903 words were needed before 14-year-old Scott Isaacs of Englewood, Colo., won the 1989 competition. A total of $26,550 in cash prizes will be awarded by program sponsor Scripps Howard. First prize includes $5,000, a trophy cup and special prizes from Encyclopaedia Britannica. The program also is sponsored by 208 daily, weekly and Sunday newspapers in 47 states. The 226 local champions, the most in the history of the program, include four-time contestant Kanika Bahl, 14, of Beavercreek, Ohio, and 9-year-old Erika Harrell of Muncie, Ind., the youngest. Bahl, an eighth-grader at Ankeney Junior High School, is the daughter of a physicist. She is the only speller to compete four times for the title. Five contestants will be competing for the third time, and 35 spellers are making their second appearance. While Harrell is the only fourth-grader competing, there were sixteen fifth-graders and 31 sixth-graders. The 9-year-old Harrell attends North View Elementary School in Muncie, Ind., and lists math and science as her favorite subjects. Both her parents are teachers. To get to the nation's capital this year, the 127 girls and 99 boys competed against nearly 9 million students at the local level, including Alaska and Hawaii, the District of Columbia, Guam, Mexico, Puerto Rico, the Virgin Islands and Department of Defense Schools. Last year 222 youngsters competed in the national bee. Co-champions were named in three of the previous 62 championships. Of the 65 champions 30 have been boys and 35 girls.

DOC.HEAD: Illinois NOW Recommends Simon Endorsement
DOC.TEXT: The president of the Illinois National Organization for Women says the group's endorsement of Sen. Paul Simon was only intended as a recommendation to the national NOW. On Tuesday, Illinois NOW President Kim Villanueva said the group's state political action committee ``enthusiastically and wholeheartedly endorses Paul Simon in his re-election campaign'' against Rep. Lynn Martin, R-Ill. But later Tuesday, national NOW President Molly Yard issued a statement saying, ``The only NOW group authorized to endorse in federal elections is the National NOW PAC.'' Informed of Yard's statement, Villanueva said Illinois NOW actually was recommending that NOW's national political action committee endorse Simon, a Democrat. ``I think that was an inaccuracy on my part,'' Villanueva said Tuesday. ``... I should have explained it further.'' Yard said the National NOW PAC would consider the Illinois group's recommendation for a Simon endorsement at its next meeting. The Senate race in Illinois has posed a problem for women's groups, who have to choose between a woman and a male longtime ally. The National Abortion Rights Action League on Tuesday endorsed Simon because of his strong pro-choice stand, spokeswoman Renee Cravens said. Simon is a co-sponsor of a bill that would write the U.S. Supreme Court's Roe vs. Wade decision into federal law. ``Paul Simon is a strong leader in the Senate, and we want to keep him there,'' Cravens said. At the NOW news conference, Simon said he has a stronger record on women's issues than Martin. ``Independent women's groups are looking at the record of both Lynn Martin and myself, and to my knowledge, every independent women's group that is taking a stand is either endorsing me or staying neutral,'' Simon said. Reacting to the Illinois NOW's recommended endorsement of Simon, Martin said: ``Throughout my years in Congress, I have never received the endorsement of Illinois NOW. ``If I must support mandated quotas, budget-busting amendments and other extreme positions, as NOW does, in order to win their endorsement, then hats off to Paul Simon.''

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Says California-Based Evangelist May Buy PTL Assets
DOC.TEXT: A California-based evangelist may be the next owner of the defunct PTL ministry's assets, including its satellite TV network and the Heritage USA Christian retreat, a newspaper reported today. The Charlotte (N.C.) Observer quoted unidentified sources as saying Morris Cerullo, 58, an Assemblies of God pastor who heads Worldwide Evangelism Inc., based in San Diego, has offered $52 million for PTL's remaining assets. Cerullo's organization also has branches in Great Britain, Canada, Israel and Zimbabwe. A woman who answered the phone at Cerullo's organization today said he was out of town and could not be reached for comment. ``He's not available and I have no one else who is available,'' said the woman, who declined to give her name. PTL bankruptcy trustee Dennis Shedd did not immediately return a call today. He has confirmed he is negotiating with a ``major party.'' Earlier this month, Shedd signed a contract to sell PTL's television network to evangelist Oral Roberts for $6 million unless someone else agreed to buy all the assets as a package deal. Shedd was scheduled to ask U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Thurmond Bishop on Thursday to approve the contract with Roberts. But he said that if he accepts the broader offer he will recommend throwing out the Roberts deal. The Home Box Office cable television network has asked the Bankruptcy Court in Columbia to block the sale to Roberts, saying it doubts he has the resources to make the $242,000 monthly lease payments for the use of a satellite controlled by HBO. In court papers, HBO cited the ``widely reported economic turmoil of the Oral Roberts organization.'' HBO also argued that Shedd had no right to transfer the satellite lease. PTL has been in bankruptcy proceedings since June 1987, two months after founder Jim Bakker resigned in the wake of a sex-and-money scandal involving church secretary Jessica Hahn. Bakker is serving a 45-year term in a federal prison at Rochester, Minn., on convictions last year of fraud and conspiracy. Although the PTL network still operates, carrying other evangelists' programs, Heritage USA has been closed since September. The 500-acre retreat near Fort Mill has five restaurants, a $10 million water park and two 500-room hotels, one of them unfinished. It also includes about 1,700 undeveloped acres. Last year, Toronto businessman Stephen Mernick failed to close on his $65 million deal to buy PTL because he could not get title insurance for the Heritage USA property. The land is part of an unsettled claim by the Catawba Indians, who have filed suit contending 144,000 acres of land was illegally sold to the state in 1840.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT ^Government and Rebels Sign Accord on Demobilization
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with accord signed. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The Contra rebels agreed today to resume disbanding after the new government promised to set aside rural areas where they can live, police themselves and join town councils. The agreement was contained in an accord drafted by the government and Contras on Tuesday night and signed early today. The Contras agreed to try to finish disbanding by June 10, a deadline set in a May 19 accord the government of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro. That accord broke down when the Contras stopped disarming, saying the Chamorro government was not fulfillig its commitments to provide food, housing, jobs and security for fighters who lay down their weapons. On Tuesday, the rebels and the government resumed talks, suspended Friday after the guerrillas announced an alleged massacre of 14 disbanded fighters. No evidence of any such attack has surfaced. ``There were misunderstandings, but misunderstandings are solved by talking, and what we want as Nicaraguans ... is peace and reconciliation,'' Chamorro said at a dawn news conference. Israel Galeano, the top Contra commander, said there was no reason the demobilization should not resume. The U.S.-backed rebels fought a nine-year war with the former leftist Sandinista government, which left office on April 25. Under the agreement announced late Tuesday but signed today, the rebels were to demobilize a ``considerable'' number of combatants in honor of Mother's Day, celebrated today in Nicaragua. They also said they would demobilize at least 100 rebels a day in each of the five security zones where the 13,000-strong guerrilla force has concentrated. If the deadline is to be met, however, the number of rebels disarming would have to be at least 200 daily in each zone. So far, fewer than 2,000 rebels have turned in their weapons to United Nations and Organization of American States missions supervising the demobilization process. In exchange for the demobilization, the government agreed to establish more than 20 rural development centers. Rebels, who are largely peasants, will also be given priority in recovering farmlands confiscated by the Sandinistas. Under the latest accord, a police force staffed by demobilized combatants will be created immediately. The force, which will police only development centers, will fall under the Goverment Ministry. The Contras were to be represented in the government of resettlement areas. They were also to be represented in government ministries that deal with the resettlements. In the development zones, the rebels are to integrate themselves back into peaceful civilian life. Most of the zones will be in war zones around the country, but the exact areas have not yet been determined.

DOC.HEAD: Negotiators Await Key Soviet Military Figure
With PM-Summit Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A key Soviet military figure was bound for Washington today in an 11th-hour drive to forge agreements on nuclear and conventional weapons for President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to announce at their summit meeting. The imminent arrival of Col. Gen. Labronislav Omelichev, first deputy on the Soviet defense ministry's general staff, was viewed by U.S. officials as a move by Moscow to settle some of the issues that have eluded U.S. and Soviet negotiators over four days of talks. Omelichev, a specialist on strategic nuclear weapons, was considered instrumental in the headway the two superpowers made in negotiations here in February. The current negotiations at the State Department got a pre-summit boost on Tuesday with an agreement on how to define tanks and armored personnel carriers. This will help in carrying out cutbacks in U.S. and Soviet arsenals in Europe and also in verifying compliance with an eventual arms reduction treaty. But U.S. officials, disclosing Omelichev's imminent arrival, said there was no breakthrough on a half-dozen strategic nuclear weapons issues. Nor, they said, have the negotiators settled on a definition of combat aircraft, the key sticking point in the conventional arms arena, despite the presence of the top Soviet negotiator, Oleg A. Grinevsky. There is ample agreement on enough strategic weapons reductions to allow Bush and Gorbachev to issue a declaration during the four-day summit, which begins on Thursday. Bush also intends to press the Soviet leader to revitalize the stalled negotiations between the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Warsaw Pact in Vienna, Austria, on reductions in troops and non-nuclear weapons. Apart from disagreement over combat aircraft _ the United States is pushing to limit planes that the Soviets insist are defensive in nature _ the Soviets are reluctant to complete the accord without assurances that a unified Germany would not pose a threat to peace in Europe. U.S. officials, insisting on anonymity, said Bush was prepared to tell the Soviet leader that the Western allies would consider limits on the new German army but only as part of a deal in which Soviet troops would be curbed within the Soviet Union.

Milwaukee's Roman Catholic Archbishop Rembert G. Weakland says the latest draft of the proposed U.S. bishops' pastoral letter on women is so unsatisfactorey that it might as well be abandoned. In a column in the archdiocesan weekly, Catholic Herald, he said the ``very credibility of the document comes into question'' in treating the issue of women's ordination. He said that the document emphasizes women's equality, but fails to deal with the traditional link between church authority and ordination, a role the document rejects for women, as does the pope. ``It is easy to see the bind the authors are in,'' Weakland wrote. However, since the letter avoids a basic question involved, he suggested dropping the effort.

Declaring ``Judaism in America cannot survive as a secularist faith,'' the newly elected president of the Rabbinical Assembly called for an intensified emphasis on religious education. ``We must rekindle the spirit of our people,'' said Rabbi Irwin Groner of Southfield, Mich., who heads an organization of 1,300 Conservative rabbis. ``Let us extend the teaching of our faith with a new sense of purpose. ...''

Work has begun on an interdenominational chapel at Camp David, the presidential retreat in the Maryland mountains near here. Kenneth H. Plummer Sr. of Chambersburg, Pa., a retired building contractor and United Methodist layman who launched the chapel project, says he hopes the work can be completed near Thanksgiving. ``It is a dream of mine,'' he says. He says about 90 percent of the $1 million goal for the project has been raised with most major contributions from Greek Orthodox and Roman Catholic churches. ``We are counting on faith that the additional $100,000 will come in this fall,'' he said. Support is being raised privately, except for a large bell provided by the U.S. Navy to be hung in the chapel's tower.

DOC.HEAD: Durenberger Discloses Vacations, Loans in Senate Financial Report
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs
DOC.TEXT: Sen. David Durenberger, one of seven senators facing ethics investigations, today disclosed that he accepted free lodging at the Florida condominium of a friend for each of the past three winters. Durenberger said he accepted the Christmastime gifts from Robert Windom, a former official in the Department of Health and Human Services. Aides said the gifts were inadvertently omitted from financial information material the Minnesota Republican filed in previous years. Durenberger disclosed the vacation gifts as he and 99 other senators made an annual public accounting of their finances. As in previous years, lawmakers reported accepting thousands of dollars in speaking fees to supplement their salary. Also disclosed were hundreds of trips, many abroad, for which lawmakers were reimbursed by special interests, political organizations and think tanks. The reports also show that Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell boosted his income by $50,000 last year by making paid speeches while Republican leader Bob Dole more than doubled that by accepting $108,900 in honoraria. Mitchell donated $11,000 of his honoraria to charity to keep within Senate standards for outside income while Dole gave away $73,150 to fall below the limits, the reports show. Dole reported assets worth considerably more than Mitchell's but the worth of both was dwarfed by the numerous multimillionaires in the Senate, workplace of a Rockefeller, Kennedy and the several heirs to family fortunes. Sen. John Heinz, R-Pa., for example, reported assets valued at $13.7 million to $17.25 million or higher, among them 45 holdings listed as being worth ``over $250,000.'' Large blocks of stock in the food giant H.J. Heinz Co. are a considerable chunk of his holdings. In addition to the vacation stays, Durenberger's amendments reported a $484,000 loan he had not previously disclosed in his Senate reports but which has been previously reported in the media. Durenberger reported accepting $62,185 in honoraria last year, and said he gave $26,400 to charity to meet Senate limits for keeping honoraria. Another of the members under investigation, California Democrat Alan Cranston, reported accepting no honoraria last year in keeping with a pledge he made in late 1988. Cranston's investment and real estate holdings supplemented his $89,500 Senate salary handsomely, and he also reported being reimbursed for trips to Jamaica, Switzerland and Yugoslavia. Mitchell's report shows him to be a man of relatively modest assets. He kept $39,000 of his honoraria to supplement his $99,500 annual Senate salary and received a $5,000 award from Bowdoin College in his native Maine. Besides his Washington home, which Mitchell said was purchsed in late 1988 for $320,000, his only reported assets were bank accounts worth from $17,005 to $55,000. He said he had no liabilities. Mitchel reported reimbursements for 15 trips, all within the United States and several to speak to Democratic Party groups. He also was paid $22,500 in book royalties. Dole reported assets worth $345,297 to $809,277 and no liabilities. The value of the assets cannot be determined precisely because members are required to list their worth only in ranges. For example, an asset worth $10,000 would be listed only as being worth $5,001 to $15,000 and a $1 million asset as being worth ``over $250,000.'' His $108,900 in 1989 honoraria was up from $67,750 in 1988, when he gave $31,750 to charity. This is the last year House member can accept honoraria, but the Senate has not taken any action to end the controversial practice. House members were allowed to keep honoraria up to 30 percent of their salary, or $26,850 for most members. Senators can keep up to 40 percent of their salary, $35,800 for most members and $39,800 for members of the leadership. As majority whip, Cranston falls third in the Democratic leadership, behind Mitchell and Senate President Pro Tempore Robert Byrd. Cranston, one of the so-called ``Keating Five'' under investigation for intervening with regulators on behalf of California savings and loan owner Charles Keating, announced in late 1988 he no longer would accept honoraria. The California Democrat reported 1989 income of $330,797 to $571,485, supplementing his $89,500 Senate salary with rent, interest and dividends from investments and real estate holdings. He also received $18,253 in Social Security benefits. Also among his assets was a blind trust valued at ``over $250,000.'' Byrd, on the other hand, reported 1989 income of $132,203 to $154,693, supplementing his $99,500 Senate salary with $19,500 in honoraria. He also received $120.80 in royalties for a country music record on which he plays fiddle and said he accepted a rocking chair valued at $465 from the West Virginia Forestry Association. Dole's top deputy, Republican Whip Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming, reported 1989 income of $229,900 to $248,100. He said he accepted $90,600 and gave $55,100 of that total to charity. Simpson was paid $40,000 to do the ``Face Off'' radio program he conducts with Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass.

Here are excerpts from recent editorials in newspapers in the United States and abroad. May 29 The Clarion-Ledger, Jackson, Miss., on the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission: A recent U.S. Supreme Court decision should slap some sense into Congress about the Frankenstein monster of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission. ... Voting 9-0, the court struck down California regulations aimed at assuring survival of trout in the American River and Rock Creek, a small tributary. The court said the Federal Power Act preempts California's stream-flow regulations. So, with one fell swoop of the pen, California, its citizens and its elected representatives have no say over their wildlife or streams or the environment they live in if FERC has an interest in the matter. That cannot possibly be the intent of Congress. That FERC can decide the fate of fish and wildlife in a state without the citizens' input runs counter to the most basic notions of civil government. That's fascism. Congress must rein in this agency-run-amok.

May 28 Los Angeles Times on clean air bills: Two versions of a federal Clean Air Act now heading for conference on Capitol Hill should make many Americans breathe easier. ... (F)or now, and for (President) Bush, the 401-20 House vote for the bill _ with his marks all over it _ is the tidiest victory of his presidency. ... And Bush got everything he asked for, and then some. Both the Senate and House approved the pioneering program to control acid rain that is killing lakes and forests in Canada and the northeastern United States. ... Both bills call for 10-million-ton reductions in sulfur dioxide emissions. Both versions went along with the Bush idea to give utilities that make an extra effort to cut emissions pollution credits that they could save for future use or sell to other companies. And toxic emissions from chemical plants and other polluters would fall by as much as 70 percent to 90 percent. ... In one example of what makes the House bill by far the preferable one, the Senate version dictates precisely how crude oil must be refined to make cleaner gasoline. (It seems when politicians start practicing chemistry, strange things happen.) The Senate formula would, in effect, make carbon-monoxide-reducing ethanol, most commonly make from corn, the only gasoline additive that could raise its oxygen content to stipulated levels. This might make senators from corn states more interested in clean air. But ethanol also increases emissions of the basic ingredients of smog, and for Southern California and many other urban areas, that is bad. ... The bills could cost American industry and consumers $20 billion a year, so writing the Clean Air Act was a bruising process. And it's not over yet. But at this point, it looks like winners all around.

May 25 The Hudson Dispatch, Union City, N.J., on Wellesley students protesting Barbara Bush as their commencement speaker: A group of seniors at Wellesley College gave the nation's newspaper columnists an early Christmas a few weeks ago by expressing their patrician outrage at the selection of Barbara Bush as commencement speaker at the Massachusetts school. They petitioned school officials to boot the first lady off the platform arousing a furious chorus of howls from the columnists. How exactly did they do it? They said this: ``Wellesley teaches us that we will be rewarded on the basis of our own merit, not that of a spouse. To honor Barbara Bush as a commencement speaker is to honor a woman who has gained recognition through the achievements of her husband, which contradicts what we have been taught over the last four years at Wellesley.'' The customary response to this irritating sneer has been to point out that Mrs. Bush left Smith College to become a wife and mother and a homemaker, and if that isn't what America's all about, by golly, then what is? If the Wellesley seniors are saying they'd never stoop so low to marry a millionaire and don't want to listen to a lady who did, well, fine. They're certainly more intellectually consistent than their college's administration. If they're saying that they wish to consider only the sort of futures and realities in which they, not husbands, will be at center stage, well, that's their prerogative.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: their prerogative.
DOC.TEXT: May 26 Foster's Daily Democrat, Dover, N.H., on the estimated $300 billion cost of the savings and loan bailout: How much is $300 billion? Look at it with all its 11 zeros: $300,000,000,000. Counting once a second, it would take you 9,520 years to count to 300 billion. About 9,500 years ago human beings were just discovering the wheel. ... Federal bank regulators have sent 20 fraud cases to the Justice Department for prosecution in recent weeks and they are preparing 100 more. ...
