Now if only those key members of Congress and the Reagan administration who let the S&L mess fester for so long could be put on trial too. They share blame with unscrupulous bankers for this unprecedented fiasco.

May 24 Shawano (Wis.) Evening Leader on standards for door openers: It's time for the federal government to impose standards on automatic garage door openers. Too many of these openers are killing and maiming youngsters throughout the United States. Currently, manufacturers of garage door openers are not required to meet Underwriter Laboratory standards for automatic reverses. Such mechanisms automatically reverse the downward motion of garage doors if something impedes their progress. Most of the time, the item struck by the closing garage door is a bike or a ball or some other object. In increasingly alarming numbers, however, children are being caught under the doors. When functional reverses are in place, the garage door pops right back up and little damage is done. Yet some experts think that up to 50 percent _ or half of all automatic garage doors installed in the U.S. today _ do not have reverses, or have reverses that for one reason or another are not in working condition. As more homeowners install automatic garage door openers, the danger to children increases. To deal with this growing problem and prevent future harm, we believe the U.S. Products Safety Commission should mandate standards for reversing mechanisms on all new automatic garage door openers.

May 27 The Providence (R.I.) Journal-Bulletin on Radio Free Europe: There's been some talk in Washington lately about closing Radio Free Europe. The notion behind this is that Eastern and Central Europe's democratic revolutions are so well entrenched that the need for an honest and pro-democratic voice to beam news about national and regional events into the area is no longer necessary. That's ridiculous. Soviet troops still reside in much of the region. Indeed, it was recently disclosed that the modest withdrawal of Soviet troops from East Germany that had been under way has been suspended _ without explanation. At the same time, Soviets have made contradictory remarks about arms-control negotiations. And perhaps most ominous is that communist bureaucrats of totalitarian and conspiratorial bent are still comfortably in place throughout Eastern Europe. Many are doing what they can to sabotage the political and economic reforms being attempted by the democrats who are officially in charge of these bureaucracies. ... The Voice of America, chartered to tell the story of the United States abroad, does a fine job, but it isn't specifically organized to promote democracy in Eastern and Central Europe. For that task, the region still needs Radio Free Europe, which has been a messenger of hope to millions of people.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: of people.
DOC.TEXT: May 29 Le Monde, Paris, on Colombia's elections: Colombia has taken a gamble. This little country, despite decades of blind violence, has decided to remain faithful to its democratic principles. ... Especially for the drug traffickers, Cesar Gaviria's victory is a challenge. A deadly challenge, because alone among the candidates, Cesar Gaviria promised a ``battle without mercy.'' The others spoke of ``dialogue'' or even of ending the ``caprices of the United States,'' meaning the extradition of the traffickers. ... The government cannot be ready to do battle against this redoubtable adversary when Colombians' sacrifices are rendered futile by a lack of international solidarity. It was no accident that the first appeal of the future president was to Washington: ``What can we do when the (drug) consuming countries do nothing?''

May 25 Mainichi Shimbun, Tokyo, on statements about Korea by Emperor Akihito and Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu: The apology clarified it was Japan that had caused the unfortunate past, and a feeling of pain and regret for hurting Korean people was indicated as the emperor's honest feeling. Behind the prime minister's comments is an apology from each Japanese national ... and a severe sense of self-criticism. ... However, it is not a problem that only words can solve. Japan should have 120 percent understanding of the past, and promise the establishment of fruitful partnership between Japan and South Korea. We need to realize that we only reached the starting point where we should begin solving the core problems left between Japan and South Korea. ... It is natural for Koreans to think that Japan has never felt pains of victims or guilt as the assailant because Japan has been lazily delaying solution while showing no sincere efforts. ... The important thing is to have a firm recognition of history and an effort to pass it to the next generation, which is largely missing here. ... We need education to have people learn true history.

May 29 The Nation, Bangkok, Thailand, on Saturday's parliamentary election in Burma: While there was widespread pessimism at first that the election would be far from ``free and fair'' ... early reports ... indicated minimal intimidation or vote rigging in the polls that could leave the National League for Democracy of Aung San Suu Kyi with a majority. This is as much a resounding victory for the NLD as a damning testimony against the military dictatorship of Gen. Saw Maung which seized power in a coup in September 1988 that left thousands of pro-democracy demonstrators dead. Loudly and clearly the people in Burma are airing their desire to end the choking status quo. They have done this legally through the ballot. Now that the military has allowed the world to see what the majority of people really desire they have placed themselves in the open. The ball now is in the court of the military. After so many years in power the military apparatus is in a consolidated position of privilege. Even if they want to give up their rule they will want a guarantee that they would not be left out in the cold. The NLD landslide triumph and the euphoria of the people should not necessarily be considered the end of the repressive period. It is in fact the beginning of the ordeal over how Burma will develop so that the people and the military can coexist peacefully without fear or repression.

May 30 The Indian Express, New Delhi, on the Burma election: The people of (Burma) have repudiated the ruling military junta in no uncertain terms in the just-concluded elections. But the establishment soon of a genuine democratic set-up for which they have given a resounding vote cannot still be taken for granted. In 1988, the popular uprising was drowned in blood, with the champion of Burmese socialism, Gen. Ne Win, stepping down only to pull the wool over the people and enable another military dictator, Gen. Saw Maung, to continue to rule with an iron hand. Now, with the National League for Democracy led by Ms. Aung San Suu Kyi heading for a two-thirds majority in a new 485-member legislature, as conceded even by the hated miliitary rulers, grave doubts about their true intentions have arisen. If the game of these tyrants-in-a-democratic-guise is to be foiled, the world powers, in particular, the United States and Japan, must put economic diplomacy to good effect. A heartening development is that the U.S. Senate has recently voted 92-0 to ban all imports from (Burma). ... It is to be hoped that the U.S. House of Representatives, too, will likewise exert presure on the Bush administration to ensure that the people are not denied the fruits of their clear-cut verdict.
DOC.HEAD: End Editorial Rdp
Suspected Arson Fire Kills Five Children, One Adult
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with fifth child dead, IDs.
DOC.TEXT: An arson fire early today was confined to one room of an apartment, but it killed five children and an adult, city fire officials said. ``It was definitely a set fire,'' said fire department spokesman Tom Sheppard. The fire apparently started on a mattress in the living room on the second floor of the two-story apartment building, said First District Deputy Fire Chief William Nolan. The fire was confined to that room, but that was where all the bodies were found, he said. Nolan said a gasoline can was found in the apartment's dining room and that a preliminary investigation found evidence of gasoline in the living room and dining room. The victims were Hermino Elricalde, 36, and his daughters, Greta, 16, and Laura, 15, said Sheppard. Also dead were Vernice Garcia, 10; Clara Garcia, 9; and Joel Garcia, 8, believed to be the children of Elricalde's girlfriend, who was not home at the time of the fire, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Three Killed in Bus Crash; Rescue Delayed by Snakes
DOC.TEXT: A bus whose passengers included a snake charmer fell into a ditch, and dozens of people lay trapped for hours because rescuers feared the snakes had escaped from their basket, a newspaper said Wednesday. The snake charmer was among the three fatalities in the accident Tuesday outside Dhaka, the Bengali language newspaper Ittefaq said. It said the unidentified snake charmer was carrying at least six snakes in his basket. ``The passengers were groaning inside the bus ... But fear of snakes prevented the people from rescuing them,'' Ittefaq quoted villagers as saying. After about three hours, another snake charmer was called from a neighboring village. He caught three snakes and said the others had fled, the newspaper said. The bus, which was coming to Dhaka, collided head-on with another bus and fell into a ditch filled with water, according to the report.

DOC.HEAD: Coach Jailed for Nine Months After Punching Referee
DOC.TEXT: A rugby coach who punched a referee during a match has been jailed for nine months after pleading guilty to assault, the Fiji Times reported Wednesday. The newspaper said the magistrate's court was told that coach Jone Baravilala hit the referee after the game was awarded to the other team when a fight broke out between players. The court was told that Baravilala admitted to six previous convictions, including two of assault, and was serving a nine-month suspended sentence when he committed the most recent offense.

DOC.HEAD: Skinheads Injure Three Youths
DOC.TEXT: A group of neo-Nazi skinheads with baseball bats stormed a streetcar in the East German city of Magdeburg and attacked three youths, the government news agency ADN said Tuesday. The three youths, described as ``punk rockers,'' were severely injured in the attack by rival skinheads late Monday night, ADN said. Another group of skinheads, driving cars with West German license plates, later attacked a group of ``punk'' youths at an intersection, it said. Magdeburg police detective Georg Knittel said the incidents were the latest in a ``small war'' between punk rockers and gangs of neo-fascist skinheads, who he said come from both East and West Germany, ADN reported. Magdeburg is near the West German border.

DOC.HEAD: Passenger Railway Fares to Double Friday
DOC.TEXT: The state-run railroad, recently hit by a crippling strike, will double passenger fares Friday, the official PAP news agency reported. The fare increases were planned before the labor strife broke out May 20, railway spokesman Tadeusz Bronowski told PAP on Wednesday. He said the increases are due to higher fuel and operating costs, and the cut in state subsidies under the government's economic reform program. Typical of Poland's state industries, the railroad had used large government subsidies to keep fares unrealistically low. For example, a first-class ticket for the three-hour express train ride from Warsaw to Gdansk has cost about $3. Wildcat strikers snarled freight and passenger service to northwest Poland from May 20 until Monday, when Solidarity leader Lech Walesa persuaded the workers to return to work and give the government until June 13 to consider their demands for higher pay.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Ship Rescues 101 Vietnamese in South China Sea
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. Navy ship rescued 101 Vietnamese refugees from two boats in the South China Sea after spotting smoke signals and a white flag flying from one of the vessels, a Navy spokesman said Wednesday. The Beaufort, a Navy salvage and rescue vessel based in Sasebo, Japan, was en route to the Philippines when it came upon the wooden boats last week, said Robert Coble, a spokesman from the Subic Bay Naval Base in the Philippines. The Beaufort arrived at Subic on Wednesday morning, and base authorities were negotiating with Philippine and U.N. refugee officials to allow the refugees to disembark, Coble said. Coble said the Beaufort's captain picked up the refugees after concluding that both wooden boats were ``unseaworthy and did not have much provisions.'' He said the Beaufort's crew on May 24 found a 21-foot wooden boat with 24 people, including nine children, after spotting smoke signals and a white flag on the vessel. The refugees had no water, a little rice, and had been at sea for seven days after sailing from Tien Giang through the Mekong River and into the South China Sea, Coble said. The refugees said pirates had robbed them of money and jewelry, he added. Two days later, the Beaufort found a slightly larger boat with 77 people on board. Philippine officials said many of the refugees were suffering from dehydration and malnutrition.

DOC.HEAD: Naval Academy To Expel Middies Found Guilty of Physical Abuse
DOC.TEXT: Following weeks of intense congressional and media attention, the U.S. Naval Academy has announced new regulations to halt physical and mental abuse of freshmen. Under the new rules, any midshipmen found guilty of physical abuse of freshmen, or plebes, during indoctrination could be expelled, even if the act falls short of what is considered hazing. Tuesday's order follows weeks of intense attention and calls for investigations into reports of student abuse, including that of 19-year-old Gwen Marie Dreyer of Encinitas, Calif. She resigned from the academy last month after male midshipmen handcuffed her to a urinal, taunted and photographed her. Tuesday's general order by the academy superintendent, Rear Adm. Virgil L. Hill Jr., also calls for increased demerits and restrictions for forcing a fellow upperclassman to engage in horseplay. ``Up to now the maximum punishment would be restriction and demerits. What we've done is elevate violation rules governing physical contact to a dismissal,'' said Lt. Cmdr. Mark Van Dyke, academy spokesman. ``We try very hard to prevent violations of human rights, but we also accept the fact that mistakes will happen. ``These actions are being taken to underscore the determination that the superintendent, and the other academy leadership have to keep these problems in check.'' The order came one day after 35 people, organized by the Anne Arundel County chapter of the National Organization for Women, demonstrated outside the academy during the annual graduation ball. The protesters called for tougher punishment for behavior that amounts to ``acts of terrorism,'' specifically complaining that the middies who handcuffed Dreyer were only reprimanded. Van Dyke declined to say if the midshipmen who taunted Dreyer would have been dismissed under the new rules, saying the case is still under review. He also declined to say if their dismissal was still a possibility. Van Dyke noted that hazing, which has been prohibited for almost 100 years, already carries the penalty of expulsion. The freshmen indoctrination manual defines hazing as any ``unauthorized assumption of authority by a midshipman,'' such as an older student subjecting a freshman to cruelty, undue humiliation, hardship or ``oppression or the deprivation or abridgement of any right.'' Plebe indoctrination is part of the required training of a first-year student, Van Dyke said. It includes, for example, ``chopping,'' in which a plebe must walk double time, can't talk and must make a 90-degree turn at every corner. ``It's designed to apply stress and teach them to obey strict orders. But that's not hazing,'' Van Dyke said. ``If you had someone chopping through the halls and the plebe is grabbed by a midshipman, that's a dismissal offense.'' Women have been admitted to the nation's service academies since 1976. At Annapolis, they account for a little more than 10 percent of this year's graduating class of about 1,000. At the U.S. Air Force Academy in Colorado, 100 women are among the 971 graduates. There are 89 women in this year's graduating class of about 900 at the U.S. Military Academy at West Point, N.Y.

DOC.HEAD: New Orleans, New York Finalists for 1992 Democratic Convention
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with Brown commenting on finalists; quotes. Picks up 7th graf pvs `Some senior ...'
DOC.TEXT: Without a presidential candidate in sight, Democrats leapt ahead today with 1992 convention preparations by designating New Orleans and New York as finalists in the competition for the party's nominating session. ``This is a wide-open process,'' party chairman Ronald H. Brown said after receiving the recommendation from the convention site selection committee. The convention is scheduled to run from July 16 through July 19, 1992. Brown said he would visit both cities within the next week or two and expected ``some tough negotiations'' before making the final decision. At this point, Brown said, ``I don't have a personal choice.'' He said he doesn't believe the location of the convention has any particular political significance in a presidential campaign. ``It is not where the convention is held, but what is said from the podium,'' Brown said. The Republicans are receiving bids for their 1992 convention and plan to announce their decision in January. While the GOP will visit potential sites and weigh their bids, President Bush could make those efforts academic if he decides to express a choice. New Orleans was the site of the 1988 GOP convention that nominated Bush for president. The 1976 Democratic convention that nominated Jimmy Carter, the last Democrat to win a national election, was held in New York. Some senior Democrats have recently expressed concern about the lack of activity by potential 1992 presidential candidates. So far no Democrat is expressing any interest in challenging Bush for re-election and none is engaging in the sort of covert early maneuvering usually picked up at this early stage. ``Normally at this stage of the game you would have least one or two out making all the body language, doing the fund-raising, denying they were a candidate,'' said former party chairman John White. The 46-member site-selection committee visited four cities this year, including the two finalists, Houston and Cleveland. The Cleveland presentation impressed the panel with its enthusiasm. The city's convention hall in suburban Brook Park was described as the equal or better than the facilities in competing cities. But Cleveland's shortage of nearby hotel rooms was a fatal handicap. ``I think we were taken seriously this time which gives us a real chance in '96,'' said Ohio Democratic Party chairman James Ruvolo. The Democrats want unlimited access to the hall for six weeks before the opening of the convention and a commitment of $15 million in support services to include police protection and rental of the facility. The convention is expected to attract 35,000 people and millions of dollars in economic benefits. Atlanta was estimated to have gained about $70 million from the 1988 convention that nominated Michael Dukakis for president. New York made the strongest financial bid, offering the Democrats $22 million in cash and services, plus an enormous potential for additional fund-raising during the convention. But Madison Square Garden was regarded by many as too small for the more than 5,000 delegates and alternates and thousands more onlookers. City officials offered a plan to provide additional seating, but several selection committee members were skeptical. In addition, the media work space in New York would be in the Javits Center, half a mile away from the convention site. New Orleans had trouble meeting the financial requirements and is in a state that is a stronghold of the anti-abortion movement, placing it at odds with the prevailing sentiment of the Democratic Party. But its Superdome offered more than enough space for the delegates plus the thousands of news media needing room to work. Both cities were able to guarantee plenty of hotel rooms and are home to some of the nation's best-known restaurants. Cities that have expressed interest to the Republicans include Houston, the city Bush calls his hometown; Kansas City, Mo.; St. Petersburg, Fla.; and Cleveland. New York and New Orleans also are regarded as potential bidders. Atlanta expressed early interest but has since dropped out.

DOC.HEAD: Two Girls Missing in Ohio Flooding; N.C. Waterspout Picks Up Man
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 5-7, `Hail pelted...', with six grafs to UPDATE with trailer homes destroyed, tornadoes in Colorado, Ohio governor to declare disaster areas; CORRECTS name of missing Ohio girl to Carrie sted Karen. Picks up 8th graf, `Rescuers in ....'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos CO1, CO2
DOC.TEXT: A search resumed today for two teen-age girls apparently swept away while wading in a rain-swollen creek in southern Ohio, and thunderstorms rumbled across north Texas, triggering tornadoes, hail and flash flooding. In North Carolina, a waterspout spawned by heavy thunderstorms came ashore at a campground Tuesday, lifting a man and his tent high into the air and dumping him in a marsh 70 feet away, officials said. ``He said it was just like Dorothy and `The Wizard of Oz,''' said Diana Gardner, spokeswoman for Albemarle Hospital in Elizabeth City, where John Vergnes was in stable condition with five broken ribs. At least two tornadoes were sighted in northern Texas, one near Blooming Grove and the other near Paradise. Property damage was reported near Paradise. Five trailer homes were destroyed by high winds in Valley View, about 55 miles north of Dallas, said Cooke County sheriff's dispatcher Laurie Butler. One of the homes was destroyed by fire caused by an electrical short, and a boy suffered a broken arm, Ms. Butler said. Hail pelted several counties, and flash flooding was reported on U.S. 287 late Tuesday near Decatur, about 30 miles north of Fort Worth. Severe storms raked central Colorado on Tuesday, unleashing tornadoes and heavy rain. Three tornadoes were spotted in the Denver area Tuesday afternoon, but they did only minor damage, the National Weather Service said. The resulting wind, lightning and rain tore off shingles, broke branches and downed power lines, police said. Flooding from weekend rain in southern Ohio left part of one community under 6 feet of water, and flood warnings remained in effect for several rivers. Gov. Richard Celeste said today he would declare four southern counties disaster areas, opening the way for state and possibly federal relief. Authorities resumed searching today for 15-year-old Carrie McFadden and 16-year-old Felicia Smith, feared drowned Tuesday in Paint Creek in Chillicothe, said sheriff's Sgt. Terry Myers. Rescuers in southeast Ohio also searched the Muskingum River near McConnelsville for a man trapped in a canoe as it passed over a dam Monday. Two teen-age boys canoeing with Terry Sherman, 24, of Newark, Ohio, were rescued. Residents of Murray City in southeast Ohio were cleaning up from flash flooding caused by heavy rain Tuesday that left part of the community under 6 feet of water. ``This is all my husband and I own. We don't know where to start,'' said Helen James, 59, crying as she surveyed damage from 3 feet of water in their one-story house. In North Carolina, a dozen other tents at the Outer Banks campground were destroyed by the waterborne tornado, but only 50-year-old Vergnes was hurt, said campground owner Ward Barnett. ``I was lifted very high and the tent was spinning,'' said Vergnes, of Verona, Pa. ``I could feel the spinning motion and the upward lift, maybe for three seconds. I was carried across a channel ... I was stripped completely of my clothes.''

DOC.HEAD: Mayor Jostled By Demonstrators as he Arrives to End Blockade
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 13 grafs to UPDATE with earthquake having no effect on the protesters in Bucharest. Pickup 10th, `Iliescu who...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Europe-Earthquake
DOC.TEXT: Angry anti-Communist demonstrators jostled the mayor of Bucharest this morning as he arrived with garbage trucks and street sweepers to end their 39-day protest in a city square. Shouting ``Down With Communism!'' and ``Get Out! Get Out!,'' a group of about 40 demonstrators stood behind a newly reinforced metal barricade at one end of University Square. They urged Mayor Dan Predescu to send the equipment elsewhere, where there are piles of garbage. Predescu announced late Tuesday that the city would take ``due measures'' today to clear the square because the lengthy blockade has cut off one of the city's main thoroughfares. But 10 hours after the mayor arrived, the trucks and sweepers remained parked just outside the square, which the demonstrators have declared a ``Communist-Free Zone.'' No move was made to tear down the barriers and rush-hour traffic continued to detour around the square. A strong earthquake struck Bucharest and other cities today, but it caused no panic among the demonstrators, said Dr. Dragos Nicolescu, who has been tending to hunger strikers participating in the protest. ``The demonstrators were swearing at Iliescu when the earthquake happened,'' Nicolescu said, referring to President-Elect Ion Iliescu. Dan Lungu, 28, who has lost 48 pounds since he started fasting May 3, said: ``I was praying to God when the earthquake came. It was as if it was God who was calling us. I could feel that.'' Pedestrians stopped to watch, shout and occasionally boo the protesters. After a sleepless night waiting for something to happen, the demonstrators spotted about 10 women street sweepers walking toward the square at 6:30 a.m., followed by the mayor. Several demonstrators rushed toward the mayor, surrounding and pushing him. One woman hit him on the head with a newspaper and was pulled away by Octavian Radulescu, a member of the Association of Former Political Prisoners. He shouted: ``Don't push him, because that's what they are waiting for.'' One man yelled: ``Take your communism away from our free zone.'' The demonstrators' key demand is that former high-ranking Communists be banned from public office for 10 years. The mayor insisted he had nothing to do with Iliescu, a former Communist Party Politburo member who won a landslide victory in May 20 elections. Iliescu, who called the protesters ``thugs'' and later apologized, had ordered the square cleared before the elections. But Prime Minister Petre Roman said the demonstrators could stay, even though their protest was unauthorized. ``I am not a Communist and I am not a representative for what Iliescu says. I only want to clean this place. It is my duty,'' the mayor said. Eventually, demonstrators who act as guards for 11 hunger strikers participating in the protest surrounded Predescu to protect him. The mayor remained in the square for an hour, arguing with any protester who approached him. Viorica Panaitescu, 64, who was visiting the hunger strikers' tent camp on the side of the square, said: ``Authorities will be more and more drastic. It's still the Communists that are leading us. ... I know they (the hunger strikers) are right, but they must stop fasting.'' Shortly before midnight, a drunken man who tried to remove one of the barricades was surrounded by a group of about 60 nervous demonstrators. Several punched and beat him and he was taken by ambulance to a hospital, his face bloody. The government released a statement Tuesday night saying it would do everything possible to stop the hunger strike. Some people have been fasting for four weeks and the Ministry of Health warned that they could face irreversible damage. Demonstrators have remained split on ending their occupation. Six key groups in the square, fearing the hunger strikers might die, have decided to switch to weekly protests. The Group for Social Dialogue, Romania's leading intellectuals, backed them, saying the demonstrators had already won ``a moral victory.'' Other groups have vowed to remain in the square because their demands haven't been met. Orthodox Church leader Patriarch Teoctist urged the government Tuesday to start a dialogue with the demonstrators. Several other attempts to initiate talks have failed.

DOC.HEAD: CNN and CBS To Share Berlin News Bureau
DOC.TEXT: In a cost-saving test that might be tried elsewhere overseas, Cable News Network and CBS News will share a bureau and satellite facilities in Berlin, says CNN executive vice president Ed Turner. The test will start in mid-June and is a ``a limited experiment'' in which the two organizations will maintain separate correspondents and producers, he says. CBS News spokesman Tom Goodman said Wednesday the network had no comment on what would be a unique sharing of office space with a still-growing cable rival. Although an experiment and on a small scale, the Berlin bureau arrangement would be the second deal between CBS and a company owned by Atlanta cable tycoon Ted Turner, who tried to buy CBS in 1986. Last September, Turner Network Television announced a $50 million contract with CBS that lets TNT show 50 hours of coverage from the 1992 and 1994 Winter Olympics. CBS owns the U.S. television rights to those Games. The CNN-CBS News arrangement in Berlin is ``really more symbolic than anything else,'' Ed Turner, no relation to CNN's owner, said in an interview last week. What is unusual about it is two rival TV news organizations ``cohabiting under the same roof and sharing a (satellite) feed point and saving each other a little money,'' he said. ``And we'll see where it goes from there.'' Asked if there might be similar CBS-CNN arrangements elsewhere overseas, Turner replied that ``We're looking at some, but right now there's nothing to talk about.'' The cost-saving effort comes at a time all the major networks are trying to reduce or share costs of news coverage overseas. Several years ago, NBC bought nearly 38 percent of Visnews, a London-based overseas TV news service. Visnews' majority owner is the Reuters news company, but the British Broadcasting Corp. also owns an 11.25 percent interest. NBC and Visnews recently began sharing the same office in Moscow, and the BBC uses NBC's satellite facilities there to transmit its stories to London, according to NBC. ABC owns 45 percent of another London-based overseas TV news service, Worldwide Television News, whose subscribers include ABC News, CBS News and CNN.

DOC.HEAD: He Didn't Ask, but Here's Some Political Advice for Gorbachev
With AM-Summit Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail Gorbachev, a politician in deep trouble back home, could get plenty of advice from this town's political consultants. They'd tell him: Open a negative campaign against Boris Yeltsin, do something, almost anything, to satisfy a Soviet ``what-have-you-done-for-me-today mentality'' _ and get rid of that dreadful red flag. When Washington's practitioners of public relations and campaign consulting were asked what they would tell the visiting Soviet president if he were a client, they didn't hesitate. Gorbachev's political problems _ breakaway republics; the election of critic Yeltsin as president of Russia, the largest Soviet republic; bloody clashes in Armenia; panic buying in the stores _ weren't enough to faze most of the imagemasters. ``The thing he can't do is lose the initiative,'' said Jody Powell, former press secretary to President Jimmy Carter and now with Ogilvy & Mather, the p.r. firm. ``He's got to keep being in motion and doing things and making sure the people are reacting to him rather than the other way around.'' Another veteran of the Carter White House, Anne Wexler, now running a government relations firm, shares that view. ``If I were advising him on anything,'' she said, ``I'd say move ahead briskly.'' Consultant Bob Beckel, adviser to Democrats, agreed. ``Gorbachev understands he has to come up with one big bomb after another. Three yards and a cloud of dust is not for him.'' Beckel said he is just the man to advise Gorbachev: ``Since I ran Walter Mondale's campaign, you know I know what it is like to bring bad news to the boss.'' Roger Stone, who has earned a living offering tips to Richard Nixon, Ronald Reagan and George Bush, thinks Gorbachev made a big mistake with that long-faced television speech Sunday night imploring his people ``not to give in to panic.'' Gorbachev went on the air as waves of consumers swept through state-run stores buying everything in sight to beat sharp announced price rises. ``Austerity has never won an election in this country,'' said Stone. ``Walter Mondale ran for president saying, `I will raise your taxes' and you see where that got him. Austerity as a political message is a loser. If I were Gorbachev, I'd be looking for deep tax cuts. It worked for Ronald Reagan.'' Gorbachev's speech got Bob Squire's head shaking, too. Squire, an expert for Democrats on using television, said, ``On TV, he looked like Gorbachev imitating Brezhnev,'' the sour-faced former Soviet leader. ``The problem with that speech is that he looked so grim it might have induced people to listen to what he was saying, which would be a disaster,'' said Squire. Squire's advice: pick a fight with Yeltsin, whose theme song ever since he was thrown out of the Soviet leadership in 1987 has been that Gorbachev was doing too little, too late. ``Gorbachev has let Yeltsin become the good guy,'' said Squire. ``Gorbachev needs to focus on policies, not personalities. Yeltsin's proposals would be much more painful than the reality the people are facing today. He's got to make Yeltsin the issue. Gorbachev's problem is he invented the good guy version of Soviet politics. If you live by your personality, you die by your personality.'' Beckel, tongue in cheek, offered this counsel: ``Take an early pension.'' And this: ``Maybe he ought to give it up and get himself made secretary general of the U.N.'' Pause. ``The problem is, the Russians might veto him.'' John Buckley, who advises conservatives, says Gorbachev's problem, short-term anyway, is just about hopeless. ``Good policy makes good politics,'' says Buckley. ``No truer cliche has ever been spoken.'' Victor Kamber, who runs a p.r. and advertising agency that serves liberal causes, finds himself agreeing with Buckley. ``All the great speeches in the world won't help Gorbachev. There's a what-have-you-done-for-me-today mentality he hasn't dealt with.'' And after Gorbachev solves all his immediate crisis-sized problems, Squire offers one last bit of advice: ``He's got to do something about that awful flag. He's got a blood red flag with a hammer and sickle on it. He needs a blue flag with a white dove, something like that. But that can come later.''

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Summit Rdp Bjt
Small Pacts Ready For Signing; Big-Ticket Items Proving Elusive
DOC.TEXT: Agreements ranging from chemical weapons to air travel will be concluded at the U.S.-Soviet summit, but getting superpower signatures on big-ticket missile and trade accords is proving more difficult. President Bush's talks with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev starting Thursday are likely to produce a joint declaration on progress toward agreement on the first treaty to reduce the number of U.S. and Soviet long-range nuclear missiles. But it's almost certain the treaty will not be ready for signing. Expectations for signing a trade agreement to ease U.S. tariffs on Soviet products also are fading, but better than a half-dozen separate agreements are ready for signing at a ceremony set for Friday. Here is a brief rundown on the agreements: _An end to production of all U.S. and Soviet chemical weapons, mainly poison gas and nerve agents, and destruction of all but 5,000 tons of each side's chemical arms stockpiles until a global production ban is put in place. It is unclear whether this would be put in the form of a formal treaty requiring ratification by a two-thirds majority of the Senate or an executive agreement that would require a simple majority vote by both the House and Senate. The agreement is expected to include provisions for each side to inspect the other side's weapons destruction. _A protocol to provide against cheating on existing treaties that limit nuclear tests. The 1974 Threshold Test Ban Treaty and the 1976 Peaceful Nuclear Explosions Treaty limit Soviet and American underground nuclear tests to a yield of 150 kilotons. No agreement is expected on the tougher question of whether to prohibit all nuclear tests. The Soviets favor such a ban; the Bush administration opposes it. _Expanding commercial air travel between the United States and the Soviet Union by adding four American and six Soviet cities to current airliner routes. The deal will allow one more Soviet and six more U.S. airlines to run the routes, and it will inaugurate regular cargo flights between the two countries. Additional U.S. cities to be provided service are Anchorage, Alaska; Chicago, San Francisco and Miami. The additional Soviet cities are Kiev, Minsk, Magadan, Khabarovsk, Tbilisi and Riga, in Latvia. _A new 5-year bilateral atomic energy agreement would provide for closer cooperation in nuclear reactor safety, fusion energy and basic atomic science. The deal coincides with heightened international concern about the safety of some Soviet commercial nuclear reactors in light of the 1986 Chernobyl accident that killed at least 31 people. _A grain deal, effective Jan. 1, 1991, committing the Soviets to buy more American wheat, feed grains and soybeans. It guarantees at least 10 million tons in U.S. sales annually, an increase of 1 million tons annually from the current agreement, which took effect in 1983. _A maritime transportation pact to make it easier for U.S. and Soviet commercial vessels to deliver goods to ports in one another's country. The agreement will increase the number of ports in which the ships can call, and will ease the length of advance notification time required of the arriving ships. The two nations also are likely to conclude a maritime boundary agreement that recognizes Soviet jurisdiction over four disputed Arctic islands. _Opening reciprocal cultural and information centers in Washington and Moscow. The centers, one in each city, would offer student counseling and provide lending library and language services, as well as sponsor seminars and exhibitions. Some terms of the agreement were still being negotiated this week. _The first government-to-government agreement to increase student exchanges between the two countries. It sets an exchange goal of 1,000 students from each country by 1995.

DOC.HEAD: Man Accused of 11-Cent Robbery
DOC.TEXT: A man has been arrested for robbing two people of 11 cents, police said Wednesday. Thomas J. Schooley, 20, of Evansville was being held Wednesday on $1,000 bond, authorities said. Andrew McNeeley and William O'Leary told police they were robbed early Tuesday as they came out of an alley, said Detective James Kelley. The man said he had a gun and demanded money. The pair emptied their pockets and handed over 11 cents. The robber took the change and ran away, police said. McNeeley and O'Leary described the robber to a woman who in turn told police Schooley's name and address. Schooley was arrested at his apartment. Police said Schooley also was wanted on charges of failure to appear, theft, receiving stolen property and conspiracy.

DOC.HEAD: Arab Leaders Denounce U.S. Policies as Summit Ends
With AM-Israel, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Arab leaders ended their summit Wednesday with harsh criticism of the United States, saying its support of Israel encourages the Jewish state to stonewall peace moves and settle Jews on occupied land. Their statement was seen as a major defeat for pro-American moderates led by Egypt and Saudi Arabia. The 20-page final communique urged a halt to the influx of Jews into Israel and pledged financial and political support for the Palestinian uprising against Israeli rule of the occupied territories. No figures were made public. The communique was released after a three-day summit marked by disagreement between hard-liners and moderates. PLO chief Yasser Arafat called the summit to discuss Arab concerns over the immigration of Soviet Jews to Israel. Some last-minute changes were made on the draft text, tempering an outright threat of economic sanctions, and possibly an oil embargo, on states that encourage Jewish immigration to Israel. Instead, the leaders instructed economic, financial and foreign ministers of the 21-member Arab League to meet within two months to reevaluate relations and recommend to the next summit possible sanctions against states that facilitate immigration to Israel. That appeared to be the only concession the hard-liners _ led by Iraq and the PLO _ made to the moderates. Israeli officials have said hundreds of thousands of Jews could go to Israel in the next few years because of relaxed travel restrictions in the Soviet Union and tighter entry quotas in the United States. Arabs fear the emigrants will be settled in occupied territories and drive out the Palestinians. The Israeli government denies it has a policy of settling Jewish emigrants in the occupied territories. Libyan leader Col. Moammar Gadhafi, wearing a silver and white African robe, spoke to the conference Wednesday and said, ``Palestine will be the graveyard of the Jews.'' He said Arabs must increase their population from 100 million to 1 billion to confront Israel with a ``population explosion.'' A recording of his address was broadcast by Baghdad television. The final communique said: ``The Arab leaders affirmed that the Arab powers will take political and economic measures against whichever country that recognizes Jerusalem as the capital of Israel.'' It ``denounced'' non-binding recent votes in both chambers of the U.S. Congress that described Jerusalem as the capital of Israel. It also warned of an ``explosion'' in the Middle East because of Israeli policies. ``The United States shoulders the main responsibility for this situation because of the military capabilities, financial assistance and political cover it extends to Israel, without which Israel would not have been able to continue its aggression and challenge of international will,'' the statement said. It urged all states to ``stop any assistance or loans that might facilitate the settlement of Jewish emigrants in occupied Palestinian or other Arab lands.'' It askd the United Nations to ``to guarantee that the Jewish emigrants will not be settled'' in occupied territories. It demanded ``international supervision'' to guard against the settlement of Jews on occupied land and to protect Palestinians of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. On other issues, the final communique stressed backing for ``Iraq's legitimate right to self-defense and its right to defend itself against any aggression with whatever means it sees fit.'' That was a declaration of support for Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, who has said he would hit Israel with chemical weapons if it deployed its nuclear arsenal against Iraq or any other Arab country. Iraq has binary chemical weapons. Iraq-bound shipments, allegedly containing components of an Iraqi ``super gun,'' have been seized in Britain, Greece, Turkey and Italy. An Egyptian suggestion that the summit call for a ``nuclear, chemical and biological weapons-free Middle East'' was shot down by hard-liners on grounds that Israel would not make such a commitment. The communique also called for a special fund to help rebuild war-torn Lebanon. Syria, Iraq's main Arab foe, boycotted the meeting mainly because of its venue. Lebanon, which has two-thirds of its territory under Syrian control, also did not participate. The next summit, the communique said, will convene in Egypt in November.

DOC.HEAD: Pekingese and Peter Pan Gen Censused
DOC.TEXT: One census form came back with tooth marks on it. Another included a note asking for money. A third simply included the response ``none of your business.'' When you send questionnaires out to count a quarter-billion Americans, chances are not all the responses will be what was expected. ``For wanting to know how many people live in the U.S., you people are all nosey,'' wrote one woman on her census form. ``I thought this was a Census, not a history quiz,'' replied another. And one man methodically wrote ``none of your business'' in response to each question on his form. The census is continuing and people who don't provide information will likely get a call from their local census enumerator. So far, officials say, just more than 80 percent of American households have been counted, either in the mail-back portion of the count or by workers going door-to-door. The effort is expected to continue for at least several weeks. Some enumerators have even resorted to rowboats in flood-ravaged areas of Texas, reported Census spokesman Jim Wilson in Dallas. Many of the people filling out forms are going beyond the limits of the form's square boxes, however, to express more personal thoughts about the census and themselves. Wilson has been collecting some of the census responses from across the nation that go beyond the bureaucratic expectations. His collection includes: _A census form with a large chunk missing and teeth marks over the remainder, with a note saying that the family's golden retriever had chomped it, and asking for a new form. _``The census sounds like an autobiography, not a head count.'' _``I answered the questions the best I know how, we are two old people.'' _``Brad, study and no science questions, notes on bugs, dad can help.'' (Wilson suggests this note, scrawled on the envelope, may not have been intended for the Census Bureau). _``I am 74, I own this property, that is all I intend to say.'' _One woman listed her two Pekingese, with a note saying that, to her, ``these are people, these are not dogs.'' Their language spoken was listed as Pekingese. _One man listed his state of residence as ``confusion.'' _A woman, apparently annoyed at questions about type of employment and place of work, included a note stating: ``When my husband is home from work and is resting my work still goes on, I cook the meals, I wash the dishes, I mow the yard, wash the clothes and hang them on the line, make sure the bills are paid on time and that the floors are vacuumed or mopped. If this is not a job I don't know what is.'' _A man answering the question on commuting to work said his wife traveled by broom. _One respondent included Tinker Bell and Peter Pan as sharing the household. _And a man called a census office to ask if he had been sent a long form at the instigation of his estranged wife, who was trying to find out about his live-in girlfriend.

DOC.HEAD: Israelis Intercept Seaborne Guerrilla Attack; 4 Raiders Killed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 18 grafs to UPDATE with Palestinian group claiming responsibility. Pickup 11th pvs ``It was....' NOTE: The military censors banned publication of some details of the raid.
DOC.TEXT: Palestinian guerrillas in speedboats attacked the Israeli coast today, but Israeli forces killed four of them and captured 12 before they could hurt thousands of people on the beach or Tel Aviv hotels. A faction of the Palestine Liberation Organization claimed responsibility for the raid, which apparently was aimed at the hotels, which were crowded because of a religious holiday. No Israelis were hurt. One of the six guerrilla speedboats came ashore only a few hundred yards from a crowded Mediterranean beachclub in Nizzanim, 18 miles from Tel Aviv. The other five guerrilla boats were intercepted before they reached land. Witnesses said the speedboat that reached land had 11 guerrillas abaord and was headed north toward Tel Aviv when it was chased ashore by an Israeli gunboat. The guerrillas were pinned down in the sand dunes by heavy fire from elite army units and soldiers in two U.S.-made Cobra helicopter gunships. Four guerrillas were killed, the army said. A second boat was intercepted en route to an undisclosed location on the beachfront north of Tel Aviv. In Bagdad, Iraq, the PLO faction known as the Palestine Liberation Front said it carried out an attack in retaliation for the killing of Palestinian leader Abu Jihad in Tunisia two years ago. Abu Jihad, a nom de guerre for Khalil al-Wazir, was killed by a commando widely believed to be Israeli in Tunis, Tunisia, in April 1988. The faction is led by Abul al-Abbas, who has been convicted in abstentia by an Italian court for masterminding the hijacking of the Italian cruise liner Achille Lauro in 1985. One American was killed during the hijacking. Hussein al-Abed, the faction's representative in Baghdad, said the guerrillas today attacked ``selected and limited targets on the Palestinian coast.'' It was unclear whether the attack had the endorsement of PLO chairman Yasser Arafat, who pledged in December 1988 to abandon terrorism. Al-Abed confirmed that four guerrillas were killed, but he insisted that 11 others were still fighting. Most civilians were forced off the beaches south of Tel Aviv, where they had come on the Shavuot holiday or Festival of Weeks, which marks the giving of the Ten Commandments. In his comments on Lt. Gen. Dan Shomron, the armed forces chief of staff, blamed the raid on al-Abbas' group. ``Abul al-Abbas was responsible,'' Shomron said during a news conference in Tel Aviv. ``It was his decision to kill people in the most populated areas of Israel.'' The army said a guerrilla mothership from Beghazi, Libya, released the six smaller craft 120 miles from the coast. It said the raiders, who were armed with Katyusha rockets and other heavy weapons, planned to kill civilians at hotels in Tel Aviv. The raid was the largest Palestinian infiltration attempt by sea since March 11, 1978, when a dozen guerrillas from Palestine Liberation Organization chief Yasser Arafat's Fatah faction came ashore and hijacked a bus on the coastal highway north of Tel Aviv. Thirty-three people were killed and 82 wounded in the incident. Today's attack was launched on the final day of an Arab summit in Baghdad. During the summit, Arab leaders, including Arafat, verbally attacked Israel. The leaders also called for political and economic sanctions against nations that recognize Jerusalem as the capital of Israel, and they denounced U.S. policies in the Middle East. After today's raid, police ordered the evacuation of thousands of Israelis from a 30-mile stretch of beaches south of Tel Aviv. They also told thousands of other residents near the beach to stay home. ``It was well planned but as far as we know totally unsuccessfully,'' said an army spokesman, who could not be identified in keeping with army regulations. One guerrilla squad landed at midmorning on an empty stretch of beach at Nizzanim, 18 miles south of Tel Aviv. About 3,000 Israeli beachgoers were enjoying themselves at a packed club only a few hundred yards away. Naval Rear Adm. Micha Ram said the second vessel was spotted about 20 miles from Tel Aviv and told to stop by an Israeli gunboat. ``They lifted their hands and were ordered to jump in the water. Later, we fished them out,'' he said. Zvi Amitai, 57, a member of the Nizzanim Kibbutz communal farm, said he was collecting driftwood when he saw the speedboat slicing through the water followed by an Israeli patrol boat. He said a spotter plane circled overhead, and there was gunfire. He said the guerrillas landed 20 yards away on a strip of beach that was empty except for himself and a few fishermen. ``They jumped from the boat and didn't shoot, as if they didn't see us,'' Amitai said. ``They just ran for the dunes.'' An Israeli who was on the beach with his wife and children said all the attackers had been killed or captured in little more than a half hour. ``We heard some firing. ... I saw a boat coming in very fast from the sea onto the beach,'' he said. ``Minutes after that, a couple of Israeli patrol boats came into the area and started shooting in the direction where the boat had landed,'' said the man who declined to give his name. ``The firefight continued for about half an hour and then helicopters flew in and started shooting in the same area.'' Army radio said the mother ship from Libya had passed by Port Said on the Suez Canal. It said Egyptian authorities had been notified but did not elaborate. Though the attack appeared to have been planned in advance of the Arab summit, Foreign Minister Moshe Arens linked the raid to the strident rhetoric coming from the Arab leaders.

DOC.HEAD: Pact Allowing U.S. Bases in Greece Initialed
DOC.TEXT: Greece and the United States initialed a new defense pact on Wednesday that will allow U.S. military bases to remain on Greek soil for the next eight years. The agreement ended nearly a year of uncertainty over the fate of the bases. The United States has four bases and about 20 smaller units around the country but is closing two of the bases as part of a worldwide cost-cutting drive. Sources who asked not to be identified said the new accord allows for the two remaining U.S. bases to continue to operate in Greece. They are a major naval installation at Souda and an Air Force electronic surveillance station at Gournes. Both are on the southern island of Crete. Government spokesman Vyron Polydoras told reporters the content of the pact would be released in two weeks. ``The agreement will remain classified until submitted to the appropriate services of the U.S. Defense and State Departments,'' Polydoras said. He confirmed that some operations of the Hellenikon Air Force base near Athens, slated for closure by Washington, would be transferred to Souda. The other base to close under the U.S. plan is a naval communications station at Nea Makri northeast of Athens. The previous five-year agreement, covering defense and economic ties between the countries, expired in December 1988. The new agreement's title makes no reference to economic ties between the two countries. Polydoras refused to say whether Greece would receive financial aid as part of the new agreement. Kiki Munshi, press attache of the U.S. Embassy in Athens, also refused to give details of the pact. Premier Constantine Mitsotakis of the conservative New Democracy Party was elected in April and pledged to reach an agreement with the United States on the bases. Andreas Papandreou's socialist government, which lost power in national elections in June 1989, had conducted 17 rounds of talks with the United States but failed to arrive at an accord. Mitsotakis is a staunch supporter of defense ties with the United States. He leaves for Washington on June 3 for talks with President Bush. The Greek Parliament will have to ratify the accord before it becomes law, with an absolute majority required in the 300-member house. Mitsotakis has 150 seats in Parliament and the backing of one deputy who represents a small conservative party. Political analysts expect the bill to go through. The diplomats leading the negotiating teams initialed the accord at the Foreign Ministry on Wednesday. They are ambassadors Christos Zacharakis of Greece and Alan Flanigan of the United States. The initialing followed two rounds of intensive talks in Athens and one in Washington this month.

DOC.HEAD: `Vivien Leigh Double' Dies
DOC.TEXT: Millicent Miller, who worked as Vivien Leigh's stand-in during filming of ``Gone With the Wind,'' has died. She was 81. Mrs. Miller died Tuesday. The cause of death wasn't given. She lived most of her life in Stillwater, except for nine years she spent in California. In California, she joined the Screen Actors Guild and was asked to interview for the job as Miss Leigh's stand-in for ``Gone With the Wind.'' She was hired from a group of more than 300 applicants. She appeared in the movie as Scarlett O'Hara hiding under a bridge while a wagon passes overhead. And it was her hand that pulled a turnip from the ground after the ruination of Scarlett's plantation Tara, and her hand that drew a revolver from a drawer before Scarlett shoots a Union soldier. Mrs. Miller is survived by her husband, Jimmy ``Pete'' Miller, a daughter and granddaughter. Services are scheduled for Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: World Bank Lending $200 Million for Education in Africa
DOC.TEXT: The World Bank announced over $200 million worth of loans on Wednesday to foster education and other social goals in four west African countries. The bank, owned by 152 countries, is the largest source of aid to the Third World. Most of the money, such as the $120 million to improve higher education in Nigeria, will be repayable only after 35 years or more at less than 1 percent interest a year. Ghana will get $50 million to improve primary and secondary schools. Two loans worth $21.6 million will go to Gambia. One, for $14.6 million, is to raise the quality of education at all levels. The other, for $7 million, includes training in reading and arithmetic for 10,000 women in 125 villages. In Cameroon, the bank's loan will contribute $21.5 million to an $86 million social project that includes school supplies and vocational training. Canada, France, West Germany, Japan, the United States and other international agencies are also contributing to the project.

DOC.HEAD: Two National Guard Jet Trainers Collide
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with crew members taken to Spencer hospital, add quotes from witness who saw parachutes, CORRECTS `either' to `each other,' in quote in 8th graf.
DOC.TEXT: Two jet trainers from the South Dakota Air National Guard collided over Iowa this morning and crashed, a guard spokesman said. The three crew members _ two from one A-7 trainer jet and one from the other _ parachuted to safety, said Lt. Reid Christopherson, executive officer of the South Dakota Air National Guard. He would not release the names of the crew members, who were brought to Spencer Municipal Hospital, where administrator Jim Striepe said he could not give a condition report. Witnesses said the planes crashed on a farm two miles north of Royal, which is about 8 miles southwest of Spencer. Christopherson said the planes crashed at 10:30 a.m. John Schultz of Spencer said he was watching the planes in the air when they collided. ``At first, it was like stunning, watching the flames,'' Schultz said. ``Then, it really got disheartening because I figured there was probably lives lost. Glad to hear they got out of there.'' Christopherson said the planes were on a local training flight out of Sioux Falls. ``They were flying around like they were chasing each other, dog fighting like,'' Schultz said. ``I was sitting there watching. They were looping around and banking around. It looked like they were having a great time.'' Schultz said he saw three planes, and one flew out of sight. ``I was watching the other two. They just collided,'' he said. ``They just hit head on. Each one exploded in a ball of fire, and that was it. I didn't see the parachutes.'' Dan Van Berkum of Spencer also was watching the planes maneuver. ``You could see a flash and explosion,'' Van Berkum said. ``After that explosion, you could see two jets definitely falling to the ground. After a minute or so, you could see three parachutes.'' The A-7 fighters ``date back to the '60s,'' Christopherson said. He had no word on what kind of damage the planes did on the ground. The area is mostly farm fields.

DOC.HEAD: Hoarders Causing Food Shortages, Government Says
DOC.TEXT: East Germans are clearing store shelves and filling their refrigerators because they fear massive price increases when the nation converts to a free market, officials said Wednesday. East Germans are making a run on canned goods, meat, soap, sugar and ``everything that can be stored,'' said Commerce Ministry spokeswoman Christian Boschek. Food distributors also are sitting on large stocks of meat and other goods, creating shortages, apparently while waiting for the July 2 economic merger with West Germany, the government said. Unification of the German states' economies is expected to bring higher prices and massive unemployment. Government spokesman Matthias Gehler said subsidies on food will be scrapped July 2 and prices will be set by the free market, rather than the state. But subsidies for utilities, rents and public transporation will remain at least until Dec. 31, when the government will assess the effects of capitalism on the country, Gehler said. ``We cannot have half a marriage. We want to enter into it entirely,'' he said at a news conference. Prices of many products already are rising as West German goods begin filling East German stores. Boschek said people she called ``hamster buyers'' were purchasing as many goods as they can. Gehler said more than 100 inspectors will be sent around the country to investigate reports that East German food distributors and producers are intentionally keeping products off the market until July 2. On that date they can be paid in convertible West German marks. The centerpiece of the economic union is the conversion of East German currency to West German marks. Under a treaty between the Germanys, most East Germans will be able to convert up to $2,400 to West German marks at a 1-1 rate. Amounts above that will be converted at a 2-1 rate. Salaries and pensions also will be converted at a 1-1 rate. The government will begin passing out applications next week to East Germans for converting their cash. East Germans now have 440 billion marks in savings accounts, said Wolfrid Stoll, vice president of the East German Staatsbank. That includes 25 million accounts held by 16 million East Germans and hundreds of thousands held by enterprises, legal entities and foreigners. Stoll said banks would stay open longer and personnel would be reinforced to handle the expected crunch. He urged East Germans to remain ``calm and level-headed'' when the droves of people begin descending on East German banks. He said East Germans are expected to open between 1.5 million and 2 million new accounts in June alone in anticipation of the economic union. East Germans must have their money in bank accounts to convert their currency. The government will begin passing out West German currency to stores in the days before the economic union is official. East Germans will be able to buy products in East German marks and get their change back in West marks at a 2-1 exchange rate.

DOC.HEAD: Earthquake Kills 7, Injures Hundreds in Romania
LaserPhotos BUCH1,XBUC3
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 10 grafs to UPDATE casualties in Romania, deaths reported in Soviet Union. Pickup 7th pvs, `In Golden...'
DOC.TEXT: A strong earthquake struck Romania today, killing eight people, injuring 260 and heavily damaging buildings in Bucharest and other cities across much of the country, police said. The temblor was felt in the Soviet Union, Hungary, Greece, Turkey and Bulgaria, but of those only the Soviet Union reported casualties. Six people were reported injured and buildings were damaged in the Soviet republic of Moldavia near the Romanian border. A Soviet lawmaker said initial reports from the region indicated there were an unspecified number of deaths. In Romania, some people were killed or injured by large chunks of concrete and plaster that fell from buildings onto sidewalks and streets. Several people in Bucharest were hurt when they jumped from windows or balconies. Thousands of frightened residents in the capital city of 2.2 million people fled into streets as buildings swayed and cracked. Romania's General Inspectorate of Police said two people died in Bucharest, two in the Danube River port of Braila, and one each in the cities of Buzau and Brasov, and in the Ialomita and Prahova counties, north of the capital. The inspectorate reported 260 people injured, 45 critically. It said 35 of the critically injured were in Bucharest, where 138 people were hurt. Elsewhere, it said, 51 people were injured in Braila, 21 in Dolj in the southwest, 20 in Prahova, 12 in Ialomita, 10 in the eastern county of Galati, 7 in the nearby county of Constanta bordering on the Black Sea, and one in Buzau. An earlier erroneous police report said 42 were injured in Brasov. In Calarasi County in southern Romania, the ceiling of a major electrical steel plant crashed to the floor, the state news agency Rompres reported. In Golden, Colo. the U.S. Geological Survey said the earthquake measured 6.5 on Richter scale. Its epicenter was 100 miles north of Bucharest, in the wooded Vrancea range of the Carpathian mountains. The earthquake struck at 1:40 p.m. (6:40 a.m. EDT) and rumbled across the Carpathians, which run through eastern Romania, the western border of the Soviet Union and southwest Poland. In Bulgaria, the state BTA news agency said the temblor was felt nationwide but there was minor damage only in Silistra, a town on the border with Romania. A nuclear power plant in Kozlodoui on the Danube river was closed. In the Soviet Union, the quake knocked out telephone lines and shook buildings in at least three of the country's 15 republics: Russia, the Ukraine and Moldavia. In Ottawa, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said when asked about the earthquake: ``Everything is OK. There was no devastation, no destruction.'' Six people were hospitalized in Kogul, near the Soviet Union's border with Romania, said Lt. Ivan Koltuk of the regional Interior Department. ``The quake was really strong. Everything and everybody was falling,'' said Alexander Yevchenko, a local official. Buildings were damaged in Izmail, Bolgrad, Reni, Kogul and Komrat, Soviet officials said. The quake also shook buildings in Moscow, 1,000 miles east of Bucharest, and was felt as far north as Leningrad. U.S. officials closed the older U.S. Embassy, which is 10 stories tall. ``It's an old building, and when the upper floors shook we called around other places in town and closed the building as precaution to do safety checks,'' said embassy spokesman Jim Bullock. One of the two people killed in Bucharest, shop assistant Petruta Lungu, died when she was hit by a collapsing balcony as she ran outside after the quake struck, police said. The Fire Department said two small fires were reported in Bucharest, one in an apartment and another in the chemical laboratory of a high school. Jeremy Sutton-Hibbert of Glasgow, Scotland, staying in an apartment in a 10-story building in Bucharest, said: ``The walls of the bedroom crumbled with plaster falling. Stuff came flying off shelves and all the plaster came off the ceilings. Outside there's a massive crack in the building.'' Elena Chibzui, 56, who was in her sixth-floor apartment in central Bucharest, said: ``I'm very scared, and I could hear shouts in the neighboring apartment.'' Her building suffered only a minor crack. Doina Stoica, a 22-year-old student, said: ``I was scared. I was in a book shop and the first thought was to get my mom and get out on the street.'' Michel Desprats, 24, a French journalist at the Bucuresti Hotel, noticed the chandeliers in the marble lobby swinging. ``In panic, I followed all the people out of the hotel and people were all shouting and crying,'' he said. Inside the hotel, which suffered structural cracks on almost every floor, small chunks of plaster littered the carpet. In Vienna, the Austrian Seismological Institute said the epicenter of the quake appeared to be located in Romania's Vrancea range of the Carpathians. This was the third major earthquake in Romania since 1977. The other two were also centered in the Vrancea range and the most serious, on March 4, 1977, killed 1,500 people. The Richter scale gauges the amount of energy released by a quake as measures by the ground motion recorded by seismographs. Every increase of one number means a tenfold increase in magnitude. A powerful earthquake struck Soviet Armenia in December 1988, killing an estimated 25,000 people and leveling buildings in several villages and cities. An earthquake measuring 7.1 on the Richter scale struck the San Francisco Bay area Oct. 17, 1989, killing 67 people and injuring more than 3,000 others.

DOC.HEAD: DA's Office Decides To Drop All Charges Against Gonzo Journalist
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors asked today for dismissal of drug possession, explosives and sexual assault charges against Hunter Thompson, saying their case against the ``gonzo'' journalist was not strong enough. The dismissal motions, to heard Thursday in Pitkin County District Court, said potential witnesses had not cooperated with district attorney's office investigators. A statement by the district attorney's office also said a preliminary hearing May 22 resulted in discrepancies between sworn testimony and previous statements to investigators. Thompson said in an interview that the decision was ``a huge victory for all of us'' and there would be a ``celebratory orgy'' tonight at his favorite hangout, the Woody Creek Tavern in Aspen. Thompson, 53, last week was ordered to stand trial June 25 on four felony and three misdemeanor charges after the preliminary hearing before Judge Charles Buss, who threw out a felony charge of using cocaine. The charges stemmed from a visit to Thompson's home in Woody Creek last February by Gale Palmer-Slater of Port Huron, Mich., an entrepreneur and ex-pornographic film actress and producer. She claimed that Thompson grabbed her breast and threw a drink at her and that she saw him sniff cocaine during her hours-long visit to his home. Authorities subsequently searched Thompson's home and said they found LSD, cocaine, tranquilizers, marijuana and explosives. Thompson claimed the drugs had been left by guests over the years and were only turned up because his home was searched with a thoroughness inappropriate for a misdemeanor assault charge. Thompson is an author and journalist known for his accounts of political campaigns, shark hunts in Hawaii and the Hell's Angels. He often has laced his exaggerated first-person reports with accounts of his own drug and alcohol abuse.

DOC.HEAD: Mets Manager's Firing an Omen?
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, a not-quite-yet announced candidate for re-election, joked to reporters that Davey Johnson's firing as manager of the New York Mets could be a portent. ``What it means is incumbents are in trouble,'' Cuomo said Wednesday. Cuomo was in Manhattan to sign an agreement that freezes Consolidated Edison electric rates for two years. He called it important news for consumers and business people. While mentioning a long list of people responsible for negotiating the rate freeze, the two-term Democratic governor added, ``I'll take all the credit I can, especially this year.'' Cuomo has said he will make an announcement soon about his future and that it would contain no surprises. The election is in November. Johnson was fired Tuesday after more than six seasons as Mets manager.

DOC.HEAD: Leopard Attacks Zoo Keeper
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS leopard's weight from 90 pounds to 70 pounds, reflecting later information from zoo director.
DOC.TEXT: A 70-pound Persian leopard leaped on a zoo keeper's back and sank its teeth into his neck in front of a crowd of schoolchildren, hanging on as the man screamed, `Get him off! Get him off!'' witnesses said.
DOC.HEAD: Another keeper, 2nd graf
Gorbachev Reaffirms Opposition to NATO Membership for United Germany
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 21 grafs to UPDATE with Gorbachev quote on Germany and NATO, toasts by Mulroney and Gorbachev; Picks up 16th graf, `Gorbachev left ...'; SUBS last 5 grafs with 1 graf to tighten.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto OTT1
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today paid his respects to Canada's war dead and prepared to head for Washington, expressing confidence that he and President Bush will agree on a way to permit German unification. But Gorbachev reaffirmed his country's opposition to a united Germany belonging to NATO. ``I haven't yet heard any alternative from the West,'' he said after meeting with Prime Minister Brian Mulroney. ``It seems that it is just like an old record that seems to be playing the same note again and again. ... I would like us to find a new melody.'' Gorbachev planned to fly to Washington this afternoon for four days of talks with Bush. They are expected to focus on German unification, arms reduction and trade. Asked Tuesday if he was optimistic about reaching agreement over Germany and its membership in NATO, Gorbachev replied: ``I am sure of that. And tell that to the American people.'' Gorbachev has warned that U.S. insistence on NATO membership for a united Germany could stall the withdrawal of Soviet troops from Eastern Europe. The Soviet Union has moved progressively from outright opposition to German reunification to acceptance of the concept under some formula that would provide assurances a new German giant would never again pose a military threat to its neighbors. Gorbachev met Mulroney at the War Memorial and laid a wreath honoring Canadian soldiers. After playing of the national anthems, there was a moment of silence, then a lament played by a lone piper. Gorbachev then surprised everyone by walking part of the short distance to Parliament Hill for his second round of talks with Mulroney. Gorbachev and Mulroney strolled slowly toward the ornate gray stone Parliament building, smiling and occasionally speaking to people in the crowd. They then got in their cars to drive the final stretch. It was the second time since his arrival that Gorbachev mingled with Canadians on the street. Tuesday night, he spent nearly an hour amiably chatting, answering questions and shaking hands with a crowd on a pedestrian mall. Outside Parliament today, hundreds of protesters chanted, waved flags and carried placards appealing for independence for the Baltic republics of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia, which were forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940. Later, in a toast at a luncheon, Mulroney lamented the lot of leaders who attempt reform _ a problem faced by both himself and Gorbachev. ``Leadership in the service of reform is no guarantee of political popularity,'' Mulroney complained, obviously referring to Gorbachev's difficulties in implementing economic and political reform and Mulroney's own problems involving French-speaking Quebec and disgruntlement over new taxes. Gorbachev also talked about change and the ``breakdown of established views and stereotypes.'' ``Today, at a watershed in world history and politics, the friendly feelings and creatiave aspirations of our two peoples can serve as the northern pillar of the bridge of confidence and security between the East and the West,'' he said. At Parliament Hill, Gorbachev was asked by a reporter about the powerful earthquake that struck Romania and the Soviet Union today. ``I've been told there were several shocks in Moldavia and Armenia which were ... even felt in Moscow,'' Gorbachev said. ``But everything is OK. There was no devastation, no destruction.'' Gorbachev said he saw no reason to break off his trip and return home. After the U.S.-Soviet summit ends Sunday, he plans to leave for Minneapolis, followed by a trip to San Francisco, where he will meet with South Korean President Roh Tae-woo, U.S. officials said today. The two countries have no formal diplomatic relations and the Soviets maintain strong ties with Communist North Korea, which conducted a brief and now-suspended dialogue with the pro-U.S. government in Seoul. Gorbachev left worsening domestic troubles at home _ including panic-buying and clashes between troops and militants in Armenia _ as he flew to Canada for an overnight visit before going to his second summit meeting with Bush. On the sidelines, Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze and Joe Clark, Canada's minister for external affairs, held two meetings on a number of international and bilateral issues. The future of a new, united Germany and a changing role for the North Atlantic alliance figure to be among the more sticky issues during the visit to the United States. Clark said the two subjects were high on the agenda in meetings between Soviet and Canadian officials. Shevardnadze said he and Clark were in general agreement on Canada's desire for an increased role for the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, but there were differences on Germany and its membership in NATO. Clark said both Canada and the Soviet Union would work toward a summit of the CSCE nations _ the United States, Canada, and all European nations except Albania _ which met for the first time in Helsinki, Finland, in 1975. Meanwhile, Canada announced it will extend a $500 million line of credit, or about $425 million in U.S. dollars, to the Soviet Union for the purchase of Canadian goods and services over the next two years. In the past, Canada has extended $360 million to the Soviets.

DOC.HEAD: Man Lobbies to Change Name of Gay, W.Va.
DOC.TEXT: The name of his hometown is nothing to smile about for Chuck Raines. He's tired of all the jokes, and has begun a lobbying effort aimed at getting town leaders to rename the tiny Jackson County town near the Ohio line. ``When the community was first named, the word gay meant merry, joyous and lively,'' Raines said. ``But as times have changed so has the meaning of the word.'' Last week, Raines petitioned the Jackson County Commission, which would have to approve any name change. Raines hasn't suggested a new name, he just knows he hates ``Gay.'' The commission has not acted yet, but Raines is already facing opposition. Ruth Skinner, the town's postmaster for the past 32 years, said the town got its name in the 1850s. The way she sees it, Gay was Gay before gay was homosexual. ``I'm satisfied with the way things are. This place was named Gay a long time before this other stuff got started.''

DOC.HEAD: Tickets To See Gorbachev Are Hard To Get
DOC.TEXT: Friends World College was celebrating the news that Mikhail S. Gorbachev would accept its peace award _ then the Soviets said the school could bring only 12 people to the embassy ceremony. Tickets to other summit events aren't quite that scarce. But anyone hoping to make this week's social scene needs good friends in the right places. It doesn't hurt to be rich or famous, either. From a series of short awards ceremonies at the Soviet Embassy to the full-fledged state dinner Thursday night at the White House, guest lists have a familiar ring. As in Eisenhower, Roosevelt, Hearst, Cronkite, Kennedy, Fulbright, Galbraith and Schlesinger. Gorbachev agreed several months ago to accept the Martin Luther King Jr. Peace Award from Friends World College, a tiny Quaker school which requires its 550 students to live in two foreign countries and learn two foreign languages in order to graduate. The Huntington, L.I. college was euphoric. So were many others, and they all wanted to attend the ceremony. The demand from ``major political people and major corporate people'' was tremendous, said college president Lawrence Weiss. Among the prospective guests are New York Gov. Mario Cuomo, former Costa Rican President Oscar Arias (himself a former winner of the award) and a passle of New York politicians from Congress and the state legislature. By Tuesday Weiss had persuaded the Soviets to give him 20 slots.
