He was agitating for 50 on Wednesday. ``It's a historical event,'' he said. ``A lot of Americans are very attracted to Gorbachev and would like to see him in person and shake his hand and be photographed doing that.'' The hottest events are the state dinner featuring opera singer Frederica von Stade and a dinner Friday night at the Soviet Embassy. President Bush compiled the list for the White House event, based on suggestions from friends, aides and the State Department. Invitations to about 130 prospective guests were mailed 10 days ago. And while Bush aides won't discuss turndowns, at least one prominent Washingtonian had to send his regrets to both the White House and embassy dinners. Mstislav Rostropovich, a Soviet emigre who is music director of the National Symphony Orchestra, will be conducting both nights at the Kennedy Center and can't go to either event, said spokeswoman Tiki Davies. Arthur Hartman, a former ambassador to the Soviet Union, isn't going to any events, either. His daughter is getting married. ``We have a wedding this week, and we chose the date before they did,'' he said. Other coveted invitations include those for an ``intellectuals'' luncheon Thursday at the Soviet Embassy and a reception later that day at the Library of Congress, where Raisa Gorbachev will open an exhibit of ancient Soviet books, documents and manuscripts. Pamela Harriman, the millionaire Democratic fund-raiser, will be at both. Of course, she and Raisa go way back. Mrs. Gorbachev had tea with Harriman during the 1987 summit in Washington, and Harriman met with her for more than two hours earlier this month in Moscow. The 200 people who received courier-borne invitations last week to the Library of Congress event were selected by librarian James Billington and industrialist Armand Hammer. Many of them qualify as household names _ Supreme Court justices, Cabinet members, presidential relatives _ and many who don't are prominent in the corporate realm.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Strong Earthquake Rocks Peruvian Jungle, 67 Reported Dead
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE number of dead, injured; Pickup 7th, `Moyobamba...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Europe-Earthquake
DOC.TEXT: A powerful earthquake jolted Peru's northeastern jungle, killing at least 67 people, injuring hundreds and wrecking dozens of homes, Civil Defense authorities said today. Thirty five of the deaths Tuesday night occurred in Moyobamba, a town of 50,000 people 400 miles north of Lima, officials said. The other dead were from villages in nearby jungle areas, they said. The quake, measuring 5.8 on the Richter scale, occurred at 9:33 p.m. (10:33 p.m. EDT) Tuesday, according to the Peruvian Geophysical Institute. The epicenter was in the jungle 75 miles northeast of Moyobamba, it said. Many houses and buildings in Moyobamba were destroyed, including a downtown church, according to Gen. Jorge Ferreyro, Peru's Civil Defense chief. Electricity and telephone lines were completely cut in the region, Ferreyro said. Moyobamba has few doctors, and authorities there asked the government to send in medical staff, medicine and generators to help tend to the hundreds of injuired. Health Minister Paul Caro Gamarra said an air force plane was to leave for Moyobamba carrying doctors and emergency supplies. Health department workers have been on a nationwide strike for two months, but a union official in Lima said today workers were helping with emergency plans. The institute said the area suffered at least 20 aftershocks, including one shortly after midnight that registered 4.7 on the Richter scale. The temblor came two days before the 20th anniversary of a devastating earthquake that killed 70,000 people in northern Andes Mountains. That quake registered 7.7 on the Richter scale. An estimated 20,000 people in Yungay were buried in mud and ice that came crashing down from a nearby mountain. The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake, as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph. A quake of magnitude of 5 can cause considerable damage.

DOC.HEAD: World War II Veteran Haunted by Memories Takes Life on Memorial Day
DOC.TEXT: A veteran of the World War II invasion of Normandy, haunted by the memories of seeing his friends killed in battle, committed suicide on Memorial Day. ``He was never able to recover from the shock of being in hand-to-hand combat and seeing friends killed before his eyes,'' Wayne Mathews said of his father, James Arnold Mathews. The elder Mathers, 65, shot himself in the head at his suburban Hoover home, Wayne Mathews said Tuesday. Wayne Mathews said his father had seen psychiatrists for years for treatment of depression. ``It was helping him when he was involved with it, but it didn't stick.'' His father was 18 when he went to fight German forces in France as a tank gunner. The invasion of Normandy began on June 6, 1944, D-Day, and Mathews went in as part of the Army's second wave a day later. During a battle in Belgium, the gun on Mathews' tank jammed and he climbed out under heavy fire to clear it with a ramrod. An officer saw his heroism and helped him get the Bronze Star. In the same battle, the tank next to his was blown up, killing his best friend. Before the war ended, most of his other friends fell. After the war, he built a successful home improvement company and raised four children, but friends said the man who appeared to be a witty charmer could never shake his vivid memories of the war. ``He was not wiped out instantaneously in combat, but I really think the scars he sustained in a combat situation did claim him. It just took it a long time. I would say the war probably invaded his life every day,'' said Chris Doss, a Samford University law professor. Mathews' funeral was scheduled for Thursday at Elmwood Chapel in Birmingham.

DOC.HEAD: Duke Bill an Unconstitutional Gesture of Racism, Blacks Say
LaserPhoto covering
DOC.TEXT: A bill sponsored by former Ku Klux Klan leader David Duke to ban affirmative action easily passed the Louisiana House, enraging blacks who called it unconstitutional and a racist political ploy. The bill was designed to help Duke's campaign for the U.S. Senate, state Sen. William Jefferson charged at Wednesday news conference by the 20-member Black Legislative Caucus. ``It is simply a bill to advance the causes of Mr. David Duke. That's it. We're not going to just play a game that involves David Duke's electoral politics,'' said Jefferson. Duke is running as a Republican for the Senate seat now held by Democrat J. Bennett Johnston. The state GOP leadership, however, has endorsed another Republican, state Sen. Ben Bagert. While Duke basked in Tuesday's 65-36 victory, he acknowledged his bill would have problems ``in the liberal Senate.'' ``The Senate, being the kind of body it is, won't pass it,'' predicted Jefferson, a power in the upper chamber. State Rep. C.D. Jones, a black caucus member, told reporters Louisiana' 1.3 million blacks should be concerned only with the intent of the bill, drafted by a former Klan grand wizard whose legislative office once sold pro-Nazi books. ``The bill is in conflict with federal law and therefore is nothing in and of itself,'' said Jones. ``The issue here is the intent of the bill to divide races, the racist intent to set poor people and blacks back 25 years. ``The House vote sends a signal to the nation that it's all right to be racist, all right to be a former member of the Ku Klux Klan, that you can draw on that experience to be a member of this body. It sends a signal to corporate America that Louisiana is a place where racism is alive and well.'' Gov. Buddy Roemer said he would veto the bill if it got to his desk, but didn't expect it to clear the Senate. Duke said all his bill does ``is prohibit discrimination.'' ``For blacks to call this a racist bill is hypocrisy,'' he said. ``Those who voted with me endorsed the principle that people should be judged on individual merits, abilities and talents _ not on their race.'' Affirmative action programs are geared to help minorities overcome past discrimination, said Jones. ``Lyndon Johnson, when the Civil Rights Act was passed 25 years ago, said you cannot take people who for years have been shackled, remove the shackles, put them in a race and tell them they can now compete with everybody else evenly.'' Asked how long affirmative action programs would be needed, Jones said, ``until racism ends.'' Jefferson said he didn't believe racism is widespread in the Legislature. He said he understood the affirmative action vote might have been revenge for black defections earlier in the day on a vote to establish a state lottery. Lottery proponents blamed its defeat on three blacks, longtime supporters who didn't vote for the measure because they didn't like certain amendments to the bill. ``I don't think it's a good trade to get upset about a lottery vote and then vote the other way on a basic human rights issue,'' Jefferson said. Duke's affirmative action bill got only 36 votes last year but many of those who voted against him in 1989 backed his latest measure. ``I think maybe the lottery affected one or two votes,'' Duke said. ``But, I had the votes to pass it, lottery or not.'' Roemer said he hopes the rest of America doesn't judge Louisiana on the basis of the House vote. ``I have trouble with the author. He sends all kinds of wrong signals,'' Roemer said. ``The signal is not what the author says but that the state is open to everyone, black and white and from whatever part of the world they come. ``Watch our actions, and not the words of one legislator or even one vote in the House. A lot of those votes have complex feelings behind them, including feelings of the failure of old affirmative action programs. We have new programs.''

DOC.HEAD: New Homes Sales Continue Decline
With AM-Economy
DOC.TEXT: New home sales plummeted in April to their lowest level since the nation's economy emerged from the 1981-82 recession, the government said Wednesday. Analysts attributed the fifth consecutive decline to continued double-digit mortgage rates. The Commerce Department reported that new home sales totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 546,000 units in April, the smallest number since 521,000 units were sold in December 1982. ``We're seeing the worst of it right now,'' said economist Mark M. Zandi of Regional Financial Associates in West Chester, Pa. ``In April and early May, mortgage rates were at their highest levels and have come back down since then.'' According to national surveys by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp., recent mortgage rates peaked at 10.67 percent during the first week in May and had fallen to 10.33 percent by last Friday. The rates ranged between 10.25 percent and 10.56 percent in April. Thomas Holloway, an economist with the Mortgage Bankers Association, said the recent decline may help sales in the near-term but that rates would track in the range of 10.25 percent to 10.5 percent for the rest of the year. On the other hand, John A. Tuccillo, chief economist with the National Association of Realtors, said ``we expect mortgage rates to trend downward in the summer, which should spur sales of new homes and existing homes.'' Tuccillo said rates also have cut into sales of existing homes, which also slipped in April, down 2.1 percent. It was their third drop in four months, although sales were unchanged in March. David Seiders, chief economist with the National Association of Home Builders, said in addition to high rates, the general economic sluggishness is having an adverse affect on sales. ``Income growth and employment growth are clearly weak,'' he said. As a result of the weak sales, inventories of new homes rose to their highest level since July 1982 _ a 8.1-month backlog at the April sales pace, compared with 8.2 months during the last recession. Both median and average prices for new homes set records in April, but analysts generally agreed that reflected sales gains in the expensive Northeastern market _ the only region posting increased purchases. The median price jumped 13.8 percent, to $135,900, while the average price increased 11.2 percent, to $160,200. The median price means half of the homes cost more, half less. New home sales in the Northeast gained 18 percent, to 105,000 units, after a 34.8 percent gain in March. Few economists believe the pace can be sustained, however. ``There's no reason for a rebound in the Northeast,'' Seiders said. ``Interest rates are the same everywhere and employment is weak there. I don't expect any continuation of the percentage increases we saw in March and April.'' Sales were down 6.4 percent in the West, to 146,000 units; down 6 percent in the South, to 203,000 units; and down 2.1 percent in the Midwest, to 92,000 units. For the first four months of 1990, sales have fallen 6.8 percent, to 206,000 units.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Spill From Train Threatens Alaskan Wildlife Preserve
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with cleanup activity, environmental assessments. Adds byline. Picks up 6th graf, `Environmental officials...'
DOC.TEXT: Railroad crews pumped jet and diesel fuel off beaver ponds today after draining 10 of the derailed tanker cars that spewed 120,000 gallons into an area with wildlife and newly spawned fish. Using suction machines, they had siphoned about one-tenth of the spill by morning, said Chuck Kleeschulte, a spokesman for the state Department of Environmental Conservation. ``They should be pumping fairly furiously this morning and this afternoon to get the product off the surfaces of the two ponds,'' he said. ``The biggest concern right now is going to be with our waterborne fur-bearers _ beavers, muskrat, otters,'' said Mac McLean, a habitat biologist with the state Department of Fish and Game. He said oil had been carried at least eight miles by Goldstream Creek, and officials were concerned about Northern pike and whitefish that had just finished spawning. ``The eggs could hatch any time, and that's a pretty sensitive life stage,'' McLean said. The refined fuel is more toxic than crude oil, but also dissipates faster, officials said. The jet and diesel fuel spilled after an Alaska Railroad freight train derailed Monday 40 miles south of Fairbanks. Seven cars, each holding 20,000 gallons, ripped open, spilling fuel into beaver ponds on both sides of the track. Despite efforts to dam it, one pond was draining fuel into the creek and the 500,000-acre Minto Flats Wildlife Refuge downstream, said Pete McGee, a regional supervisor for the state Department of Environmental Conservation. More fuel probably would have run into the creek if not for the beaver dams, said Al Townsend, a biologist for the state Department of Fish and Game. Environmental officials had no immediate estimate of the threat to wildlife in the boggy, conifer-covered area, a prime nesting area for waterfowl. But when asked about the effect on the beavers, Townsend drew a finger across his throat. The cause of the derailment wasn't immediately known. The train, with a crew of three, was going about 40 mph, carrying fuel to Anchorage from the Mapco Alaska Petroleum Inc. refinery in the town of North Police, said railroad spokeswoman Vivian Hamilton. No one was injured in the accident.

DOC.HEAD: Bush, Gorbachev Still at Odds on Arms, Trade
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev arrives tonight for summit talks with President Bush that will focus on tough arms control and trade differences and search for common ground on the future of a unified Germany. The White House said Bush was in a mood of ``anticipation and confidence'' as Gorbachev wound up a brief visit to Canada and headed for his second summit with Bush and his first in Washington since he conferred with President Reagan in 1987. ``The president sees a new horizon in this meeting _ a horizon of opportunity,'' said presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. ``After their discussions we should have a much better view of a new day in East-West relations.'' The Soviet president, in terms harsher than comments made the previous day, reaffirmed his country's opposition to a united Germany belonging to NATO. ``I haven't yet heard any alternative from the West,'' Gorbachev said after meeting with Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney. ``It seems that it is just like an old record that seems to be playing the same note again and again. ... I would like us to find a new melody.'' Bush was spending his second consecutive day closeted with advisers over strategy for three days of summit talks starting Thursday. He also spoke by telephone this morning with West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and Tuesday night with Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney. Fitzwater said in a statement that Bush brings to the summit talk ``the understandings and insights of many allied leaders,'' including British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and French President Francois Mitterrand, with whom he met recently. Bush was not prepared to offer a position for future negotiations on the size of a unified German military _ a major concern of the Soviets _ Fitzwater said. The White House press secretary disputed news accounts suggesting Bush would offer assurances on limiting German forces to bolster Gorbachev's standing at home. On prospects for a trade agreement during the summit, Fitzwater said, ``I intentionally want to be vague.'' He added, ``I urge you not to rule out anything.'' ``This is an issue that really will depend on Gorbachev and Bush,'' he said. The Bush administration has held up the trade agreement to protest the Soviet Union's economic sanctions against Lithuania and Soviet failure to enact liberal emigration legislation. In a move to resolve disputed arms control issues, Col. Gen. Labronislav Omelichev, first deputy on the Soviet defense ministry's general staff, headed for Washington to enter talks on possible nuclear and conventional fores agreements for Bush and Gorbachev to announce. On the question of German troop levels, the United States still maintains such discussions should be held as part of future talks on reducing conventional forces in all of Europe, Fitzwater said. ``We are opposed to any proposal which would single out Germany for special limits,'' he said. However, Fitzwater said the summit would include ``discussions on the general question. We want to hear their concerns and their interests. We'll express our policy.'' ``This is not an issue which is linked in any way to German unity nor to the renunciation of four-power rights,'' Fitzwater said, referring to control of Germany's destiny by World War II victors Britain, France, the United States and the Soviet Union. ``President Bush will be exploring the subject with President Gorbachev from the standpoint of exploring mutually acceptable options and positions. Again, these issues are not going to be decided here,'' he said. However, an administration official who spoke on condition of anonymity said Bush hopes to nudge Gorbachev into accelerating the first round of conventional arms talks under way in Vienna, Austria, so a treaty can be completed by year's end. Bush was described as firmly opposed to a Soviet proposal that a united Germany be excluded from NATO's military structure while remaining within its political framework. Gorbachev was upbeat about the German issue as he spoke to reporters Tuesday outside Mulroney's residence in Ottawa. Gorbachev said he was confident that he and Bush will find a way to preserve the balance of power in Europe after East and West Germany are unified. Asked if he was optimistic about agreement on Germany and its membership in NATO, the Soviet leader replied: ``I am sure of that. And tell that to the American people.'' U.S. officials disclosed that Gorbachev would meet with South Korean President Roh Tae-woo in San Francisco after the Washington summit ends with a Bush-Gorbachev news conference on Sunday. The Soviet leader's plan to meet Roh was viewed as a further warming in relations between the two countries, which recently established ``consular departments'' in trade offices in each other's capitals. Before flying to Washington, Gorbachev acknowledged the emergence of a new domestic worry _ the election of political maverick Boris N. Yeltsin as president of the Russian republic _ as a major earthquake struck Eastern Europe. Gorbachev told reporters that ``everything is OK'' in the Soviet Union despite the quake that struck Romania this morning, killing eight people, injuring 260 and causing widespread damage. Tremors were felt in Moscow and Leningrad and a Soviet lawmaker said initial reports from the republic of Moldavia indicated there were an unspecified number of deaths. The Soviet leader said he saw no reason to break off his trip and return home. A major earthquake in Soviet Armenia in December 1988 forced Gorbachev to cut short a visit to the United Nations in New York, where he also met with President Reagan. In advance of the Soviet leader's early evening arrival, it was announced that Vice President Dan Quayle will meet Gorbachev briefly on Friday at the Soviet Embassy to discuss cooperation on space exploration. Arms control negotiators for the two countries, meanwhile, wrangled for more than two hours Tuesday over U.S. and Soviet conventional forces in Europe as well as their nuclear arsenals, including bombers and submarines. Meeting in secrecy at the State Department, they made some progress toward reductions in both areas. They agreed, for example, on definitions for such conventional weapons as tanks and armored personnel carriers, which will make it easier to verify that treaty terms are carried out, an official told The Associated Press on condition of anonymity. Although Secretary of State James A. Baker III's recent trip to Moscow led to agreement on sea and air-launched missiles, a handful of tough strategic weapons issues remained unsettled. Arms control issues still in dispute include whether to ban ballistic missiles with multiple warheads and the number of flight tests the Soviets could conduct of their heavy SS-18 missiles. The arsenal of such missiles is to be halved, from 308 to 154, but there is no agreement restricting improvement in the missiles that remain. Bush and Gorbachev still are expected to issue a joint declaration of progress toward a major reduction in nuclear arsenals, officials said, but they cautioned that long-range nuclear weapon issues still disputed may be excluded from that declaration. On the economic front, State Department spokeswoman Margaret D. Tutwiler said Tuesday that a new commercial air travel agreement has been initialed. Officials said it will be ready for signing at the summit.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Narrow Convention Field to New Orleans, New York
DOC.TEXT: Democrats narrowed the competition for their 1992 convention site to New Orleans and New York on Wednesday and party chairman Ronald H. Brown said the final choice remained ``wide open.'' After receiving the dual recommendation from the party's site-selection committee, Brown said he would visit both cities and that he anticipated ``tough negotiations'' before making his decision in mid-June. The Democratic chairman is on track to settle on the convention city at the earliest date in recent memory, hoping to ``get behind us housekeeping details.'' The Democratic convention is scheduled to run from July 16 through July 19, 1992. The Republicans have just begun their selection process and are expected to complete it next January. In New York, Mayor David Dinkins said, ``We will redouble our efforts from this point on to host the convention because no one can do it better than New York City.'' ``We're very pleased at this news of course,'' he said. ``Should we lose to New Orleans we will all go forth and support New Orleans as we anticipate New Orleans would support us.'' Brown and other party officials were determinedly positive in their assessments of the four cities that bid for the convention. The chairman dismissed speculation he was concerned about the potential for embarrassing demonstrations in either New Orleans or New York. ``I am not one of those that believes the site of the convention sends a major political message,'' said Brown. The two losers at this stage in the competition were Houston and Cleveland. Members of the selection committee went out of their way to praise Cleveland's bid. ``I would not be surprised to find us in Cleveland in 1996 as we renominate our Democratic president,'' said Anne Campbell. In Cleveland, Mayor Michael R. White said the city's effort would be useful in preparing a bid for the 1996 Democratic convention and the 1992 Republican National Convention. ``There's nothing to be ashamed of here,'' White said at a news conference. Houston was not considered a serious contender because of its inability to guarantee the Democrats the long-term access they required to the hall, in that case the Astrodome, where the Houston Astros baseball team plays its home games. New Orleans, the site of the 1988 Republican National Convention, has the Superdome, a huge stadium that could easily accommodate the 5,500 delegates and alternates and additional thousands of spectators. Madison Square Garden in New York presents size problems but city officials have assured the Democrats they can make adjustments to provide for additional seating. Asked about the difference in the halls, Brown said, ``I don't know that that is going to be a major factor in the decision.'' Supporters of New Orleans argued that the Louisiana city would prove far more affordable than New York for most delegates. Brown insisted that New York, where he grew up, also has an abundance of affordable hotels and restaurants. Of far greater concern to many party officials was the potential for street demonstrations. Racial tensions have been extremely high in New York in recent weeks, while New Orleans is in an area considered a stronghold of the anti-abortion movement. Once again, Brown dismissed suggestions that negative factors would weigh heavily in his decision. ``We are the party of choice (on abortion),'' he said. ``It is not where the convention is held, but what is said from the podium,'' he added.

DOC.HEAD: Zoo Keeper Recovering After Mauling by Leopard
DOC.TEXT: A zoo keeper who screamed ``help me! help me!'' after a 70-pound Persian leopard bit his neck was up and about Wednesday, a day after the attack, a hospital spokeswoman said. Alan Feinberg, 41, was in fair condition at San Francisco General Hospital, where doctors stitched up his wounds, said the spokeswoman, Gloria Rodriquez. It was the second attack by an animal at the zoo this year. Zoo officials were investigating why the female leopard, named Fatima, attacked Feinberg, a zoo keeper for 18 years. Zoo director David Anderson said the 14-year-old leopard may have attacked as the keeper reached into the cage for a bone. Feinberg was standing in the keeper's area of the cage when the attack occurred. He had apparently opened the gate that separates the keeper's area from the exhibit area, Anderson said, making it possible for the animal to attack. The gate to the exhibit area is supposed to remain closed. ``Keepers are never supposed to be in there,'' he said. ``Maybe he thought the animals weren't in there.'' The mauling took place as a group of schoolchildren watched. ``The leopard had him by the neck and wouldn't let go until the other keeper came and poked him,'' said Berry Accius, 15, of San Rafael. ``I thought the leopard was going to kill him,'' said Othon Franco, also 15 and from San Rafael. ``He was screaming, `Help me! Help me! Get him off! Get him off!''' Senior zoo keeper Tony Colonese, alerted by a visitor, ran to the cage and poked the leopard with a shovel until the animal released Feinberg. Other keepers pulled the injured man from the cage. A spokesman for the zoo said it was investigating the attack. Veterinarians examining Fatima found only superficial wounds, probably caused by the shovel. Contacted at the hospital, Feinberg refused to comment. In February, a keeper's back was fractured when he was knocked into a moat by a 7,000-pound elephant.

DOC.HEAD: No Easy Answer to the German Question for Gorbachev, Bush
With AM-Summit Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev open their summit meeting with no clear answer to the German question: How does a united German nation fit into a Europe still haunted by the memories of Nazi aggression. Bush has made it clear he favors a united Germany as a full member of the U.S.-led NATO alliance. But he is also said to be prepared to explore ``options and positions'' on the size of Germany's armed forces. Gorbachev is portrayed by Soviet officials as unlikely to be convinced by Bush that the new Germany should be a full-fledged NATO member. Indeed, he said Wednesday in Canada, before flying to Washington for the summit, that such an idea was ``just like an old record that seems to be playing the same note again and again.'' In Washington, Georgi Arbatov, director of the Soviet Institute for U.S. and Canada Studies, said, ``A military alliance against the Soviet Union, that's the way we see NATO. It's an ominous question for us.'' White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said Wednesday, ``We are opposed to any proposal which would single out Germany for special limits.'' However, he added, ``President Bush will be exploring the subject with President Gorbachev from the standpoint of exploring mutually acceptable options and positions.'' The Soviet Union suffered heavy losses at the hands of the Germans in World War II, and feelings about that time still run deep half a century later. ``The size of the Bundeswehr is of obvious concern to the Soviets, and we understand that,'' said a U.S. official who commented on condition he not be identified by name. The West German armed forces currently number some 494,000. The East German military stood at 173,000 last year but may have been cut somewhat since. It is unclear how many of East Germans might be absorbed into the unified German military. At present there are 380,000 Soviet troops stationed in East Germany and 250,000 U.S. troops in West Germany. In December, the two superpowers agreed to slash their central European forces to 195,000 each, with the United States allowed to keep an additional 30,000 troops in Britain and southern Europe. With actual cuts yet to be made, there are now 305,000 U.S. troops and an estimated 565,000 Soviet troops in Europe. Gorbachev told reporters in Ottawa on Tuesday he is confident that he and Bush will find a way to preserve the balance of power in Europe. Asked if he was optimistic about agreement on Germany and whether it should be a NATO member, the Soviet leader replied: ``I am sure of that. And tell that to the American people.'' Bush has made his own position clear. ``I want to convince Mr. Gorbachev ... that a U.S. presence in Europe, a unified Germany, a Germany in NATO, not only is no threat to the Soviet Union, but preserves the kind of stable Europe that the Soviets should welcome,'' Bush said in an interview broadcast last weekend to the Soviet Union. ``I believe in President Bush's eloquence, but it is hard for me to believe that he could manage to do this,'' Arbatov told a news conference on Tuesday. Assistant Secretary of State Raymond Seitz, speaking with reporters Wednesday, said a Soviet attempt to define the terms of German membership in NATO ``is unacceptable to us.'' The United States, he said, wants rapid unification, in ``an orderly fashion'' with Germany enjoying the privileges and responsibilities of all other nations in Europe. ``That doesn't seem to be the Soviet approach,'' he said. The Soviets have ``a lot of legitimate concerns'' which the United States and its allies must address, ``but not at the cost of a fully sovereign Germany,'' Seitz said. The goal should be a Europe ``in which everyone will feel safe,'' including the Soviet Union, Arbatov said.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Says it Foiled Palestinian Attack on Beachfront Hotels
DOC.TEXT: Israeli soldiers killed four Palestinian guerrillas and captured 12 on Wednesday as they sped toward the coastline in speedboats to launch attacks coinciding with the Jewish holiday of Shavuot. The guerrilla faction of Abul Abbas, mastermind of the Achille Lauro hijacking, claimed responsibility. It claimed all the boats reached their targets and that 11 guerrillas escaped and rocketed the coast at Tel Aviv and nearby towns. The group said the attacks were in retaliation for the killing of seven Palestinians by an Israeli civilian last week, and for the assassination of a Palestinian military leader two years ago. The Israeli army said the guerrillas planned to attack beachfront hotels filled with people celebrating Shavuot, which marks the giving of the Ten Commandments. The six small speedboats were sent from a mothership that sailed from Libya, the army alleged. No Israelis were killed or injured, the army said, although one guerrilla speedboat outran an Israeli patrol boat and splashed ashore near a crowded Mediterranean beach club. Police evacuated a 30-mile stretch of coast south of Tel Aviv jammed with people on holiday. Of the six guerrilla vessels, only two got near shore, authorities said. One carried 11 Palestinians. It was attacked by helicopters and troops as it sliced into an almost empty beach near Nizzanim, 18 miles south of Tel Aviv. Four guerrillas were killed there and seven captured, the army said. Zvi Amitai, a resident of the Nizzanim communal farm, said he was collecting driftwood when he saw the speedboat and heard gunfire. The guerrillas landed 20 yards away from him. ``They jumped from the boat and didn't shoot, as if they didn't see us,'' he said. ``They just ran for the dunes. I certainly feel like I won the lottery.'' Five other guerrillas surrendered aboard another boat that was intercepted by Israeli vessels near a beach north of Tel Aviv. The other vessels broke down or were abandonded at sea, the army said. The armed forces chief of staff, Lt. Gen. Dan Shomron, said the attack boats were armed with rockets, machine guns and anti-aircraft missiles. ``The security forces ... were able to frustrate today an operation that, if it was carried out successfully, would have caused a great many casualties to Israeli citizens,'' he told a news conference in Tel Aviv. Army intelligence chief Maj. Gen. Amnon Shahak told the same news conference: ``The goal was to attack the hotels in the Tel Aviv region to conduct a massacre.'' Deputy Foreign Minister Benjamin Netanyahu claimed the PLO violated its pledge not to engage in terrorism and was responsible for an act that could have ``plunged this whole region into bloodshed and a broad war.'' It was unclear whether the attack had the endorsement of PLO chief Yasser Arafat, who pledged in December 1988 to abandon terrorism. The faction that claimed responsibility is the Palestine Liberation Front, a pro-Arafat faction. Its leader is Mohammed Abbas, whose nom de guerre is Abul Abbas. An Italian court convicted him in absentia of masterminding the 1985 hijacking of the Italian cruise ship Achille Lauro, during which American Leon Klinghoffer was killed. Abbas was sentenced to life in prison, but his whereabouts is not known. A PLF spokesman said Abbas was not in Iraq, where Arab leaders Wednesday concluded a three-day summit with a sharp denunciation of U.S. policies toward Israel. Foreign Minister Moshe Arens said he hoped the incident would convince Washington of the need to abandon its dialogue with the PLO. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said in Washington, ``The United States is horrified at this terrorist attack.'' She added that if it is determined the attackers had PLO connections, ``we would view this as a very serious matter.'' In Baghdad, PLF representative Hussein el-Abed said the attack was aimed at ``teaching the enemy a new lesson on the road to liberating Palestine.'' He said the attack was in revenge for the killing of PLO military chief Khalil Al-Wazir, whose death in Tunis in April 1988 was widely blamed on Israel. The front, in statements issued in Lebanon and Iraq, said the raid also was in retaliation for the killing of seven Palestinians by an Israeli civilian last week. It said 15 guerrillas _ not 16, as Israeli officials reported _ attacked points near Tel Aviv. ``All the boats succeeded in reaching their specified targets,'' it said. Al-Abed confirmed that four guerrillas were killed but denied the others were captured. The Israeli army said the mothership fled toward Port Said in Egypt and that Egyptian authorities were notified. Sunday's attack also came amid a cycle of violence set off by the May 20 massacre of the Palestinian laborers. The slaying touched off riots in the occupied territories that left 15 Palestinians dead. A pipe bomb explosion in a crowded market killed an elderly Israeli man. Wednesday's raid was the largest Palestinian infiltration attempt by sea since March 11, 1978, when a dozen guerrillas from Arafat's Fatah PLO faction came ashore north of Tel Aviv and hijacked a bus. The bus headed for Tel Aviv and 33 people died in a shootout between the guerrillas and Israeli forced. The last infiltration was on March 8, 1988, when another Fatah squad infiltrated from Egypt and hijacked a bus near Tel Aviv. Three passengers were killed and eight wounded.

DOC.HEAD: Presbyterians Elect Lay Leader
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with election of moderator, quotes from new leader. Picks up 7th graf, `No official....'
Eds: SalmonCampbell cq
DOC.TEXT: Delegates to the annual convention of the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) today elected a 67-year-old layman to lead the 2.9 million-member denomination for the next year. Price H. Gwynn III of Charlotte, N.C., captured almost 53 percent of the votes on the second ballot at the denomination's 202nd General Assembly. Gwynn, immediately took office as moderator, replacing the Rev. Joan SalmonCampbell of Philadelphia. Gwynn became the eighth moderator since factions of the church reunited in 1983, healing a Civil War-era split over slavery. He was one of six men seeking the position. During his nomination speech, Gwynn said Presbyterians were more concerned about a perceived malaise in leadership than whether homosexuals should be ordained _ an issue the 10-day assembly may address. ``The question I'm asked is do we have our act together up here... can we put aside our differences to get our act together in the world,'' Gwynn told the assembly. The first meeting of the Protestant denomination in predominantly Mormon Utah began Tuesday night with a worship service where SalmonCampbell urged partipants to be humble and gentle with each other. The denomination was planning to take action on its first statement of faith since the 1983 merger. The proposed statement mixes traditional Christian beliefs with more modern concerns for the environment and sexual equality. Resolutions on the environment, U.S.-Cuban relations and Northern Ireland also were on the agenda. No official dialogue is planned between the Presbyterians and the Mormon Church, although private meetings are scheduled between Mormon leaders and the Presbyterian Inter-Faith Office. Further, the conference will consider a paper on healthy relations between Mormons and Presbyterians in Utah. While 70 percent of Utah's 1.7 million people are Mormons, the next largest denomination is Roman Catholic, with an estimated 5 percent, or 80,000 members. The Presbyterians have 5,000 members, or about six-tenths of 1 percent. Church officials acknowledge it is unusual to hold its annual assembly where there are so few Presbyterians, but say the Salt Lake meetings are in response to local Presbyterians seeking recognition in Utah. During Tuesday night's service, delegates were urged to fill out prayer cards, some of which were used during the service. Participants were asked to take a card and pray for the request throughout the convention. The service focused on children with children's choirs and dancers, and a special Prayer of the Children, written by Richard Wunder of Salt Lake. SalmonCampbell told commissioners and visitors to be mindful of their behavior _ in thought, word and action. She urged them to work together in humility and to be gentle with one another, ``positive in Christ's love.'' She told commissioners that in such a democratic body, they can expect conflict and disagreement, but to remember the life, death and resurrection of the savior. ``The presence of the spirit waits to assist each of us in doing God's work,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Postal Service Says Some Doonesbury Stamps Appearing
DOC.TEXT: ``Doonesbury'' protest stamps are starting to zonk their way into the mail, the Postal Service said Wednesday. Cartoonist Garry Trudeau included a sheet of mock stamps, featuring Zonker Harris of the Doonesbury comic strip, in Sunday papers May 20. The stamps carry the legend ``Mad as Heck'' and ``Ticked Off'' and show a value of -5, which the comic strip indicates is -5 cents. The stamps were intended to protest the coming increase in postal rates from 25 cents to 30 cents. Postal Service spokesman Lou Eberhardt said an empty envelope from California bearing two of the stamps arrived at Postmaster Anthony Frank's office and that a few others have also been delivered. But Eberhardt said he did not know how many of the stamps were used. He said many envelopes with the stamps may have ended up in dead letters offices for lack of postage. Some may have gotten through because of the large volume of mail postal workers handle. Eberhardt said Frank finds Trudeau's work funny and takes the stamps in the manner in which they were intended _ as a protest. Eberhardt said letter-writers should have no problem if they put the cartoon stamps in addition to valid 25-cent stamps on their mail. But if the Doonesbury stamps are the only ``postage'' on a letter, that's not legal postage. If the letters appear to be of value they would then either be returned to the sender marked insufficient postage or to the addressee marked postage due, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanian Leaders Ask Bush, Gorbachev to Deal With Baltic Republic
With AM-Summit Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Lithuanian leaders appealed to Presidents Bush and Gorbachev Wednesday to ``solve'' at their summit the question of the breakaway Baltic Republic where oil shortages threaten to shut down heating systems. The Soviet economic blockade of Lithuania could also force the shutdown of a nuclear power station that relies on electricity to function, Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene said in a videotaped appearance broadcast in the United States. Prunskiene and Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis made their comments together in Vilnius on Tuesday. The session was beamed by satellite to the United States on the day Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev was arriving for a four-day summit with President Bush. Lithuania is likely to be a topic of contention between the two superpower leaders. The United States has urged the Soviet Union to negotiate with Lithuanians about their future. ``We still hope that the negotiations taking place in Washington will be in accordance with the attitudes of the American public and will help solve the Lithuanian question,'' Prunskiene said. She said the economic situation in Lithuania is dire. Gorbachev imposed the sanctions after Lithuania declared its independence March 11. ``During this week, if there is no repeal of the restrictions in furnishing Lithuania with a variety of products, especially oil, then the situation becomes essentially critical,'' Prunskiene said. The nuclear power plant the Lithuanians say might have to close supplies power to the region of Kaliningrad, which houses several Soviet military bases. Landsbergis said it would be impossible for Lithuanians to return to the status they had before they declared independence. ``Is it really possible to turn back the clock of history, even by three months?'' he asked. ``Besides, why should it be turned back? What are the arguments?''

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev's Style Poses Security Headaches _ With Some Advantages
With AM-Summit Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Demonstration organizers say their efforts will be peaceful during Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev's visits to Minneapolis-St. Paul and San Francisco, but city, state and federal agencies are beefing up security anyway. Protest groups and police shared one problem: Gorbachev's changing schedule. ``The bad part is it doesn't give us much time to plan how to protect him,'' said Richard McDrew, agent in charge of the Secret Service in San Francisco. ``The good part is it doesn't give a potential assassin time to plan, either. If we don't know exactly what he is going to do, neither does anyone else.'' The flags of the Baltic republics will fly Sunday in Minneapolis to show Gorbachev that emigrants in Minnesota support the push for independence by the Soviet republics of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia. ``We will be demonstrating for Baltic independence, not against Gorbachev coming here,'' said Karin Berkholtz, a Latvian-American member of the Governor's Commission on Eastern Europe. ``Our ultimate goal is to show Gorbachev that `Everywhere you go there will be people who feel the same way that they do back in Eastern Europe,''' Berkholtz said. Between 500 and 1,000 people of Eastern European descent are expected to participate in non-disruptive demonstrations during the six hours the Soviet president is in Minnesota. After Minnesota, Gorbachev will go on to San Francisco, and then leave the United States on Monday. The planned Minnesota demonstrations ``are not meant to offend anyone,'' said Walter Anastas, the Ukrainian representative on the Governor's Commission on Eastern Europe. ``We want to express to Gorbachev and to our fellow Minnesotans that we have concerns about the human right of national self-determination.'' ``We're planning a peaceful demonstration, in keeping with the peaceful revolution in the Baltics,'' said Joe Sidas, spokesman for the Baltic Alliance in San Francisco. Security will be tight. Sharpshooters will be posted on buildings at every location the Gorbachevs will visit in California. Dozens of Highway Patrol cars will line the 35 miles between San Francisco and Stanford University during their drive Monday to the campus. McDrew said the Secret Service will have hundreds of agents in San Francisco from around the country leading a security operation that will involve thousands of officers. The San Francisco Police Department will have 1,775 officers and the Stanford University police will have 30 officers, bolstered by Santa Clara County sheriff's deputies, to deal with demonstrations planned by Armenians, Estonians, Lithuanians, Latvians, Soviet Jews and Eritreans from Ethiopia. Minnesota State Patrol Chief Kevin Kittridge said tentative plans are for 150 to 200 state troopers from around the state to be brought into St. Paul for Sunday's visit. ``We've canceled everyone's day off,'' he said. But in Minneapolis, police Sgt. Keith Oldfather said there's been no blanket prohibition on officers taking a scheduled day off Sunday and that he doesn't expect one, although he said plans are not firm because Gorbachev's itinerary is not set. ``It's very likely we won't know until the last minute or last day exactly what we are going to do, in which case all our planning and worrying was for nothing,'' said Minneapolis police Lt. Jim Heimerl. If Gorbachev ventures into crowds to talk with protesters, as he has in the past, it will present a risk, said McDrew, but one that the Secret Service is preparing to handle. ``Extemporaneous visits and unplanned movements are things we've handled before,'' he said. ``It's pretty difficult sometimes. John F. Kennedy didn't want a bulletproof top on his car in Dallas. We'd like to have the best security at all times, but we have to adapt to the circumstances.''

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: The Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh, president emeritus of the University of Notre Dame and holder of the world's most honorary doctorates, has added another notch to his cap and gown. Hesburgh just took on his 121st honorary degree, a doctorate of honorary letters, from St. Olaf College in Northfield, Minn. He delivered a speech at the school's 100th anniversary commencement on Sunday. Hesburgh's academic laurels already are listed in the Guinness Book of World Records. The priest, who retired as Notre Dame president in 1987, passed Herbert Hoover's 89 honorary degrees in 1982.

Longtime Hollywood star Douglas Fairbanks Jr. reminisced about growing up in Rhode Island on a trip here to plug a new television program. Fairbanks, 80, is host of ``Romance Classics'' on cable television's American Movie Classics and was at Providence College to introduce a screening of ``Wuthering Heights.'' Fairbanks was not in ``Wuthering Heights,'' although he said he took a test for the classic, which established the late Laurence Olivier with American audiences. ``It was so bad that it was shown for a joke,'' he said of his own screen test. Fairbanks recalled Tuesday the summers he spent in Westerly, where his mother married his father long before stage actor Douglas Fairbanks went off to Hollywood to become a silent screen star. The house where they stayed, Kenneth Ridge, is now a rest home for nuns. On a visit a few years ago, Fairbanks asked ``if they ever looked into the secret panels,'' he said. ``They didn't know anything about it. But I knocked on the walls and found it. Inside there were three or four pieces of statuary,'' he said.

A court battle between comedian Pat Paulsen and his former wife is no joke, with Paulsen claiming she defrauded him of $200,000 and Linda Chaney-Paulsen accusing him of racketeering, libel and slander. Paulsen testified Tuesday in Jefferson County Court that he set Chaney-Paulsen up in the booking business and she repaid him by diverting money from business accounts of Pat Paulsen Enterprises Inc. in Lakewood. She also hid business records from him, leaked harmful stories about him to the National Enquirer and faked illnesses to get his sympathy, Paulsen alleges in his lawsuit. Among other charges, Chaney-Paulsen claims in a countersuit that the comedian married her, then filed for divorce simply to take over the business that was in her name. She also claims Paulsen's income rose dramatically while she arranged his bookings.

Former U.S. Sen. John Tower has had his cancerous prostate removed. Tower, 64, underwent surgery Tuesday at Zale Lipshy University Hospital. ``I'll be out of here in a week, and I'll be back to normal again real soon,'' Tower said in telephone interview from his hospital room Tuesday night. ``And one thing for sure _ I'll never have prostate cancer again because they took my prostate out.'' He was listed in good condition Wednesday, said hospital spokeswoman Susan Rutherford. Tower had a previous brush with cancer. A rectal polyp removed in December 1988 contained some malignant cells. In January 1989, a non-malignant polyp was removed from his colon. Tower's physician, Dr. Paul Peters, said Tower's recovery should be ``unusually good.'' President Bush reportedly is considering naming Tower chairman of the President's Foreign Intelligence Advisory Council. Tower was appointed to the board last year after the Senate refused to confirm him as defense secretary, amid allegations about his personal life and possible conflicts of interest.

Actor Michael Douglas was picked to receive the third annual Spencer Tracy Award, joining William Hurt and Jimmy Stewart as recipients of the honor praising standard-setting performances. The award, presented Wednesday, was established by Susie Tracy, the late actor's daughter, at the University of California, Los Angeles, to pay tribute to a Hollywood star whose instinctive, natural style sets him apart from other actors. Douglas won three successive television Emmy Award nominations for his role in the old ``The Streets of San Francisco.'' He won an Academy Award for his role in ``Wall Street.'' His movie credits include ``Romancing the Stone,'' ``Fatal Attraction,'' ``Black Rain'' and ``War of the Roses.''

DOC.HEAD: Arkansas Governor Faces Businessman; Ex-Mayor Takes on Kentucky Senator
DOC.TEXT: A millionaire who once ran the largest utility in Arkansas won a mudslinging Republican primary and will challenge Democratic Gov. Bill Clinton, whose party nominated him for a fifth term. The former head of Arkla Inc., Sheffield Nelson, beat Rep. Tommy Robinson in a GOP race that was dominated by bitter accusations over both men's relationship with Dallas Cowboys' owner Jerry Jones. In another primary Tuesday, Kentucky Democrats picked former Louisville Mayor Harvey Sloane to challenge U.S. Sen. Mitch McConnell, who had no trouble winning the Republican nomination for a second term. Clinton had a somewhat tougher time than expected winning the Democratic nomination for governor. Pre-election polls had shown him with as much as a 30-point lead, but he won the race by 15 percentage points over his closest challenger, Tom McRae. With 98 percent of the precincts reporting, Clinton had 261,005 votes, or 54 percent, to 187,823, or 39 percent, for McRae, the former president of the Winthrop Rockefeller Foundation. Four other challengers split the remaining 7 percent. Clinton, who has been discussed as a potential presidential candidate, said he wasn't disappointed. ``I feel great,'' he said. ``We ran better than we thought we would ... in a lot of places.'' ``Anybody in this campaign can tell you,'' he added, ``I was always more worried about this race than the general _ always.'' Nelson captured the GOP race by a 55-to-45 percent margin. With 94 percent of the precincts reporting, he had 47,690 votes to Robinson's 39,515. The rancor of the campaign apparently helped deliver a record turnout for a Republican primary in Arkansas _ at least 87,000 voters, compared with 68,000 in the 1988 GOP presidential primary. Robinson, a lifelong friend of Jones, had criticized Nelson's business relationship with the Cowboys owner. That, in turn, led to a rift between Robinson and Jones. ``Now let me talk to the ones we defeated tonight,'' Nelson said in his victory speech. ``I appeal to Tommy Robinson and his people to come over and join us and let's have a unified effort to move forward to November.'' In Kentucky, Sloane defeated state schools Superintendent John Brock in the Democratic primary. McConnell overwhelmed perennial candidate Tommy Klein in the GOP race. Final, unofficial returns gave Sloane 183,629 votes, or 59 percent, to Brock's 125,496 votes, or 41 percent. McConnell had 64,019 votes, or 89 percent, to Klein's 8,219 votes, or 11 percent. Voters also renominated veteran Democratic congressmen in both states. In Kentucky, Rep. Romano Mazzoli defeated former television newsman Jeffrey Hutter and Alderman Paul Bather to capture nomination for an 11th term. He faces a general election challenge from Republican Al Brown, a personnel consultant who defeated businessman Tim Hardy. In Arkansas, Rep. Bill Alexander, who has served in Congress for 22 years, fended off a strong Democratic primary challenge from lawyer Mike Gibson, a political newcomer with strong business backing. Alexander faces Republican challenger Terry Hayes in November.

DOC.HEAD: Aviation Pioneer Arthur Woodley Dies at 84
DOC.TEXT: Arthur Woodley, an aviation pioneer who brought air shuttle service to Alaska at a time when dog teams were used to transport supplies there, has died at age 84. Woodley died Monday at his home in this Seattle suburb. The cause of death was not given. In 1932, Woodley founded Woodley Airways, which offered passenger service between Anchorage and Nome with the motto ``Have Plane, Will Travel.'' It was a one-plane, one-pilot operation, but quickly caught on as an alternative to the month-long dog-sled journey. It also was cheaper. Woodley charged passengers $150; the dog-sled trip cost $750. ``There was an obvious need for an airline in Alaska, and dad saw the need,'' said his son, Gordon, of Bellevue. Woodley extended credit to his passengers until the end of each trapping season. He estimated he was owed $300,000 in 1935, but it was all eventually paid. After Alaska's 1964 earthquake, with airports and airlines shut down, Woodley stepped in. ``Dad said, `We're flying,' and he flew in everyone who had to get in, and he flew out everyone he had to get out,'' his son recalled. ``He never charged for it.'' After World War II, Woodley changed his airline name to Pacific Northern Airlines. He later sold to Western Airlines and became a vice president of Western until he retired in 1971. Woodley is survived by his wife, Miriam, three sons and six grandchildren.

DOC.HEAD: Cop Throws The Book _ Phone Book _ at Speeder
DOC.TEXT: Officer Jim Viola had to think quickly. A motorcyclist was trying to get away after a 120 mph chase. If Viola didn't catch him, no one would. So, faster than you can say ``Information, please,'' Viola threw the book at him. The phone book. ``I let him have it in the face,'' Viola said. ``It stunned him ... When you're going 20 to 25 and get hit with a phone book, it gets your attention.'' Bobby Roberson, 30, was booked with driving while intoxicated, going more than 100 mph in a 55 mph zone, reckless driving, flight from police and numerous traffic violations, said state police Trooper David Staton. Viola said the only way to catch Roberson was by throwing the phone book, which he keeps with him because he has a portable phone. Staton said the chase began Wednesday morning when he tried to stop Roberson for weaving between lanes on U.S. 80 near Louisiana Downs. ``As soon as I turned on my lights, he saw me and hit (Interstate) 220 and opened it up,'' Staton said. He said the motorcyclist tried to shake him by racing down a stretch of road under construction, then taking a zig-zag 10-to 12-mile route up, down and around Bossier City. He turned around at one roadblock, drove around three more, and slowed to drive around Viola's car, also parked for a roadblock, police said. ``I was the last unit I saw,'' said Viola. ``I knew if I didn't stop him he was going to get away.'' After Viola threw the book, Roberson fell into a ditch. He was scratched but otherwise unhurt, Viola said. ``That's what is called directory assistance,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Terry Waite Turns 51 Years Old In Captivity
DOC.TEXT: Anglican church envoy Terry Waite turns 51 Thursday, more than three years after he disappeared in Beirut while trying to negotiate the freedom of other Western captives. No group has claimed it holds him, and there has been no word on his fate. But Western and Lebanese intelligence officials are convinced he is held by a Moslem group known as Islamic Jihad. He marks his 51st birthday a day after a Moslem Shiite cleric with ties to kidnap groups said British hostages in Lebanon could be released sooner if Britain expels author Salman Rushdie. Rushdie, who is in hiding under the protection of British authorities, wrote ``The Satanic Verses.'' The novel offended many Moslems and prompted the late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini of Iran to issue a death threat against the author in February 1989. Moslem fundamentalist leader Hussein Musawi said Wednesday the deportation of Rushdie would ``greatly facilitate the release of some British hostages.'' Musawi, who heads the pro-Syrian faction within the Iranian-backed Hezbollah did not provide names of the hostages he had in mind. British official have said they will not deport Rushdie. Waite's brother, David Waite, said Wednesday that no events were planned in Britain to mark the birthday. ``We think of Terry every day since he has been taken and tomorrow will be just the same, and we'll all be thinking about him,'' he told The Associated Press. ``We've been very encouraged'' by freed U.S. hostage Frank Reed's account of seeing British hostages John McCarthy and Brian Keenan, Waite's brother added. Reed and a second U.S. hostage, Robert Polehill, were freed last month with the help of Iran and Syria. Waite said that while he supported the British government's refusal to make deals for hostages, he believed Britain should talk directly to Iran. He suggested that Britain ``mend its fences with Iran ... now that it has been proved that Iran has direct influence over the hostage-takers.'' Waite is one of 16 Westerners missing in Lebanon. They are six Americans, four Britons, two West Germans, two Swiss, an Irishman and an Italian. Besides Waite, the British captives are McCarthy, a journalist who was kidnapped April 17, 1986; ex-Royal Air Force pilot Jack Mann, kidnapped May 12, 1989; and writer Alec Collett, kidnapped March 25, 1985. In addition, teacher Brian Keenan, a Belfast man with dual British-Irish nationality, was abducted on April 11, 1986. The longest held captive is Terry Anderson, 43, of Lorain, Ohio. Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, was kidnapped in Beirut on March 16, 1985. Waite disappeared in Moslem west Beirut Jan. 20, 1987. He was last seen leaving his seaside hotel to meet with kidnappers holding Anderson and educator Thomas Sutherland. Waite, a policeman's son who became personal emissary of Archbishop of Canterbury Robert Runcie, told his Druse bodyguards he did not want them to escort him to the clandestine meeting. Western hostages freed since Waite disappeared have reported seeing a man believed to be the 6-foot, 7-inch Briton in an underground prison. Waite's disappearance provoked several rumors about his fate. He has been reported ill, released, killed, wounded while trying to escape and smuggled to Iran. An anonymous telephone caller, purporting to speak for the pro-Iranian Organization of the Oppressed on Earth, another Shiite faction, threatened to kill Waite on Aug. 1, 1989, unless Israel freed a kidnapped Shiite leader, Sheik Abdul-Karim Obeid. Though Obeid was kept imprisoned, no one later claimed Waite was killed.

DOC.HEAD: West Germany Urges State Property in East Germany Returned
DOC.TEXT: The government said Wednesday that East German property expropriated by the former Communist leadership should be returned to its original owners, some of whom now live in West Germany. The statement signaled a possible dispute with the East Berlin government over how to handle West German claims on houses, apartments and businesses in East Germany. Berlin officials insist that instead of getting their property back, former owners should be paid some sort of compensation. East Germany also says its own citizens should have first option on property that was formerly state-owned. West German experts say up to 1 million people will lay claim to property they left behind when fleeing to the West after World War II or during East Germany's 40 years of Communist rule. How to handle such claims is a sensitive issue, because in many cases the property is occupied. The issue was excluded from a treaty on merging the German economies to buy time for reaching a mutually agreeable solution. The economic merger is to occur July 2. On that date, East Germany has said it will begin dismantling state ownership, without any decision on what to do about West German claims on East German property. Chancellor Helmut Kohl's coalition government met Wednesday to discuss the fast-approaching economic merger. According to Kohl's chief spokesman, Hans Klein, the issue of private ownership came up. Klein said the Bonn government ``expressed certain expectation that private property will be guaranteed and that a socially bearable solution will be found in the short term to the still-open property questions.'' ``Expropriated property is, in principle, to be handed back. Only in exceptional cases should compensation solutions be found,'' Klein said. West Germany is apparently also waiting to hear from East Germany on how it plans to guard against currency speculators reaping profits when the West German mark becomes East Germany's own legal tender July 2. West German Finance Minister Theodor Waigel rejected demands by the opposition Social Democrats that Bonn spend additional money for East Germany's economic reconstruction. West Germany already plans massive financial help for East Germany as part of the economic merger. Up to 2 million East Germans are expected to lose their jobs and prices are expected to soar during the transition.

DOC.HEAD: Police Ready but Few Demonstrators at White House
With AM-Summit Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Dozens of police showed up to deal with an expected crowd of summit protesters near the White House Wednesday, but the only demonstrators on hand were a Soviet rock band promoting AIDS research. Lafayette Park across Pennsylvania Avenue from the presidential residence normally is protest central for meetings such as the summit this week between Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev and President Bush. And up to 2,000 demonstrators had been expected Wednesday, according to reservations issued by the U.S. Park Police to groups representing the interests of Lithuanians, Cubans, Vietnamese, South Koreans and AIDS victims. But Cure AIDS Now was the only organization that showed up, bringing along the Soviet rock band Gaza to blast out some tunes. It was the most visible, and audible, presence in the park. Other demonstrators, said one U.S. Park Police officer, ``probably figured out that Gorbachev's not even in town yet.'' Instead of protesters, the park hosted the usual groups of homeless, chess players, tourists and office workers seeking a sunny respite from their desks. At two previous summits _ in 1985 in Geneva and in 1987 in Washington when Gorbachev met with then-President Ronald Reagan _ Cure AIDS Now had demanded that each side devote the monetary equivalent of 10 missiles to eradicate the deadly disease and care for its victims, said the organization's leader, Bob Kunst. The ante is up this year. ``We want the value of 1,000 missiles now,'' said Kunst, 47. ``We see AIDS as as catastrophic as nuclear war.'' He estimated that each missile costs $180 million. As for the timing of his demonstration, he said, ``This is a little teaser, an appetizer, to take advantage of the press here. We hope Gorby sees us when he comes in, on television.'' Also in the park Wednesday was Concepcion Picciotto, 45. But then, she's been there since 1981 as part of the anti-nuclear peace vigil. ``I want to do something for humanity,'' she said, handing out a leaflet that reads: ``Every gun that is made, every warship launched, ever rocket fired, signifies a theft from those who are hungry and are not fed, from those who are cold and are not clothed.'' Misha Knight, who emigrated from the Soviet Union in 1978 because he ``did not see a future there,'' said he came to this summit to show support for the growing friendship between the United States and his homeland. He also was selling Gorbachev T-shirts _ $15 each _ and an $8 cassette tape featuring himself singing ``I Am a Gorby Man,'' and ``Give Peace a Hand,'' among other tunes.

DOC.HEAD: Armenians, Baltic Natives, Well-wishers Greet Gorbachev
With AM-Gorbachev, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Several hundred Armenian demonstrators lined the street outside the National Gallery of art Wednesday yelling, ``Karabakh! Karabakh!'' as Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev went inside for a brief tour. Across the street, in front of Ottawa's Cathedral, hundreds of people gathered to demonstrate on behalf of the three breakaway Baltic republics. They carried placards, waved flags and chanted in their native languages. ``It's just a reminder that whether Gorbachev's in Soviet territory or Canada, there are Baltic people everywhere,'' said Maimu Palumae, a 23-year-old Canadian of Estonian extraction who protested earlier outside Parliament. Albin Barsauskas, 71, said he was one of 94 members of the Lithuanian Golden Age Club of Montreal who arrived in Ottawa on two buses. Although he did not see Gorbachev, he said he was not disappointed. ``I don't want to shake his hand anyway,'' he said. ``I just want to ask nicely: Give us freedom, take away army, no blockade.'' Gorbachev has been struggling with the leaders of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia, which were forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940 and have been seeking to secede. He imposed economic sanctions on Lithuania after it declared its independence. He also has been troubled by violence between Armenians and Azerbaijanis. They are battling for control of the mostly Armenian enclave of Nagorno-Karabakh, which is controlled and surrounded by the republic of Azerjaijan. Armenian demonstrators outside the art gallery waved the red, blue and orange flags of their homeland. ``I'm screaming for my people,'' said Gevork Abrikian, 23, a professional musician from Armenia visiting friends in Canada. ``It may not do anything, but I'll feel a little bit better because I've done it.'' Outside Canada's gothic, gray stone Parliament building, a crowd of demonstrators estimated between 500 and 2,000 people chanted and waved flags of the three Baltic republics. Inside, Gorbachev was meeting with Prime Minister Brian Mulroney. ``Red Army: Get civilized, stop murdering our sons,'' said a placard signed, ``Latvian mothers.'' Another sign said: ``Latvia, Lithuania, Estonia are still in a Soviet labor camp.'' Some people distributed leaflets showing a caricature of Soviet tanks and the words: ``Red Army Go Home.'' Police lined the perimeter of the lawn and set up a barricade to hold back the crowd. Lauri Vahtra, 22, an Estonian visiting relatives in Canada, said he believed his republic faces a ``now-or-never'' situation. ``Everything is getting worse, economically, culturally. We need our freedom, and I think it's the last chance for us.'' Several hundred schoolchildren also gathered on the lawn outside Parliament to greet Gorbachev, not with protests but with cheers. During his two-day visit to Canada, Gorbachev twice went among Ottawans to shake hands, answer questions and chat amiably. He spent about an hour on one of his trademark ``walkabouts'' Tuesday night, and then on Wednesday walked with Mulroney a short distance from Canada's war memorial toward Parliament Hill. Imre Sooaar, 21, a deserter from the Soviet Army who arrived in Canada in March 1989, said he had shaken Gorbachev's hand and managed to speak with him three times in the last two days by following him to virtually every public appearance in Ottawa. Their longest conversation took place on a pedestrian mall Tuesday evening. ``I really felt when I was looking into his eyes that he personally would like to give us freedom,'' Sooaar said.

DOC.HEAD: Judge's Ruling Lets Chicago's Beer Gardens Roll Out the Barrels
DOC.TEXT: It's been a long, dry spring at some of Chicago's outdoor beer gardens because of a lengthy, new licensing process, but a court order temporarily turned on the taps Wednesday. Neighbors' complaints prompted the city to make taverns get permission if they wanted to serve outdoors. But a judge ruled the city was trying to do with licensing regulations what its police could not _ adequately monitor the burgeoning number of outside bars. ``It's good news for people who want to sit on Dick's Dock and drink,'' Jeremy DeBlieux, manager of Dick's Last Resort, rejoiced Wednesday as he readied his beer garden along a slip by the Chicago River. ``We lost the entire month of May,'' DeBlieux said. ``There is no catching up. But we're very, very happy that the beer will once again flow.'' On Tuesday, Cook County Circuit Judge Kenneth Gillis temporarily prohibited enforcement of the new law until June 7, when he will hear arguments on whether the ordinance should be tossed out. Two tavern owners are challenging the law. Gillis said the city apparently ``jeopardized financial interests (of the owners) as a substitute for effective police enforcement.'' The city adopted the new licensing procedure last fall; previously taverns with liquor licenses could open a garden without further review. But tavern owners say the licensing requirements are a maze from which there seems to be no exit. Of an estimated 125 taverns that previously served beer and other libations outdoors, only 21 had obtained the city's stamp of approval to open their beer gardens for business by Tuesday. Two were denied permission for gardens because of strong objections from neighbors, said John Holden of the city's Department of Revenue, which handles the licenses. He said about 110 are going through the application process. ``These bar owners brought it on themselves,'' said David Hartsell, who led a neighborhood group opposing a beer garden. ``This is not little European cafes we're talking about _ the beer garden behind my house is like `Animal House.' It's like having a frat party in my back yard every night.'' That bar, Kincade's, withdrew its application but planned to take advantage of the judge's ruling and open its garden, said owner Kevin Killerman. The ordinance requires barkeepers to head for the city's Maps Bureau, where a circle representing 250 feet is drawn around the beer garden. Then the Building Department determines what addresses fall within the circle. Next, the Board of Elections gives the owner a list of voters living within the circle. The voters are notified by registered mail of the tavern's intent, and have 30 days to respond. Owners then post notices of intent and wait at least another 21 days for city inspections of the property. ``With anything that's starting up, you expect to learn from your experience,'' Holden said. ``We don't think the process is terribly complicated.'' Mayor Richard M. Daley also stands behind the new requirements. ``We're going to go back to court ... to defend the city's position,'' mayoral spokeswoman Carolyn Grisko said. ``We think the law is important.'' Hartsell agrees. ``We hope the city vigourously defends this,'' he said. ``We don't think it's a burden or unfair that for the first time the neighbors have some input.''

DOC.HEAD: US Suggests Abortive Attack in Israel Could Affect Dialogue with PLO
With AM-Israel, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The State Department condemned the abortive terrorist attack on a crowded beach area in Israel on Wednesday, and left open the possibility that the incident could derail the U.S. dialogue with the Palestine Liberation Organization. Spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said if Israeli allegations that the PLO was behind the attack are true, ``we would view this as a very serious matter.'' Asked whether the United States would suspend its dialogue with the PLO if a faction of the organization were found to be responsible, she said, ``Our policy has not changed, but I do not want to ... rule anything in or anything out.'' The attack prompted calls by the Israeli government and the Anti-Defamation League for a suspension of the U.S.-PLO dialogue, which began in December 1988 in the waning days of the Reagan administration. The Conference of Presidents of Major Jewish Organizations called on the administration to reassess its policy of talking with the PLO. President Reagan agreed to open the dialogue after PLO chairman Yasser Arafat gave forceful assurances that the group had renounced terrorism. Lt. Gen. Dan Shomron, the armed forces chief of staff, said Wednesday the raid was carried out by the Palestine Liberation Front, a PLO faction headed by Abul al-Abbas, who masterminded the Achille Lauro cruise ship hijacking in 1985. A western news agency in Israel said the PLF claimed responsibility for the Wednesday attack by speedboats near Tel Aviv. But Ms. Tutwiler said U.S. officials were still gathering facts about the incident and were unable to assess responsibility for it. She said the U.S. ambassador to Tunisia, Robert Pelletreau, was trying to contact PLO officials in Tunis. In Washington, Assistant Secretary of State for Near East and South Asian Affairs John Kelly spoke with Israeli Ambassador Moshe Arad. ``The United States is horrified at this terrorist attack,'' Ms. Tutwiler said. ``The U.S. government is pleased that all terrorists were apprehended or killed in action and that no innocent victims were harmed.'' In March, the State Department issued a report asserting the PLO had complied with Arafat's 1988 pledge not to engage in terrorism. It stated there was no evidence any of nine attacks directed against Israel since then were approved by Arafat or any of the groups under the PLO umbrella. Kelly ran into a storm of criticism last week from some House members when he testified on the report. Rep. Lawrence J. Smith, D-Fla., called the report a ``sham and a fraud'' and said the administration ``ought to be ashamed of itself.''

DOC.HEAD: Text of Disarmament Agreement
With AM-Nicaragua, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is the text of the disarmament agreement signed by Contra rebels and the government on Wednesday. Protocol of Managua on Disarmament Within the spirit of the declaration of Managua, signed May 4 of this year, the Resistance, the government of Nicaragua and his Eminence, the most Rev. Cardinal Miguel Obando y Bravo, through the present document agree: 1. To ease the fulfillment of what is included on the ``commitment to guarantee the physical and moral integrity of each and every one of the combatants of the Nicaraguan Resistance, their families and the civilian population that accompanies them'' in the following way: a) Immediate transfer of the seriously ill so that they receive indispensable medical attention in the country's hospitals. b) Immediate transfer of the war handicapped and wounded for specialized attention in Managua. c) Create a commission of the government, Nicaraguan Resistance, the International Verification Commission and his Eminence, the most Rev. Cardinal Miguel Obando y Bravo, to travel to Honduras and Costa Rica for the purpose of carrying out an exhaustive investigation of the living conditions of the relatives of the resistance and applying emergency measures to solve the problems that are found. d) The Resistance is urged to present immediately the list of widows and orphans so that the INSSBI (Nicaraguan Institute of Social Security and Well-being) includes them in its budget and they receive the monthly pensions to which they have the right. 2. Establish by common agreement among the parties the development zone described in the document on the zones called ``El Almendro,'' based on the proposal presented by the government. Begin on this date a series of necessary actions for the implementation and installation of the demobilization in the zones. 3. The Nicaraguan government agrees to provide minimal economic aid to each person who is demobilized. 4. Create immediately an internal police with participation of the former Resistance combatants, for the fundamental purpose of guaranteeing the life and physical integrity of the citizens who live in the development zones. Also established is the intention that these police will become part of the structure of the Interior Ministry. The United Nations or a friendly nation will be asked for technical advice for the professional training of the police. 5.
