Create the security condtions in the demilitarized zones, for which it is considered necessary: a) Request the expansion of the mandate of the U.N. security forces for Central America. b) That the government complement the assistance for the demobilized who leave the security zone. c) Desmilitarize the conflict zone. d) Continue picking up weapons from civilians in the conflict zones. 6. Guarantee the security of the former combatants who demobilize and leave the security zones and who locate in the development zones. At the same time, maintain the option for those who want to return to their place of origin. It is understood that they will assume the risks of any other citizen. 7. The government agrees to name a representative of the demobilized recommended by the Resistance to the ministries that deal with the former combatants and their families: health, agrarian reform, labor and others, as well as two members of the board of directors of the Nicaraguan Repatriation Institute. 8. The Nicaraguan government pledges to give former combatants of the Resistance who have located in the development zones participation in the local government, that is to say, within the development zone. At the same time, the former combatants who return to their place of origin will receive from the state the support necessary for their involvement in civilian life. 9. The Managua declaration is ratified in each and every one of its points, placing particular emphasis on references to the fact that the Resistance may become a political party, which will allow its clear involvement in the political life in this country. 10. In fulfillment of the Toncontin agreement and its addendum, the Resistance ratifies its commitment to demobilization and disarmament at the latest June 10, 1990. To that effect the Resistance agrees to demobilize a minimum of 100 combatants per day per zone beginning on this date. At the same time, in honor of Mother's Day, a considerable number of Nicaraguan Resistance combatants will be demobilized. Presented in the city of Managua, May 30, 1990 Signed: Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, President of the Republic Israel Galeano, Commander Franklin (for the Resistance) Miguel Obando y Bravo, Cardinal of Managua

DOC.HEAD: Two National Guard Jet Trainers Collide in Flight, Three Survive
DOC.TEXT: Two Air National Guard fighter jets collided in a ball of flame Wednesday during a training flight over northwestern Iowa but both pilots and a civilian passenger parachuted to safety. Debris from the two A-7 jets tumbled to the ground over a wide area in farm fields two miles north of Royal. There were no reports of damage on the ground. ``They just hit head on,'' said John Schultz, who saw the collision from his home in Spencer, eight miles northeast of the crash site and about 70 miles southeast of Sioux Falls, S.D. ``Each one exploded in a ball of fire, and that was it. I didn't see the parachutes.'' The three people aboard the planes did eject and used their parachutes, said Air Guard Lt. Ruth Christopherson. The three were South Dakota Air National Guard pilots Maj. GregoS.D.) Argus Leader, said Christopherson. ``They're all fine, ready to be released to go home,'' she said. Bushee was along as part of a public affairs program to acquaint civic leaders with the operation of the National Guard, she said. Lt. Reid Christopherson, executive officer of the South Dakota Air National Guard, said the planes were among four A-7s taking part in a training mission from the Air Guard's 114th Tactical Fighter Group, based at Sioux Falls. The two other planes returned to Sioux Falls. Witnesses said the four jets were conducting maneuvers that resembled mock dogfighting. ``I was outside hanging up laundry and I heard the planes flying up above, and usually they're so high up it's hard to see them,'' said Joni Griffith, who lives on a farm near the crash site. ``It sounded like they got louder, and I looked up and saw the two bright flames, the fires. ``I watched for a second and watched one of the flames start doing a nose dive. And I ran around a garage and I watched it go all the way to the ground and explode.'' The A-7 fighters cost about $3 million each to build and are used by Air National Guard units all across the country. They were flying in approved air space over a sparsely populated area that is mostly farmland, Christopherson said. The fighters collided about 25 miles north of where a United Airlines DC-10 was flying when an engine exploded July 19. The explosion knocked out the plane's hydraulic system, which powers flight controls, and the plane crashed during an emergency landing in Sioux City, killing 112 people.

DOC.HEAD: Raisa Gorbachev to See Tourist Spots
DOC.TEXT: Raisa Gorbachev, like millions of tourists who have visited San Francisco, will tour Fisherman's Wharf and several other popular spots while her husband meets with executives at a business luncheon. Mrs. Gorbachev is scheduled to take a one-hour whirlwind tour of the city from 3 p.m. to 4 p.m. on June 4 after she and her husband, Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev, return from his speech at Stanford University. Among the sights listed on an itinerary released Wednesday are Golden Gate Park, Civic Center, Davies Symphony Hall, the Bank of America Building and Fisherman's Wharf, with possible stops at the M.H. de Young Museum and the Opera House. Mrs. Gorbachev is expected to be escorted by Tatyana Kamenev, wife of the Soviet consul general, and perhaps Sherry Agnos, wife of Mayor Art Agnos, said Charlotte Mailliard Swig, San Francisco's chief of protocol. ``They won't have much time, but I think she'll like it and come back,'' Swig said. ``I just hope they don't stop in Civic Plaza.'' Civic Plaza, across from City Hall, has become a campground for the homeless in recent years. After returning to the consul general's residence, where she and her husband are staying, Mrs. Gorbachev will meet with Friends of Raisa Gorbachev, including women who have met her on trips to the Soviet Union to promote peace. The Gorbachevs are scheduled to leave at 5:30 p.m. for a view of the Golden Gate Bridge at Vista Point before going to San Francisco International Airport for their departure at 6:30 p.m.

DOC.HEAD: USDA Forecasts Farm Exports Up Slightly from February Estimate
DOC.TEXT: The Agriculture Department forecast Wednesday that American agricultural exports for the fiscal year ending in September would total $40 billion, an increase of $1.5 billion from the previous estimate. The department revised the estimated volume of U.S. agricultural exports upward by 1.5 million metric tons from the February forecast to 150 million metric tons. Much of the increase, however, is the result of a change in the way shipments between the United States and Canada are reported, the department said in its report. It said the alteration was designed to eliminate under-reporting of exports by both countries. The department added, however, that the prospects for exports of U.S. corn, soybeans and cotton have improved since February in both volume and price. Meanwhile, USDA raised the forecast for U.S. agricultural imports from $21.5 billion to $22 billion. It said the main reason was an upswing in fruit and vegetable imports from Latin America in the wake of December's freeze in Florida and Texas. The department forecast the U.S. agricultural surplus for the year at $18 billion, only a shade below that for fiscal 1989. The surplus had been rising steadily since fiscal 1986 when it skidded to $5.4 billion. In terms of volume, the estimate of $150 million tons is up from last year's total of $146.4 million.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Urges Unconditional India-Pakistan Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Tuesday in 2nd graf is cq
DOC.TEXT: President Bush wants India and Pakistan to stop preparing for war and hold talks about Kashmir, where the Indian government has cracked down on a militant Islamic secessionist movement. ``I urge you to seek negotiation and conciliation rather than confrontation,'' Bush said Tuesday as newly arrived Ambassador Abid Hussain presented his credentials at a White House ceremony. The Indian Embassy later released the statements by Bush and Hussain. More than 400 people have been killed since January when the Indian crack down began. Kashmir is the only predominantly Moslem state in Hindu-dominated India. Pakistan is a Moslem country. U.S. Assistant Secretary of State Raymond Seitz told foreign correspondents Wednesday that Bush and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev will discuss the Kashmir dispute at their Washington summit that begins Thursday. ``Kashmir has turned into a flash point on the international scene,'' Seitz said. Other U.S. officials have referred to it as one of the world's most worrisome regional crises. India and Pakistan have fought three wars since independence from Britain in 1947, two over Kashmir. Both India and Pakistan are regarded as capable of producing atomic weapons. Bush told the Indian ambassador the United States believes the 1972 Simla agreement is the ``best framework for a peaceful resolution of the dispute, and we call on both India and Pakistan to begin bilateral talks without preconditions.'' Pakistan, accusing Indian security forces of wanton killing and repression in Kashmir, has maintained that the Simla pact doesn't preclude third-party mediation. Pakistani officials reportedly have approached the U.N. Security Council. Hussain did not name Kashmir in his statement, but referred indirectly to the dispute. ``Terrorism and fundamentalism are direct threats to the secular and representative character of our political system,'' he said. ``We cannot condone the activities of those who espouse violence for political ends and take up arms to undermine the unity and integrity of the state.''

DOC.HEAD: Gas Leak on Ship Forces Evacuation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: 1,3-dichloropropene in 2nd graf cq
DOC.TEXT: Firefighters at a chemical plant worked Wednesday to contain a gas leak aboard a ship and prevent an explosion from the mixture of two chemicals, officials said. Freeport's 12,000 residents were urged to stay inside and to close all windows. About 20,000 gallons of amino ethyl ethanolamine were in the Marine Chemist's tank Tuesday night when about 5,000 gallons of 1,3-dichloropropene were accidentally added, said Margaret Gaspard, a Dow Chemical Co. spokeswoman. The flow of dichloropropene was stopped when employees realized a reaction was occurring and heat was increasing within the tank, she said. ``The venting of the gases has decreased and the temperature of the reaction has decreased by half and that's a good sign,'' Dow spokeswoman Cindy Suggs said Wednesday afternoon. Firefighters were pouring water on the ship moored at the plant's dock and the Coast Guard closed traffic on the Intracoastal Waterway, Police Chief Charles Bankston said. No injuries were reported, but plant employees were evacuated, as were a few residents downwind and students from three schools, authorities said. Dow officials said breathing high concentrations of the gas could cause lung irritation but said levels being released should pose no problems. ``Right now it appears that the only problem anyone will experience will be throat irritation if exposed to very large quantities,'' Ms. Suggs said. A recording at the Dow offices also urged Freeport residents to stay inside, close all outside ventilation and not to use air conditioners. The recording also advised residents having breathing problems to apply a wet cloth over their mouths. The gas is made up of ammonia, hydrogen chloride and some light hydrocarbons, Ms. Gaspard said. Amino ethyl ethanolamine is used in products such as shampoo and cleaners, according to Dow. It said 1,3-dichloropropene is a soil fumigant and used as a fungicide.

DOC.HEAD: Advocates Claim Consumers Coerced in Car Coverage Rentals
DOC.TEXT: Consumers are being coerced by car rental companies into purchasing unneeded damage coverage, an advocacy group charged Wednesday. An industry organization claimed, however, that only about one in five renters purchases the so-called collision damage waiver, which pays for a wrecked or stolen car. ``A lot of people don't need it at all but are buying it out of fear,'' said Lucinda Sikes, a staff attorney for the U.S. Public Interest Research Group. ``It's just a way for (rental companies) to make a lot of profit. The product itself is inherently a fraud on consumers.'' Sikes also claimed the coverage _ which can add as much as 48 percent to the rental price _ costs too much for those who do need it. ``It really should be only a few dollars a day,'' she said. In a 23-page report entitled ``Taking Consumers for A Ride: A Report on Collision Damage Waivers,'' the group said the waivers are often ``sold under coercive circumstances, at excessive prices and with deceptive statements about coverage.'' The report was compiled from a survey of 10 Washington-area companies. Sikes claimed consumers often aren't told about exceptions to the waivers, which may be voided for reasons ranging from travel on a gravel road to driving after having o available for objects older than that. In the new work, the researchers dated coral samples with both carbon-14 dating and a second method, which depends on the constant radioactive transformation of uranium-234 into thorium-230. The second method, like the tree rings, provided an independent measure for calibrating the carbon-14 data. In a telephone interview, Zindler said the newfound accuracy cleared up an inconsistency in a climate theory. Scientists had theorized that subtle changes in Earth's orbit affected growth and melting of glaciers by changing the amount of solar energy to reach the surface, he said. But previous carbon-14 dating of ancient coral clashed with that theory by suggesting the last peak of glaciation was about 18,000 years ago, he said. The corrected date from the new study was 21,500 years ago, which ``fits with that theory very well,'' Zindler said.

DOC.HEAD: Antiquated Car Licensing System Endangering Lives, Hindering Police
DOC.TEXT: Georgia's slow system of recording license plates is blamed for a four-day delay in the search for the killer of a high school student, the latest case in which police say the system is helping criminals get away. Georgia issued new plates this year, the first since 1983, but hasn't entered them on the national law enforcement computer network. After the new tags went on, some residents traveling out of state found themselves jailed on stolen car charges because of the unlisted plates. And police say criminals stand a better chance of escape. ``When a law enforcement officer cannot give his all to his job, the citizens of the state are losing,'' said Appling County Sheriff Lewis Parker. ``When it takes hours to find out the tags, and when we know that somewhere the tag is on file, it's also dangerous to the citizens.'' Jeff Davis County Sheriff Mark Hall said the slow process of tracing license numbers added four days to the search for the killer of Rhonda Sue Coleman, a Jeff Davis High School senior slain two weeks ago in Hazelhurst. Information on a partial license number was received Thursday from a man who said he saw a dark truck the night Miss Coleman disappeared. But 84 Georgia counties have issued license plates containing the sequence of numbers the man described, Hall said. Officers have started calling all 84 county license plate offices. A legislator who thinks funds for a new computer system is overdue worries that it will take a disaster to spur the state to action. ``What's going to happen is some drunk will run a school bus off the road and kill a bunch of kids and everybody will get up in arms and not be able to find the person who did it,'' said state Rep. Jerry D. Jackson, chairman of the House Motor Vehicles Committee. Division of Motor Vehicles officials estimate that it will take up to five months to record information on license plates purchased this year because Georgia lacks a network that would link computers in each county to the state processing center. The state has clerks working late into the night six days a week to computerize the data. In some weeks, they process 180,000 of the 6 million records which must be updated.

DOC.HEAD: US Worried That Mauritania May Be Used as Missile Test Site
DOC.TEXT: The State Department expressed concern Wednesday over reports that the West African country of Mauritania may become a testing site for development of medium-range ballistics missiles. Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler suggested that a ``Middle East'' country may be involved in the reported program but she refused to be more specific. She was responding to a report in The Washington Times that Iraq plans to use Mauritania for missile testing. The Times story said Iraq has begun delivering parts of fixed-missile launchers to Mauritania. ``We are naturally concerned over reports that Mauritania may be a testing site for missiles from another country,'' she said. ``Such a development would be worrisome both with respect to missile proliferation in the Middle East and to regional stability in West Africa. ``We have expressed these concerns to the government of Mauritania and we will continue to monitor the situation.''

DOC.HEAD: Shiite Leaders Says Hostage Release ``Remains Frozen''
DOC.TEXT: A Lebanese Shiite Moslem leader with close ties to groups holding hostages said efforts to release six Americans held in Lebanon remain frozen because of negative U.S. positions. Hussein Musawi, head of the Islamic Amal faction based in east Lebanon, spoke a day after the Bush administration announced it had provided Iran with information on Iranians missing in Lebanon as a gesture of goodwill. In an interview on the Lebanese Voice of the People radio station, he said ``those concerned in Iran and Syria are dismayed by the negative American stands.'' At a May 3 news conference, President Bush said he hoped that providing Iran with information on the fate of the four missing Iranians would satisfy Iran's request for a gesture of thanks for its role in freeing two U.S. hostages. Bush also said he remained firmly opposed to negotiating for the release of the remaining six American hostages in Lebanon. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Tuesday in Washington that the United States had concluded that the Iranian were dead. He said the information was passed to Tehran via the Swiss government. Musawi's Islamic Amal is a pro-Syrian faction within the Iranian-backed Hezbollah, or Party of God. Hezbollah is believed to be the umbrella for extremist factions holding most of the 16 Westerners missing in Lebanon. Iranian leaders said on Wednesday they had evidence their four missing countrymen were still alive. ``Following the Islamic republic's inquiry into the fate of Iranian hostages in Lebanon, we have got information from reliable sources over the past few days that our hostages are alive,'' said Foreign Ministry spokesman Morteza Sarmadi. He was quoted by the Islamic Republic News Agency. ``The Islamic republic will continue efforts to obtain more detailed information about the situation of its hostages,'' he said. Sarmadi gave no more details on the fate of the Iranians. Iran has repeatedly said that information on the fate of the four Iranians is one condition for helping gain the release of the 16 Western hostages held in Lebanon, most by pro-Iranian factions. The four Iranians were seized in July 1982 at a Lebanese Forces checkpoint at Badara, the northernmost point in the Christian enclave, 25 miles north of Beirut. The kidnapped men included Ahmad Motevaselian, the commander of a contingent of Iranian Revolutionary Guards based in the Bekaa Valley of east Lebanon, a diplomat, a photographer and their driver. Sources in the Lebanese Forces have said the Iranian prisoners were killed in artillery battles between the militia and Moslem factions, including the Iranian-backed Hezbollah or Party of God. But there have been unconfirmed reports that three of the Iranians are alive, and the fourth was shot trying to escape. Of the 16 Westerners held hostage, the longest held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985. Also held is Anglican church envoy Terry Waite, who turns 51 on Thursday, more than three years after he disappeared in Beirut while trying to negotiate the freedom of other Western captives. Musawi on Wednesday reiterated earlier remarks that the deportation by Britain of writer Salman Rushdie would ``greatly facilitate the release'' of at least some of the British hostages in Lebanon. Rushdie, an Indian-born naturalized Briton, was sentenced to death Feb. 14, 1989, by Iran's late revolutionary leader, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, for allegedly blaspheming Islam in his novel, ``The Satanic Verses.'' Rushdie has been in hiding under British protection ever since.

DOC.HEAD: Durenberger Got Gift and Loan; Reports Disclose Senate Millionaires' Club
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS grafs 4-9, bgng Despite growing, with seven grafs, to UPDATE with Common Cause figures, Hatch fees, Kohl's income and Burns' plight; SUBS 12th graf pvs, Durenberger's troubles, with his explanation; SUBS last graf with explanation of Twits fund
DOC.HEAD: With BC-Senate Finances-List
DOC.TEXT: Sen. David Durenberger, already the subject of an ethics probe, said Wednesday he failed to report an earlier gift and loan, while Senate colleagues disclosed they talked, wrote, invested and even fiddled to raise their incomes last year. Durenberger, R-Minn., amended his financial reports for five years to acknowledge a friend's gift of 35 days of lodging in Florida and a $484,000 loan to buy a house. He is being investigated by the Senate Ethics Committee because of a $100,000 book-promotion deal that was not listed on past disclosure reports. The figures on income, speaking fees and gifts for senators were included in financial disclosure reports that were made public on Wednesday. Although there is growing concern about the practice of accepting fees for speaking to special interests, a compilation by the Common Cause lobbying organization showed 74 senators spoke for pay last year. By next year, the report said, 34 senators will no longer keep such fees, compared with 19 in 1988. The 74 collected $2.7 million, donated $685,449 to charity, and kept the rest, Common Cause said. Although Democrats control the Senate, the top two Republicans earned more in speaking fees in 1989. Republican Leader Bob Dole of Kansas picked up $108,900 in honoraria; his deputy, Alan Simpson of Wyoming, got $90,600. Sen. Orrin Hatch of Utah, senior Republican on the Labor and Human Resources Committee, was paid $92,499 in fees. Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, was paid $39,000 for speeches, but his deputy, Alan Cranston, D-Calif., no longer accepts honoraria. One of the wealthiest senators, John Heinz, R-Pa., whose family started the food company, reported assets that could exceed $17 million; his income for the year may have topped $2.5 million. Sen. John C. Danforth, R-Mo., whose family founded Ralston Purina, disclosed holdings that could be in the $15-million range. Sen. Claiborne, Pell, D-R.I., may have made $2.8 million or more last year; his assets were in the $8 million range. Also among the richer senators are Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., whose assets are hidden in a trust; Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., with vast real estate holdings, and Herbert Kohl, D-Wis., owner of the Milwaukee Bucks basketball team. Kohl's 1989 income could have topped $20 million. On the other hand, Sens. Jim Jeffords, R-Vt., and Conrad Burns, R-Mont., could be on the brink of insolvency, with more liabilities than assets. Sen. Joseph R. Biden Jr., D-Del., reported little in the way of assets except his home, and liabilities that include loans to pay for a son's college education. The law requires most high-level federal officials to report annually on their assets, liabilities, financial transactions and gifts received. House members' reports were made public Tuesday; all but a few senators, who were granted 30-day extensions, made their reports Wednesday. Because the forms are so vague, it is impossible in most cases to discern an official's true financial status. For example, a $10 million piece of real estate may be listed on the forms as worth ``over $250,000.'' Some senators had dozens of holdings valued at that level. Durenberger's troubles with the Ethics Committee are traceable in part to his failure to disclose some transactions as required by law. His office said Wednesday that the Florida lodging was inadvertently left off a past form and that the loan was omitted by someone who didn't understand the form. Sen. Robert C. Byrd, D-W.Va., included in his income $120.80 in royalties on a record of fiddle music he recorded several years ago. Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., reported $167 royalties on two past books and a $5,000 advance for another he is writing for Harvard University Press. Mitchell and his Republican colleague from Maine, William Cohen, shared royalties from a book they wrote after serving on the committee that investigated the Iran-contra scandal. Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, received $5,058 in royalties for a tape cassette in the ``Living Scriptures'' series. Simpson listed $40,000 he was paid for debating Kennedy in the Mutual Radio series, ``Face Off.'' Kennedy's report did not include his share. Sen. Bennett Johnston, D-La., chairman of the Senate Energy Committee, received about $3,000 of royalties on oil and gas investments. Sen. Tim Wirth, D-Colo., shares with his wife a blind trust valued at more than $250,000, which generated as much s $50,000 income last year. In 1989, most senators were paid at the annual rate of $89,500; leaders earned $99,500. Senators could keep honoraria equivalent to 40 percent of their salaries and give the rest to charity. House members voted to give up their honoraria starting next year in exchange for higher government salaries, but senators insisted on keeping those fees and taking a smaller check from the treasury. Sen. John Breaux, D-La., a first-term senator who chairs the Democratic Senate Campaign Committee, picked up $53,000 for speaking and gave $17,200 of it to charity. Biden, who heads the Judiciary Committee, was paid $35,548 in honoraria and kept it all. This year's figures on speaking fees may not tell the whole story. Instead of accepting checks and turning them over to charity, some senators have begun instructing groups they address to write the check directly to a designated charity. Dole and Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, acknowledged doing this in some cases. Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill., accepted a long list of gifts, including a lamp stand (value unknown) from the president of Malawi. Sen. John Warner, R-Va., accepted four Washington Redskins season tickets. Freshman Sen. Joseph Lieberman, D-Conn., received several months of free lodging before his family joined him in Washington. Political leanings are not forgotten in the financial reports. Sen. Barbara Mikulski, D-Md., pointedly noted a fund in which she invests has no holdings in South Africa. Sen. Bob Packwood, R-Ore., turned over $25 of his honorarium to ``Pompous Twits Anonymous,'' a home-state charity that helps the needy while tweaking public figures for their outlandish statements.

DOC.HEAD: Seabrook Sends First Nuclear-Powered Electricity To Consumers
DOC.TEXT: The Seabrook nuclear plant has quietly generated electricity and fed it to commercial customers for the first time after almost two decades of regulatory delays, financial woes and mass protests. The plant that became a symbol of the nation's anti-nuclear movement in the late 1970s and 1980s generated 65 megawatts of electricity that was fed into the New England power grid Tuesday night. On Wednesday, the reactor was operating at 23 percent of capacity, generating 216 megawatts, which plant spokesman Rob Williams said could supply electricity to 185,000 homes. Williams said the power would be reduced for more testing and brought up again to 30 percent in the next few days. The milestone was reached during tests to ready the 1,150-megawatt, $6.5 billion reactor for full power commercial operation, expected this summer. Until Tuesday, low-power testing had not generated any electricity, plant officials said. Ed Brown, president of plant operator New Hampshire Yankee, called the step ``an extremely significant moment,'' while plant opponents said nothing had changed. ``The notion that, 10 years behind schedule, they generate a few kilowatts of power and that all is fine and there are no problems is ludicrous,'' said Roy Morrison, spokesman for the Clamshell Alliance. Massachusetts Attorney General James Shannon and an environmental group filed briefs Tuesday in Washington on appeals of Seabrook's commercial license, granted March 1. Arguments are scheduled for Sept. 18. Opponents contend the seaside plant is unsafe and the evacuation plan for the surrounding area is inadequate, especially for crowded beaches. Plant operators say it is safe in all respects. Seabrook had been shut down for a month for modifications on its non-nuclear side after problems cropped up during the start-up process. No protesters greeted plant workers arriving for their shifts Wednesday morning. Sandra Gavutis, director of Citizens Within The Ten-Mile Radius, said the battle against Seabrook has taken on different dimensions. ``The fight is by no way waning,'' said Gavutis. ``We're definitely working in other arenas. We're working in the political arena.'' Gavutis said her group lobbied for the congressional investigations of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission and subsequent Seabrook-related allegations filed with the commission's inspector general. Sen. John Kerry, D-Mass., on Wednesday called the NRC's actions on Seabrook ``one slap in the face after another.'' ``This past weekend, as the official beach season opened, miles and miles of cars lined the traffic-filled streets surrounding the Seabrook nuclear plant,'' Kerry said. ``You don't have to be a nuclear physicist to imagine the problems that would arise if there were even a minor incident during beach traffic hours.'' Ground was broken for Seabrook in 1976, but the plant was not finished for 10 years. The long delay led to soaring costs _ original projections called for two reactors costing less than $1 billion _ and forced its lead owner, Public Service Co. of New Hampshire, into bankruptcy reorganization. Connecticut-based Northeast Utilities has won preliminary approval to take over Public Service.

DOC.HEAD: Navy Graduates Midshipmen in Midst of Controversy
DOC.TEXT: Graduates of the U.S. Naval Academy are the best and brightest in the country, the superintendent said Wednesday at commencement. He made only a brief mention of reports of sexual harassment and abuse of middies. Graduates drew praise from Rear Adm. Virgil L. Hill Jr. and Vice President Dan Quayle at a ceremony unmarred by the controversy that has swirled around the campus since a female middie resigned because she was handcuffed in a men's bathroom, taunted and photographed. The brigade of midshipmen is ``literally the best and brightest the nation has to offer,'' Hill told the 990 graduates. They are part of ``a chain of excellence in leadership ... unmatched by any other institution. The chain has never been stronger.'' Five military and congressional panels are investigating complaints that women have been sexually harassed and freshmen have been mentally and physically abused during plebe indoctrination. And some professors have complained that academic standards are declining and that they are being pressured to give passing grades to students who have failed exams. The only mention of the criticism on Wednesday came from Hill, who was warmly applauded when he mentioned telling a local newspaper editor that he was ``just a little upset that most of the coverage has been a little less than productive.'' Quayle did not mention the controversy, although he devoted much of his speech to praising midshipmen for their academic and athletic achievements and their record of public service in Annapolis. The vice president touched only briefly on national and international affairs, telling graduates that they are beginning their careers at a remarkable time. But he said that even in times of worldwide change, ``America will need its strong global Navy to preserve our liberty and our way of life.'' Gwen Dreyer, a 19-year-old freshman from Encinitas, Calif., resigned earlier this month because of hazing she said dated to December, when she was handcuffed to a urinal, taunted and photographed. Other current and former women midshipmen have complained that many male midshipmen resent women at the academy. Complaints about academic standards surfaced after a department head was demoted because he refused to raise grades for third-year midshipmen students in an electrical engineering course. Not all women at the academy agree that females are subjected to unfair hazing. ``It's not a matter of gender. It's a part of life here,'' midshipman Susan Slaven said as she argued with members of the National Organization for Women who picketed outside the graduation ball on campus Monday night. ``Some people just don't belong in a military academy,'' she said. Hill announced general orders Tuesday designed to end physical and mental harassment of freshmen. Under the new rules, any midshipmen found guilty of physical abuse of plebes during indoctrination could be subject to dismissal, even if the act falls short of what is considered hazing. There were 96 women among the 990 Naval Academy graduates receiving diplomas and commissions as military officers Wednesday. The ratio is similar to that at the two other service academies. At the U.S. Air Force Academy in Colorado, 100 women were among the 971 cadets who received degrees Wednesday. There will be 89 women, including the first female brigade commander, among about 900 graduates of the U.S. Military Academy at West Point, N.Y., at Thursday's commencement.

DOC.HEAD: Summit at a Glance
DOC.TEXT: Here, at a glance, are Wednesday's pre-summit developments as Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev completed a two-day visit to Canada and traveled to Washington for meetings with President Bush.
DOC.HEAD: BUSH
DOC.TEXT: President Bush met with top advisors and conferred by phone with West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl in last-minute preparations for the talks. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Bush's mood was ``one of anticipation and confidence that democratic values are sustaining positive change in the world order.''
DOC.HEAD: GORBACHEV
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet leader said the issue of German reunification took up much of his four hours of talks with Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney. Gorbachev said the West's insistence on keeping a united Germany in NATO is sounding ``like an old record'' and appealed for some new alternative.
DOC.HEAD: GERMANY
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will cut no deal with Gorbachev to limit German troops, U.S. officials said, but he is prepared to discuss a formula that might eventually scale down those forces along with the Red Army.
DOC.HEAD: ARMS TALKS
DOC.TEXT: American and Soviet negotiators held a fourth day of pre-summit talks at the State Department to try to expand on the kinds of long-range nuclear weapons to be reduced in an arms treaty. The Kremlin assigned Col. Gen. Labronislav Omelichev, first deputy on the Soviet defense ministry's general staff, to the talks.
DOC.HEAD: DEMONSTRATIONS
DOC.TEXT: Several hundred Armenian demonstrators lined the street outside Canada's National Gallery yelling, ``Karabakh! Karabakh!'' as Gorbachev went inside for a brief tour. Across the street, hundreds of people gathered to demonstrate on behalf of the three breakaway Baltic republics. In Washington, some 2,000 demonstrators reserved spots at Lafayette Park across the street from the White House, but by early afternoon few had shown up.
DOC.HEAD: LITHUANIA
DOC.TEXT: Lithuanian leaders appealed to Bush and Gorbachev to solve the question of the breakaway Baltic Republic, where oil shortages threaten to shut down heating systems. Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene and Lithuanian President Vytas Landsbergis made their comments together in Vilnius, and the session was beamed to the United States by satellite.
DOC.HEAD: KOREA
DOC.TEXT: Gorbachev broadened the scope of his U.S. visit by adding a private meeting with the president of South Korea. U.S. officials said Gorbachev planned to meet South Korean President Roh Tae-woo next Monday during a stop in San Francisco, where he also is to see Ronald Reagan and former Secretary of State George P. Shultz and visit Stanford University.

DOC.HEAD: Crowing Roosters Lead to New Law
DOC.TEXT: A rooster strutting his stuff too early in the day will leave his owner with little to crow about. Bird owners face a $500 fine under a new town ordinance intended to put a damper on early morning clucks and crowing. A flock of cries of fowl play prompted the town council to unanimously approve the ordinance earlier this month. People who ``knowingly or intentionally permit fowl to make unreasonable noise after being asked to make the fowl stop'' can be charged under the new law, council president Fred Feiock said this week. ``Personally, I always liked to wake up and hear a rooster crowing, but then I don't live next to someone who has a lot of chickens or roosters,'' Feiock said. Police say they will enforce the ordinance. ``I don't know what you're going to do though,'' said officer Ron Shrout. ``Dogs will bark and chickens will make noise.'' One person has been warned so far but no one has been fined, Police Chief Lawrence Dalton said Wednesday. Dalton said he hasn't heard any roosters crowing, and doubts that very many people keep them within the city limits of this town of 3,900. ``I've been to two worlds' fairs and a bull fight, but this is the first time I've heard of a chicken ordinance,'' Dalton said. Officials have been plagued with clucks and squawks about rowdy roosters and chickens for more than 1{ years, Feiock said. ``At first, it seemed more or less a joke.'' ``Other than having their vocal chords operated on,'' Feiock said he had no useful tips for quieting the bothersome birds. Feiock said officials don't want to outlaw roosters, although they may be the prime offenders. ``Every chicken ought to have a rooster. My mother used to raise chickens, and I know what it's like,'' Feiock said. ``But times are changing, and we have to have rules to protect people.''

DOC.HEAD: Film Critics Call for New, Adult Rating
DOC.TEXT: The National Society of Film Critics on Wednesday recommended a new rating for non-pornographic, adults-only movies. The rating, ``A,'' is needed ``because of the alarming increase in the application of the `X' rating to films of non-pornographic intent,'' the society said in a letter to Jack Valenti, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, and Richard Heffner, head of the Ratings Board. The society said the rating would promote ``more equitable access and distribution of serious, adult-themed movies.'' The society comprises 42 critics from major, general interest publications. Last week, Pedro Almodovar, producer-director of ``Tie Me Up! Tie Me Down!'' filed suit in Manhattan against the Motion Picture Association, seeking to have the Spanish movie's rating changed from ``X'' to ``R.'' ``Since `X' only means a skin flick, the minute you put it on a serious film, many theaters won't exhibit it and many newspapers and television stations will not carry the ads and you get a diminished audience,'' said William Kunstler, attorney for Almodovar and the movie's distributor, Miramax Film Corp.

DOC.HEAD: More Thunderstorms In Central U.S., Chilly In Northeast
DOC.TEXT: More rain fell across parts of the Plains on Wednesday and welcome heavy rain fell on parched northern California. Temperatures dipped to unseasonable lows from the Great Lakes to New England. Showers and thunderstorms developing ahead of a warm front extended from Arkansas to Nebraska during the afternoon. During the six hours up to 2 p.m. EDT, 1.01 inches of rain fell at Harrison, Ark. A powerful storm over the Pacific Ocean spread showers into Oregon and California, and a snow advisory was issued for higher elevations of the Sierra Nevada range of California, north of Yosemite National Park. Up to 10 inches of snow was possible at the highest elevations. The rain has delayed the start of fire season in northern California, but offered little help with the state's four-year drought. ``Obviously, we are pleased to have this rain, but it won't make any difference in terms of ending the drought,'' said Don Paff, operations chief of the Central Valley Project, the federal water system operated by the U.S. Bureau of Reclamation. However, thanks to the rain, the state's biggest water users _ the Central Valley irrigation districts _ won't have to draw water from foothill and mountain reservoirs for up to two weeks, officials said. Showers and thunderstorms also spread over southern Florida, and Key West got 3.50 inches of rain in the six hours up to 2 p.m. EDT. Elsewhere, showers continued in much of New England. On Tuesday, thunderstorms produced severe weather in Oklahoma, eastern New Mexico and the northern half of Texas, spawning several tornadoes and large hail. Heavy rain included 1.83 inches of San Angelo, Texas; 1.72 at Kingsville, Texas; 2.73 inches at Garden City, Kan.; 1.65 inches at Dodge City, Kan.; and 2.80 inches at Pueblo, Colo. Parts of Pennsylvania got record rainfall Tuesday, including 4.5 inches in Montgomery County; 2.45 inches at Harrisburg, 2.25 inches at Philadelphia, 1.62 inches at Scranton, and 1.35 at Williamsport. One death was reported Tuesday in Pennsylvania as a 6-year-old boy was washed down Wissahicken Creek. In addition, two teen-age girls were apparently washed away during flooding in southern Ohio. Temperatures dipped into the 30s and 40s early Wednesday from the upper Mississippi Valley through the Great Lakes region and the upper Ohio Valley to northern New England as strong northwesterly wind ushered in cool air. Duluth, Minn., posted a record low of 29 degrees and Toledo, Ohio, had a record low of 35. Duluth's low also was the coldest reading on record there for so late in the season. Frost and freeze warnings were posted into Thursday morning for the higher mountains of central Pennsylvania and for the northern mountains and upper Greenbrier Valley of West Virginia. Elsewhere, temperatures also dipped into the 30s and 40s in the Rocky Mountains. By contrast, the low of 81 at Brownsville, Texas, tied a 110-year-old record for the date. Wednesday's low for the Lower 48 was 28 at Alamosa, Colo.

DOC.HEAD: Earthquake Rocks Soviet Union, Phone Lines Out, U.S. Embassy Evacuated
With AM-Europe-Quake, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: An earthquake damaged dozens of buildings Wednesday in the southwestern Soviet Union near the Romanian border and was felt from the Crimea to the Baltics, officials said. A Soviet legislator said initial reports from the region indicated there were deaths, although he provided no details. Officials reported by telephone that at least six people were injured in the city of Kogul near the Romanian border, and that buildings swayed in the southern part of the republics of Moldavia and the Ukraine. The quake was centered in the Carpathian mountains of Romania and registered 6.5 on the Richter scale, according to the U.S. Geological Survey in Golden, Colo. ``The quake was really strong. Everything and everybody was falling,'' said Alexander Yevchenko, deputy chairman of the executive committee of the City Council in Izmail, an ancient fortress city of about 100,000 people. ``People could not stand firmly on their feet.'' Yevchenko estimated about 15 buildings were damaged in the city, including the building that houses his offices. Damage to buildings and houses also was reported by officials in the cities of Bolgrad, Reni, Kogul and Komrat. Ilmars Bishers, deputy chairman of the Council of Nationalities of the Soviet parliament, told legislators the quake killed people in the region, but he gave no details, the Tass news agency reported. Six people were hospitalized in Kogul, in the southern part of Moldavia, said Lt. Ivan Koltuk of the regional Interior Department. He said buildings swayed and residents ran into the streets in panic. The quake shook buildings in the capital of Moscow and Tass reported it was felt as far north as Leningrad and the republic of Latvia. The U.S. Embassy building was evacuated temporarily. ``We felt the shock and that's it,'' said a woman who answered the telephone in Kishinev, the capital of Moldavia. The republic of 4.3 million people borders Romania. In the Black Sea port of Sevastopol on the Crimean peninsula, journalist Gennady Bondarenko said people felt a light shock but there was no damage. ``Just the spoons clanked a bit and the dishes slid a little,'' he said in a telephone interview. Bondarenko said some frightened residents fled their homes to stand in the streets but returned later. In Moscow, 710 miles northwest of Kishinev, the quake shook the offices of The Associated Press offices and other structures throughout the capital. U.S. officials ordered the older American Embassy in Moscow evacuated. ``It's an old building, and when the upper floors shook we called around other places in town and closed the building as a precaution to do safety checks,'' said embassy spokesman Jim Bullock. ``We have people inside doing a top-to-bottom check.'' He said the 10-story building was expected to reopen Thursday. It is separate from the newer embassy compound. U.S. officials say an office building in the new complex was bugged so heavily by the Soviets it is to be torn down. An earthquake that struck Soviet Armenia in December 1988 killed an estimated 25,000 people and leveled buildings in villages and cities. That quake registered 6.9 on the Richter scale. The Richter scale gauges the amount of energy released by a quake as measured by the ground motion recorded by seismographs. A quake of magnitude 6 can cause severe damage. One of magnitude 7 is reckoned as a major earthquake.

DOC.HEAD: Mrs Gorbachev Will Tour, Take Tea, Talk to Wellesley Grads
With AM-Summit Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Raisa Gorbachev will go Thursday from one of Washington's most august cultural landmarks, the Library of Congress, to one of its liveliest, the Capital Children's Museum. Both places were on the agenda of the Soviet president's wife during a day that starts at the White House with a formal welcoming ceremony and a tea with Barbara Bush and ends back there that evening with a formal state dinner. There are special Soviet exhibits at both the library and the children's museum that may have served as magnets for Mrs. Gorbachev. While their husbands hold their first formal summit talks, Mrs. Bush will be host for a private tea for Mrs. Gorbachev and the wives of Vice President Dan Quayle, Secretary of State James Baker III, Assistant Secretary of State Ray Seitz, Jack Matlock, the U.S. ambassador to the Soviet Union, and Aleksandr Bessmertnykh, the new Soviet ambassador to Washington. Industrialist Armand Hammer is hosting a ritzy reception at the Library of Congress later for Mrs. Gorbachev and 350 guests, including Marilyn Quayle, wife of the vice president; Washington Post Co. Chairman Katharine Graham and Supreme Court Justice Sandra Day O'Connor. Mrs. Gorbachev will get a tour of the library's Jefferson Building from the Librarian of Congress, James Billington, then cut the ribbon on a new exhibit, ``Living Traditions of Russian Faith: Books and Manuscripts of the Old Believers, Fifteenth Century to the Present.'' Afterward, the Soviet leader's wife will pay a 25-minute visit to the Capital Children's Museum. In most museums, do-not-touch is the cardinal rule. Not so in the Children's Museum, which is teeming with hands-on, interactive exhibits for kids of all ages and draws 250,000 visitors a year. Mary Abbajay, a spokeswoman for the museum, said it currently has an exhibit of Soviet children's books by Soviet author-illustrator Anton Kumankov, who will be on hand Thursday to greet Mrs. Gorbachev. After Thursday night's state dinner at the White House, Mrs. Gorbachev will accompany Mrs. Bush on Friday morning aboard a U.S. Air Force jet to Massachusetts, where they will address the graduates at Wellesley College, then take in some sights in the Boston area. They will fly back to Washington by late afternoon and the Gorbachevs will host a return dinner for the Bushes at the Soviet Embassy Friday evening. Both women will accompany their husbands to Camp David, Md., Saturday for what the White House has billed as a day of relaxation at the presidential mountain retreat 75 miles outside Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Excerpts From Gorbachev Toast
With AM-Gorbachev, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are excerpts from a toast Wednesday by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, during a state luncheon attended by Prime Minister Brian Mulroney.

First of all, I would like to express my sincere gratitude for the invitation to visit your country and for your warm hospitality. It is highly symbolic that as we are once again ``discovering America,'' we begin in Canada. Precisely seven years ago, in May 1983, I was here with a delegation of the USSR Supreme Soviet. I have retained very vivid memories of that first encounter with Canada and Canadians. I am glad to be able to greet again my old acquaintances whom I see here in this room. I hope to meet new people. The USSR and Canada are natural partners in the international community. they know each other fairly well, particularly since there are many people in Canada with roots in Russia. However, in this day and age, we should always replenish and sometimes adjust our knowledge. It is good, though, that some things never change, such as the feeling of sympathy which, erasing the ideological prejudices and fears of the Cold War, has enabled us to forge new Soviet-Canadian relations. They are gaining momentum in the spirit of the coming new age. Over the past seven years, Soviet-Canadian political dialogue has also emerged as the leading instrument in our interaction. At a time of turbulent change and of a breakdown of established views and stereotypes, contacts and mutual understanding between states acquire special value, particularly between those that have special responsibilities to the world community.

Today, at a watershed in world history and politics, the friendly feelings and creative aspirations of our two peoples can serve as the northern pillar of the bridge of confidence and security between the East and the West, of new dramatic international relations which mankind will take with it into the 21st century. I can say that the challence of our time has not taken the Soviet Union and Canada by surprise. Indeed, in their relations with each other and with the rest of the world they have shown foresight. In times of tensions they did not exacerbate the situation but tried to use any opportunity to improve it. We and you were able to cooperate at the dawn of the Helsinki process. And now we will be drawing the final line under the horrible war of tyranny and darkness. We are against looking back to the past all the time; however. Without its lessons it is impossible to bring closer a free and secure future, a future in which there is no room for hatred and revanchism, a future built on voluntary and humane principles. We regard the Soviet-Canadian interaction as an integral and vital support structure of a future common european home.

The Arctic, the roof of the world and a source of life on our planet, has been and remains an area of special cooperation between our two countries, neighbors across the arctic ocean. at last, but, of course, not least, we work together to curb the arms race and participate in the process of disarmament. These are the main parameters in the trajectory of Soviet-Canadian dialogue.

Let me make a special point on Soviet-Canadian trade and economic relations. It should be emphasized that neither the Soviet Union nor Canada have ever tried to politicize them or questioned the need to develop them on the basis of equality and mutual advantage. The scope and consistency of our cooperation in this area and the solid legal groundwork on which it is built hold out the hope that, as we radicalize the economic reform in the USSR, these relations will grow even more dynamic with an understanding of the special aspects and difficulties of the period of transition to a new system in the Soviet Union. We are pleased to note the strong support that the Canadian government has been giving to the businesses that want to cooperate with the Soviet Union and to their initiatives that help integrate our economy in the world economic system. We say very clearly that what we want is not western ``help'' but cooperation on a mutually advantageous basis in shaping a new economy for our country, which is a vast and rich part of the world's potential. Reintegrating it fully in the world economic context is, we believe, necessary and advantageous to all. At the same time, economic interdependence lends long-term stability to bilateral and multilateral interaction. In this context, we would hope that the emergence of new, modern types of cooperation, the establishment of joint ventures will be a continuous process.

I told the Prime Minister in Moscow that we reject economic isolation and are ready to depend on other countries, to the extent, or course, that they are prepared to depend on us. I don't think Canada has any reason to fear such interdependence. It is a must in our time, in this new age that links all mankind in a common destiny

DOC.HEAD: Strong Quake Jolts Europe,, Kills 8 in Romania
LaserPhotos BUCH1,XBUC3,7
DOC.TEXT: An earthquake that was felt from Istanbul to Moscow hit Romania hard Wednesday, killing eight people, hurting 296 and badly damaging buildings in Bucharest and cities across much of Romania, police said. Large chunks of concrete and plaster fell from buildings onto sidewalks and streets, killing and injuring people. Jeremy Sutton-Hibbert of Glasgow, Scotland, staying in an apartment in a 10-story building in Bucharest, said: ``The walls of the bedroom crumbled with plaster falling. Stuff came flying off shelves and all the plaster came off the ceilings. Outside there's a massive crack in the building.'' People were hurt jumping from windows or balconies in this capital city of 2.2 million. Thousands of Bucharest residents fled into streets as buildings swayed and cracked. Shop assistant Petruta Lungu was killed in Bucharest when hit by a collapsing balcony as she ran outside, police said. The quake was centered 100 miles north of Bucharest, in the wooded Vrancea range of the Carpathian mountains, and registered 6.5 on the Richter scale, the U.S. Geological Survey said in Golden, Colo. The temblor also shook the Soviet Union, Hungary, Greece, Turkey and Bulgaria, but of those only the Soviet Union reported casualties. It said at least six people were hurt in the city of Kogul. Soviet legislator Ilmars Bishers said initial reports Wednesday indicated there were deaths, but he gave no details. The quake hit here at 1:40 p.m. (6:40 a.m. EDT) and rumbled across the Carpathians, which run through eastern Romania, the western border of the Soviet Union and southwest Poland. A communique from Romania's General Inspectorate of Police said two people died in Bucharest, two in the Danube River port of Braila, and one each in eastern Buzau, southeastern Ialomita, central Brasov and nearby Prahova County. It said 45 of the 296 people hurt were in critical condition. In Bucharest alone, 102 people were hurt, 35 critically, it reported. Doina Stoica, 22, a student, said: ``I was scared. I was in a book shop and the first thought was to get my mom and get out on the street.'' French journalist Michel Desprats, 24, noticed chandeliers swaying in the marble lobby of the Bucuresti Hotel _ ``In panic, I followed all the people out of the hotel and people were all shouting and crying.'' The ceiling collapsed at a big electrical steel plant in Calarasi County in southern Romania, the state news agency Rompres reported. In Moscow, Soviet officials said people from the Crimea to the Baltics felt the quake and dozens of buildings were damaged in the southwestern part of the country. In Ottawa, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said he was told several shocks shook Moldavia and Armenia but ``no devastation, no destruction.'' He said he saw no reason to break off his trip to return home, as he did in December 1988, when a quake killed an estimated 25,000 people in Armenia. The 1988 quake prompted him to cut short travel plans and fly directly home from New York. Buildings shook in Moscow, 1,000 miles east of Bucharest, including the offices of The Associated Press. The 10-story U.S. Embassy building was evacuated temporarily. Six people were hospitalized in Kogul, Moldavia, Lt. Ivan Koltuk of the regional Interior Department said. He said buildings swayed and residents ran in panic into the streets. The Soviet news agency Tass reported the quake was felt as far north as Leningrad and the Baltic republic of Latvia. The Richter scale gauges the amount of energy released by a quake as measured by the ground motion recorded by seismographs. A quake of magnitude 6 can cause severe damage. One of magnitude 7 is reckoned as a major earthquake. The Romanian General Inspectorate's communique reported injuries from the counties of Dolj, Prahova, Buzau, Ialomita, Galati, Braila, Constanta, Vaslui, Bacau and Vrancea. Bulgaria's state BTA news agency said the temblor was felt nationwide there, but there was minor damage only in Silistra town, bordering Romania. A nuclear power plant in Kozlodoui on the Danube was closed. The quake knocked out telephone lines in the Soviet Union and shook buildings in Russia, the Ukraine and Moldavia. This was the third major earthquake in Romania since 1977. The other two were also centered in the Vrancea range. The most serious, on March 4, 1977, killed 1,500 people.

DOC.HEAD: State Promises Times Beach Pollutant Incinerator is Temporary
DOC.TEXT: A state official promised Wednesday that a proposed toxic waste incinerator at the dioxin-contaminated and abandoned town of Times Beach would not become a permanent fixture. Tracy Mehan, head of the state Department of Natural Resources, outlined a plan he said provided multiple safeguards to ensure that the proposed incinerator would be used only to burn dioxin-tainted soil from Times Beach and 26 other sites in eastern Missouri. ``I am committing to the citizens of St. Louis County here and now that the Department of Natural Resources will not allow Times Beach to become the dioxin dumping ground of the nation,'' Mehan said at a news conference. But some Times Beach neighbors who have opposed the incinerator said Mehan's pledge did nothing to ease their fears. ``As far as I'm concerned, it means absolutely nothing. It's just another promise that we don't believe,'' said Eureka Mayor Otis Nelson. The federal Environmental Protection Agency plans to build a huge incinerator at Times Beach, about 20 miles southwest of St. Louis, to burn all the soil that was contaminated there and at the other sites in the 1970s by dioxin-tainted oil sprayed to control road dust. After the highly toxic chemical was detected, the federal government bought out residents seven years ago and the town was abandoned. Nelson and other opponents fear that once the incinerator is built, officials could decide to use it to burn toxic wastes from across the country. They also oppose it because it is to be built alongside the Meramec River and would be vulnerable to flooding. The EPA says the incinerator would be protected from flooding by a levee. ``What if they have a malfunction and pump a lot of toxic, dangerous runoffs or whatever into the Meramec? Then what are they going to say? `Whoops, we made a mistake?''' Nelson said. One of the points in Mehan's plan was a guarantee that the department would not issue permits for the Times Beach facility that allowed any other waste to be brought in. The EPA has said the entire cleanup would cost about $118 million and could take up to 10 years.

DOC.HEAD: Four Bodies Found After Soldiers Attack U.N. Compound
DOC.TEXT: Government soldiers on Wednesday stormed a U.N. compound where members of rival tribes had taken shelter, killing a U.N. security guard, wounding two people and abducting at least 30, witnesses said. Villagers took reporters to four bodies dumped a few miles outside Monrovia and said they were victims of the attack. Civilians in the capital were outraged at the attack, with hundreds of people booing and hissing at President Samuel Doe as he tried to calm people several hours later. ``Kill us! Kill us!'' the crowd screamed at young soldiers guarding Doe, whose government is fighting for its survival after guerrillas reached within 30 miles of the capital. Doe said soldiers were not acting on his orders when they attacked the compound early Wednesday, killing the U.N. security guard and abducting about 30 men. ``They are doing it on their own and I am going to deal with them drastically,'' he promised. A government statement promised the soldiers would be arrested within 24 hours and said troops found harassing civilians would be executed. Villagers took reporters to four bodies lined up in the grass a few miles outside Monrovia alongside the road from the capital to the main international airport. Witnesses said the four were abducted from the U.N. compound. There have been repeated charges that Doe's soldiers have killed civilians from the Gio and Mano tribes, which they accuse of supporting the rebels. In the past weeks, several bodies of beheaded Mano and Gio men were discovered near the capital. There are also reports that the rebels have been targeting members of Doe's small tribe, the Krahn, and the Mandingo, a tribe they say supports the Krahns and exploits other tribes. Guerrillas from the National Patriotic Front, led by a former Doe aide, Charles Taylor, invades in December from the Ivory Coast in an attempt to oust Doe, whom they accuse of corruption and nepotism. Taylor has said he would maintain strong U.S. ties if his forces oust Doe. Frightened Liberian families have packed their belongings and fled the capital amid rumors that rebels are closing in. Senior government officials, including several Cabinet ministers, are apparently deserting Doe. At U.N. headquarters in New York, officials announced they were evacuating all 57 U.N. personnel from Liberia and had lodged a protest with the Foreign Ministry over the attack. U.N. officials said they were trying to find churches to take in the nearly 1,000 people who have sought refuge at their facilities. U.N. spokesman Francois Giuliani said about eight soldiers wearing masks forced their way into the U.N. compound in Monrovia. ``They bayoneted a guard and shot two others _ killing one and wounding the other,'' he said. The soldiers then began beating men, women and children and forced as many as 40 people into army vehicles before driving off, he said. Local newspapers on Wednesday published government appeals asking people to ``stop listening to rumors, stop panicking and go about your businesses.'' Ghana Airways, the main commercial air link to Liberia, said on Wednesday it was cancelling flights to the country. The statement came a day after rebels ambushed two truckloads of troops a few miles from Robertsfield International Airport, 21 miles from Monrovia. Diplomats said Doe, who took power in a bloody 1980 coup, fears for his safety and no longer sleeps in the same place each night. The diplomats also said Doe's presidential jet and an army Cessna plane are being kept ready at an airfield in the capital. According to news reports and Western officials several high-ranking government officials have deserted Doe and the portfolios of foreign affairs, internal affairs and information are being handled by acting ministers.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Studies, Gorbachev Tours and Talks on Eve of Summit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates in top 8 grafs with Quayle comments, later developments, picking up in 4th graf pvs, Concluding a
DOC.TEXT: President Bush met with top advisers and consulted by phone with West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl on Wednesday as he made last-minute preparations for his summit with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. ``He's upbeat, he's confident, he knows what he wants to talk to Gorbachev about,'' said Vice President Dan Quayle. Bush met with Quayle and senior advisers in a final session to run down the range of issues expected to come up at the four-day summit that begins Thursday. The president did not watch on television as Gorbachev and Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney talked at an Ottawa news conference about Germany's future, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. At the news conference, Gorbachev gave sometimes testy responses to questions on Soviet policy on German reunification and Lithuania. Earlier Wednesday, Bush talked with Kohl on German unity and other summit issues, Fitzwater said, and he had talked the day before to Mulroney. On the eve of his second summit with Gorbachev, Bush, in contrast to his Soviet counterpart, was completely out of public view. Concluding a short stay in Canada, Gorbachev was highly visible, breaking with his formal schedule at one point to stroll toward Ottawa's Parliament Hill for discussions with Mulroney. Fitzwater said Bush brings to his meetings with Gorbachev ``the understandings and insights of many allied leaders.'' Bush earlier had consulted with British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and French President Francois Mitterrand, the spokesman told reporters. Fitzwater said that Kohl and Mulroney initiated the respective calls. Bush's mood on the eve of the summit was ``one of anticipation and confidence that democratic values are sustaining positive change in the world order,'' Fitzwater said. He said Bush looked forward to ``frank, penetrating discussions.'' ``The president approaches this summit as a very serious meeting in which very specific and meaningful agreements will be achieved,'' Fitzwater said. It was the second consecutive day that Bush remained out of sight _ and behind closed doors _ meeting with senior advisors and poring over summit briefing books. Within sight of Bush's Oval Office windows, a military band rehearsed on the South Lawn and workers put the finishing touches on scaffolding and a three-tier viewing stand for Thursday's official morning welcoming ceremonies. Enormous U.S. and Soviet flags were draped over the entrance to the Old Executive Office Building next door and smaller flags decorated lamp posts surrounding the White House complex. Across the street, a rock band made up of Soviet youths, bearing T-shirts declaring ``Rock Not Rockets,'' played in Lafayette Park _ sparsely populated on Wednesday but expected to be crammed with demonstrators on Thursday. Bush had no plans to leave the White House, nor was he expected to speak to Gorbachev _ arriving in Washington in early evening after his stopover in Canada _ before Thursday's arrival ceremony, Fitzwater said. However, since both leaders have in the past demonstrated a degree of unpredictability, Fitzwater declined to be pinned down when asked to say for certain that Bush would not contact Gorbachev on Wednesday night. ``I don't rule anything out,'' the spokesman said. Bush attended two briefings from advisors in the morning _ one dealing with economic and trade issues and the second with arms control. In the afternoon, he held a final briefing session ``with key advisors to consider overview questions, the general tone and texture of the summit,'' Fitzwater said. While not detailing what Bush and Kohl talked about in their Wednesday morning phone call, Fitzwater said the president does not plan to unveil any new proposal at the summit to limit the military forces of a unified Germany. He said that Bush still shares Kohl's views that a reunified Germany should be a full member of NATO. ``We are opposed to any proposal which would single out Germany for special limits,'' Fitzwater said. At the same time, Fitzwater said, the issue of force levels within Germany was a proper subject for ``follow-on conventional arms control negotiations'' once a treaty to reduce troops and tanks throughout Europe is reached. ``The issue of the size of the (German army) is of obvious concern to the Soviets. We understand that,'' Fitzwater said. However, he added that it was not an issue that could be resolved at this week's summit. Fitzwater said Germany unity would likely be discussed in greater depth at the more-relaxed talks expected to take place on Saturday between Bush and Gorbachev at the U.S. presidential retreat at Camp David, Md. As it stood Wednesday, Bush and Gorbachev at their White House sessions on Thursday and Friday planned to deal primarily with arms control, conventional arms, chemical weapons, trade and other issues that could lead to ``various specific agreements,'' Fitzwater said. ``There are a lot of floating parts at this moment,'' the White House spokesman said. ``And trying to put order in that process is really what Saturday's discussions are all about.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Will Offer Gorbachev Assurances On Germany But No Deal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3rd graf to UPDATE with Gorbachev quote.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will cut no deal with Mikhail S. Gorbachev at this week's summit to limit German troops, but he is prepared to discuss a formula that might eventually scale down those forces along with the Red Army, U.S. officials said Wednesday. The issue of German unification and its impact on arms control loomed as the potential spoiler at the four-day summit, and Gorbachev signaled his determination to press the matter before leaving Canada for Washington. ``There are different scenarios that might not be exactly what the West would propose,'' he told reporters before leaving Ottawa. ``There should be no attempt to dictate a solution.'' Gorbachev's reservations about the more powerful nation that will emerge from the merger of East Germany with West Germany have contributed to a slowdown in negotiations to cut U.S. and Soviet troops, tanks, aircraft, helicopters and other non-nuclear weapons in Europe. American and Soviet negotiators held a fourth day of pre-summit talks at the State Department to try to overcome the slump and to expand on the kinds of long-range nuclear weapons to be reduced in another treaty. They met for an hour and a half in the morning and did not resume in the afternoon. ``Everybody would like to see things progress, but there isn't a lot of progress,'' a U.S. official said. ``They are waiting for the rest of the team.'' Meanwhile, Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze arranged to meet separately Friday at the White House while Bush and Gorbachev hold their first session. In 11th-hour drive to forge agreements, the Kremlin assigned Col. Gen. Labronislav Omelichev, first deputy on the Soviet defense ministry's general staff, to the talks. There was no immediate word of his arrival from Moscow. The move was viewed by U.S. officials as a positive step. Omelichev, a specialist on strategic nuclear weapons, was considered instrumental in the headway the two superpowers made in negotiations here in February. Before leaving Ottawa for the summit in Washington, Gorbachev referred to U.S. insistence on full NATO membership for a more powerful German neighbor, saying, ``I would like us to find a new melody.'' Bush administration officials here said the president was determined to have a successful meeting with Gorbachev and to try to ease the Soviet leader's concerns without backing away from having Germany in the Western alliance. They said any settlement would require the participation and consent of West Germany and the other partners in the 16-nation military group. ``We are opposed to any proposal which would single out Germany for special limits,'' Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said. However, Bush and Gorbachev will discuss the ``general question'' of German unification and ``we want to hear their concerns and interests,'' Fitzwater said. The formula other U.S. officials said Bush was ready to take up with Gorbachev involved a tradeoff, to be negotiated by NATO and the Warsaw Pact in Vienna after a treaty to reduce U.S. and Soviet troops and non-nuclear forces in Europe is finished. The Western allies would consider imposing limitations on the size of the German army, but in exchange the Soviets would have to agree to cut down the Red Army proportionally within the Soviet Union, said the officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity. And, in a concession to Gorbachev, who finds the buffer provided by the Warsaw Pact crumbling, NATO troops would keep out of what is now East Germany while some Red Army troops could stay there for ``a transitional period,'' the official said. Spokesman Fitzwater, hinting at the arrangement, said Bush was prepared to explore ``mutually acceptable options and positions.'' He stressed there would be no bargaining, though, over unifying Germany. Assistant Secretary of State Raymond G.H. Seitz told reporters that the United States wants rapid unification in ``an orderly fashion'' and with the new Germany enjoying the privileges and responsibilities of all other nations in Europe. ``That doesn't seem to be the Soviet approach,'' he said. Seitz said the Soviets have ``a lot of legitimate concern'' which the United States and its allies must address ``but not at the cost of a fully sovereign Germany.'' As for the arms talks, Margaret D. Tutwiler, the State Department spokeswoman, said, ``There are still a lot of questions to be answered. ... I can tell you there has been some progress, but there has not been a definite resolution.'' The current negotiations got a pre-summit boost on Tuesday with an agreement on how to define tanks and armored personnel carriers. This will help in carrying out cutbacks in U.S. and Soviet arsenals in Europe and also in verifying compliance with an eventual arms reduction treaty. But U.S. officials, disclosing Omelichev's imminent arrival, said there was no breakthrough on a half-dozen strategic nuclear weapons issues. Nor, he said, have the negotiators settled on a definition of combat aircraft, the key sticking point in the conventional arms arena, despite the presence at the table of the top Soviet negotiator, Oleg A. Grinevsky. There is ample agreement on enough strategic weapons reductions to enable Bush and Gorbachev to issue a declaration during the summit pledging to reduce their arsenals of nuclear missiles, bombers and submarines by 30 to 35 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Barry, Feds in Plea Bargain Talks, Source Says
DOC.TEXT: Preliminary plea bargaining has begun between Mayor Marion Barry's attorney and federal prosecutors over the mayor's drug and perjury case, a source familiar with the mayor's legal situation said Wednesday. The source, a long-time confidant of Barry's who spoke only on condition of anonymity, said U.S. Attorney Jay B. Stephens and defense lawyer R. Kenneth Mundy held their first discussion last week. Barry has pleaded innocent to all charges and lawyers on both sides of the case have consistently denied any plea bargain discussions were taking place The mayor is scheduled to stand trial on 14 charges beginning June 4. In an interview published in Wednesday's editions of The Washington Post, Barry acknowledged smoking crack cocaine just prior to his Jan. 18 arrest at a downtown Washington hotel in an FBI sting operation. But he said federal authorities had tried to kill him by allowing him access to potent drugs. He also dismissed earlier reports that he was considering a plea bargain. ``I think the prosecutors know that in this town all it takes is one juror saying, `I'm not going to convict Marion Barry. I don't care what you say,''' Barry told the newspaper. However, Barry added, ``I'm not saying that never in life that one doesn't re-examine one's position.'' Later, he added: ``My ego is not such that I'm going to go crazy if I'm not the mayor.'' The source who disclosed the discussions between Mundy and Stephens said, ``These are preliminary talks, sort of a feeling-out process. But they're still talking.'' ``Of course, these are plea bargain discussions,'' the source added. The source said Stephens and Mundy have had at least four conversations since last Friday, when U.S. District Court Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson denied Mundy's motion to dismiss the case. ``They're still talking, but they are a long way off,'' the source said. ``They are not making a great deal of progress, but it would be wrong to say they cannot ultimately reach a settlement.'' Barry, who faces three felony counts of lying to a grand jury about his alleged drug use, would be barred from office and prohibited from running for re-election if convicted of any of those charges. ``He would not plead to that,'' the source said. ``The thinking is, he would rather take his chances in court.'' The 54-year-old mayor also faces 10 misdemeanor cocaine possession charges and one misdemeanor cocaine conspiracy charge. Neither Mundy nor Stephens could immediately be reached for comment. Several telephone calls to each were not returned. Barry has not publicly revealed his political plans but has been making a series of campaign-style appearances around the city in recent weeks. Anita Bonds, Barry's campaign manager, said in a statement Tuesday that her staff is ``very hopeful that we will have a candidate for mayor in Mayor Marion Barry later this season.'' Bonds told The Associated Press that she intends to pick up candidate petitions from the city's Board of Elections later this week. Such a move would mark Barry's first formal step toward a candidacy.

DOC.HEAD: Engineers Suspect Leaking Fuel Line
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with launch off until middle of next week at earliest, provides details of leak, quotes from launch director, plans to go into payload bay to replenish telescope's argon supply; DELETES outdated material.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto CSB1; LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Space shuttle Columbia will not take off until next week at the earliest after a fuel leak scrubbed Wednesday's launch, NASA officials said. Columbia had been scheduled to lift off at 12:38 a.m. EDT with a $150 million observatory called Astro. But it was called off about six hours before launch time when hydrogen began leaking while Columbia's external fuel tank was being loaded. Workers were expected to enter Columbia's rear engine compartment early Thursday to search for the leak and assess the problem. But first all the hydrogen must be vented from the external tank and the system must be purged with non-flammable helium. ``It's hard to believe at the rate (of) leak we've seen that we missed it,'' said Bascom Murrah, a NASA official in charge of pre-launch operations for Columbia. ``Something gave. But it's a guessing game until we get in there.'' It was the first time a shuttle launch had been scrubbed during fueling.
