More than a half-million gallons of super-cold liquid hydrogen and liquid oxygen were being pumped into Columbia's external tank. ``The system was tight going into launch count, and it passed all of our standard leak tests. We felt good about it,'' said NASA launch director Bob Sieck. ``The problem did not manifest itself until we saw cold cryogenic temperatures. Of course, it is our hope that it is still there under ambient conditions when we go into our troubleshooting.'' Columbia's seven astronauts returned to their home base at Johnson Space Center in Houston on Wednesday. They planned to practice liftoffs and landings in a shuttle mission simulator while awaiting a new launch date. Engineers for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration spent hours opening and closing valves and watching a network of sensors before finding the general area of the leaks late Tuesday. A 17-inch valve in a pipe that carries fuel from the external tank to the shuttle's main engines was believed to have a leak the size of a pinhole, Sieck said. Sieck said hydrogen leaked for fewer than five minutes before the fueling was halted. Readings showed hydrogen inside the aft end of Columbia as well as outside the orbiter. Hydrogen also leaked from equipment on the launch platform, but that was minor and would not have prevented NASA from proceeding with the launch, Murrah said. If the problem is ``something obvious that we can repair on the pad, then we'll do that and fly,'' Murrah said. Sieck said given those circumstances, the middle of next week would be the earliest another launch could be attempted. A worse-case scenario would mean rolling Columbia back to its hangar, which likely would mean a delay of about a month, Murrah said. ``There is still maybe some unknown that we can check or test every aspect of the (valve) between the orbiter and the external tank in the current configuration at that pad,'' Sieck said. ``However, it's a technical problem and with technical problems we can find them. We will find it and we will fix it and we will get on with (the mission). There's just a schedule uncertainty as to when we'll be there.'' In either case, NASA plans to open Columbia's payload bay on Friday and replenish the argon supply of Astro's X-ray telescope, Sieck said. The telescope constantly needs argon so its instruments remain cold. The job is expected to take more than two days but could be done in conjunction with other work. NASA said Wednesday it would proceed as planned with Friday's scheduled launch of a German X-ray observatory known as Rosat. The observatory will be boosted into orbit by an unmanned Delta rocket. Columbia's nine- to 10-day mission with Astro will be the 36th shuttle flight and the first one in five years devoted entirely to scientific research. The observatory's four telescopes will examine ultraviolet light and X-rays emitted from extremely hot stars and galaxies. Such radiation is invisible from the ground.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Leader Appeals for Compromise on Germany; Speaks of `Leeway'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 24 grafs to UPDATE with Gorbachev comments on Lithuania and the Baltics, tightens; Picks up 24th graf, `Canada announced ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos OTT102, OTT1; LaserColor OTT103
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said Wednesday the West's insistence on keeping a united Germany in NATO sounds ``like an old record,'' and indicated he would offer new ideas to break the impasse. ``We do have some leeway to find an accommodation. There are different scenarios that might not be exactly what the West would propose,'' he told reporters before he flew to Washington for his summit with President Bush. Western leaders ``are trying to dictate to a certain degree,'' Gorbachev said. ``There should be no attempt to dictate a solution.'' Gorbachev said he and Prime Minister Brian Mulroney spent ``a considerable part of our time'' discussing German unification, but said they had not resolved a disagreement over whether a united Germany could belong to NATO. ``In spite of all that, I think we can say we had an exchange which was positive and very constructive,'' he said. ``It was a short visit but a very intense visit.'' Mulroney, like Bush and the other western allies, supports keeping Germany within NATO. West Germany currently belongs to the western military alliance; East Germany belongs to the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact. The Soviet Union has suggested that a united Germany could belong to both military alliances, or a new security system, but has opposed suggestions that it belong only to NATO. Gorbachev has said failure to somehow neutralize Germany or prevent it from ever again threatening the Soviet Union could stall the Soviet military withdrawal from Eastern Europe. ``We have to find a course of action that will support, rather than do damage to, those very important changes that are happening in Europe and in the world,'' he said. ``It has to be a course of action that we find together. ``I have not yet heard any alternative from the West. It seems that it is just like an old record that keeps playing the same notes again and again. I would like us to ... find a new melody.'' At an airport news conference before leaving for Washington, Gorbachev said that the nations discussing German unification must carefully consider the consequences, as well as the views and interests of all sides. ``This is not just a 30-second basketball match,'' he said. ``You have to ask: What does the other side want? Maybe we have to take a time out.'' In addition, he said, German leaders have much work to do before achieving unification. ``They have to get rid of euphoria and get down to business because they have enough problems,'' he said. Gorbachev also spoke of a ``changing Europe, changing for the better. Instead of confrontation, we are getting to know each other better. We are even getting to trust each other.'' Mulroney was conciliatory, saying he believes there has been an ``inadvertent insensitivity to the legitimate security apprehensions of the Soviet Union.'' He told reporters that no country suffered more than the Soviet Union in World War II. Mulroney urged the United States and the Soviet Union to pursue a compromise course to avoid dealing ``a lethal blow'' to the progress that has been made in East-West relations. Gorbachev also answered questions about his problems with the three secessionist Baltic republics. He noted there has been ``pressure to use very hard measures to resolve this question.'' Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia were forcibly annexed in 1940 and have been seeking to secede from the Soviet Union. Gorbachev imposed economic sanctions against Lithuania after it declared independence on March 11. He became very animated when he discussed Lithuania's declaration, which he said was done in a ``dishonest, thief-like manner'' on the eve of an important meeting of the Soviet Parliament. And he said those Lithuanians seeking immediate independence are ``adventurists.'' Gorbachev has said the republics can only win their independence by following the Soviet Constitution, which requires the republics to get the approval of Soviet lawmakers. On a conciliatory note, he said ``our federation does require some fundamental changes'' to give republics greater sovereignty and the ability to preserve their languages and cultures. ``I think this is a progressive movement, and I think this should be reflected in modern politics,'' he said. But he warned that fears are raised when separatism ``rears its head.'' Canada announced during the visit it will extend a $500 million line of credit to the Soviet Union over the next two years. The aid is about $425 million in U.S. dollars. Earlier, after a wreath-laying ceremony at a war memorial, Gorbachev and Mulroney surprised their escorts by walking part of the short distance to Parliament Hill to continue their talks. As they strolled toward the ornate stone Parliament building, they smiled and occasionally paused to speak to the crowd that gathered behind police barriers. They then got in their cars to drive the final stretch and avoided an encounter with a group of several hundred demonstrators who protested Gorbachev's refusal to grant independence to the Baltic republics of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia.

DOC.HEAD: 71 Students Eliminated in First 3 Rounds; 155 Spellers Survive. ^Eds: Tops with 6 grafs to update with 3rd round of competition and conclusion of first day; picks up 5th graf: ``The youngsters,'' DELETES 11th graf pvs: ``During the,'' now redundant
DOC.TEXT: Scores of super-spelling youngsters, conquering such words as ``clepsydra'' and ``probouleutic,'' breezed through the early rounds Wednesday of the 63rd annual National Spelling Bee. About two-thirds of the 226 competitor who had begun the two-day spelling contest in a hotel ballroom remained in contention after the first three rounds. Seventy-one of the spellers dropped out, victims of such words as ``upeygan,'' ``ipsedixitism'' and ``quercitron'' in the annual contest. The opening rounds moved quickly as the competitors were asked to spell words from a master list of 1,000 selected by a panel of researchers. The words in the first three rounds were among more than 2,000 words provided to competitors for study. Organizers of the competition said the spellers, who are 10 to 14 years old, will find it tougher in the next rounds when words will be used that have not been on the study list. ``There will be a dramatic change,'' said Alex Cameron, the pronouncer in the competition. In Wednesday's competition, eight spellers were eliminated in the first round. The tougher second round took 33 additional contestants, including Erika Harrell, 9, the youngest competitor. Erika, a fourth grader from Muncie, Ind., stumbled on ``soliterraneous'' _ forgetting the second ``r.'' Another 30 contestants dropped out in the third round. The youngsters sat on rows of chairs on a stage and, one by one, walked to the microphone to be challenged. The winner of the bee, which concludes Thursday, will win $5,000, a trophy cup and special prizes from Encyclopaedia Britannica. ``Waiting for your number to come around'' is the hardest, said Melissa Lake, 14, an eighth grader from Denver, between rounds. She had just spelled correctly ``erubescent''. Nathan Erb, 13, an eighth grader from Lapeer, Mich., agreed, saying that ``keeping yourself awake'' between words was also a challenge. The first two words thrown at him were not much of a challenge, however. He handled both ``casserole'' and then ``belomancy.'' Margaret Rhine, 10, a fifth grader from Lexington, S.C., and one of the younger competitors, had not competed before this year. But she has had a lot of advice from her brother, who made it to the nationals twice, each time being eliminated in the fourth round. ``I got two relatively easy (words),'' Margaret said with some relief. She advanced through the second round by spelling ``eviternity.'' Here are a few other words that contestants spelled correctly in the early rounds: clepsydra, probouleutic, weddellite, chasmophyte, burisiculate, gastriloquist, pityriasis and leggieramente. Last year 903 words were spelled before Scott Isaacs, 14, of Englewood Colo., emerged as champion. The competition, which began in 1925, is sponsored by Scripps Howard Newspapers and 208 other daily, weekly and Sunday newspapers in 47 states. This year one contestant is making a fourth appearance in the national competition; five others were competing for a third time, and 35 were at the event for a second time. To get to the national competition, the 127 girls and 99 boys had competed against nearly 9 million other students at the local level.

DOC.HEAD: Accused Arsonist Says She Was Angered By Court Abortion Decision
DOC.TEXT: A woman told police she tried to set fire to a Planned Parenthood Center because she was infuriated by a U.S. Supreme Court ruling that protesters could not block abortion clinics. Shari D. DiNicola, 24, was arrested Monday and charged with two counts of arson and one count of attempted arson. She pleaded innocent Tuesday and was released. City Court Judge Langston C. McKinney ordered her not to go near Planned Parenthood; its director or his home. DiNicola said made the first of three attempts to burn down Planned Parenthood's Syracuse clinic on May 23, two days after the Supreme Court decision. In a statement to police after her arrest, she said the high court's decision ``made me furious.'' ``My intentions in doing these acts were not to hurt anybody. I am opposed to abortions and my objective was to burn the building down to put Planned Parenthood out of business,'' DiNicola said. DiNicola's relatives said she is receiving psychiatric counseling. Her lawyer, Gaetano Colozzi, said he might raise her mental condition as a reason for suppressing her statement in court. On May 21, the Supreme Court upheld a ban on demonstrations at New York City area abortion clinics by the group, Operation Rescue. A week earlier, the court left intact a ban on Operation Rescue blockades in Atlanta. DiNicola was arrested early Monday after police said a videotape camera they set up caught her trying to set a fire at the clinic. DiNicola also admitted in her statement to two other arson attempts at the center. None of the fires caused any serious damage. Planned Parenthood officials had blamed the fires on Operation Rescue. Sixty-four Operation Rescue protesters have been arrested at the clinic since March 1989. DiNicola and her relatives said she has never been a member of the group.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Summit Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a transcript of the arrival statements Wednesday by Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

Baker: Mr. President, Mrs. Gorbachev, I am delighted to welcome you to Washington on behalf of the president and Mrs. Bush and on behalf as well of the American people. Mr. President, the eyes of the world are on you, and they are on President Bush. Together, our nations have the responsibility to leave behind not only the Cold War but also the conflicts that preceded it. To do that, we must see a Germany unified and Europe reconciled. We must reduce the danger of war by controlling nuclear, chemical and conventional arms and by resolving regional conflicts. And of course we want to see continued movement toward democracy and openness in the Soviet Union. Mr. President, the world has looked forward since last winter to this visit and to the promise that this visit holds. So together this week, let us seek to fulfill that promise.

Gorbachev: Thank you, Mr. Secretary of State for your words of welcome and hospitality. In these first minutes of our visit to America I wish to convey on behalf of the people of the U.S.S.R. our best wishes to the people of the United States. We are looking forward to important talks with President George Bush. A lot will depend on their results in determining how things will work out, not only between you Americans and us, but also on a larger scale. We shall also have meetings with other political leaders, public figures and, I hope, with other Americans of various positions and walks of life. This summit stands out in its importance, first of all, for the promise it holds as the first major step to reduce strategic nuclear arms. Both sides have worked painstakingly together to prepare it. This meeting is also special because this is the first time that the president of the United States and I will have enough time to reflect on and discuss, not only in a formal setting but also in more informal surroundings, one on one, all questions either of us might have that fall within our responsibility. I would like once again to wish peace and well being to every American home. Thank you.

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Win Right For Ceremony, But Get City's Cold Shoulder
DOC.TEXT: A Chinese group won the right Wednesday to use a Buffalo park to commemorate last year's Tiananmen Square crackdown, but was promptly warned not to expect any help from City Hall. The group, June 4 Memorial Fund, persuaded a judge to block enforcement of a city ordinance that forbids ``any speech, oration or harangue'' in a city park without written permission from the parks commissioner. The judge said the ordinance was probably unconstitutional. ``In the absence of narrowly drawn reasons and definite standards for officials to follow, the ordinance must be invalid,'' said state Supreme Court Justice Leo J. Fallon. Parks Commissioner Stanley Buczkowski rejected the group's bid to use Delaware Park, Buffalo's major park, this Sunday, but offered instead to close a downtown square to traffic so the ceremony could be held there instead. Russell Sciandra, the city's lawyer, said he would not recommend an appeal, but warned the group it can expect no special services from the city. ``We were attempting to assist them by creating special arrangements for them in terms of police, fire, streets, sanitation, et cetera,'' Sciandra said. ``They don't feel they need it. If they have the unfettered right to use the park, so be it.'' Eva Koepsell, the group's secretary, said she found the city's attitude ``appalling.'' ``Every other major city in the United States is sponsoring a ceremony to remember the students who died'' in the June 4 military crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators in Beijing, she said. Wei-Hsung Lin, the group's president, said the city's cold shoulder would force organizers to look elsewhere for a stage and electricity, but he said the experience was instructive. ``It taught me a lot about the constitutional rights of freedom of speech and freedom of assembly,'' said Lin, a graduate student at the State University of New York at Buffalo.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Leader Adds South Korea Talks to U.S. Agenda
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Top 10 grafs new to update with embassy tea, color from arrival ceremony; picks up 7th graf pvs, ``U.S. officials xxx'' and adds 2 grafs at end with congressional meeting
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, seeking to broaden Moscow's links to the capitalist world, will meet with South Korea's president next week in San Francisco, U.S. officials said Wednesday. Moscow and Seoul have no formal diplomatic relations, and Gorbachev's decision to hold the meeting represents the strongest Soviet gesture yet toward South Korea. The Korea announcement came hours before Gorbachev arrived in Washington for four days of summitry with President Bush. At a red-carpet welcoming ceremony at Andrews Air Force Base, Md., Gorbachev said his meeting with Bush ``stands out in its importance'' for an expected U.S.-Soviet agreement on the outlines of a strategic nuclear weapons treaty. He also alluded to his desire to improve Soviet relations with the non-communist world. Referring to the global importance of the Washington discussions, Gorbachev said, ``A lot will depend on their results in determining how things will work out not only between you Americans and us but also on a larger scale.'' Gorbachev was greeted by Secretary of State James A. Baker III, and the pair traveled together to the Soviet Embassy for tea. Soviet television broadcast tidbits from the embassy reception. About 1,000 people, both sightseers and protesters, were kept a block and a half from the embassy, and as the motorcade drove by the applause drowned out the boos. Among the protesters were about 30 people chanting ``Stop killing Armenians'' and another group with Lithuanian flags and signs saying such things as ``No tanks in Lithuania.'' Gorbachev is scheduled to meet with South Korean President Roh Tae-woo on Monday in San Francisco, where he also will see Ronald Reagan and former Secretary of State George Shultz. U.S. officials said they played no role in arranging the meeting but were pleased to see it happen. Gorbachev flew to Washington from Ottawa, where he said after a day of talks with Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney that he was waiting for the Western allies to sing ``a new melody'' on the contentious issue of a united Germany's membership in NATO. Conflicting U.S. and Soviet views on the military alignment of a reunified Germany _ and on the future role of NATO itself _ was expected to be a major topic of Gorbachev's three days of meetings with President Bush starting Thursday morning. ``The United States has strongly supported Seoul's efforts to establish normal relations with the Soviet Union,'' said Margaret Tutwiler, a State Department spokeswoman. Shortly before Gorbachev headed for Washington, the president and the prime minister of Lithuania issued a joint statement on the summit, stressing their desire for an early end to Moscow's economic sanctions. In a videotaped message broadcast via satellite from Vilnius, the Lithuanian capital, Kazimiera Prunskiene, prime minister of the breakaway Baltic republic, said the energy situation there would reach an ``essentially critical'' stage this week unless Gorbachev agreed to end his cutoff of oil and other fuel shipments. ``We will be forced to stop not only the functioning of heating systems, but also the nuclear power station, which is our primary source of electricity, in order to avoid a disaster similar to Chernobyl,'' Prunskiene said in reference to the 1986 nuclear power plant accident that killed at least 31 people. While hoping to pressure Gorbachev into opening negotiations with Lithuania on a transition to independence, the Bush administration also is concerned that a mounting number of domestic Soviet crises could break Gorbachev's grip on power. Administration officials sought Thursday to accentuate the positive. ``He is a man of great political strength, clearly in control of the political apparatus,'' said Raymond Seitz, assistant secretary of state for European and Canadian affairs. ``It would be foolish to think he doesn't have problems, but lots of political leaders have lots of political problems,'' Seitz told reporters in a pre-summit briefing. During at least part of his stay in Washington, Gorbachev may be able to set aside his worries. At least four U.S. organizations are planning to present the Soviet president with special awards at a ceremony Friday at the Soviet Embassy. The Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt Institute said it would give Gorbachev its Franklin Delano Roosevelt International Four Freedoms Award for his ``extraordinary contributions'' in creating the possibility of the United States and the Soviet Union once again becoming allies. Also on Friday afternoon Gorbachev is to receive a ``Man of History'' award from the Appeal of Conscience Foundation, a group of religious and business leaders; the Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Peace Award from the Friends World College of Long Island, N.Y.; an the Albert Einstein Peace Prize from the Chicago-based Albert Einstein Peace Prize Foundation. Earlier in the day Friday, Gorbachev scheduled a meeting with congressional leaders at the Soviet Embassy. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said he was invited to attend the session, along with Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan.; Sen. Rudy Boschwitz, R-Minn.; Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., the majority whip; Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Armed Services Committee; Sen. Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., chairman of Foreign Relations; House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo.; House Minority Leader Robert Michel, R-Ill.; Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of Armed Services; Rep. Dante Fascell, D-Fla., chairman of Foreign Affairs.

DOC.HEAD: Massachusetts Man, Two Soviets Share Prize on Ruble Convertibility
With AM-Summit Rdp
DOC.TEXT: An American and two citizens of the Soviet Union won $10,000 prizes Wednesday for their proposals on how to make the Soviet ruble convertible into dollars and other international currencies. The winners were Giuzel Anulova of the Moscow Institute of World Economy, K. Panov, a Soviet citizen who works for the United Nations Commission for Africa in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia and Franklyn Holzman of Tufts University in Medford, Mass. near Boston. The prizes were awarded by a private San Francisco foundation. ``These papers have in common the underlying assumption that the only effective path to ruble convertibility is through the creation of a market economy,'' said a statement signed by six jurors in the competition. Three signers were from the Soviet Union and three from the United States. The Soviet Union needs dollars and other western or ``hard'' currencies to buy essential imports like grain and certain machinery. To get hard currencies, it sells oil, natural gas, diamonds, furs, arms, vodka and other exports. Ordinary people and most Soviet government enterprises cannot simply go to world currency markets and offer rubles for dollars, as citizens of other countries can trade their currencies. Few people will buy rubles because the ruble can buy very little on world markets. Many joint ventures involve awkward barter arrangements to get around the lack of currency convertibility. The Soviet central government sets the rules for currency conversions, including rates and amounts, to conserve its limited stock of foreign currencies, and it controls the allocation of that inventory. Major cities have lively black markets but these work only on a small scale for individuals, who for instance may be willing to spend the rubles they get in sightseeing and other tourist activities. The black market cannot be used for the big transactions of world trade. Officially, the ruble is worth about $1.56(0.64 rubles per dollar). In fact, Soviet importers reportedly got only 80 cents (1.25 rubles per dollar) for each ruble last year; travelers get 16 cents per ruble (6.26 rubles per dollar) and on the black market, the ruble can go for as little as 6.7 cents (15 rubles per dollar). ``After two days of intense discussion the jury came away impressed with the difficulties involved in devising a workable strategy for achieving a convertible ruble, and also with the immense importance of making headway on this issue,'' the jury statement said. One of the Soviet judges was Ivan D. Ivanov, deputy chairman of the Soviet Foreign Economic Commission. He suggested at a news conference that convertibility might be achieved by the end of the century. One of the American judges was Ed A. Hewett, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, a leading Washington-based research institute. He said the judges deliberately refrained from distinguishing publicly among the ideas of the three winners. Another American judge, Anne O. Krueger, a professor of economics at Duke University and former vice president of the World Bank, said all the winners agreed that a first step would have to be stabilization of prices within the Soviet Union. Stabilization would have to be followed by a freeing of prices for all kinds of goods now regulated by the state, and finally links between the Soviet domestic economy and the international economy that she did not detail. The differences among the papers were small, she added, and concerned such matters as the relative time and importance given to the successive stages. Prices in the Soviet Union are highly controlled, and inflationary pressures typically show up as shortages. Many prices are to increase drastically on July 1 as the government hopes to ease shortages. A second prize of $4,000 was awarded to each of three other contestants: _Saltan Dzarasov, chairman of the Department of Political Economy as the Soviet Academy of Sciences. _Zsuzsa Kelen of the Hungarian Ministry of Finance _Kurosch Shafei of Frankfurt, West Germany. Their plans called for the Soviets to introduce a new kind of money, parallel with the existing ruble, as a step toward convertibility. The jury said it was not convinced a parallel currency would necessarily work but recognized that a large body of expert opinion supports the idea. There were 584 entries from 23 countries, according to organizers of the prizes. There will be a conference in Moscow in October where the winners and others will be asked to present their ideas. The $42,000 in prize money came from the Furth Foundation of San Francisco, Calif., which has previously spent much of its effort on helping young Americans get educations.

DOC.HEAD: Phone Book of Khashoggi Reveals Famous Friends
DOC.TEXT: Any doubt that Saudi financier Adnan Khashoggi mixes with the rich and famous was dispelled Wednesday when one of his personal phone books was admitted into evidence at his fraud trial. Entries in the looseleaf book included presidents, entertainers, athletes, business figures and apparently Leona Helmsley. Among the politicians: former Presidents Richard Nixon and Jimmy Carter; former Secretary of State Henry Kissinger; and Robert McFarlane, the former national security adviser under President Reagan. Actors and entertainers included Christopher Reeve, Farah Fawcett, Liza Minnelli, Paul Anka, Wayne Newton and Brooke Shields. Also listed was George Hamilton, a close friend of Khashoggi's co-defendant, Imelda Marcos, who earlier testified at the trial. The book also held phone numbers for Muhammad Ali, Chrysler Chairman Lee Iaccoca and a ``Mrs. Helmsely,'' an apparent reference to hotel queen Leona Helmsley, who last year was convicted of tax evasion in the same Manhattan federal courtroom where Khashoggi and Mrs. Marcos are being tried. The book was admitted into evidence during testimony by Robert Shaheen, a longtime employee of Khashoggi, who said the phone numbers were kept by Khashoggi's staff at his Fifth Avenue duplex apartment. Khashoggi, once described as the world's wealthiest man, is charged with obstruction of justice and mail fraud.

DOC.HEAD: Bush, Gorbachev Stake Out Rival Stands on Germany as Summit Convenes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, setting the stage for the first post-Cold War summit, staked out rival stands Wednesday on the military shape and political alliance of a unified Germany. The Soviet leader opened his American visit with a warm red-carpet welcome at a military airport, then moved on to a boisterous greeting from a thousand people at the Soviets' downtown embassy. Applause drowned out a chorus of boos. Secretary of States James A. Baker III welcomed Gorbachev and touched immediately on the German question, which loomed as the thorniest summit issue. ``Together our nations have the responsibility to leave behind not only the Cold War but the conflicts that preceded it. ``To do that we must see a Germany unified and Europe reconciled,'' Baker said. He added, ``We want to see continued movement toward democracy and openness in the Soviet Union.'' Even as the Soviet leader arrived in Washington, there were new indications of domestic turmoil: political maverick Boris Yeltsin announced his intention to seek sovereignty for the republic of Russia. Bush will formally welcome Gorbachev to the White House at a Thursday morning ceremony of pomp and military honors. Vice President Dan Quayle said the president spent Wednesday reviewing ``all the possible issues that could be raised, all the points he wants to raise with Gorbachev.'' At a pre-summit news conference in Ottawa, Gorbachev punctuated the issue of German unity by complaining that the West was trying to ``dictate'' the future of the new nation. ``This will not suit us,'' he warned. Yet the Soviet leader did not mention the dispute when he arrived in Washington. ``A lot will depend on our results,'' Gorbachev said. ``This summit stands out in its importance, first of all, for the promise it holds as the first major step to reduce strategic nuclear arms.'' The two leaders were ready to sign long-sought agreements to reduce nuclear and chemical weapons, but their differences on Germany pushed to the top of the agenda on the eve of the four-day meeting. Gorbachev emphasized his opposition to a united Germany belonging to the West's NATO alliance and challenged Bush to offer another solution. ``It seems that it is just like an old record that seems to be playing the same note again and again. ... I would like us to find a new melody,'' Gorbachev said in Ottawa. The White House said Bush was sympathetic to Soviet anxieties about the military might of a combined Germany and said it would pursue an answer that was ``politically acceptable and reasonable.'' Gorbachev also voiced hopes for compromise. ``We do have some leeway to find an accommodation. There are different scenarios that might not be exactly what the West would propose.'' In a reminder of Gorbachev's domestic troubles, Lithuanian leaders sent a televised appeal via satellite to Washington for a lifting of Moscow's economic blockade. They said oil shortages threaten to shut down heating systems in the breakaway Baltic republic. A few hours later, Yeltsin, the newly elected president of Russia, said he would seek sovereignty for the Soviet Union's largest republic. The summit, opening Thursday, was the biggest show in town. Red Soviet flags snapped in the wind alongside American flags in front of 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue. Vendors hawked summit T-shirts, and television cameras staked out building tops within eyesight of the White House. Thousands of demonstrators were poised to raise their voices in Lafayette Park in protest of Soviet pressure against the Baltic states and other issues. Gorbachev comes to Washington as a leader besieged by growing domestic woes ranging from an economic crisis to fractures within the Soviet Communist Party. Bush enjoys strong political support but stands accused by conservative critics of giving away too much in arms deals to a weakened Soviet leader. Bush, closeted with advisers in a final day of preparations, gave the pre-summit limelight to Gorbachev. The president spoke by telephone with West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, who is trying to accelerate the move of East Germany to the West into a single nation outside of Soviet influence. Bush also talked with Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, who was Gorbachev's host during an overnight visit in Ottawa. U.S. and Soviet negotiators were wrapping up a dozen agreements ranging from nuclear and chemical weapons to air travel and grain sales for the leaders to sign at a formal ceremony Friday evening. ``As we move from conflict to cooperation, the agreements reached on Thursday and Friday will provide for a realistic foundation for the growing and changing U.S.-Soviet relationship,'' said White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater. He hinted Bush might be willing to sign a trade agreement with Gorbachev despite differences over Lithuania's struggle for independence. The treaty would be a step short of giving Moscow coveted most-favored-nation trade status, which would lower tariffs on Soviet goods. ``I intentionally want to be vague'' about prospects for a trade pact, said Fitzwater. ``I urge you not to rule out anything.'' Describing Bush's mood as one of ``anticipation and confidence,'' Fitzwater said, ``The president sees a new horizon in this meeting, a horizon of opportunity. And after these discussions we should have a much better view of a new day in East-West relations.'' The sharp differences over Germany threatened to mar summit harmony. The United States insists that a united Germany be a full partner in NATO, politically and militarily. Gorbachev has been reluctant to let the World War II prize of Germany slip away. He has proposed that it be a member of both NATO and the Warsaw Pact, or that both alliances be isbanded. Fitzwater said Bush would explore the subject with Gorbachev from the standpoint of seeking ``mutually acceptable options and positions.'' ``These issues are not going to be decided here,'' he said. Fitzwater said the size of German forces are ``of obvious concern to the Soviets. We understand that.'' He said the problem could be addressed within the context of European-wide troop reductions in future talks, following an expected first-stage agreement this year. ``We are opposed to any proposal which would single out Germany for special (military) limits,'' he said. Assistant Secretary of State Raymond Seitz, briefing reporters, described the German question as an area of ``real conceptual differences'' between the superpowers. He said the United States wants rapid unification, in ``an orderly fashion'' with Germany enjoying the privileges and responsibilities of all other nations in Europe. ``That doesn't seem to be the Soviet approach,'' he said. There were last-minute jitters over a pact to slash long-range nuclear missiles and hopes for progress to cut troops and tanks in Europe. U.S. officials said there was an impasse on a half-dozen issues for a strategic weapons accord. The Soviets called in Col. Gen. Labronislav Omelichev, a nuclear arms expert, in what was viewed by U.S. officials as a move to settle some of the issues that have eluded negotiators over four days of talks.

DOC.HEAD: Military Promises to Hand Power to Civilian Gov't
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Name Nu in 10th graf is correct
DOC.TEXT: Gen. Saw Maung said Wedneday that his military regime was willing to lawfully hand over power to a civilian government, but he warned that threats to national unity could disrupt the process. In remarks to top government officials reported on state radio and television, Saw Maung said the military would yield power to a government formed by the parliament elected in Sunday's general elections. Official results indicate that parliament would be heavily dominated by the party most critical of Saw Maung's rule, the National League for Democracy. Some Western diplomats and other analysts have expressed skepticism over whether the military would actually hand over power. Saw Maung told government employees ``to serve loyally any government that comes to power.'' But he said the military government would ``continue attending to the country's need for security, transportation and food.'' He did not elaborate. ``Whoever interferes in our carrying out our tasks of preventing disintegration of the union, perpetuating national sovereignty and protecting national unity will not be tolerated,'' Saw Maung said. It was the first public statement on the elections by Saw Maung, who led a brutal suppression of pro-democracy demonstrations in September 1988 and established martial law. The military government called for general elections after the crackdown and for a time allowed relatively free political activity. But when opposition leader Aung San Suu Kyi, the charismatic daughter of independence hero Aung San, criticized the military and gathered mass support last summer, she was put under house arrest. The co-leader of her National League for Democracy, Tin Oo, was also jailed. Former Prime Minster Nu also remains under house arrest. Sources in the National League for Democracy said their party's unofficial vote tally showed they had gained 391 of the 485 seats contested in the election. The latest official vote tally showed the league had won 76 out of 82 seats. The official count apparently lags behind unofficial tallies because signed certificates must be sent from polling stations to the election commission in Rangoon, which has become a time consuming process. The official Working People's Daily newspaper said 76 percent of eligible voters turned out for the election, Burma's first multiparty polls in 30 years. The military government, which still rules under a martial law decree, has promised to turn power over to civilians once a new constitution is completed and a strong government is in place. The election has proved a massive defeat for the pro-military National Unity Party, which wielded unchallenged power when it ruled under another name from 1962 to 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Group Wants Attacks Halted on Human Rights Workers in Latin America
DOC.TEXT: Amnesty International complained Wednesday that attacks are increasing on human rights defenders and investigators in Latin America and urged the Organization of American States to take steps to stop the violations. In a letter to the OAS, the world human rights group cited examples of obstruction, threats and harassment, torture, disappearances and extrajudicial executions in Brazil, Colombia, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras and Peru. It identified 16 clergymen, priests, lawyers, politicians and others who it said were threatened, tortured, abducted or killed in the past 12 months. One case cited was that of Elizabeth Suarez Giraldo, a human rights worker in Cali, Colombia, who reported being detained by the army March 2 when she inquired about trade unionists in custody. She said she was kept blindfolded and was tortured and raped before being released April 19 after she was acquitted on charges of violating an anti-terrorist law. The letter said that Luis Tenderini, president of the Brazilian Justice and Peace Commission in Recife, was abducted and tortured in March 1989 for demanding that death squads be investigated. It expressed concern over lack of ``substantial progress in proceedings'' in the investigation of eight El Salvador soldiers in last November's murders of six Jesuit priests and two others. In Guatemala, at least 77 members or sympathizers of the Council of Ethnic Communities received death threats during the past year, four were abducted and four others murdered, the letter said. It said violatons ``continued at an alarming level in the past year'' against human rights defenders in Honduras, while in Peru the Lima offices of the Andean Commission of Jurists and of Amnesty were bombed Feb. 18 and March 4. The OAS General Assembly begins its 20th session Monday, meeting in Asuncion, Paraguay. 9. An Amnesty International delegation will attend as a special guest. The human rights group, which is based in London, hopes its letter will be considered there. ``There was no specific incident that prompted us to send the letter, but an accumulation of reports in our files,'' spokeswoman Anita Tieson said. The letter, sent to the ambassadors of the 32 OAS member states, said those responsible for the violations were generally the police and military in uniform and plainclothes, acting as death squads, and also civilian representatives of the army and citizens' militias operating under military control. Official investigations of the abuses ``have been slow and inefficient and almost invariably have not produced concrete results,'' the letter said. Judicial authorities who tried to investigate reported violations were sometimes threatened or attacked, it added.

DOC.HEAD: North Carolina Layman Elected Church Moderator
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SalmonCambell in 3rd graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: The layman son of a Presbyterian minister was elected head of the Presbyterian church Wednesday, saying he hopes to teach the love of Christ and a sense of community to a church divided. Price H. Gwynn III of Charlotte, N.C., described himself as a long-shot candidate who nevertheless sensed he might eventually win leadership of the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A). He won on a second ballot cast by the 605 commissioners meeting in the faith's 202nd General Assembly to pick a successor to The Rev. Joan SalmonCampbell. Gwynn, 67, received 322 votes, or almost 53 percent. ``I'm not a renegade,'' said Gwynn, who earlier had roused the General Assembly with a speech critical of church bureaucracy. He said a belief in the divinity of Jesus Christ and his Resurrection is all that is needed to heal rifts and a membership malaise affecting the 2.9 million-member church. The church's membership has steadily declined over the past two decades, losing more than 120,000 in the past three years and 30 percent of its membership since 1970. Gwynn said the cure lies not in the General Assembly, but in the church's individual members and local congregations. ``If you are warm and inviting and the love of God is visible, then I'm not concerned,'' he said. ``Rising water lifts all boats.'' The new moderator, who will serve for a year, said the church leadership needs to do a better job keeping abreast of the times. ``Change is driven by belief and faith and conviction. It is no longer driven by technology. If we shoot ourselves in the foot, we're going to have to answer for that,'' he said. ``This could be a five million-member denomination by the year 2000.'' Gwynn is the eighth moderator since factions of the church reunited in 1983, healing a Civil War-era split over slavery. The moderator presides over the General Assembly and represents the church for the remainder of the year. Gwynn said he believes leadership may be out of touch with the churchgoer, who worries more about the church itself than issues such as whether homosexuals should be ordained as ministers _ a topic the General Assembly likely will take up next week. ``The question I'm asked is, `Do we have our act together up here ... can we put aside our differences to get our act together in the world?''' Gwynn told the assembly, which meets through June 6. But emphasizing unity does not mean there is no place for dissension, he said. ``We're going to disagree,'' said Gwynn, who pointed out Presbyterians have a history of factionalism dating back to the Civil War. ``Nobody should be shocked. But we don't have to agree to work together.'' Gwynn is a semiretired president of a Charlotte packing company and chairman of the board of Presbyterian Hospital and Presbyterian Health Services Corp. An elder in the Steele Creek church in Charlotte and father of three, Gwynn said he is not an ``activist'' and has no plans for radical changes. He said he could not support ordination of homosexuals, who he said are sinners deserving of God's love but not of the ministry. Gwynn said he supports ``responsible choice'' in dealing with abortion. He said his experience with hospitals has taught him that those who suffer when abortions are unavailable are the ``poor, the powerless and the unwanted child.'' About 750 Presbyterians from around the U.S. are attending the 10-day conference in Salt Lake City, the first meeting of the Protestant denomination in predominantly Mormon Utah.

DOC.HEAD: Militants Kill 10 In Punjab Village
DOC.TEXT: Sikh militants in a jeep opened fire at crowds in a Punjab village Wednesday, killing at least 10 people and injuring 18, police said. Elsewhere in Punjab, seven other people were reported killed Wednesday, United News of India said. The killings were reported from separate areas in the prosperous northern farming state. In the village of Talwandi Bhaiyan, 70 miles south of Amritsar, at least six militants in a jeep fired at crowds at two places, Police Superintendent Anil Sharma said in a telephone interview. The militant Sikh insurgency for an independent nation has claimed at least 950 lives in Punjab state this year. At least 1,821 people were killed last year. Sikh militants have been fighting for an independent nation in Punjab since 1982, claiming Sikhs are discriminated against by the majority Hindus. Sikhs are in a slight majority in Punjab but form only 2 percent of India's 880 million people. Hindus make up 82 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Albania Asks to Restore Ties with United States
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 6th pvs, `Another member...' to UPDATE with Albanian report on the meeting. Pickup 7th pvs, `The United...'
DOC.TEXT: Albanian Communist Party leader Ramiz Alia on Wednesday told the first U.S. official delegation to visit his country since 1939 that Albania wants to re-establish full diplomatic relations with Washington as soon as possible. Rep. Tom Lantos, D-Calif. said he had an ``extremely long...lively, constructive'' meeting Wednesday evening with Alia, whose hard-line Communist country has recently shown signs of easing its extreme isolationist policies. Alia ``asked me to convey to President Bush and Secretary of State (James A.) Baker their desire to establish full diplomatic relations as early as possible, and I certainly feel the time is right,'' Lantos said in a telephone interview. ``It is in the interest of both the United States and Albania'' to re-establish relations, Lantos said. ``We hope to have an embassy in Tirana by September or October.'' Lantos said ``Albanians have a long way to go'' in improving their human rights record but said that should not stop the United States from resuming relations. Another member of the U.S. delegation, Joe DioGuardi, a former Republican congressman from New York, quoted Alia as saying that Albania is interested in becoming a party to the Helsinki accords on human rights. The official Albanian news agency ATA said Alia and Lantos had ``warm and friendly talks'' but gave no other details of the meeting that was held in the People's Assembly in Tirana. The United States has long accused Albania _ the sole remaining hard-line Communist state in Eastern Europe following a wave of pro-democracy uprisings last year _ of human rights violations for denying freedom of worship and emigration and other rights. The United States and Albania broke relations before World War II. Lantos said Albania was also ``extremely eager'' to pursue joint ventures with U.S. companies. Albania severed ties with the Soviet Union in 1961 due to an ideological dispute, but has recently expressed interest in restoring ties with Moscow. While Albania is reforming its political and economic system, it has avoided any promises of instituting sweeping reforms similar to those implemented by the other Eastern European nations.

DOC.HEAD: Republicans Designate Political Unknown As Cuomo Opponent
DOC.TEXT: New York Republicans on Wednesday nominated a political unknown to challenge Democratic Gov. Mario Cuomo's expected re-election bid this year. ``I'm going into this thing to win,'' economist Pierre Rinfret said in his acceptance speech. ``The Cuomo years have become a disaster,'' said Rinfret, who was nominated by acclamation. ``The people of our state have twice put their faith in Mario Cuomo. Unfortunately, he seems to have lost faith in the people.'' It had taken New York Republicans nearly a year to find a candidate to challenge Cuomo. State GOP Chairman J. Patrick Barrett had been turned down by one big-name Republican after another, including U.S. Sen. Alfonse D'Amato. Cuomo is expected to announce his plans to seek a third, four-year term within days. Considered a potential 1992 Democratic presidential contender, Cuomo is generally viewed as a big favorite for re-election, even by Republicans. Rinfret's acceptance speech was his first public appearance since his name surfaced early last week as a possible candidate. The Canadian-born Rinfret, 66, has never run for public office before. But he did serve as an unpaid adviser to Presidents Kennedy, Johnson and Nixon. He currently heads a New York City-based economics consulting firm and he lives in Manhattan. Rinfret said he was running because ``I'm a lucky and successful American dream.'' He promised that if elected, he would ``cut tax rates and tax burdens to restore economic growth'' and he pledged to ``enact the death penalty and get tough on drug dealers.'' Cuomo has presided over two consecutive years of $1 billion-plus tax increases, including a record $1.8 billion in tax and fee increases this year. The tax increases have become necessary because of continuing budget deficits and economic problems in New York. Cuomo has vetoed death penalty legislation every year since he became governor in January 1983. Rinfret's lack of experience in politics and his abortion-rights stance have prompted the state Conservative Party to reject him as its nominee. Instead, the Conservatives plan to nominate New York University professor Herbert London on Saturday as their gubernatorial candidate. London could not convince GOP leaders to choose him as their candidate. He then rejected an offer to be Rinfret's running mate. A split between Republicans and Conservatives would divide the anti-Cuomo vote and make the governor's re-election even more likely.

DOC.HEAD: Syrians Seize Weapons from Shiite Militias
DOC.TEXT: Syrian troops seized arms from rival Shiite Moslem militias Wednesday in raids aimed at preventing new clashes between the warring factions in west Beirut, police reported. The Syrians also closed militia offices and banned gunmen from wearing military fatigues, police said. Large quantities of weapons were seized in buildings and apartments used by the pro-Iranian Hezbollah, or Party of God, and the Syrian-backed Amal militia in the daylong raids, police reported. Syrian troops, armed with automatic rifles and rocket-propelled grenade launchers, also arrested a number of gunmen walking along the streets, police said. Syrian patrols were reported in various districts throughout the Moslem sector. Syria, with 40,000 troops in Lebanon under a 1976 Arab League peacekeeping mandate, is the country's main power broker. Amal and Hezbollah have been fighting intermittently since May 1987 for dominance of Lebanon's 1.2 million Shiites, the country's largest sect. At least 1,049 people have been killed and 3,136 wounded in that power struggle. Last week, five people were killed and 42 wounded in street battles between the two militias. The crackdown was launched after Syrian Vice President Abdul-Halim Khaddam held separate talks with the senior Sunni Moslem cleric in Lebanon, Sheik Mohammed Rashid Kabbani, and the Shiite spiritual leader, Sheik Mohammed Mehdi Shamseddine. Sources close to Kabbani quoted Khaddam as saying that lawlessness in the Moslem sector of Beirut had to be halted.

DOC.HEAD: Gold Opens Lower in Hong Kong
DOC.TEXT: Gold dropped $2.35 an ounce on Hong Kong markets Thursday, opening at $.365.28. It closed at $367.63 Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Operating Room Fire, Accident Injuries Both Cited in Woman's Death
DOC.TEXT: An auto accident victim who died on the operating table after sheets covering her caught fire was killed by both the crash injuries and burns, the coroner's office ruled Wednesday. Angela Hernandez, 26, a mother of four, died early Monday after undergoing emergency surgery at UCLA Medical Center. She had suffered heart and liver injuries when she was crushed in an accident late Sunday in Santa Monica. Surgeons were about to take Hernandez out of the operating room when the sheets and blankets ignited, the Fire Department has said. A medical examiner found no smoke in Hernandez' lungs but determined she died both from burns and traumatic injuries suffered in the crash, said Los Angeles County coroner's spokesman Scott Carrier. ``It's going to be listed as an accidental death,'' Carrier said. Still under investigation Wednesday was the cause of the fire. Fire officials have said they were looking at whether a penlike cauterizer used to stop bleeding from an incision was present in the operating room along with pure oxygen. Such a combination was blamed for a flash fire that killed a 15-year-old boy in an operating room at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Arrest Made in Killing of Coasters Singing Group Member
DOC.TEXT: A 19-year-old North Las Vegas man was arrested Wednesday in connection with the February slaying of a member of The Coasters singing group. North Las Vegas Police Lt. Gary Rainey said Kinney Poole was booked for investigation of murder in the shooting death of singer Cornelius Gunter. Rainey said a police investigation into the Feb. 26 slaying of Gunter gathered both physical evidence and eyewitnesses linking Poole to the slaying. ``It all started to fall together about three weeks ago,'' said Rainey. Rainey said robbery appeared to be the motive in the slaying of Gunter, who was shot to death in his car at a North Las Vegas intersection. Witnesses told police that a man was standing next to Gunter's car and arguing with him at the time of the slaying. The man shot Gunter and ran into the desert, tossing away a jacket as he fled. Gunter was a member of the doo-wop group whose hits included ``Yakety Yak'' and ``Charlie Brown.'' Another former member of the group, Nathaniel ``Buster'' Wilson, was shot to death in April 1980. His mutilated body was dumped near Hoover Dam.

DOC.HEAD: Gabon Says Murder Ruled Out in Opposition Leader's Death
DOC.TEXT: The opposition leader whose death set off national anti-government riots apparently died of natural causes and was not murdered as some protesters claimed, officials said Wednesday after an autopsy. Military authorities meanwhile said an army patrol killed a rioter during the night in the oil production center of Port Gentil. On Tuesday, protesters fatally injured a paratrooper there. Unconfirmed reports spoke of up to seven additional deaths in Port Gentil, including a demonstrator whose body was shown to journalists. Residents said relatives removed the bodies of other victims. Rioting broke out last week in Libreville and Port Gentil in this former French territory after the body of Joseph Rendjambe, secretary-general of the opposition Gabon Progress Party, was found in a hotel room. Many opposition supporters blamed President Omar Bongo's government for the death, but officials in Libreville and in Paris said preliminary results of an autopsy found no signs of foul play. Gabonese and French doctors jointly conducted the autopsy. Needle marks were found in Rendjambe's stomach, but officials said he was a diabetic who received regular injections in that part of the body. In Paris, Foreign Minister Roland Dumas praised the performance of French troops sent to Gabon to protect European oil workers and their families during the disturbances. He said the troops would stay as long as needed to protect the French community. His ministry reported that about 2,000 of the more than 20,000 French citizens in the former French colony were evacuated after trouble broke out. Pierre Mamboundu, a Gabonese opposition leader speaking from exile in Dakar, Senegal, said soldiers took Gabonese National Assembly President Augustin Mbouma from his home in Libreville late Tuesday. Mamboundou said Mbouma had threatened to quit Bongo's governing Gabon Democratic Party. There was no official confirmation of such an action. At least 15 people were reported injured Tuesday in clashes in Port Gentil as troops sought to retake control of the city from protesters. Witnesses said at least 20 officials and supporters of the Gabon Progress Party were arrested. Oil companies, which generate 80 percent of Gabon's income, drastically cut production following the unrest. However, Elf-Gabon, an affiliate of the French state-owned Elf company, said Wednesday it had restored production to 90 percent of normal.

DOC.HEAD: Condition of Jamaican Prime Minister Improves
DOC.TEXT: Jamaican Prime Minister Michael Manley, hospitalized with double pneumonia, showed marked improvement Wednesday, a government spokesman said. ``This morning the doctors said he had turned the corner and that he was no longer on the danger list,'' said Hartley Neita, who was with Manley at the hospital. ``Naturally, they are still monitoring and doing continuous tests to make sure everything is normal.'' Manley, 65, was flown to Miami Heart Institute from Kingston on Monday. Doctors who are treating the pneumonia with antibiotics have prescribed bed rest, said Neita. He said doctors have not indicated how long Manley will be hospitalized, and they have indefinitely postponed prostate surgery that Manley was scheduled to undergo June 5 at Sloane Kettering Cancer Institute in New York. The prime minister is a socialist who has moderated his positions and emphasized cordial U.S. relations since losing 1980 elections. He had served eight years as leader of the Caribbean island nation. In February 1989, he returned to office after leading his People's National Party to victory in 1988 general elections. Manley had been admitted Sunday to Kingston's University Hospital, where the pneumonia was diagnosed.

DOC.HEAD: Former Dissident Elected President of Croatia
DOC.TEXT: Croatia's first multiparty Parliament in more than 50 years on Wednesday elected a retired army general and former political prisoner as president of Yugoslavia's second-largest republic. Thousands of flag-waving people gathered on a square outside of Parliament in Zagreb's old quarter to greet Franjo Tudjman, leader of the Croatian Democratic Union. The party won a landslide victory in elections for the regional legislature earlier this month. The center-right party favors greater autonomy for Croatia within Yugoslavia's six-republic federation. The party won 205 of the Parliament's 356 seats and named Stipe Mesic as the republic's prime minister. Tudjman was elected president Wednesday with 281 of 338 votes cast. In his acceptance speech, Tudjman told delegates Croatia is ``willing to remain within Yugoslavia but only as fully sovereign state in an alliance with other sovereign states.'' He said Croatia would ``use the experiences of the free world, and particularly the United States and Western Europe'' to create a pluralistic political system. In an attack on the rival republic of Serbia, where the Communist leadership is firmly entrenched, Tudjman said parts of Yugoslavia where democracy had not taken hold would find Communist rule ``represents a barren historical anachronism.'' Croatia, a part of Yugoslavia since the country was established in 1918, has long been at odds with Serbia, the largest republic. The 66-year-old Tudjman, who was once the Yugoslav army's youngest general, spent almost five years in jail in the 1970s for Croatian nationalism and ``hostile activities'' against the state. Mesic also spent time in jail on similar charges. In a break with the republic's Communist past, a flag was displayed at the meeting of Parliament bearing the red-and-white checkered Croatian coat of arms instead of the Communist red star. The Croatian national anthem was sung in place of the Yugoslav anthem. Zagreb's cardinal, Franjo Kuharic, and representatives from Croatia's Moslem and Jewish communities attended the sesion of Parliament. The Serbian Orthodox church was not represented. Earlier Wednesday, thousands of people, including Tudjman, crowded into Zagreb's 14th century cathedral to hear Kuharic pray for ``the wisdom of those assuming responsibility for governing our people.''

DOC.HEAD: New Stamps to Honor Five Olympians
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS Wrightman to Wightman in 6th graf, which is 3rd bullet graf: ``_Donor of,''
DOC.TEXT: A set of postage stamps honoring five American Olympic athletes will be issued July 6, the Postal Service announced Wednesday. Featured on the 25-cent stamps are Jesse Owens, Ray Ewry, Hazel Wrightman, Eddie Eagan and Helene Madison. Texts adjacent to the stamps state: _Jesse Owens won world acclaim by capturing four gold medals in track and field at Berlin in 1936. _Three-time Olympian Ray Ewry won eight gold medals in the standing high jump and other jumping events. _Donor of the trophy for the U.S.-Great Britain women's tennis series, Hazel Wightman won two gold medals in 1924. _Boxer and bobsledder Eddie Eagan was the only U.S. gold medal winner in both the Summer and Winter Games. _Swimmer Helene Madison won three Olympic gold medals in the Summer Games at Los Angeles in 1932. The stamps will be printed in sheets of 35. First day of issue ceremonies will be held in Minneapolis, Minn. The stamps are the first issued by the Postal Service as part of its co-sponsorship of the 1991 Olympic Games to be held in Albertville, France, and Barcelona, Spain.

DOC.HEAD: Producer Says Disingenuous Ending Intended All Along
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to UPDATE with network spokesman offering comment. Picks up 8th graf pvs: `On April, ...'
DOC.TEXT: Even though ABC said Laura Palmer's murder would be resolved in last week's season finale of ``Twin Peaks,'' executive producer Mark Frost said he never made such a promise. ``I don't know what they would have been basing that on,'' Frost said Tuesday in an interview from Hawaii. ``We never told anyone that was our intention.'' In fact, Frost said, it was decided long ago to keep the audience guessing right to the end to force the network into renewing the prime-time soap opera. ``We had no guarantee that ABC would ever renew us,'' Frost said. ``I intentionally structured that last hour so that if ABC was really curious about who killed Laura, they'd have to pick up the show. ``Our sole strategy was survival. By withholding the identity of the killer, we thought we were down to our last coin.'' An ABC spokesman told the press early this month that the mystery would be solved in the last show. But on Wednesday, spokesman Bob Wright changed his tune. ``I was always under the assumption that the central part of the story pertaining to the murder would be resolved,'' Wright said. ``I was wrong. From now on, I will not make any promises about `Twin Peaks.''' So ``Twin Peaks'' will be back in the fall, along with, it appears, disappointed viewers who charted every dizzying turn of the show's nine hours trying to figure out who murdered the sleepy Northwest lumber town's homecoming queen. On April 8, television was introduced to a world out of kilter, confected by Frost and film director David Lynch, who made ``Blue Velvet.'' The ratings were only mediocre, but die-hard fans threw ``Twin Peaks'' parties and more was written about the program than any other in recent memory. So with much ballyhoo, ``Twin Peaks'' hurtled toward its season finale with viewers waiting for the solution to Laura's murder, as promised by ABC. ``There were a lot of people who were disappointed that they didn't learn the identity of Laura's killer,'' Frost said. ``I just think there was a misunderstanding somewhere. ``I can't give anything away, but when viewers come back _ and we're coming back with a two-hour premiere _ I think their curiosity will be satisfied.'' What about the dancing dwarf who spoke backwards? And series star Kyle MacLachlan, who had three bullets pumped into him at point-blank range in the last episode? ``There are a lot of different ways that that can go,'' Frost said. ``I think that when you see the show next year, you'll understand why we left it that way. With scrutiny, everything so far will come together.''

DOC.HEAD: Earthquake Shakes Europe, Kills 8 Romanians
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 2 grafs on U.S. input
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos BUCH1,XBUC3,7
DOC.TEXT: An earthquake shook buildings from Moscow to Istanbul on Wednesday and cut a path of destruction across Romania, where eight people were killed and nearly 300 injured. Early Thursday morning, Bucharest was rocked again by a long aftershock. It was felt at about 3:18 a.m. (8:18 p.m. EDT) and lasted for nearly three minutes. There were no immediate reports of new damage or casualties. Chunks of concrete from high-rise buildings crashed to the ground and crushed people Wednesday in this capital city of 2.2 million, killing two. Tens of thousands of residents rushed into the streets, many crying and screaming in fear as ceilings fell, walls cracked and books toppled from shelves. Romanians leaped in panic from windows and balconies, and some were badly hurt, ambulance officials said. It was the third major earthquake since 1977 with its epicenter in Romania's Carpathian Mountains. Its force was felt in the Soviet Union and Bulgaria _ where injuries were reported _ and in Hungary, Greece, Turkey, Yugoslavia and Poland. The quake center was 190 miles northeast of Bucharest, in the wooded Vrancea range. BBC monitors in London, quoting the Bulgarian news agency BTA, said one person died in Silistra of a quake-induced heart attack. Soviet legislator Ilmars Bishers said initial reports indicated some Soviet deaths occurred, but he gave no details. Richter scale readings ranged from 6.5 to 7.5. Uppsala Seismological Center in Sweden said the quake was felt so widely because it was about 63 miles deep. ``I think it was this deafening sound of cracking walls that scared people,'' said clerical worker Sica Burcea, 52. ``The building was swinging horizontally and vertically. We were lucky only to have some cracks in the walls. I shivered when I realized 1977 was coming back.'' More than 1,500 Romanians died in a 1977 earthquake. A communique from the General Inspectorate of Police said two people died in Bucharest, two in the Danube River port of Braila, and one each in eastern Buzau, southeastern Ialomita, central Brasov and nearby Prahova County. Food shop clerk Petruta Lungu was killed when she ran outside and was hit by bricks and concrete falling from an upstairs wall, Bucharest police said. A man's body was pulled from rubble outside the shop. The inspectorate reported 296 people injured, 45 critically. It said 35 of the critically injured were in Bucharest, where 102 people were hurt. ``I fell on the stairs as the earthquake was reaching its peak and my fingers went out of their sockets,'' said Cristina Amza, 28, who was recovering from an operation at Bucharest's Emergency Hospital. ``It was a nightmare.'' The earthquake lasted for about 45 seconds, the Romanian news agency Rompres said. In Moscow, Soviet officials said the quake was felt from the Crimea to the Baltics and damaged dozens of buildings in the southwest. In Ottawa, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said he was told shocks shook Moldavia and Armenia but ``no devastation, no destruction.'' He said he saw no reason to break off his trip to return home, as he did in December 1988, when a quake killed an estimated 25,000 people in Armenia. In Soviet Moldavia, bordering on Romania, six people in Kogul were hospitalized for quake-related injuries, Lt. Ivan Koltuk of the regional Interior Department said by telephone. Buildings shook throughout Moscow, 1,000 miles east of Bucharest, including the offices of The Associated Press. The 10-story U.S. Embassy building was evacuated. Telephone lines were knocked out and buildings shook in at least four Soviet republics. In Istanbul, the Anatolia News Agency said tremors were felt in eastern Thrace in Turkey and elsewhere around the Marmara Sea region. The quake also was felt in Hungary. A nuclear power plant was shut down in Kozlodoui, Bulgaria, on the Danube. The quake hit when Bucharest's streets were crowded with lunch-hour shoppers and pedestrians. Many people tried to get home, creating a huge traffic jam that police said was made worse because the capital's main thoroughfare, University Square, was blockaded by anti-Communist demonstrators. The mayor had announced the square would be cleared Wednesday. Some protesters saw the quake as divine intervention to keep them from being ousted. ``The demonstrators were swearing at Iliescu when the earthquake struck,'' said Dr. Dragos Nicolescu, 42, who has been tending hunger strikers supporting the protesters. ``They said it was a sign of God that Iliescu would fall.'' The earthquake struck 10 days after Romanians elected onetime Politburo member Ion Iliescu president. The protesters want former Communists like Iliescu banned for 10 years from holding public office. The Richter scale gauges the amount of energy released by a quake as measured by the ground motion recorded by seismographs. A quake of magnitude 6 can cause severe damage. One of magnitude 7 is reckoned as a major earthquake. The National Earthquake Center in Golden, Colo., registered the initial quake at 6.5 and Thursday's aftershock at 5.9. ``We've had no reports of injuries or damages, but certainly a 5.9 is capable of that, especially when people are asleep,'' said Pat Jorgenson, with the U.S. Geological Service in Menlo Park, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Fuel Spill Threatens Alaskan Wildlife Refuge
With LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Railroad crews worked Wednesday to collect 120,000 gallons of jet and diesel fuel spilled just upstream from a wildlife refuge when 19 tanker cars derailed. Soggy terrain and the remote location hampered cleanup workers, but officials said more fuel would have seeped into a creek running into the refuge if not for beaver dams on both sides of the Alaska Railroad tracks. ``I would have to give the railroad a good grade on first response and the beavers even a better grade,'' said Al Townsend, a biologist for the state Department of Fish and Game. The last of the derailed tankers were dragged away Wednesday and the Alaska Railroad reopened, with trains moving at reduced speed, said Dale Nelson, environmental engineer for the railroad. A 68-car train was transporting more than a million gallons of jet and diesel fuel from a refinery at North Pole to Anchorage on Memorial Day when 19 cars jumped the track about 40 miles south of Fairbanks. Seven tankers tore open, dumping fuel into beaver ponds on both sides of the tracks. Some fuel was seeping into Goldstream Creek and the 500,000-acre Minto Flats Wildlife Refuge, a prime waterfowl nesting area. ``One of our concerns is the fairly substantial number of pike and whitefish that just finished spawning,'' said Mac McLean of the Fish and Game Department. ``The eggs could hatch anytime, and that's a pretty sensitive life stage.'' He also said beaver, muskrat and otters were particularly threatened. Suction machines had skimmed an estimated 10,000 gallons of the spilled fuel by late Wednesday. Work had been slowed, however, because the pumps were mounted on rail cars and couldn't get past the tangled pile of derailed tankers, officials said. An oily sheen extended at least eight miles down Goldstream Creek despite the beaver dams and plywood dams and absorbent booms laid by crews. The refined fuel is more toxic than crude oil, but can evaporate more quickly if exposed to air and sunlight. State environmental officials planned to have the creek water tested to determine underwater levels of toxicity. Representatives of local, state and federal agencies met Wednesday to discuss a long-term cleanup plan, which the railroad must submit by Monday to the state. Railroad investigators took routine blood tests for alcohol and drugs from the three crew members on the train, and brought the train's speed indicator to Anchorage for inspection. Tests showed the train was moving within the 44 mph limit posted for the area when it derailed, said railroad spokeswoman Vivian Hamilton.

DOC.HEAD: Steelworker Statue Angers Croatians, Union
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 9th graf, `Jimenez, the ...' with 4 grafs to UPDATE with artist's comment. Picks up 10th graf pvs: `Verlich, the .. .'
DOC.TEXT: An artist's use of an alleged ethnic slur in the inscription of a steelworker statue is being attacked by Croatians, the United Steelworkers union and other ethnic and labor groups. The 12-foot fiberglass statue, in the middle of a downtown park, is inscribed with the title and signature: ``Hunky Steelworker. Luis Jimenez '90.'' ``The sculptor's choice of words has touched a raw nerve among our members across a wide range of ethnic backgrounds,'' said Andrew V. ``Lefty'' Palm, director of the union district that covers Pittsburgh steelworkers. ``It's a blatant insult,'' said Edward Verlich of the Croatian Fraternal Union. ``We aren't trying to deny anyone freedoms, but we don't want this emblazoned on a statue where a half-million people will see it.'' The term ``hunky'' originated in the late 1800s as a term to describe people of Hungarian descent, but its use was expanded quickly as an insult toward anyone whose ancestors came from central Europe, said Sarah Thomason, a professor of linguistics at the University of Pittsburgh. ``It's also of the same origin as the word `honky,' which some blacks use to describe whites,'' Ms. Thomason said Wednesday. The city's controller, Tom Flaherty, noticed the inscription on the back of the statue while jogging past it. Last week, he held a press conference at its base to decry what he called a slur against eastern Europeans. The statue was erected as a tribute to steelworkers. Jimenez, the artist, expressed surprise at the criticism of his work. ``I certainly didn't think there would be a problem with this,'' he told the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette. ``I was trying to pay tribute to the contributions steelworkers have made to this country.'' Jimenez, 49, of Hondo, N.M., said he researched steelworkers at Pittsburgh's Carnegie Library. ``I came across the term `millhunk' or `hunky' as a way that steelworkers referred to themselves,'' he said. ``I used it as a term that was part of the popular culture. I didn't mean it as any kind of derogatory term.'' Verlich, the son of a Croatian father and Czechoslovakian mother, said he didn't fault Jiminez but would like to see the title changed. ``He thought he was using a term of endearment, but the term is derogatory and inflammatory and has no business on a statue in the city of Pittsburgh,'' Verlich said. The city's Croatians and other ethnic and labor groups have suggested that covering up the `Y' in hunky _ forming ``Hunk Steelworker'' _ would be appropriate. The new title could work, they said, because the steelworker depicted is disproportionally stout in a hunk of fiberglass. ``They can cover that with plastic,'' Verlich said. The organizers of the Three Rivers Art Festival, which brought the statue to the city, have said they'll meet with people who don't like the statue but won't remove it from the park's most prominent part. The festival director wasn't available immediately Wednesday. The festival opens Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Peruvian Quake Kills 115, Injures Hundreds
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with quake worst in 20 years, details from scene. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A strong earthquake killed at least 115 people, injured more than 800 and almost destroyed several towns in Peru's northern jungle, Civil Defense officials said Wednesday. At least 42 people were missing after the quake Tuesday night, which officials called Peru's deadliest in two decades. It was followed by dozens of aftershocks, including one Wednesday morning that measured 5.1 on the Richter scale. Civil defense officials declared a state of emergency late Wednesday in San Martin province, 400 miles north of Lima. At least 35 of the confirmed 115 deaths from the quake occurred in Moyobamba, a farming center of 50,000 people and the provincial capital of San Martin, officials said. Most of the other dead were from nearby villages in the jungle area. The Civil Defense said at least 818 people were injured. The quake, measuring 6.2 on the Richter scale, occurred at 9:33 p.m. and lasted 45 seconds, the Peruvian Geophysical Institute reported. It was centered in the jungle 75 miles northeast of Moyobamba, the institute said. The institute earlier Wednesday gave a Richter scale measure of 5.8, but revised that figure Wednesday night. An institute spokesman said Wednesday night the area was hit by at least 45 aftershocks, including one that measured 5.1 on the Richter scale. The National Earthquake Information Center in Golden, Colo. said the quake measured 6.3 on the Richter scale. Local police reports reaching Lima by radio Wednesday said several villages around Moyobamba suffered widespread damage and were nearly destroyed. Civil defense authorities said the area was completely cut off from electrical service and telephone communications due to the quake. Gen. Jorge Ferreyro, Peru's Civil Defense chief, said a downtown church in Moyobamba was destroyed, and most municipal buildings were badly damaged. Ferreyro said Moyobamba had few doctors and officials there were asking the government to send doctors, medicine and electrical generators. Health Minister Paul Caro Gamarra said an air force plane left for Moyobamba on Wednesday afternoon carrying a team of 10 doctors and emergency supplies.
