For Release Sunday AMs, June 3, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: A Banner Season on Broadway Makes for Strong Tony Competition
DOC.TEXT: A banner season on Broadway means Sunday's annual Tony Awards celebration will have something it hasn't had in a long time _ respectable and, in some cases, strong competition in several categories. But ``City of Angels,'' a Hollywood detective musical, and ``The Piano Lesson,'' August Wilson's drama about a black family coming to terms with its past, are favorites for the top awards of best musical and best play. The two-hour festivities, to be broadcast by CBS starting at 9 p.m. EDT, will be presided over by Kathleen Turner, a best-actress nominee for her sultry performance in the box-office smash revival of ``Cat on a Hot Tin Roof.'' Among the stars scheduled to perform or present awards are Matthew Broderick, Len Cariou, Dixie Carter, Michael Crawford, Morgan Freeman, Timothy Hutton, James Earl Jones, Kevin Kline, Bernadette Peters, Joan Rivers, Jessica Tandy and Lily Tomlin. This year's theme will be ``the year of the actor,'' with actors doing solo turns. Kline will do a soliloquy from ``Hamlet,'' a role he currently is playing off-Broadway. As usual, the program will feature scenes from best play and best musical nominees. ``City of Angels'' will compete against ``Grand Hotel,'' Tommy Tune's stylish recreation of Vicki Baum's novel set in the 1920s. The musical received 12 nominations, more than any other show, including two for Tune for best director-musical and best choreography. The other best-musical nominees are ``Aspects of Love,'' Andrew Lloyd Webber's tale of passion in post-World War II France, and ``Meet Me in St. Louis,'' a lavish stage version of the famous Judy Garland movie. ``The Piano Lesson,'' which already has won this year's Pulitzer Prize for drama, faces its stiffest competition from ``The Grapes of Wrath,'' an adaptation of John Steinbeck's novel by Frank Galati and Chicago's Steppenwolf Theater Company. Also nominated are ``Prelude to a Kiss,'' a Manhattan fairy tale by Craig Lucas, and ``Lettice & Lovage,'' Peter Shaffer's look at an eccentric British tour guide played by Maggie Smith. Miss Smith and Miss Turner are top contenders for best actress honors. They will compete against Geraldine James, who played Portia in a revival of ``The Merchant of Venice,'' and newcomer Mary-Louise Parker, the bewildering bride in ``Prelude to a Kiss.'' The prize probably will go to Miss Smith. Dustin Hoffman, snubbed by Tony nominators six years ago for his performance in Arthur Miller's ``Death of a Salesman,'' received a best-actor nomination this year for playing Shylock in ``The Merchant of Venice.'' He is the biggest name, but the strongest competition comes from Robert Morse, who portrays writer Truman Capote in the one-man play ``Tru.'' Also nominated are Tom Hulce as a brash lawyer in the military courtroom drama ``A Few Good Men'' and Charles S. Dutton of ``The Piano Lesson.'' Unlike the 1989 awards when two categories _ best book of a musical and best score _ were eliminated, this year's competition will have a full complement of 19 categories. One category, choreography, was whittled down to three nominees instead of the usual four because of a scarcity of competition. Last year, Tony suspense was minimal with only three shows in the best musical competition _ ``Starmites,'' which quickly folded, and two revues, ``Black and Blue'' and ``Jerome Robbins' Broadway.'' Even the 1989 best play, ``The Heidi Chronicles'' by Wendy Wasserstein, was a predictable winner. One sure winner Sunday is Tyne Daly, who plays the formidable Mama Rose in the revival of ``Gypsy.'' Her competition for best actress in a musical includes Beth Fowler of ``Sweeney Todd,'' Georgia Brown of ``3 Penny Opera'' and Liliane Montevecchi of ``Grand Hotel.'' The two stars of ``City of Angels,'' James Naughton and Gregg Edelman, are nominated for best actor in a musical and compete against David Carroll, the debonair jewel thief of ``Grand Hotel'' and Bob Gunton, who played the title role in the revival of ``Sweeney Todd.'' Naughton is the likely winner. The 1989-90 season was one of the best in terms of quantity and quality. There were the inevitable flops, musical duds like ``3 Penny Opera'' starring Sting and ``The Prince of Central Park.'' But there also were a variety of plays and revivals, many with big names. In fact, a lot of them weren't nominated for a Tony. Among the also-rans were Vanessa Redgrave, who starred in a controversial revival of Tennessee Williams' ``Orpheus Descending'' and Rex Harrison, Glynis Johns and Stewart Granger, the three stars of Somerset Maugham's ``The Circle.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, June 3

DOC.TEXT: Prices surged on Wall Street and the Dow Jones industrial average reached another new closing high. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials jumped 49.57 to 2,870.49 on Tuesday, surpassing the blue chip barometer's previous closing high of 2,856.26 set last Wednesday. Broader indicators also rose. Technology issues issues led the advance.

Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., continuing a major overhaul, named an executive from parent American Express Co. to run the troubled firm's retail brokerage and asset management units. Shearson is expected in coming days to announce a reorganization that could split its investment banking business from its retail brokerage network, possibly including the resurrection of the venerable Lehman Brothers name. In what analysts called a precursor to the division, Shearsonsaid Tuesday that Jonathan S. Linen would become president and chief executive of the firm's retail brokerage and assest management businesses starting next week.

The Supreme Court upheld a ruling that blocks states from forcing securities brokers to give investors the option of suing, rather than seeking arbitration, to settle alleged broker fraud. The judges let stand on Tuesday an appeals court ruling that blocked the state of Massachusetts from requiring brokers to make arbitration optional in disputes with investors on the grounds the state regulation was pre-empted by federal law. Thirty states supported the Massachusetts appeal.

Chairman William Jovanovich resigned from textbook publisher Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc., three years after orchestrating a recapitalization that kept the company independent but left it heavily in debt. The 70-year-old Jovanovich stepped down Tuesday from his last major corporate assignment at the company he joined as a textbook salesman and editor in 1947. The new chairman is former U.S. energy secretary John S. Herrington, 51, who has been on the board of directors for a year.

Officials from 40 nations signed a treaty creating a $12 billion development bank to finance Eastern Europe's conversion to a market economy. The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development will be a ``catalyst between the capital and know-how of the West and the businesses of the East,'' French President Francois Mitterrand said Tuesday at a signing ceremony. The bank is expected to become operational in April 1991. The 12 European Community nations hold a controlling 51 percent interest, although the United States is the single biggest shareholder with 10 percent.

East Germany plans to speed privatization of its industry as the nation lays foundations for a switch to capitalism, its economics minister said. Economics Minister Gerhard Pohl said Tuesday only 180 of about 8,000 state-owned industries have been converted into publicly held companies so far. Pohl said the East German parliament is to approve a legal framework by October to quicken the process. He said ``incentives'' were planned for potential investors in now state-owned enterprises, but he did not elaborate.

A top U.S. trade official appealed to other rich nations to give a push to trade talks stalled by a dispute between the United States and European nations over government payments to farmers. U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills made the appeal Tuesday on the eve of the opening of high-level discussions by trade and finance chiefs of two dozen industrialized nations.

DHL International Ltd. said Japan Airlines, Lufthansa and the Japanese trading company Nissho Iwai will acquire a minority stake in the air express service company. Japan Airlines and Lufthansa each will get a 5 percent stake in DHL with an option to buy up to 25 percent within 18 months, DHL said Tuesday. Nissho Iwai will acquire a 2.5 percent interest with an option for up to 7.5 percent.

Tektronix Inc. announced it will lay off about 1,300 employees as part of a restructuring designed to offset the electronics manufacturer's financial problems. Under the restructuring, the 44-year-old company said Tuesday it plans to sell or close some of its test and measurement operations and non-television communications businesses.

Bond prices posted some modest gains. The dollar finished below last Friday's levels in New York, but staged a partial recovery from an earlier foreign selloff. Copper futures prices plunged; precious metals, grain and soybean futures were mostly lower; and livestock, pork and energy futures gained.

DOC.HEAD: Americans Could Fly to Far-Flung Soviet Cities Under New Accord
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Under a new air travel agreement slated to be signed at the Bush-Gorbachev summit, Americans would be able to sample glasnost and local delights in some of the more exotic Soviet cities. Americans longing to see the ancient Golden Gate in Kiev or diamond mines in Magadan, Siberia, would finally get their wish. They also would be able to fly to Minsk, Tbilisi, Khabarovsk (another Siberian city) and Riga, the capital of Latvia. New flights to those places from the United States are sure to be filled, Alexey Mesiatsev, a spokesman for Intourist, the Soviet tourism organization, said Tuesday. ``Demand is very big right now; the Soviet Union is one of the hottest tourist destinations,'' Mesiatsev said from his office in New York. He said some 150,000 Americans visited the Soviet Union last year, up from 125,000 in 1988, 110,000 in 1987 and 25,000 in 1980 _ when relations between the two countries hit a low point. Nearly all arrived by air. Commercial flights between the two countries now serve New York, Washington, Moscow and Leningrad. So far at least, U.S.-Soviet travel has been mostly a one-way street. Only 460 Soviet citizens visited the United States last year, most of them officials on tours organized around glasnost themes. Under the new agreement, concluded on Sunday, air travel between the two superpowers will be greatly expanded, possibly quadrupled. And the two countries also will inaugurate regular cargo flights. The air agreement represents closer ties as Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev tries to get a grip on his troubled economy. He will meet with President Bush beginning Thursday. The air travel accord will add four U.S. cities _ Anchorage, Alaska; Chicago, San Francisco and Miami _ and the six new Soviet cities to current airline routes. Six additional U.S. airlines will be allowed to fly between the two countries, and a planned new Soviet airline will be able to participate in U.S.-Soviet service. Currently, only Pan American World Airways and the Soviet national airline Aeroflot fly U.S.-Soviet routes. Aeroflot launched its first major marketing campaign in the United States last spring. A number of U.S. carriers have expressed interest, including Delta Air Lines, United Airlines, Alaska Airlines and Northwest Airlines. A Pan Am spokesman was skeptical about a new wave of U.S. tourists hitting the Soviet Union and whether there would be enough passengers to fill new flights to that country. ``We do believe that the market is still rather thin and the additional (airline) capacity is not warranted by the demand,'' said Jeff Kriendler. Delta spokesman Neil Monroe said his airline plans to apply to the Transportation Department for permission to fly between Delta's base of Atlanta and Moscow, and possibly Leningrad and Tbilisi. The latter, the capital of the Soviet republic of Georgia, is the sister city of another Georgia town, Atlanta. ``We're very interested in the Soviet Union,'' Monroe said. United has expressed interest in operating a Chicago-Moscow route, said spokesman Rob Doughty. Under the new U.S.-Soviet accord, the two sides also agreed to allow at least 100 annual charter flights over the North Atlantic route and to consider as many as 100 charters across the Pacific. American tourists venturing beyond Moscow and Leningrad will find wo historical museums in Minsk, the capital of the Byelorussian republic, Mesiatsev said. Kiev, capital of the Ukraine, offers monuments, parks and museums _ and the remains of the Golden Gate, part of the old city's fortifications built in the 11th century. The Intourist official said Kiev's cuisine, which includes borscht and ``galushky'' dumplings, is not to be missed. He described Tbilisi as an industrial and cultural city full of old churches. For the truly adventurous, there are the two Siberian cities. Khabarovsk, in the southeast, is the final point on the trans-Siberian railroad, with Mongolia and China beyond. Magadan, like Khabarovsk an industrial city, has diamond mines. Riga, the Latvian capital on the Baltic, has a distinctive culture and architecture, Mesiatsev noted. Like its fellow Baltic republics of Lithuania and Estonia, Latvia has recently been buffeted by nationalist stirrings. Pan Am charges $1,725 for a normal round-trip coach fare between Washington and Moscow. The average Intourist package costs around $3,500 for a 12- to 14-day trip.

DOC.HEAD: Group Seeks to Represent Eastern Pilots in Bargaining
DOC.TEXT: A group seeking to replace the Air Line Pilots Association as the representative of Eastern Air Lines pilots in collective bargaining is pressing for an election to decide the issue. The Eastern Pilots Association filed an application Tuesday with the National Mediation Board in Washington and said it was seeking immediate action on its request. ``Our organization better represents the real interests of the men and women who are flying Eastern's planes every day,'' Thomas Cooper, chairman of the EPA steering committee, said in a statement. ``The fairest way for the pilots of Eastern to determine the destiny of their own careers and the future of Eastern is to have an election,'' he said. Miami-based Eastern officially recognizes ALPA as the pilots' bargaining agent. The group's membership includes an estimated 1,200 to 1,400 Eastern pilots who not now working. But Cooper said APLA has lost touch with Eastern's working pilots. EPA claims to represent 93 percent of the airline's 1,775 flying pilots. Last year, ALPA called a sympathy strike against Eastern management to back striking members of the Machinists union. Some Eastern pilots continued to fly, and the airline hired replacements for striking pilots. In a statement, ALPA spokesman Lou Baldwin said, ``Under the Railway Labor Act, ALPA is the legal bargaining agent for all Eastern pilots, and the actions taken today by the EPA do not in any way affect that representation.'' The airline had no comment, an Eastern spokesman said.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Government OKs DAT Marketing
DOC.TEXT: After years of delay, Japanese electronics companies received government approval today to sell digital audio tape decks that can make virtually perfect copies of compact discs. The new decks' ability to make direct digital recordings of CDs is expected to boost sales for the long-dormant and much-debated recording medium. The approval from the Ministry of International Trade and Industry was timed to allow manufacturers to introduce the machines at the Chicago Consumer Electronics Show, which opens Saturday, the officials said. Company officials said they were unsure until today's decision whether they would be able to announce prices and marketing plans for their DAT recorders at the show. Opposition to the technology continues in the United States among song writers and record manufacturers concerned about copyright protection. However, a bill pending in Congress that would limit the number of copies that DAT recorders can make would ease those concerns. Unlike analog tape recordings, digital recordings deteriorate very little from generation to generation. Record manufacturers therefore had feared DAT machines would result in a virtually endless stream of high-quality copies of CDs that would cut into their sales. Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. spokesman Akira Nagano said his company, which makes Panasonic equipment, might begin marketing in the United States before the legislation is approved if congressional action is delayed, since current laws do not prohibit DATs. DAT decks have been sold in Japan and some parts of Europe since 1987. But in a concession to record companies, the equipment currently on the market cannot make direct digital recordings of CDs. Instead, they convert the high-quality digital signals on CDs to analog signals and then reconvert them to digital form before recording them, resulting in a slight loss in sound quality. That, combined with the high price of blank DAT tapes, which cost almost as much as CDs, has held DAT sales far below initial expectations. The biggest discord remaining in DAT's future may be its still-high prices. DAT decks are expected to begin selling in the United States for about $1,200.

DOC.HEAD: Company Seeks Approval For Human Tests of Cystic Fibrosis Drug
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs to CORRECT spelling of mucus to noun form sted adjectival mucous. A version moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Genentech Inc. hopes to win government approval for human tests of a genetically engineered drug intended to clear the lungs of the deadly mucus produced by cystic fibrosis. About 30,000 American children have cystic fibrosis, a hereditary disease in which the lungs secrete large amounts of thick mucus that impairs breathing and makes patients vulnerable to infection. Most victims die by age 30. The Genentech drug, DNase, is a mass-produced version of a natural human enzyme. Lab tests indicated that DNase, which will be given in aerosol form, loosens lung secretions, said Dr. Steven Shak, leader of the research team. Genentech also hopes DNase will let antibiotics reach and destroy infection-causing bacteria and fight less serious but more common lung diseases like chronic bronchitis, Shak said. Shak said Tuesday that Genentech has asked the Food and Drug Administration to approve human testing of the drug. Approval could come this year. Animal testing is not possible because no animal has a disease like cystic fibrosis. Several years of testing may be required before the drug can go into general use. The first stage of human testing will determine its safety and give a preliminary indication of whether it works.

DOC.HEAD: Brady Cautions Against Excess Concern About Inflation
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady said Wednesday that excess concern about inflation could hurt chances for continued economic growth. But Britain's finance chief, John Major, said inflation remained the ``main risk to continued growth and prosperity in our economies.'' The officials commented at the annual meeting of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, which brings together two dozen industrialized nations. The two-day meeting was expected to be dominated by efforts to break a deadlock in the Uruguay Round trade talks, a four-year drive to revamp the world trading system. However, Brady, Major and other finance chiefs offered a rundown on the outlook for their economies at the meeting's opening session. Brady predicted the American economy would expand at a moderate pace this year but pick up in 1991. He said that the price picture will ``require continued vigilance.'' But he cautioned, ``At the same time, we need to maintain a balanced view of the inflation risk and not allow excess concern to undermine the prospects for continued economic expansion.'' Inflation has become a worry in the industrialized world, where some fear it could bring to an end eight consecutive years of economic expansion. In particular, some fear that price-conscious West Germany could become the victim of higher inflation once it merges with East Germany. A surge in consumer demand in East Germay could put upward pressure on prices, some economists say. But West German Economics Minister Helmut Haussmann insisted his country's influential central bank, the Bundesbank, would be solely in charge of deciding monetary policy. He said the government intended to keep the annual inflation rate at about 3 percent. Major, Britain's chancellor of the exchequer, acknowledged that rising prices remain a persistent problem for the British economy. ``The fact remains that inflation is too high, and accordingly bringing it down must be, and is, the absolute priority of policy,'' he told his colleagues at OECD headquarters in the western part of Paris. He said the British government maintained a tight grip on monetary policy and warned that interest rates could climb higher. The OECD, as part of the annual meeting, estimated economic growth in its 24 member nations at a seasonally adjusted 2.9 percent this year and next. It was 3.6 percent last year.

DOC.HEAD: Officials of Rich Nations Gather to Restart Stalled Trade Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with Hills, Andriessen quotes. Minor editing throughout to tighten.
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills today made a fresh pitch for progress in stalled trade talks, but European officials resisted her call for immediate bargaining. ``The Americans made a serious mistake by trying to negotiate here,'' said Frans Andriessen, the top trade official for the 12-nation European Community. Mrs. Hills wanted trade officials attending the annual meeting of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development to give a push to the stalled Uruguay Round trade talks, a four-year effort to revamp the world trading system. But Andriessen said, ``This is not the negotiating place.'' Other countries, not attending the OECD meeting, have an interest in the discussions, he said. Mrs. Hills reminded her colleagues in a speech to the opening session of the OECD meeting that time was running short on reaching agreement on new trading rules. The negotiations began in Uruguay in 1986 and are due to conclude in Brussels in December. But a stubborn dispute between the United States and the European Community over government payments to farmers has stalled the talks. ``Agriculture is the linchpin of negotiations,'' Mrs. Hills said in her speech. Shortly before today's meeting began, West German Economics Minister Helmut Haussmann said the United States must ease its demand that European officials scrap their costly subsidy programs for farmers. The Bush administration wants the European Community to bring an end to import barriers and export and domestic farm subsidies that distort trade. The community has said it is cutting back on farm payments but cannot eliminate them completely. The dispute has raised concern that the international trade talks could end in failure. ``It's very important that the United States and the European Community find a sort of mechanism that insures an overall reduction of support prices,'' Haussmann told a breakfast meeting of the Anglo-American press Association in Paris. ``That means the United States will have to depart somehwat from its position.'' He said the community ``will certainly agree to a substantial reduction of support measures.'' The negotiations involve some 100 nations and are attempting to reduce barriers to trade in 15 areas. They include agriculture, textiles and other manufactured goods, and services such as banking and investment. Negotiators want to bring commerce in some of these areas under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade for the first time. GATT, a forum and an agreement for promoting freer trade, works to curb unfair trading practices and lower trade barriers. The community provides assistance to its farmers through guaranteed prices for many of their crops. It also gives exporters help so more expensive European farm products can compete with lower prices on the world market. Community officials argue that they have cut subsidies but say they cannot get rid of their farm program entirely because many small farmers depend on it for their livelihood. American officials also have run into trouble trying to get Third World countries to back their ideas for tough rules to prevent patent and copyright piracy. Poorer countries also are unhappy with a U.S. proposal to expand GATT's market-opening rules to cover trade in services such as banking, investment and insurance. American companies do well in those fields and poor countries fear their infant industries would be hurt. For their part, Third World countries want to tear down barriers to trade in textile products. The United States, under pressure from American textile groups, is pushing for a less comprehensive reduction of existing tariffs and quotas. Trade in textiles isn't covered by GATT rules but instead is regulated by the Multi-Fiber Agreement, an accord of some 80 nations. Mrs. Hills and other officials want to advance the trade talks so a preliminary agreement can be reached in some areas at a July 23 session in Geneva. OECD members are Australia, Austria, Belgium, Britain, Canada, Denmark, Finland, France, Greece, Iceland, Ireland, Italy, Japan, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, New Zealand, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey, the United States and West Germany.

Prices climbed higher on Wall Street today as momentum from Tuesday's big advance carried over to another day. The Dow Jones industrial average, which surged nearly 50 points and closed at a new high on Tuesday, was up another 14.00 to 2,884.49 as of 10 a.m. EDT. Advancing issues were ahead of decliners by a margin of 7 to 3 with, 704 stocks rising, 290 falling and 500 unchanged on the New York Stock Exchange. Volume came to 35.40 million shares after the first half-hour of trading. Analysts had expected a late buying burst on Tuesday to continue into the early part of today's session, but said it remained to be seen whether the market could hold its gains, especially with the Dow Jones average approaching the 2,900 barrier. The government reported today that its main economic forecasting gauge, the Index of Leading Economic Indicators, slipped 0.2 percent in April, its second loss in four months and another indication of the nation's sluggish economy. Analysts said the news was in line with market expectations and gave a boost to bond prices, which in turn helped support the stock market. The Treasury's bellwether 30-year bond was up $2.50 for each $1,000 in face amount in early trading. The most-actively traded issue on the NYSE was Torchmark, down [ at 46\. Technology stocks, which were the standouts Tuesday, were up again in the early going today. IBM rose [ to 119~ on the NYSE, while Adobe Systems rose ] to 38\ and Intel was up ] to 49 in over-the-counter trading. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed stocks rose 0.75 to 197.32. On the American Stock Exchange, the market value index gained 1.24 to 363.80. Prices rebounded on Tuesday following a 35-point drop in the Dow Jones industrials on Friday. The industrial average gained 49.57 to close at 2,870.49, surpassing the index's previous high of 2,856.26, set last Wednesday. Advancing issues outnumbered decliners by a margin of about 11 to 4 on the NYSE, with 1,107 up, 427 down and 454 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 137.41 million shares, against 120.25 million in the previous session.

DOC.HEAD: Economic Indicators Down in April
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 5th graf pvs, The economy ..., to include reports on home sales.
DOC.TEXT: The government's main economic forecasting gauge slipped 0.2 percent in April, its second loss in four months and another indication of the nation's sluggish economy, the Commerce Department said today. The Index of Leading Economic Indicators, designed to forecast economic activity six to nine months in advance, had risen 1.0 percent in March to regain February's 1.0 percent loss. The index was unchanged in January. A slight increase in the average workweek caused the department to revise the March figure up from 0.9 percent. Analysts had said in advance of the report that the economy had started the second quarter at the same weak pace that it ran in the first quarter and would improve only slightly in the second half of the year. The economy grew at a 1.3 percent annual rate in the first quarter and many economists expect it to advance only 2.0 percent for the entire year, down from 3.0 percent last year and 4.4 percent in 1988. In a second report today illustrating the economic sluggishness, the department said new home sales fell 1.6 percent in April, their fifth consecutive monthly decline to their lowest level since the recession year of 1982. The National Association of Realtors, which monitors existing home sales, said last Friday that resales of single-family homes slipped 2.1 percent in April, their third drop in four months although sales were unchanged in March. Bush administration and congressional budget negotiators had their eyes on the reports since continued growth would be required for any reduction in the federal deficit. A recession would mean a loss of jobs and lower personal incomes, diminished corporate profits and thus a drop in tax revenues. At the same time, the government would be called on to spend more on benefits. Analysts had expected a slight dip in today's leading indicators report, in part because of a continuing decline in the number of building permits in April. Permits have fallen each month since January, when builders sought to take advantage of record warm weather and to beat a deadline for meeting expensive new building standards. Many analysts foresee no immediate improvement in the construction industry in view of high interest rates and tighter restrictions on credit. In addition to building permits, five more of the 11 forward-looking statistics were negative. They included a drop in new plant and equipment orders, a decline in the average workweek, a decrease in orders for consumer goods, a drop in manufacturers' unfilled orders and an increase in weekly unemployment claims. Four of the components were positive: an increase in the price of raw materials, an index measuring consumer confidence, slower business delivery times and an increase in the money supply. Stock prices were unchanged. The various changes left the index at 144.9 percent of its 1982 base of 100 and down 0.6 percent from its level a year ago. Economists Bruce Steinberg and Laurie Allen contended in advance of today's report that ``the latest batch of indicators provided further evidence of a lackluster economy.'' Writing in Merrill Lynch Capital Markets' ``Weekly Economic & Financial Commentary,'' they pointed to reports last week showing continued sluggishness in the automobile industry and flat orders since the first of the year for durable goods _ usually expensive products expected to last at least three years. Steinberg and Allen also pointed out that the first-quarter gross national product _ the broadest measure of the nation's economic health _ was sharply revised downward, from 2.1 percent originally estimated to just 1.3 percent in last week's report. ``Like other indicators released during the past month, the latest set of data probably understate economic momentum,'' they added. ``But they amply illustrate that the economy is going nowhere fast.'' While the GNP grew at its slowest pace since 1986 from January through March, it contained what Robert G. Dederick, chief economist with the Northern Trust Co. in Chicago, described as ``the seeds of a pickup.'' The downward revision was attributed almost solely to a reduction in inventories, Dederick explained, which could provide for expanded second-quarter growth as businesses begin to refill their shelves and backlots. Allen Sinai, chief economist with the Boston Co., said second-quarter economic information ``so far depicts a soft economy.'' ``But if sales and demand stay up, the economy will continue to expand ... closer to 2 percent.'' Three recent surveys show other analysts also expect the economy to grow 2 percent this year, down from 3 percent last year and 4.4 percent in 1988. They were conducted by the Business Council, the National Association of Business Economists and Blue Chip Economic Indicators of Sedona, Ariz.

DOC.HEAD: Seabrook Sends First Nuclear-Powered Electricity to Consumers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 4th graf pvs, Spokesman Rob ..., with 2 grafs to UPDATE with increased power today, disconnect plans. A version moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Four years after it was completed and 14 years after construction began, the Seabrook plant has supplied nuclear-generated electricity to New England customers for the first time. The plant was operating at 15 percent capacity and producing enough electricity to supply 65,000 homes when it was hooked into the New England power grid Tuesday night, officials said. The milestone occurred during tests to ready the $6.5 billion plant for full commercial operation by mid-summer. At full power, Seabrook will generate 1,150 megawatts, enough for 1 million homes. Spokesman Rob Williams said today power had been increased to about 20 percent, producing about 120 megawatts. After increasing to about 215 megawatts and producing power into mid-afternoon, Williams said the plant would be disconnected from the New England power grid so equipment could be tested. Then it will be reconnected to the grid and the reactor brought to about 30 percent capacity. Seabrook has become a symbol of the nuclear industry's troubles and a target of anti-nuclear activists. Construction began in 1976 and took 10 years. Even the, the plant was unable to get an operating license until March. Because of delays, costs soared from less than $1 billion and forced the plant's lead owner, Public Service Company of New Hampshire, into bankruptcy court in 1988. Oponents contend the plant is unsafe and the evacuation plan for the surrounding area inadequate. The plant produced electricity during tests in 1985, but that was non-nuclear power generated by using the system's heater and pumps.

DOC.HEAD: Auto Journal Says Ford to Offer Big Year-End Incentives
DOC.TEXT: Ford Motor Co. will offer big incentives later this year to make room for 1991 models, an automotive journal says. This week's editions of Automotive News said Ford has told dealers it plans to offer incentives up to $1,500 on selected 1990 cars once the 1991 models get into showrooms in force. Ford already has begun selling some 1991 cars and trucks, including the Ford Escort subcompact and the Ford Explorer sport-utility vehicle. Year-end sales aren't unusual in the auto industry, but such early word of how they may be conducted is. Early word of the incentive plan may torpedo some sales now, since consumers may wait for bigger incentives later. Ford spokesman Bill Carroll was in a today and unavailable for immediate comment. Earlier this month, Ford's financial vice president, David McCammon, said the automaker spent about $1,000 per vehicle, or about $4 billion overall, on incentives last year. He said the company was trimming that cost this year. He also said new car and truck inventories were in good shape at between 60 to 65 selling days. Ford, General Motors Corp. and Chrysler Corp. have scheduled production increases in the third quarter. Some industry observers have said the manufacturing boost is a hedge against a possible United Auto Workers strike. UAW contracts with each of the Big Three automakers expire Sept. 14. If there is no strike, inventories of late 1990 and early 1991 cars and trucks could swell.

DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures opened mostly lower this morning on the Chicago Board of Trade. Analysts say the market continues to reflect concerns about the weather. There is less rain in the forecast, which could allow fields to dry enough to allow the planting of corn. Soybean planting has also been delayed, as shown by figures from Illinois, where plantings are 17 percent completed. Over the past five years, plantings are usually 81 percent compete by this time. Weather may also impact wheat futures. Rain delays to the hard red winter wheat harvest could occur in some areas. DOC.HEAD: Newspapers Would Have to Use Recycled Paper Under New Law
DOC.TEXT: The nation's toughest newspaper recycling law has been approved in Suffolk County on Long Island, where all major papers will be required to use 40 percent recycled newsprint in their editions by the end of 1996. The measure, which was approved Tuesday by a 12 to 6 vote in the county Legislature, was criticized by a group representing 64 daily papers in the state. The supporters of the bill would be able to override a veto by County Executive Patrick Halpin. ``Any use of recycled paper should be market driven,'' said John Kutzer, executive director of the New York Newspaper Publishers Association. ``We feel local government is perhaps going overboard with these requirements.'' The law would apply to all daily and weekly newspapers printed, sold, or distributed in Suffolk County, provided their Suffolk circulation is 20,000 or more a week. Advertising circulars are included if they meet the same circulation requirement. The bill would require that newspapers be printed on stock containing at least 40 percent recycled paper by Dec. 31, 1996. Compliance would be phased in in yearly steps. Papers which did not comply would face a $500 fine each day. Legislator Maxine Postal, D-Amityville, sponsored the bill, saying the measure would ease the pressure on Long Island landfills and incinerators. ``If the country does not move to resolve this problem, our most famous product next to the F-14 is going to be garbage,'' said Ms. Postal. Publishers complained there is just a single plant in the Northeast which supplies recycled paper, and the next one is not due to open until 1993. But Postal said paper manufacturers would retool to provide adequate supplies of recycled paper once publishers were willing to commit to long-term contracts. The publisher of Newsday, the largest circulation daily on Long Island, was opposed to the Suffolk plan and plans to challenge the law in court, said spokesman Sam Ruinsky. Newsday presently uses 17 percent recycled paper for printing. William K. Adler, manager of corporate relations for The New York Times, cited a voluntary agreement approved by the publishers association in which they agreed to gradually increase the use of recycled paper. That plan set a goal of 40 percent by the year 2000. ``Since the state has initiated a coordinated program, attempts by individual counties to legislate their own timetables for recycled newsprint are counterproductive,'' said Adler. The Times is currently using 8 percent recycled fiber, he said.

DOC.HEAD: SmithKline Seels Cosmetics Business
DOC.TEXT: SmithKline Beecham announced Wednesday it has agreed to sell its European cosmetics businesses to a West German firm for $358 million. Completion of the sale of the Margaret Astor and Lancaster subsidiaries, which manufacture skin care and decorative cosmetics and fragrances, to John. A. Benckiser GmbH of West Germany is subject to approval of the Cartel Office in the German Federal Republic. It is expected to take place in a month. The firms being sold had sales of $426 million last year and profits of $32 million. In December Benckiser bought SmithKline's Household Products business in the U.S. and Canada for $106 million. Benckiser, which had 1989 sales of $1.6 billion, sells Calgon water softner, Cling Free anti-static dryer sheets, Jet-Dry dishwasher rinse agent and other consumer products. Last month SmithKline Beecham sold its Yardley-Lentheric cosmetics business for $182 million to Old Bond Street Corp. With the latest transaction SmithKline said it has realized $1.68 billion from its planned divestitures, most of it in cash. The company has been reorganizing to focus on what it sees as its key businesses, such as pharmaceuticals, since Philadelphia-based SmithKline Beckman and London-based Beecham merged last year. Besides the cosmetics and households subsidiaries, SmithKline has sold its Ambrosia, Bovril and Marmite food brands for $257 million and 32 U.S. over-the-counter specialty products for $53 million. It said discussions are continuing to sell some nonstrategic human and animal pharmaceutical products, and the Yardley-Lentharic operation in South Africa.

DOC.HEAD: Pistor Resigns As NorthPark Bank President
DOC.TEXT: Charles Pistor, who serves on the boards of some of America's largest corporations, has resigned as chairman of a small Dallas bank, a post he had taken after leaving the huge First RepublicBank Corp. shortly before it failed. Pistor, a former vice chairman of First RepublicBank Corp. and past president of the American Bankers Association, said Tuesday that he decided to leave NorthPark National Bank because of the bank's past financial difficulties and Texas' slumping economy have prevented the expansion planned when he took the helm in April 1988. ``The reasons I was hired were obvious, to enhance the franchise in the sense of making a much bigger organization with acquisitions ... and to increase private banking. Those opportunities are still in front of the bank but I don't expect them to happen right away,'' Pistor said. NorthPark is a retail and commercial bank owned by Dallas developer Raymond Nasher. Although serving mainly upscale North Dallas neighborhoods, NorthPark has had its share of problem loans. The $700 million bank posted an $8.2 million loss in 1988 and a $6.1 million loss in 1989. But the bank, which received a $10 million injection of capital from Nasher last year, was profitable in the first quarter of 1990. Pistor also serves on the boards of Southern Methodist University, the Meadows Foundation and Dallas-based Centex Corp. and Oryx Energy Co.; Fort Worth-based AMR Corp.; and New York-based American Brands. Pistor left First RepublicBank just months before its banks were seized by regulators in July 1988 and sold to NCNB Texas National Bank.

DOC.HEAD: Deere Names Hans W. Becherer as Chairman and CEO
DOC.TEXT: Hans W. Becherer was elected chairman and chief executive officer of Deere & Co. today by the board of directors, the company announced. Becherer, 55, succeeds Robert A. Hanson, 65, who earlier announced his retirement as chairman effective Friday. Becherer, who has been serving as president and CEO, was considered the likely choice to succeed Hanson. The farm and heavy equipment manufacturer's board also named David H. Stowe Jr., 53, as president and chief operating officer. Stowe has served as Deere's executive vice president for worldwide agricultural equipment and consumer products. Bill C. Harpole, 56, was elected to succeed Stowe in the worldwide equipment and consumer products job, while Harpole's former job of senior vice president for the worldwide parts and logistics division goes to Bernard L. Hardiek, 50, who has been Deere's vice president for business development, planning and taxation. Becherer joined Deere in 1962 and served in a various marketing and management positions in Europe. He was elected vice president responsible for marketing operations in Latin America, Australia and the Far East in 1977. In 1983, he was elected to senior vice president of the overseas farm and consumer products division, and in 1986 to executive vice president, worldwide farm equipment and consumer products. He joined the company's board of directors in February 1986 and was elected president and chief operating officer in April 1987. He was elected president and chief executive officer in August 1989. In the last fiscal year, ending Oct. 31, Deere had net income of $380 million on revenue of $7.2 billion. The company has plants in eight countries and markets its products worldwide.

DOC.HEAD: A Decade's Eye View of Work Changes
DOC.TEXT: Some economic analysts view events by the month, others by the year and a very few by the decade, which is probably the least publicized but most revealing study of all. A decade review puts into perspective all those little blips on the trend line that cause excitement for a day or so or at most a week. What is revealed may be the true underlying direction of change. Following those longer trend lines, F. Thomas Juster, research scientist at the University of Michigan's Survey Research Center, traces lifestyle patterns during the 1980s and follows them through some unusual twists and turns. Example: Real hourly earnings during the 1980s fell from growth rates of around 3 percent a year in the 1950s and 1960s to less than 1 percent in the 1970s and 1980s. That decline, however, can't be demonstrated by certain other sets of data. Why not? Because, says Juster, while earnings per hour of work have almost stagnated for close to 20 years, total earnings have grown substantially. What seems to be a contradiction, however, is readily explained. What occurred, says Juster in a paper, ``is that total earnings have grown substantially because total hours of work have grown, especially for women.'' But doesn't that seem to be at odds with a popular belief, that Americans have become more leisure oriented? Not so, says Juster, who explains ``while total work hours in the market have grown, work hours in total have declined.'' Just a minute, you say, that doesn't make sense. But it does after Juster explains that while people might have spent more time on the job, that is, working for money, they spent less time working at home. Well, the women did, anyway. It was a slightly different story for men. Juster found that for most people, especially those between ages 25 and 44, the amount of time spent working for pay in the market and that spent at unpaid household work moved in different directions for men and women. Women spent less time at home and more in the marketplace. Men spent less time in the market and more time at home. If that's so, was the much-touted leisure generation a myth? No, it wasn't. ``Leisure time for both men and women has increased during the 1980s compared to earlier decades, and has in fact shown a steady increase since the 1960s,'' says Juster. And where did this leisure time come from if women went to work in the marketplace and men had to do more chores at home? The answer, apparently, is that while the time spent on household chores by women, especially young women, diminished sharply, the added time men spent on household tasks rose only modestly. The added leisure time, that is, came right out of the home, and that leaves some puzzling questions: Are men more efficient than women at household chores? Did household chores not get done? Was the need for less attention to household chores a result of more efficient houses and equipment to run them? The answers weren't in Juster's research paper.

DOC.HEAD: Construction Index Hits Four-Year Low
DOC.TEXT: Contracts for new construction declined 6 percent in April, reaching a four-year low and resuming a slide that began late last year, the F.W. Dodge division of McGraw-Hill Inc. reported Wednesday. The decline was blamed on a credit crunch affecting commercial and residential builders. ``Events of the past six months have changed the character of the construction sector from stable to vulnerable,'' said George A. Christie, chief economist at F.W. Dodge. He said tight credit for builders had become a bigger problem than mortgage rates, which he described as ``workable.'' ``The current rate of contracting, which is only about 85 percent of what it was last fall, seems to bear out the concern that we've been getting an overreaction by bankers to the regulatory clampdown on high-risk real estate lending practices,'' Christie said. That clampdown was precipitated by the crisis in the savings and loan industry. The Dodge index, which uses 1982 as its base of 100, dropped to 146 in April from 156 in March. The last time the index was lower than 146 was in January 1986 when it reached 145. With the exception of a 3 percent increase in March, the index has been declining since it peaked at 181 in September. The yearly pace of total contracting was $230.2 million last month, down from March's $245.5 million. Non-residential building set the pace with a 12 percent drop in April. Homebuilding construction dropped 4 percent in April, while public works and utilities projects increased 1 percent. For the first four months of 1990, construction contracting trailed the first four months of 1989 by 9 percent. The Northeast continued its decline of recent months by dropping 27 percent compared with the first four months of last year. The South trailed the pace set in 1989 by 11 percent. The West held even with last year's contracting through April and the North Central, leading last year by 5 percent, was the only region to show improvement in the first four months of 1990.

DOC.HEAD: Aetna Agrees To Temporarily Halt Withdrawal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS state abbreviation in dateline; CORRECTS company name in lede
DOC.TEXT: Aetna Life and Casualty Co., which earlier this month announced it would pull out of Pennsylvania's car-insurance market, has suspended its departure pending the outcome of a rate case before the state Insurance Department. Under an agreement with the Casey administration, which was announced Tuesday, the company also said it will rescind notices sent to customers notifying them their policies would not be renewed. As its part of the agreement, the state agreed to rule within two weeks on Aetna's request to sidestep rate rollbacks in the state's new car insurance law, which takes effect July 1 and requires premium cuts of at least 10 percent for all drivers. If approved, the company's proposal would result in rate increases for the majority of its 200,000 policyholders. Aetna spokesman John C. Hawkins said the company would not rule out any options, including withdrawal from the state, if the department rejects its request. Aetna, the state's fifth largest car insurer, announced May 9 its intent to leave the state, claiming the new law would preclude its ability to make a profit. The law calls for rate cuts of 10 percent for all drivers and at least 22 percent for drivers who give up their right to sue in most cases. Gov. Robert P. Casey and Hawkins said the agreement signaled a lessening of hostilities between the company and the state. Aetna had filed suit against the law; the state later named Aetna in a suit. The agreement will not affect the pending litigation. Casey said the agreement was another step toward getting the new law in place by July 1. He said 155 of the state's 223 car insurance companies, or about two-thirds, had filed rates in compliance with the law, although 41 of those are seeking exemptions from mandatory rate rollbacks. ``It's good news. It's real progress,'' Casey said, referring to the agreement with Aetna. Some of the state's largest insurers _ Allstate, State Farm and Erie _ have yet to file reduced rates under the law. Last week, the state granted exemptions to Keystone Insurance Co. and Colonial Penn Insurance Co. For Keystone customers that retain their full right to sue, rates will be boosted by 3 percent; other customers would see cuts of about 11 percent. Colonial Penn's rates would be cut by an average of 5.4 percent for those who retain the right to sue and cut 18 percent for others. Casey said those rulings recognized that the new law would have taken too large a chunk out of the companies' profit margin. He said that in the ``vast majority of cases,'' drivers in Pennsylvania could expect the full 10 percent or 22 percent cuts.

DOC.HEAD: Anthony D'Amato Named Borden's President, Chief Operating Officer
DOC.TEXT: Borden Inc. on Wednesday announced the appointment of Anthony S. D'Amato to the vacant posts of president and chief operating officer. D'Amato, 59, also was elected to Borden's board of directors. The appointments are effective July 1. ``Mr. D'Amato's promotion is an important step in preparation for an orderly succession,'' Borden Chairman and Chief Executive Officer R.J. Ventres said in a news release. Ventres said D'Amato's ``distinguished 31-year career at Borden has provided him with broad experience in both consumer and industrial product businesses to apply to the company's future growth.'' Ventres, 65, is due to retire at the end of 1991. The pattern at Borden has been that the president and COO is the successor when the chairman and CEO retires, spokesman Nicholas R. Iammartino said. D'Amato has served in various capacities during his Borden career. He succeeded Ventres as an executive vice president and president of the chemical division in 1985. Joseph M. Saggese was elected an executive vice president of the company and president of the worldwide packaging and industrial products division, succeeding D'Amato. Borden, the country's biggest dairy products company, also makes other foods and non-food consumer items ranging from glue to wallcoverings. It also manufactures industrial products, including chemicals and plastics. The company has its corporate headquarters in New York.

DOC.HEAD: Deere Names Hans W. Becherer as Chairman and CEO
DOC.TEXT: Deere & Co. elevated its president Hans W. Becherer to company chairman Wednesday, succeeding Robert A. Hanson, who is retiring. Becherer, 55, also retains the position of chief executive officer, to which he was named in August. Hanson, 65, had announced his retirement as chairman effective Friday. Deere's board of directors also promoted three other top company officials. ``This newly elected leadership ... is the same group of executives who have been actively involved in the development of the current strategic focus of Deere & Co.,'' said spokesman Robert J. Combs. John E. McGinty, an analyst with New York-based First Boston Corp., said the management changes were expected. He said the significant move came when Becherer was named chief executive officer. Among other changes, the farm and heavy equipment manufacturer's board named David H. Stowe Jr., 53, as president and chief operating officer. Stowe has served as Deere's executive vice president for worldwide agricultural equipment and consumer products. Bill C. Harpole, 56, was elected to succeed Stowe, while Harpole's former job of senior vice president for the worldwide parts and logistics division went to Bernard L. Hardiek, 50, who has been Deere's vice president for business development, planning and taxation. ``Under Bob Hanson's guidance, Deere & Co. met the tremendous challenges of the 1980s in our major market, the U.S. farm economy, and emerged as a stronger, more productive organization,'' Becherer said in a statement. ``We look forward to the challenge of extending Deere & Co.'s long history of leadership and excellence.'' Becherer joined Deere in 1962 and served in various posts covering operations in Europe, Latin America, Australia and the Far East. He joined the company's board of directors in February 1986 and was elected president and chief operating officer in April 1987. He was elected president and chief executive officer in August 1989. In the past fiscal year, which ended Oct. 31, Deere had net income of $380 million on revenue of $7.2 billion. The company has plants in eight countries.

DOC.HEAD: State Department Says `Nyet' to AT&T Plan For New U.S.-Soviet Phone Link
DOC.TEXT: The State Department opposes an American Telephone & Telegraph Co. plan to use the Soviet Intersputnik satellite system to increase long-distance calls between the United States and the Soviet Union. The department, in a letter to Federal Communications Commission Chairman Alfred Sikes, said there was insufficient reason to deviate from existing U.S. policy that requires most satellite telephone traffic between the two countries to be carried by the 119-nation Intelsat satellite cooperative. In December, AT&T asked the FCC for permission to use an Intersputnik satellite located above the west coast of Africa to try to keep pace with a large increase in U.S.-Soviet phone traffic. AT&T said in a letter to President Bush that calling between the two countries increased by more than 140 percent in the past two years as East-West relations improved. The company said demand still far exceeded capacity, and it sought FCC permission to nearly triple telecommunications capacity between the two nations. But Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger said there were insufficient foreign policy reasons to give AT&T permission to shift some future traffic away from Intelsat. Eagleburger, however, in his May 14 letter to the FCC, said the State Department would support use of Intersputnik for services not interconnected with the public, switched phone network, such as data transmission. An FCC decision is pending. Intelsat spokesman Tony Trujillo said Thursday it wasn't true that Intelsat didn't have the capacity to meet the demand for U.S.-Soviet calling. However, Charles Miller, AT&T vice president for federal government affairs, said the issue wasn't Intelsat's capacity but the Soviet Union's problem of buying additional space on Intelsat because the ruble isn't traded officially in international money markets. ``The principal concern was ... the hard currency problem,'' he said. Miller said the United States has 56 circuits to the Soviet Union, about the same as for Iceland, a country with about 0.1 percent of the Soviet population. AT&T, which handles more than 80 percent of all U.S. international telephone calling, has the only Western phone facilities to the Soviet Union. The traffic is carried on undersea cable, land lines and by Intelsat. Other long-distance companies lease space on the AT&T circuits. AT&T said it would need to build a new satellite earth station near Catawissa, Pa., to connect with the Intersputnik satellite.

Among blue chip issues, IBM was up 1| to 121], General Electric fell ] to 69], and Philip Morris was off 1[ to 42{. Technology stocks led Wall Street on Tuesday, but today's gains were more evenly spread among the market, said Jack Barbanel, president of First Global Asset Management Inc. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed stocks rose 0.13 to 196.70. On the American Stock Exchange, the market value index gained 0.55 to 363.11. Prices rebounded on Tuesday following a 35-point drop in the Dow Jones industrials on Friday. The industrial average gained 49.57 to close at 2,870.49, surpassing the index's previous high of 2,856.26, set last Wednesday. the previous session.

DOC.HEAD: Marine Midland Agrees To Sell International Private Banking To Barclays
DOC.TEXT: Marine Midland Bank has agreed to sell Barclays Bank PLC its international private banking business, which primarily operates in Latin America, the two banks announced Wednesday. Marine Midland's decision to sell is part of a strategy to focus on retail banking through its 317 branches in New York state, Geoffrey A. Thompson, president and chief executive of Marine Midland, said in a press release. Marion J. Cotrone, a spokeswoman for Barclays, said the bank already does business in Latin America, but the acquisition of Marine Midland's operations is an opportunity to expand Barclays' client base. Terms of the agreement, which is expected to be completed in August, were not disclosed. Tony Mattera, a Marine Midland spokesman, said he could not discuss the specific size of Marine Midland's international banking arm, but said: ``It's not insignificant, but on the other hand it's not a giant business.'' Marine Midland's holding company, Honkong and Shanghai Banking Corp. Ltd., also known as HongkongBank, also handles international private banking from the United States, he said. Barclays, headquartered in London, operates branches in more than 70 countries. The bank had $205 billion in assets at the end of 1989. Hongkong and Shanghai had assets of $133 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Auto Company Plans $27 Million R&D Expansion
DOC.TEXT: Honda announced Wednesday it will expand its research and development operation in a $27 million project. The company said construction of the 81,000-square-foot facility next to the Transportation Research Center and near the company's Marysville operations in west-central Ohio is to begin in August and be completed next year. Masaru Otabe, president of Honda R&D North America, said the expansion ``continues Honda's strategy to become a self-reliant motor vehicle company in the United States.'' The company said the new facilities will increase Honda's ability to assist U.S. suppliers in developing parts of Honda products made in the United States and Canada. The first Honda product to be designed, developed and engineered in the United States is the 1991 Accord Wagon. It is to be made exclusively in the United States and be exported to world markets. ``This represents the beginning of a major investment in what I see as R&D development in Ohio,'' Gov. Richard Celeste said at a news conference. Celeste said the state will make grants available to Honda to train new employees at the center. But he said he could not yet say how much money the state will provide. Honda R&D North America has 300 employees nationwide. With the expansion, it expects total employment to reach about 500. Honda's research activities started in California in 1975. The Los Angeles center is responsible for market research and analysis, product planning and styling design. The Ohio center began operation in 1985. It is responsible for development, prototype fabrication, testing and support of North American suppliers. The Transportation Research Center is a 7,500-acre complex that provides research, development and testing services and facilities to companies and government agencies involved in transportation. Honda of America Manufacturing Inc. bought the TRC property from the state of Ohio in 1988. But the independent TRC Inc. operates the center through Ohio State University and has other clients besides Honda.

DOC.HEAD: Inventor Says He Has Developed 3-D TV
DOC.TEXT: An inventor said Wednesday he has developed three-dimensional television, beating the world's electronics giants. ``We think that just as black and white was converted into color, so will color be converted into 3-D,'' said the 33-year-old British inventor, James Ashbey. The technology does not require special glasses or screens. It can convert all new and existing black and white and color films into 3-D, along with live broadcasts, animation and computer graphics, said his company, Delta Group. Ashbey displayed his invention at a London studio, showing color films in what he calls ``full natural perspective.'' The effect appears three dimensional, but it loses some resolution compared with a standard TV image, and is very blurry. Ashbey did not display the 3-D and normal television versions of the same film side-by-side for comparison. Ashbey said he has applied for an international patent for his invention, which he calls ``Deep Vision.'' He said he developed the technology with financial support from RCA-Columbia Pictures International, which he said provided $245,000, and the British entertainment group Brent Walker Holdings PLC, which he said provided $642,200. Deep Vision electronically stimulates the brain into creating an illusion, he said. The technology takes a normal film, makes a digital version and inserts what Ashbey calls stereo cues. A digital decoder added to an ordinary television set then uses these cues to send slightly different images to each eye, and that creates the experience of depth, he said.

For release Sunday June 3
DOC.HEAD: Sir John Harvey-Jones, Star British Businessman, Fights the Stereotype
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Businessmen don't get no respect in Britain. Sir John Harvey-Jones has turned himself into a national celebrity by trying to do something about that. ``I think we have an anti-industrial bias in this country and have had for many years,'' said the former chairman of Imperial Chemical Industries PLC, one of the largest British manufacturers. ``People think that business is just about money and figures and that management is about administration and bureaucracy,'' he said. ``I actually think that business is about the totality of life and finally about people.'' Since before the time Charles Dickens created Ebenezer Scrooge, ordinary Britons often have regarded businessmen as money-grubbing exploiters. The strength of Britain's socialist opposition Labor Party partly reflects an enduring contempt for capitalist role models. Harvey-Jones, 66, has bucked the stereotype. He is widely admired for turning Imperial Chemical into a multinational giant with products that range from artificial carpet fiber to household paints. Contrary to the arrogance and aloofness commonly ascribed to many British business types, Harvey-Jones looks like a friendly buccaneer, with collar-length hair, shaggy mustache and beefy frame. He goes for loud, expensive ties, drives a donkey trap around his 13th century manor house and boasts a flare for cooking curry. Perhaps another reason Harvey-Jones defies the British executive image is his political leaning. He's not enamored with Conservative Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, who has alienated many working people with her strident free enterprise strategies that have reshaped Britain's economy this past decade. ``I believe that our society has become more divisive in the past 10 years rather than less,'' Harvey-Jones said. Thatcher doesn't much care for Harvey-Jones either. The British press says he's her least favorite industrialist. But the Independent newspaper has called him the Field Marshal Montgomery of Manufacturing, referring to Britain's World War II hero, Viscount Montgomery. ``He runs on the same mixture of surface flamboyance and underlying caution,'' the newspaper said. Harvey-Jones' latest effort to win Britons over to the industrialists' side was a six-part BBC-TV series called ``Troubleshooter.'' In it, he called on businesses ranging from a pottery to a carmaker, helping solve problems. Although the documentary-style program looked like a course on basic management, it was a surprise hit, attracting between 2 million and 3 million viewers each week. ``I hoped in the series that we would be able to give a different perspective on what businessmen actually do, the sort of problems they are trying to deal with, and the reasons why management is, I think, a very worthwhile career and a very important career,'' Harvey-Jones said. ``A well-organized, well-functioning, efficient factory gives me the same pleasure, albeit in a different way, as when I go into a very nicely tended garden,'' he said. Harvey-Jones is the only child of an Army captain who later served as a hired prime minister to under-age maharajahs in India. He led a pampered childhood and once had his own ceremonial elephant. He was wrenched away at age 6 and sent to the Tormore boarding school in Kent, England, attended the Royal Naval College at Dartmouth when he was 13 and served in the Navy during World War II. He spent a dozen years in Navy intelligence doing secret work that won him the Order of the British Empire. At age 32 he joined Imperial Chemical Industries as trainee, rose through management for nearly four decades and became chairman in 1982. The company had just reported its first quarterly loss. Harvey-Jones funneled money into the company's growth areas and cut back on the poorly performing plastics, fiber and petrochemicals business. Imperial Chemical turned profitable again within two years. The reversal became part of the reason Harvey-Jones was awarded with knighthood in 1985. He retired from Imperial Chemical in 1987, and has taken on about 32 part-time paid and unpaid jobs since, ranging from charity events to his BBC series. Harvey-Jones is a director of several major British companies as well as the Economist magazine and he is Chancellor of Bradford University. ``I think the day when you stop doing anything and you just lie back in your deck chair, you're ready for your box,'' Harvey-Jones said during a recent interview at the Mayfair, a posh London hotel favored by rock stars. His accessibility is unusual in a country where most executives are tight-lipped and publicity shy. ``I'm probably better known than most,'' Harvey-Jones said, but ``if the best you can do is to have a sort of old-age pensioner as a business hero, I think we're in trouble.'' Harvey-Jones blamed Britain's anti-business attitudes partly on what he called the bias of the national education system, which exalts professions such as medicine and dramatic arts but seems to steer students clear of business careers. Few of Britain's managers are trained, he said. ``There is still a very considerable degree of snobbery in this country. People are judged by their birth and are judged by the type of career they follow. Certainly, business success in this country doesn't open doors for you,'' he said. Harvey-Jones lives in Ross-on-Wye in Herefordshire in central west England, with his wife, daughter and 17-year-old granddaughter. He has a reputation for cooking ferocious curries, a talent he picked up in India. ``I enjoy it because it's a creative thing,'' he said. ``I tend to be a big man with the onion and the garlic.'
