DOC.HEAD: First American Strong, Executive Says, Despite Chairman's Ouster
DOC.TEXT: First American Corp., Tennessee's largest bank holding company, remains strong despite the firing of its top executive and a recent loss, the chairman of its executive committee says. First American, which has 140 branches across the state, fired Kenneth L. Roberts, it chairman, president and chief executive officer, in th wake of a first-quarter loss of $44.8 million. ``Despite recent problems, First American remains a strong company with ample capital and liquidity,'' executive committee Chairman David K. Wilson said in a statement release Tuesday after Roberts was fired. Roberts, 57, could not be reached for comment Wednesday. An employee of his who answered the telephone at the Roberts home said Roberts was out of town. In a statement released by the bank, Roberts said: ``While I am proud of many achievements during the past 14 years, certainly I am not pleased with our current performance. As we effect this change in leadership, let me express my appreciation to our shareholders, directors, customers and employees for their past support,'' he said. Roberts will continue to receive his salary and other benefits for the next four years, totaling more than $1.5 million. He was recently listed by Forbes magazine as one of the nation's highest-paid executives. First American Vice Chairman James F. Smith Jr. was elected to succeed Roberts on a interim basis as chairman, president and chief executive officer. The $44.8 million loss came after a profit of only $4.2 million for all of last year. The losses came after federal regulators completed a special examination of real estate loans.

Prices moved higher on Wall Street today as momentum from Tuesday's big advance pushed the Dow Jones industrial average toward the 2,900 mark. FIve minutes before the close, the average was up 7.12 at 2,877.61.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Advance, Dow Jones Industrial Reach Another New High
DOC.TEXT: Prices advanced moderately on Wall Street today, with the Dow Jones industrial average reaching yet another closing high, as buying from Tuesday's big advance continued into a second session. The average gained 8.07 to finish at 2,878.56, eclipsing the previous high of 2,870.49, set only one day before. Analysts had expected Tuesday's surge _ in which the Dow Jones industrials gained nearly 50 points _ to spill over into today's session. They also questioned whether the market could hold its gains, especially with the Dow Jones average approaching the 2,900 barrier. The average fluctuated during the session and dipped into minus territory late in the day as higher prices triggered computer-program sell orders. But the market, continuing to show resilience, repeatedly shook off the declines. The government reported today that its main economic forecasting gauge, the Index of Leading Economic Indicators, slipped 0.2 percent in April, its second loss in four months and another indication of the nation's sluggish economy. Analysts said the news was in line with market expectations and gave a boost to bond prices, which in turn helped support the stock market. The Treasury's bellwether 30-year bond was up more than $3 for each $1,000 in face amount by late afternoon. The analysts predicted there would be caution in the market later this week, especially with May employment figures due to be released on Friday.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Chancellor Ponders Accepting Money From Felon Financier
DOC.TEXT: The chancellor of New York City's schools is reconsidering the school system's acceptance of donations from Michael Milken's foundation, following the disclosure that the financier has visited a Harlem elementary school since pleading guilty to felony charges. Milken, the junk bond billionaire, visited P.S. 92 on May 24 and 25 and on the second day gave a math lesson to about 30 elementary students who were taken out of their regular classes to be with him, according to a New York City newspaper. Milken faces up to 28 years in prison when he is sentenced in October on his April 24 plea to violating federal securities and tax laws. Milken's family foundation is a contributor to educational causes, and Milken himself has visited classrooms around the country. Money from the foundation, and from other foundations and corporate contributors, has been needed and welcomed by the New York school system, said James Vlasto, a spokesman for Schools Chancellor Joseph Fernandez. ``But under the circumstances of Mr. Milken's current situation, we are re-assessing the relationship between the Milken Foundation and the New York City school system,'' Vlasto said Wednesday. According to the New York Post, Milken's foundation gave the school a $50,000 grant last year for a computer center and flew the school's principal, Steve Kaminsky, to Los Angeles for a computer conference. In December the children received T-shirts and other Christmas presents from the foundation, the Post said. At the time, Milken was under a 98-count indictment and being threatened with added charges. Kaminsky was quoted by the Post as saying, ``I'm not going to be a hypocrite and say it's OK to take Mr. Milken's money and then not allow the gentleman into the building.'' Calls to the school seeking further comment from Kaminsky were referred to the district superintendent, Bertrand Brown. Brown, who the Post said approved Milken's visits to the school, did not respond immediately to a call for comment. A spokesman for Milken, Ken Lerer, said Milken has donated money to support education since the 1970s.

DOC.HEAD: Walt Disney World To Help Orange County Borrow Money For Low-Cost Mortgages
DOC.TEXT: Walt Disney World officials hope a plan to help Orange County borrow about $80 million for low-cost housing mortgages will foster some goodwill with its neighbors. Under the agreement, the company would back Orange County's refinancing of a 1980 housing loan with New York bankers. Disney would benefit by ending a conflict that erupted after it won a drawing that gave it the right to issue all the tax-exempt bonds allocated for a six-county Central Florida area. ``We're interested partly because we've got a responsibility to this community and a good image in this community that we want to protect,'' Peter Rummell, president of Disney's development company, said after the tentative agreement was reached Tuesday. Disney plans to spend $1.8 million to buy up the residual _ the profit a bank stands to earn over the life of a bond issue _ from the institution that holds the county's 1980 loan. A new loan for $80 million can then be negotiated. Disney's Reedy Creek Improvement District, which functions as an autonomous governmental unit, will use its tax-exempt bonding power to build a sewage treatment plant on the attraction's 27,400-acre property stradding Orange and Osceola counties. The bonds are allocated on a first-come, first-served basis by the state Division of Bond Finance. The application from Orange County, which originally had asked for $19 million, arrived Jan. 4, two days after applications from Reedy Creek and Volusia and Brevard counties. The three Jan. 2 applications were put into a box, and Reedy Creek won the drawing.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Futures Advance Amid Earthquake Concerns
DOC.TEXT: Crude oil and gasoline prices rose Wednesday as traders tried to determine the extent of damage an early morning earthquake caused to Romanian oil fields and refineries. The July contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, rose 10 cents to $18.08 per 42-gallon barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange following an 18-cent increase Tuesday. Later contract months also showed small increases. The June contract for wholesale unleaded gasoline rose 1.08 cents to 66.87 cents a gallon, on top of Tuesday's 2.38 cent increase. The July contract increased 0.30 cents to 63.26 cents a gallon. The price of crude rose 20 cents to 30 cents a barrel early Wednesday because of concerns that the earthquake, which struck at 6:40 a.m. Eastern time, had damaged oil installations in Romania and along a fault line into Turkey and the Black Sea, said Peter Beutel, assistant director of the energy group at Elders Futures Inc. Severe damage would diminish the amount of gasoline on the world market, driving up prices. But he said the price of crude, which reached a high of $18.45 a barrel, declined and stabilized as traders received word that the damage may not be as bad as originally thought. He said the extent of damage was still unclear as traders conducted business during the afternoon, but reports were more optimistic than when the market opened. ``It appears there's less likelihood now that there would have been a problem,'' he said. Beutel said Romania is major exporter of gasoline, with much of its supply shipped to the West. Analysts said the energy futures prices also may have increased in anticipation of new refinery capacity usage figures due for release after the close of markets by the American Petroleum Institute. ``They're just trying to book profits before the numbers come out in case there's a surprise,'' said William Byers, director of futures research at Bear, Stearns & Co. in New York. Among other refined products traded on the Merc, the June contract for home heating oil rose 0.91 cent a gallon to 51.15 cents, after rising 0.58 cent on Tuesday. Later months showed smaller increases. Natural gas prices were mostly up. The July contract was unchanged at $1.585 per 1,000 cubic feet, while future months increased slightly.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Gains; Gold Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar gained against most major currencies except the British pound Wednesday, benefiting from weakness in the West German mark. Gold prices posted moderate losses in domestic and overseas dealing. The dollar's advance did not reflect any fundamental improvement in market sentiment toward the U.S. currency. Rather, the dollar buying chiefly was a byproduct of mark selling. John McCarthy, chief currency dealer at the Amsterdam Rotterdam Bank in New York, said the West German currency has been under pressure due to persistent concerns about possibly negative consequences of German unification. The pound got a boost from expectations that Chancellor of the Exchequer John Major soon would indicate when Britain would enter into the European Monetary System's exchange rate accord. The pound peaked in Europe at $1.7071 after comments by Major from Paris where he was meeting with his French counterpart, Pierre Beregovoy. But sterling pulled back from its highs when it became clear that Major was not going to disclose anything significant for the time being. The pound was quoted late in London at $1.6930 compared to $1.6953 late Tuesday. In later New York trading, a pound fetched $1.6950 compared to $1.6945 late Tuesday. Foreign exchange dealers expect the dollar to trade within a narrow range as the market awaits the release of U.S. employment data for May, due out Friday. The monthly jobs report frequently moves financial markets. The dollar began its trading day in Tokyo by rising 0.05 yen to a closing rate of 150.75 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at 151.30 yen. The dollar gained more ground in New York and was quoted at 151.45 yen late in the day, up from 151.22 yen late Tuesday. Selected late dollar rates in New York, compared with Tuesday's late quotes, included: 1.6825 West German marks, up from 1.6740 West German marks; 1.42265 Swiss francs, up from 1.4105; 5.6735 French francs, up from 5.6380; 1,237.75 Italian lire, up from 1,229.50; and 1.17675 Canadian dollars, down from 1.17945. The Canadian dollar's strength against its U.S. counterpart was attributed to technical trading factors, dealers said. Other late dollar rates in Europe compared with late Tuesday's levels were: 1.6810 West German marks, up from 1.6710; 1.4210 Swiss francs, up from 1.4080; 5.6715 French francs, up from 5.6280; 1.8880 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8810; 1,237.25 Italian lire, up from 1,228.25; and 1.1778 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1815. Precious metals prices moved lower. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, a troy ounce of gold for current delivery lost $3.30 to close at $364.10. Republic National Bank quoted a late bid of $364.55 for a troy ounce of gold bullion, $2.35 lower than Tuesday. Gold was quoted at a bid of $366.65 an ounce late in London, down from $367.60 late Tuesday. In Zurich, the gold bid was $366.25, down from $367.50 late Tuesday. Gold in Hong Kong fell $2.01 to close at a bid of $367.47 an ounce. Silver for current delivery fell to $5.047 a troy ounce on New York Comex from $5.138 on Tuesday. In London, silver was quoted at a bid of $5.15 an ounce, down from Tuesday's $5.17.

DOC.HEAD: Stock Prices Advance, DJIA Reaches Another New High
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Prices moved moderately higher on Wall Street Wednesday, nudging the Dow Jones industrial average to yet another closing high and toward the 2,900 mark. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks picked up 8.07 to finish at 2,878.56 and eclipse the previous high close of 2,870.49, set only one day before. On Tuesday, the average soared nearly 50 points as technology issues led the market in a late buying surge. Advancing issues outnumbered decliners by about 8 to 7 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 893 up, 693 down and 523 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to a heavy 199.54 million shares, up from 137.41 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 248.22 million shares. The market's advance Wednesday came as little surprise to analysts who expected the momentum from Tuesday's buying spree to spill over into another session. But they also were not surprised by hesitation in the market. Computer-generated sell orders eroded gains at several points during Wednesday's session and took the Dow Jones average briefly into minus territory. A.C. Moore, an analyst with Argus Research Corp., said prices were able to withstand the dips partly because of strength in the bond market. The Treasury's bellwether 30-year bond was up more than $3 for each $1,000 in face amount by late afternoon. Including Wednesday's results, the Dow Jones industrials have had eight new closing highs this month, but analysts shied away from predicting the blue chip barometer will crash through 2,900. ``I don't sense that the tape has the type of momentum to make an inexorable drive,'' said Moore, who noted that as prices rise investors may begin to view stocks as overbought. Furthermore, analysts expected the market to become more cautious prior to the government's release Friday of May employment figures. The government reported Wednesday that its main economic forecasting gauge, the Index of Leading Economic Indicators, slipped 0.2 percent in April, its second loss in four months and another indication of the nation's sluggish economy. Analysts said the news was in line with market expectations. The most active issue on the NYSE was Texas Utilities, which rose [ to 36]. Among blue chip issues, IBM was up 1[ to 120~, Philip Morris fell 1[ to 42{, and General Electric was off ] at 69]. Mobil rose 1 to 62~, Dow Chemicals slipped 1 to 63{, and Woolworth rose 1[ to 66{. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market gained $3.189 billion, or 0.09 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 0.18 to 196.75. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 0.31 to 421.62, and S&P's 500-stock composite index gained 0.21 to 360.86. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market rose 1.26 to 458.77. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 362.91, up 0.35.

DOC.HEAD: Greyhound Will Remanufacture Old Buses Instead of Buying New
DOC.TEXT: Greyhound Lines Inc., searching for ways to save money and entice new financing, said Wednesday it would rebuild its fleet of 3,949 buses instead of buying new models. President Frank Schmieder estimated the strike-bound busline would save $318.5 million over the cost of replacing the buses in 2{ years. Greyhound plans to rebuild 728 buses annually, finishing the fleet in a little more than five years. Greyhound, which operates the only nationwide bus system, has been experimenting with remanufacturing buses for more than a year, and had begun streamlining its maintenance operation even before bus drivers went on strike March 2. The company has operated a reduced schedule since the 6,300 drivers walked out, and lower revenue and resulting losses have hurt the company's balance sheet. Greyhound will remanufacture its buses at an expanded garage in Jackson, Miss., and at a second, yet-to-be-determined site. ``A new bus is a quality piece of heavy equipment made to last 25 years,'' Schmieder said in remarks prepared for delivery in Jackson. ``It doesn't make sense to get rid of it just because its engine, transmission and air conditioning systems have failed. Those things can be replaced.'' Schmieder said it costs Greyhound about $25,000 to remanufacture a bus, compared to $200,000 for a new one. Engines and transmissions will be replaced, as will key components such as brakes and shock absorbers. Other parts will be replaced or repaired as needed then the bus will get new upholstery, side panels, glass and paint. ``We're not doing this to scrimp,'' spokesman George Gravley said. ``We expect the quality of our buses to be better,'' resulting in less downtime and ``a better product for the customer.'' Greyhound already has missed more than $14 million in lease and interest payments, putting it in violation of agreements with its creditors. The next deadline comes Friday, when the company owes a $2.5 million payment on a $40 million loan. Gravley said a decision on making the payment had not been made. Greyhound also has a $2.8 million interest payment due in mid-July. In an effort to avoid bankruptcy, Greyhound has offered to repurchase a majority of its $225 million in junk bonds for about $90 million. Greyhound must borrow the money to buy back the bonds, however, and analysts have questioned whether the company can find the financing under current market conditions. Gravley said negotiations are continuing with possible lenders, but no announcement is imminent. The repurchase offer is set to expire June 18 but could be extended. Greyhound bought 476 new buses in 1987 and 1988, the first two years after investors bought the company in a leveraged buyout. No new buses were purchased last year, and Schmieder said the remanufacturing program assumes the company will not buy any new buses until at least 1993.

DOC.HEAD: Ford Again Not Offering Year-End Dealer Credit; Using Incentives Instead
DOC.TEXT: Ford Motor Co. plans to offer customer incentives instead of a discount to dealers this fall to help spur sales at the end of the 1990 model year, a company spokesman said Wednesday. The minimum possible incentives, outlined in a letter to Ford dealers, are lower than those in the automaker's current incentive program but go higher if demanded by market conditions. The incentives would be in lieu of ``carryover'' credits _ effectively a discount to dealers _ that Ford used to offer to help spur sales of prior-year vehicles when new model years began. It's the second straight year that Ford has eliminated the 5 percent carryover credit. The carryover allowance applied to cars on a dealer's lot when the new model year began. Dealers used the allowances for customer incentives, to pay for salesperson contests, to buy advertising or simply pad their own profits. Ford spokesman Bill Carroll said Wednesday that the letter to dealrs outlined some year-end plans, including the list of minimum possible incentives on 1990 cars and trucks and a plea for more car and truck orders. Ford's current incentive program is due to expire July 9. The year-end incentives will be offered between Sept. 28 and the end of the calendar year. Automotive model years typically begin Oct. 1. ``In our letter to dealers, we're mainly pointing out that we've eliminated, for the second straight year, the 5 percent carryover,'' Carroll said. ``We feel that it's better to eliminate that and let it go by what the market is and what the incentive programs are rather than the carryover program.'' Ford's move did not sit well with the National Automobile Dealers Association, which represents about 20,000 U.S. car and truck retailers. ``It's still our longstanding belief that we are better local marketers than the manufacturers,'' NADA spokesman Jake Kelderman said Wednesday. ``From the dealers' perspective, when it comes to year-end marketing, they would like to have more control than under a program such as this,'' he said. ``We just have a general problem with all this stuff of going over our heads with our consumers. ``It creates a lot of confusion in the marketplace.'' Automakers are offering a wide array of incentives directly to customers, including cash rebates ranging from $200 to $5,000 or financing with interest rates as low as 2.9 percent. The companies also offer some other incentives to dealers, keyed to car sales. Those incentives are used for advertising, contests or are passed along to car buyers. General Motors Corp. will give dealers 5 percent of the sticker price of 1990 model cars they sell after the start of the 1991 model year in October, until Dec. 31. Chrysler Corp. spokesman Tom Jakobowski declined to say what kind of deal, if any, his company would offer dealers at the end of the model year. Ford also used its letter to seek more orders for 1990 model cars. ``We reminded them (dealers) that, `You could be in short supply of certain cars and you should figure out what you need and put orders in during this build-out period,'' Carroll said. A build-out period is the time when factory production is indexed heavily to dealer orders, while manufacturers try to limit production to expected demand. Recently, Ford temporarily shut down its Chicago and Atlanta factories, which make the company's popular Ford Taurus and Mercury Sable sedans. Ford said each closing was prompted by a shortage of dealer orders.

DOC.HEAD: Russian Mickey Mouse Mag Sells Out on Day One
LaserPhoto LA1
DOC.TEXT: Big Macs wowed Moscow, so perhaps it should come as no surprise. But the Walt Disney Co. says Muscovites gobbled up all 200,000 Russian-language Mickey Mouse comics magazines the first day of release. The 32-page magazine, designed as the first in a quarterly series, was released May 16 and sold for 1.5 rubles a copy _ $2.40 or so. It contains five comics of various lengths already published in other countries, with dialogue in the ``word balloons'' translated into Russian. Disney's familiar menagerie is on display: Goofy and Mickey fly a kite from an airplane on the front cover; Goofy and some little green men sail past planets in a bubble-top spaceship on the back. How universal can entertainment get? In fact, Disney is part of a number of Western comics publishers whose sales have risen in Western Europe in recent years and now are eyeing untapped markets in a part of the world where officials once looked askance at capitalists like Scrooge McDuck. Disney, for example, has sold Mickey Mouse comics in Hungary for about 2{ years, with recent sales reaching 125,000 a month. Eastern Europe is still a tiny fragment of Disney's annual $1.5 billion in consumer product sales, but the idea is to get the franchise in early as the trade doors open wider. The Moscow comic sales numbers reported by Disney are strong, other publishers said. ``Two hundred thousand copies in a day? I'm impressed!'' said James E. Galton, the president of New York's Marvel Comics, home to Spider-Man, X-Men, Fantastic Four, Captain America and The Incredible Hulk. Marvel, the largest U.S. comics producer, publishes in 15 languages and 25 countries. Their Conan the Barbarian has invaded Hungary and they publish four titles in Yugoslavia, Galton said. ``Right now, I've got a guy in Moscow checking out the possibilities of publishing there,'' he said in a telephone interview. ``We also have German publishers shipping copies from West Germany to East Germany _ that's been going on since they knocked down the Berlin Wall.'' The Disney publication is a joint venture between the Disney-licensed Danish publisher Gutenberghus and Soviet publisher Fizkultura I Sport. The partnership was managed by Disney's consumer products subsidiary in West Germany. The comic book was distributed at hundreds of Moscow magazine kiosks, and the publishers reported the single-day sellout, according to Disney's senior vice president in Europe, Dennis Hightower. In a telephone interview from Milan, Italy, Hightower said the publishers estimated that Soviet demand was strong enough to have sold 1.5 million copies nationwide. ``The major criticism we've gotten is why weren't there more copies, and that's unfortunately a problem with the paper allocation.'' To put the numbers in perspective, Marvel expects to set a single-issue record with a new, soon-to-be released Spiderman comic. About 2 million copies have been presold in the United States and Canada, and total sales should be 2.3 million or more, said Marvel spokeswoman Pamela Rutt. Issue No. 2 of the Russian Mickey Mouse comic book series is scheduled for July. It is expected the press run again will be limited to 200,000 copies, reflecting the amount of printing paper allocated to the magazine. In most countries of the world, U.S. comics are produced by licensed publishers. In Spain, for example, Disney produces comics in a joint venture with Brazilian publisher Abril. All of Marvel's overseas deals are licensed except in England, where Marvel has a subsidiary. However, Disney itself recently began publishing Topolino (Mickey Mouse) comics in Italy, selling as many as 700,000 copies each week. Disney also began publishing its own series of eight monthly comics in the United States in April. It's not just big publishers who are moving into Europe. For example, Eclipse Comics of Forestville, Calif., had revenue of about $3.5 million last year, with 5 percent of that from European publishing _ up from 2 percent three years ago, publisher Dean Mullaney said. ``Comics are a luxury,'' he said. ``But what seems to be happening is that they really want our entertainment, because they haven't had access to it for so long.''

DOC.HEAD: Boesky Trader Alleges Securities Trading Scheme
DOC.TEXT: Ivan Boesky's chief trader testified Wednesday that John Mulheren Jr. temporarily held large blocks of securities for Boesky in 1985 in an alleged scheme to help his former friend avoid taxes and securities rules. Michael Davidoff, testifying at Mulheren's trial in U.S. District Court, offered a trade-by-trade breakdown of an alleged pact with Boesky's Seemala Corp. that forms the heart of government's case against Mulheren. The government has said Mulheren entered into the trades with Boesky in exchange for information about pending corporate takeovers. Mulheren, 40, of Rumson, N.J., is charged with 41 counts of conspiracy, mail and securities fraud, and record-keeping violations. Davidoff has pleaded guilty to one felony charge and agreed to cooperate with the government. Boesky testified for three days last week in his first appearance as a witness since he pleaded guilty in Wall Street's insider trading scandal in 1986. During daylong testimony Wednesday, Davidoff said Boesky turned to Mulheren in mid-1985 to buy large blocks of securities and sell them back after 31 days in a ``parking'' arrangement to create phony trading losses for tax purposes. Assistant U.S. Attorney Alfred Pavlis presented more than a dozen trading records indicating that Boesky sold Mulheren the securities one date and in most cases bought them back shortly thereafter. The evidence and testimony marked the first substantive accounts backing the government's allegations. In illegal stock ``parking,'' ownership of securities is concealed to avoid disclosure or other federal guidelines. Under the deal, Mulheren bought 330,000 shares or $10 million worth of Unical Corp. stock from Boesky through a third party broker in July 1985. A month later, Davidoff told Mulheren that Boesky didn't want to buy back the stock and Mulheren agreed to keep the shares. Davidoff also cited alleged parking arrangements involving securities known as options in Boise Cascade Corp., Warner Communications Inc., American Hospital Supply Inc., Storer Communications Inc. and R.H. Macy & Co. Davidoff did not directly say that Mulheren knew the purchases and sales were designed to break the law. He did say he drew up an agreement that Seemala would be responsible for all profits and losses in the transactions. By the end of 1985, Jamie Securities, Mulheren's now-defunct trading firm, owed Boesky close to $2 million from trading profits, Davidoff said. He testified that Mulheren suggested Jamie Securities inflate brokerage fee bills and pay off the money gradually. The government has alleged the money was paid back in 1986. Davidoff said Leonard DeStefano, a trading assistant at Jamie Securities and Mulheren's co-defendant, was designated as his contact during monthly payment of the alleged brokerage bills. DeStefano, 34, is charged with two counts of conspiracy and fraud in the case. Boesky's three-year prison sentence ended last month. He had pleaded guilty to one felony count, paid $100 million in penalties and agreed to cooperate with prosecutors. Once one of Wall Street's most successful stock traders, Boesky provided the government information used against several prominent figures, including Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and its former junk bond executive, Michael Milken. Mulheren is the only one of those directly named by Boesky to go to trial. Others, including Boesky and Milken, have pleaded guilty to violating securities laws and other crimes.

DOC.HEAD: Sugar Futures Tumble on Bearish Report
DOC.TEXT: Sugar futures prices fell Wednesday for the second straight day on New York's Coffee, Sugar & Cocoa Exchange in reaction to a report of increased sugar production and a supply surplus. On other markets, grains and soybeans futures were mostly lower, energy futures gained, precious metals fell, and livestock and pork futures retreated. On Tuesday, the West German statistics firm F.O. Licht reversed its world sugar deficit estimate of 57,000 metic tons to a surplus of 694,000 metric tons. Licht also revised production and consumption figures, placing production in the season ending Aug. 30, 1990, at 108.55 million metric tons from 107.91 million. Consumption was revised down to 107.86 million metric tons from 108.07 million. Analysts said sugar futures contracts for coming months continue to trade at a premium compared to later months despite the report, an indication that a surplus does not exist. Sugar settled .27 cent to .38 cent lower with the contract for delivery in October at 13.70 cents a pound. On Tuesday, sugar prices fell by even larger amounts. Judith Ganes, a commodity analyst with Merrill Lynch & Co. in New York, said Licht issued a statement Wednesday indicating Tuesday's sell-off was overdone. But she said the sell-off should help stimulate demand for sugar. ``If you don't see major users come in at this level, prices will continue to slide,'' she said. Grain futures prices closed lower and soybeans were mixed on the Chicago Board of Trade. The expectation of drier conditions sent corn futures lower. The weather will allow many farmers to finish remaining corn planting. Soybeans prices were marginally lower as traders consolidated positions after a sell-off Tuesday. Reports of possible offers from Asia for U.S. soybeans gave some support to soybean prices. Wheat was 1 cent to 4 cents lower with July at $3.32\ a bushel; corn was 3 cents to 4} cents lower with July at $2.79{ a bushel; oats were 3\ cents to 3} cents lower with July at $1.42{ a bushel; soybeans were 1} cents lower to 3 cents higher with July at $6.05\ a bushel. Energy futures were higher on the New York Mercantile Exchange, but prices settled down from the day's highs as traders became cautious in anticipation of oil inventory figures. Analysts said they expected American Petroleum Institute stocks figures to show a rise in crude inventories. After the close of trading, the API reported gasoline stocks up 1.055 million barrels in the latest week; it reported crude oil stocks up 2.109 million barrels and U.S. distillate stocks up 737,000 barrels. West Texas Intermediate crude oil was 2 cents to 10 cents higher with July at $18.08 a barrel; heating oil was .39 cent to .91 cent higher with June at 51.15 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .10 cent lower to 1.08 cents higher with June at 66.87 cents a gallon. Livestock and pork futures were lower on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Selling to take profits and forecasts for more rain in the Midwest this week send live hog futures down. Analysts said rain could prompt farmers to bring hogs to market. Hog futures selling pushed down frozen pork belly prices. Cattle futures were lower, pressured by commercial selling and spillover from the selloff in pork. Live cattle were .10 cent to .33 cent lower with June at 73.97 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .18 cent to .35 cent lower with August at 83.57 cents a pound; hogs were .22 cent to 1.30 cents lower with June at 66.45 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .20 cent to 1.80 cent lower with July at 66.05 cents a pound. Precious metals futures were lower on New York's Commodity Exchange as the U.S. dollar showed renewed strength against major foreign currencies. Gold was $3 to $3.30 lower with June at $364.10 a troy ounce; silver was 9.1 cents to 10.3 cents lower with June at $5.047 a troy ounce.

DOC.HEAD: 25 Named to Advisory Panel on Eastern Bloc Markets
With AM-SEC-East Europe
DOC.TEXT: Top officials from the New York and American stock exchanges and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange are among 25 industry leaders appointed to an advisory panel on emerging markets in Eastern Europe. The panel, created last March by Securities and Exchange Commission Chairman Richard C. Breeden, will advise the SEC on handling requests for advice or assistance from the newly free economies of Eastern Europe. The first appointees to the SEC's Emerging Markets Advisory Committee are: Former CitiCorp vice chairman Hans H. Angermueller; Carliss Y. Baldwin, professor and research director, Harvard Business School; J. Carter Beese Jr., board member and principal at Alex. Brown & Sons, Inc.; Morgan Stanley & Co. Managing Director Lewis W. Bernard. Chicago Board Options Exchange Chairman Alger B. Chapman; J. Michael Cook, chairman of Deloitte & Touche; Benjamin F. Edwards III, chairman of A.G. Edwards & Sons Inc.; Matthew Fink, general counsel, Investment Company Institute; Joseph R. Hardiman, president of the National Association of Securities Dealers Inc. William H. Heyman, managing director of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co.; James R. Jones, chairman, American Stock Exchange; David M. Kelly, president, National Securities Clearing Corporation; Gordon S. Macklin, chairman of Hambrecht & Quist Inc. Charles B. McQuade, president, Securities Industry Automation Corporation; Leo Melamed, chairman of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange executive committee; Michael Minikes, treasurer of Bear Stearns Cos.; Shaun F. O'Malley, chairman of Price Waterhouse. John R. Opel, former International Business Machines Corp. chairman; former SEC Commissioner Aulana L. Peters; New York Stock Exchange Chairman John J. Phelan Jr.; Michael Raoul-Duval, managing director of The First Boston Corp.; Merrill Lynch & Co. Chairman William A. Schreyer. Salomon Brothers Inc. Vice Chairman Stanley B. Shopkorn; James C. Van Horne, banking and finance professor, Stanford University business school; and Roy J. Zuckerberg, general partner, Goldman Sachs & Co.

DOC.HEAD: Sony May Not Be Answer To VW Workers' Woes
With BC-Sony-VW Chronology
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LaserPhoto prospects uncertain
DOC.TEXT: For almost two years, Ron Dinsmore has scoured want ads, sifted resumes and combed a nationwide job bank to find work for some of the 2,500 people laid off when Volkswagen closed its U.S. assembly plant. The state employment counselor thought salvation may have come when Sony Corp., another foreign industrial giant, announced in April that it would convert the sprawling facility near this rural western Pennsylvania town into a high-tech television tube factory. ``Everybody wants to know how to apply,'' said Dinsmore, 43, who once was a full-time union representative at the VW plant and will be seeking work himself in a few months when grant funding expires for his own position. The Japanese electronics maker undoubtedly will give the area a needed economic boost. But it remains unclear whether local VW veterans, who once learned from scratch how to assemble cars, will be rehired to build a product far more complex. Some experts doubt it. ``I really think that Sony will recruit a new work force,'' said Richard Florida, a management professor at Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh, who has studied Japanese industries transplanted to the United States. ``Most of the jobs in that Sony plant are going to be higher-skilled than auto work.'' Sony said one reason it chose this area was the relatively high level of education among students. For example, it looked at such measures of student achivement as Scholastic Aptitute Test scores to determine the quality of area schools in educating future employees. But Kunitake Ando, president of Sony Engineering and Manufacturing of America, hinted the company may not hire many former VW workers. ``We are heavily recruiting engineering types, rather than simple assembly-line workers,'' he said when the announcement was made. The plant that Sony will occupy, built in a former cornfield, stands like a monument to the frustration stories of the two other manufacturers responsible for creating it. Chrysler Corp. began building it as an auto factory in 1968 but never finished. Volkswagen of America took over and opened the factory a decade later. Employment peaked at 5,700 in 1980, and more than 1 million vehicles were built by the time VW closed shop in 1988 because of declining demand. Pennsylvania is forgiving $40 million of the $70 million it loaned Volkswagen to start operations. Sony will lease the plant from the state. Although more than half of those laid off two years ago have found work, Dinsmore said he counsels about 150 unemployed or underemployed ex-VW workers weekly from his desk in a corner cubicle at a state-funded employment training center in the county seat of Greensburg. Dinsmore said he's had little information to share about Sony's hiring plans, except that it expects to recruit about 1,000 people in the next three years. He said he's still trying to find out what type of workers Sony needs. ``I've read all different things in the paper. They want people with dexterity skills, they want people with math skills, they want people with electronic skills,'' he said. ``Everyone's waiting to see what they need.'' Among those waiting is Calvin Tomanda, 43, who had worked in VW's supply store for more than 10 years. Tomanda issued equipment throughout the 2.2 million square-foot factory, built along a winding stretch of two-lane highway. Since his layoff, full-time work has eluded him. He entered an 18-month physical therapy training program, but that closed when he was half-finished. Tomanda now works part-time as a nurse's aide and is looking for a job in a warehouse. ``Like everyone else, we all hoped that Sony would take the facility,'' he said. ``Whether former VW workers will be able to be in there in sufficient numbers remains to be seen.'' Phil Davis, 50, who worked 10{ years as general supervisor of material and production control, is unemployed and studying business management. He said Sony's announcement interested him, but only in a passing way. ``It's good for the area,'' he said. ``I don't know if it'll have a direct impact on me.'' Davis said he'd like to find a job before Sony begins production in about 18 months. ``I'm not banking on this for salvation for my employment,'' he said. Even if Sony is not the answer to the problems of unemployed autoworkers, the reopened plant will strengthen the economic base of Westmoreland County and local municipalities, where the primary source of income is farming. ``That plant sitting idly as a dinosaur _ what was once a very fast-paced, very fast-moving production facility _ was doing nobody any good,'' said Terry Marolt, chairman of the county board of commissioners. ``It's obvious that there's the big clout benefit immediately of a plant the size of Sony coming in,'' he said. ``In addition to that, there's a rippling effect that flows throughout the business world in the area.'' Although a tax package has not been worked out, Sony has agreed to at least match the $75,000 in property taxes paid by Volkswagen, said Howard J. Keefer, an East Huntingdon Township supervisor. Keefer said he's eager to use the money to provide some long-needed repairs to roads, bridges, water lines and sewers. Local merchants also are optimistic about the arrival of a sizable, regular payroll. ``When Volkswagen first came in, it definitely had an impact,'' said Basil Hawanchak, controller of Levin Furniture Co. in Mount Pleasant. ``We're expecting the same type of impact from Sony.'' Sony has said it hopes to build complete televisions at the plant and has an option to purchase additional acreage for businesses such as glass and cabinet makers. Former VW workers won't be written off completely as potential Sony employees, said Florida. They might be hired for appearances and taught the necessary skills, he said. ``I think the Japanese can train anyone to do anything,'' he said. Dinsmore said the former autoworkers are not deterred by the prospect of learning how to do high-tech work. ``Let me say this, in 1977 there wasn't a person in Westmoreland County that built cars. In 1985 we won car of the year,'' he said. Motor Trend magazine gave the award to VW's GTI model, manufactured at the plant along with the Rabbit, Golf and Jetta. ``No one knew how to build a car _ never built one in this county before, or in the state,'' he said. ``They trained them, they sent people to Germany, they sent a bunch of Germans in here and did some training. ``So, you know, we can build televisions. We can build anything if we get the proper training.''

DOC.HEAD: History of Former Auto Plant to Be Occupied By Sony
With BC-Sony-VW
DOC.TEXT: Here is a brief rundown of key dates in the history of the former Volkswagen automaking plant in western Pennsylvania that Sony Corp. will transform in to a television manufacturing facility: February 1968 _ Chrysler Corp. begins construction of 2.2 million square-foot auto plant near Mount Pleasant in rural Westmoreland County. The company plans to open it in 1970 but abandons the project after the shell of the plant is built, leaving a dirt floor. September 1976 _ Volkswagen AG signs agreement to produce autos at the plant after talks with Chrysler for a joint venture fall through. April 1978 _ First U.S.-built VW Rabbit rolls off the line. 1980 _ Employment peaks at 5,700 workers. 1985 _ VW TGI named ``Car of the year'' by Motor Trend magazine. One millionth vehicle produced at plant. November 1987 _ VW announces that plant will be closed because of declining demand for U.S.-produced vehicles. July 1988 _ Final VW model _ 1989 Golf _ produced at plant. April 1990 _ Sony Corp. announces it will reopen the dormant plant to produce large-screen television tubes.
DOC.NOTE: End adv for Sunday June 3

DOC.HEAD: Court Approves Paying $1.2 Million to Former Ames Employees
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge Wednesday allowed Ames Department Stores Inc. to pay $1.2 million to 6,500 employees who left the discount retailer before it filed for bankruptcy protection in April. U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Howard Buschman III in New York approved a request by Ames to pay up to $2,000 in severance and vacation pay to employees who were not paid before the company filed for Chapter 11 protection. In the order, the judge indicated that payments should be mailed to about 6,500 former employees on June 7. Bankruptcy court approval is required for such expenditures. Ames, which operates 680 discount retail stores in 20 states, filed for protection April 25 after suppliers stopped shipments in the midst of mounting financial problems for the company, based in Rocky Hill. Earlier this month, the court approved a $250 million financing plan to allow the company to continue paying suppliers as it reorganizes its business and finances.

DOC.HEAD: Westinghouse President To Succeed Chairman
DOC.TEXT: Westinghouse Electric Corp. President Paul E. Lego on Wednesday was named chairman and chief executive, following a course started three years ago. Lego, who also holds the title of chief operating officer, will succeed John C. Marous. Marous, 65, and Lego, 60, were promoted three years ago when Douglas Danforth stepped down, leaving all four titles open. Westinghouse did not name a new president or chief operating officer. Analysts said Wednesday's move, effective July 1, is part of a transition the company's board designed in 1987. ``Lego has been involved with Marous in the decision-making process all along,'' said Ross Leavitt of Salomon Inc. ``There may be some modest policy shifts.'' Robert McCoy Jr. of UBS Securities said Lego's answers to questions at a meeting of New York financial analysts earlier this month lacked detail, and the appearance was blamed for a sudden drop in Westinghouse's stock price. Westinghouse's stock closed Wednesday down 62{ cents at $35 on the New York Stock Exchange. Westinghouse, a diversified company with interests in nuclear energy, manufacturing, broadcasting and commercial finance, last year posted earnings of $922 million, or $6.30 per share, on sales of $12.8 billion. The 104-year-old company employs 115,000. Lego, who joined the company in 1956 as an engineer, will be its 13th chairman. Marous earned $3.1 million in salary, benefits and stock earnings in 1989. As president, Lego earned $2.5 million, according to the company's financial disclosures.

DOC.HEAD: Continental Sells $200 Million in Terminal Bonds
DOC.TEXT: Continental Airlines said Wednesday it sold $200 million in bonds to finance a new terminal at New York City's La Guardia Airport. Houston-based Continental said the bond issue was oversubscribed on Wednesday, the same day it was issued. The offering represents the largest facility bond issue in the carrier's history, officials said. The new terminal is scheduled to be completed in early 1992. Continental, a subsidiary of Houston-based Texas Air Corp., will be the terminal's primary tenant. The terminal will have 10 aircraft gates, eight for wide-body aircraft. The underwriting group was led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. ``Continental is pleased that the financial community recognizes and is willing to participate in our future,'' said Continental President Mickey Foret. ``We are particularly gratified that investors signaled their confidence in Continental by oversubscribing in an issue of this size.''

DOC.HEAD: Jury Rules Against Ashland Oil
DOC.TEXT: Ashland Oil Inc. was ordered Wednesday to pay $10.3 million to four neighbors of its Catlettsburg, Ky., refinery who said emissions from the plant hurt their health and damaged their property. Residents of Ceredo and Kenova, W.Va. and Catlettsburg, Ky., brought suit against Ashland in Kanawha County Circuit Court after they found a white substance on their cars and homes. The substance was not easily removed and damaged their property, they alleged. ``The verdict recognizes the magnitude of the problem that people have been living with for a number of years,'' said D.L. Hamilton, an attorney for the residents. ``I hope Ashland Oil got the message.'' Hundreds of other Kenova-area residents have brought similar suits against Ashland. Dan Lacy, vice president of corporate communications for Ashland, said the company would appeal. The company's appeal to the state Supreme Court will be based on Kanawha Circuit Judge Tod Kaufman's decision to block testimony and evidence Ashland attorneys believed vital to their case, Lacy said. The court blocked testimony from a former Environmental Protection Agency official who would have testified about air quality standards, Lacy said. It also prevented jurors from hearing about evidence collected by the company's air quality monitoring units in the Kenova area. ``Had we been able to bring that information to the jury we honestly believe the jury's verdict would be different,'' Lacy said. Ashland attorneys did argue that neighbors of the refinery feared it because they didn't understand it. They also said the residents lacked concrete evidence of illness or property damage, such as medical or repair bills. Wednesday's verdict was the first part of the trial. In the second part, the court will determine whether Ashland must pay the tab for periodic health tests of the residents.
